{"uri": "2024-08-443748547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:52:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:52:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:04:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/08/04/novak-djokovic-wins-his-first-olympic-gold-medal-by-beating-carlos-alcaraz-in-the-mens-tennis-final/", "title": "Novak Djokovic wins his first Olympic gold medal by beating Carlos Alcaraz in the men's tennis final", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- For all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia, the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37. Doesn't matter a bit how long it took. Djokovic beat Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men's tennis singles final at the 2024 Games on Sunday.\n\n\"I put my heart, my soul, my body, my family -- my everything -- on the line to win Olympic gold,\" Djokovic said. \"Incredible battle. Incredible fight.\"\n\nHis impressive career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient.\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nBefore facing Musetti, Djokovic said, \"I was like, 'OK, let's get through this one.' That's why today, before the match, I did not feel as nervous as I would normally feel, because I had secured a medal.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 -- and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\nWhen the victory was his, when the gold was his, thanks to one last forehand winner, Djokovic turned toward his team in the stands -- sitting in front of his wife and their two children -- dropped his racket and knelt on the clay. As emotional as ever, he cried and covered his face, then rose and grabbed a red-white-and-blue Serbian flag.\n\nAfter hugs in the stands, Djokovic waved that flag.\n\n\"In the tough moments, he gave it an extra push,\" silver medalist Alcaraz said through his own tears. \"It hurts to lose like this.\"\n\nThe final, which lasted 2 hours, 50 minutes despite being decided in only two sets, was a rematch of the Wimbledon title match three weeks ago that Alcaraz won to follow up his French Open title in June.\n\nAlcaraz also defeated Djokovic in last year's final at the All England Club, but Djokovic won when they met in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open, the annual clay-court tournament held at Roland Garros, the site used for tennis during these Olympics.\n\nSunday's contest featured one of the best to ever do it in Djokovic, and the best at the moment in Alcaraz. Indeed, could have been frustrating for Djokovic to find himself once again across the net from a younger, speedier version of himself. Maybe that's why Djokovic frequently looked up and gesticulated and muttered toward his guest box.\n\nStill, he came out on top.\n\n\"Honestly, when the last shot went through him, past him, that was the only moment I actually thought I can win the match,\" Djokovic said.\n\nIt required long exchanges filled with superb ball-striking, deft drop shots -- Alcaraz's tended to be more successful, sometimes so good Djokovic declined to even give chase -- and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense at both ends. They served so well that neither got broken even once: Djokovic saved eight break points, Alcaraz six.\n\nMost remarkable, perhaps, was how cleanly both men played, despite the talent of the opposition and pressure of the occasion.\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, Alcaraz -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Make no mistake, this encounter between the No. 1-seeded Djokovic and No. 2-seeded Alcaraz was worthy of a major final.\n\nThose in the stands became part of the show, repeatedly breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. In the second set, as Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters began chanting, \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\") while shaking their red-and-yellow flags. Chair umpire Damien Dumusois occasionally reminded folks to remain silent during the action.\n\nYet the place also became as quiet as a theater between points, enough so that play was delayed briefly when the air thick with anticipation was pierced by a young child's crying.\n\nBoth men played to the crowd. When Alcaraz raced to reach one drop shot and deposit it over the net for a winner, he basked in the raucous reaction by pointing his right index finger to his ear. When Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point to lead 3-2 in the second tiebreaker, he waved both arms overhead to encourage folks who already were standing and screaming.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes, including five break chances for Alcaraz, before Djokovic managed to hold for a 5-4 lead. In the tiebreaker, Djokovic was superior in crunch time, as he so often is, taking the last four points.\n\nAt 3-all, Alcaraz delivered a body serve, but Djokovic slid just enough to his left to smack a cross-court forehand return winner. After two mistakes by Alcaraz, Djokovic produced a volley winner and turned to face his family with a fist held high.\n\nAnother set, and another tiebreaker, later, and Djokovic had that medal that he wanted, at long last.\n\nWhen the Serbian national anthem finished ringing out at Court Philippe Chatrier, Djokovic reached for that gold and brought it to his lips for a kiss.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8258810708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:36:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:36:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:30:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13707579/Novak-Djokovic-wins-Olympic-gold-beating-Carlos-Alcaraz-mens-tennis-final.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic wins his first Olympic gold medal by beating Carlos...", "body": "PARIS (AP) - Novak Djokovic won his first Olympic gold medal by beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling men\u00b4s tennis singles final Sunday, giving the 37-year-old from Serbia the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nDjokovic's impressive career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam titles and the most weeks spent at No. 1 in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze - and he has made clear that simply was not sufficient.\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 - and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\nWhen the victory was his, when the gold was his, thanks to one last forehand winner, Djokovic turned toward his team in the stands - sitting in front of his wife and their two children - and dropped his racket as he knelt on the clay. As emotional as ever, he cried and covered his face, then rose and grabbed a red-white-and-blue Serbian flag. After hugs in the stands, Djokovic waved that flag. Alcaraz wept afterward, too.\n\nThe final, which lasted 2 hours, 50 minutes despite being decided in only two sets, was a rematch of the Wimbledon title match three weeks ago that Alcaraz won to follow up his French Open title in June.\n\nSerbia's Novak Djokovic reacts after awinning a point against Spain's Carlos Alcaraz during the men's singles tennis final at the Roland Garros stadium during the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Louise Delmotte)\n\nAlcaraz also defeated Djokovic in last year\u00b4s final at the All England Club, but Djokovic won when they met in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open, the annual clay-court tournament held at Roland Garros, the site used for tennis during these Olympics.\n\nSunday\u00b4s contest was an enthralling matchup, featuring one of the best to ever do it in Djokovic, and the best at the moment in Alcaraz. Indeed, could have been frustrating for Djokovic to find himself once again across the net from a younger, speedier version of himself. Maybe that\u00b4s why Djokovic frequently looked up and gesticulated and muttered toward his guest box.\n\nStill, he came out on top.\n\nIt required long exchanges filled with superb ball-striking at the baseline, deft drop shots - Alcaraz\u00b4s tended to be more successful, sometimes so good Djokovic declined to even give chase - and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense at both ends. They served so well that neither got broken even once: Djokovic saved eight break points, Alcaraz six.\n\nMost remarkable, perhaps, was how cleanly both men played, despite the talent of the opposition and pressure of the occasion. Unforced errors were rare.\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans - and, naturally, the loser - was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Make no mistake, this encounter between the No. 1-seeded Djokovic and No. 2-seeded Alcaraz was worthy of a major final, and no one fortunate enough to hold a ticket could complain about not getting their money\u00b4s worth.\n\nThose in the stands became part of the show, repeatedly breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. In the second set, as Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters began chanting, \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\") while shaking their red-and-yellow flags. Chair umpire Damien Dumusois occasionally reminded folks to remain silent during the action.\n\nYet it also became as quiet as a theater between points, enough so that play was delayed briefly in the first set when the air thick with anticipation was pierced by a young child\u00b4s crying.\n\nBoth men played to the crowd. When Alcaraz raced to reach one drop shot and deposit it over the net for a winner, he basked in the raucous reaction by pointing his right index finger to his ear. When Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point to lead 3-2 in the second tiebreaker, he waved both arms overhead to encourage folks who already were on their feet, screaming.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, chock full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes, including five break chances for Alcaraz, before Djokovic managed to hold for a 5-4 lead. In the tiebreaker, Djokovic was superior in crunch time, as he so often is, taking the last four points.\n\nAt 3-all, Alcaraz delivered a body serve, but Djokovic slid just enough to his left to smack a cross-court forehand return winner. After two mistakes by Alcaraz, Djokovic produced a volley winner and turned to face his family with a fist held high.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nSpain's Carlos Alcaraz runs to return the ball to Serbia's Novak Djokovic during the men's singles tennis final at the Roland Garros stadium during the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Paris, France. {"uri": "8259503028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:55:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:55:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:54:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://maktoobmedia.com/more/sports/novak-djokovic-becomes-only-the-fifth-to-complete-career-golden-slam/", "title": "Novak Djokovic becomes only the fifth to complete career golden slam", "body": "Novak Djokovic beat Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz 7-6(3), 7-6(2) to win gold in the Olympic tennis men's singles final at Roland Garros on Sunday, becoming the oldest man to win singles gold in tennis since 1908.\n\nThe 37-year-old triumphed in a fierce battle on Court Philippe Chatrier to claim his first Olympic title.\n\nDjokovic's career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam titles and the most weeks spent at No. 1 in the rankings by any man or woman.\n\nIt also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he has made clear that simply was not sufficient.\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nNow Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 -- and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\nSteffi Graf was the first player to win all four Grand Slam titles as well as an Olympic gold, when she managed the feat in 1988.\n\nAndre Agassi became the first man to complete a career Golden Slam in 1999, when he won his first and last French Open title.\n\nRafael Nadal is the youngest to achieve a career Golden Slam, when he achieved the feat in 2010 at the age of 24. Serena Williams completed her set of all four Grand Slam titles and an Olympic gold medal in 2012.\n\nNovak Djokovic joined the illustrious list of career Golden Slam winners, adding the Olympic gold to his 24 Grand Slam triumphs.\n\n\"We almost played three hours, the final shot was the only moment when I was sure I could win the match,\" APF quoted Djokovic as saying. \"I put my body, my family on the line to win gold and finally I did it.\" He added.\n\n\"Three hours, a big battle with tough moments,\" said Alcaraz. The 21-year-old said it was very painful to lose.\n\nAlcaraz cracked first in the tiebreak and when another tiebreak was required to decide the second set, Djokovic again found another gear, sealing victory with a stunning forehand winner down the line.\n\nDjokovic roared to the sky and after shaking hands with Alcaraz, he fell to his knees in the center of the court before climbing into the crowd to be swamped by his family and team. He celebrated by holding aloft the Serbian flag on court.\n\nThe 21-year-old Alcaraz, who was denied the Olympic title to go with this year's French Open and Wimbledon crowns, was in tears at the end.\n\nDjokovic has won three of his six matches against Alcaraz, including in last year's French Open semi-finals, but the Spaniard has seized power in the men's game this year, winning the French and Wimbledon crowns back-to-back.\n\nDjokovic put on one of the finest performances of his career to deny Alcaraz the elusive title and became only the fifth player to complete a career Golden Slam -- winning all four singles Grand Slams and the Olympic title.\n\nThe opening set alone lasted an hour and 33 minutes, as neither player took a backward step in a ferocious contest. There were plenty of break points on display, but neither managed to get a break of serve as the set headed to the tie-break, where Alcaraz cracked. When another tie-break was required to decide the second set, again, Djokovic found another gear, sealing victory with a stunning forehand winner down the line.", "source": {"uri": "maktoobmedia.com", {"uri": "8259343745", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:09:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:09:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:08:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/589848", "title": "Djokovic fights off Alcaraz to finally strike gold", "body": "PARIS - Novak Djokovic completed his career Golden Slam as the 37-year-old Serb fought off Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in a magnificent Olympic men's singles final battle at Roland Garros on Sunday.\n\nAfter heartbreak in Beijing, London, Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo, Djokovic simply would not be denied the one title that had eluded him so long, winning 7-6(3) 7-6(2) in front of an enthralled crowd on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nTop seed Djokovic had to deliver one of the finest performances of his career to deny a man 16 years his junior and become only the fifth player to win all four singles Grand Slams and the Olympic title during their careers.\n\n\"It was an incredible fight and I had to play my best tennis,\" an emotional Djokovic said on court as flag-waving Serbian fans sang his name. \"I put my heart, my soul, everything to win gold. I did it for my country first, for Serbia.\"\n\nIn a raucous atmosphere, with soccer-style chants shattering the calm of the adjacent Bois de Boulogne, neither player took a backward step in a ferocious contest.\n\nThe first set alone lasted one hour 33 minutes as the two wrestled for control in a series of spellbinding games, one at 4-4 in which Djokovic repelled five break points.\n\nAlcaraz blinked first in the tiebreak to allow Djokovic to move ahead and when another tiebreak was required to decide the second set, again Djokovic found inspiration, moving 6-2 in front and sealing victory with a stunning forehand winner.\n\nALSO READ: Olympics Day 9: Chinese swimmers surge up, Djokovic completes trophy collection\n\nDjokovic roared to the sky and after consoling a crestfallen Alcaraz at the net, then fell to his knees and sobbed into the Parisian clay in the center of the court before climbing into the crowd where he was swamped by his family, friends and team.\n\nWhile Djokovic became the oldest Olympic singles champion since tennis returned to the Games in 1988, the 21-year-old Alcaraz looked inconsolable after failing to add the gold medal to this year's French Open and Wimbledon crowns.\n\n\"I think I did a really great tournament, I think I did a really great match,\" the four-time Grand Slam champion said. \"Obviously in front of me, I had a really hungry Novak.\"\n\nDjokovic had lost three times in Olympic singles semi-finals with a solitary bronze medal to show from four previous Games.\n\nHe knew Paris was his last realistic chance to fill the remaining space in a bulging trophy cabinet containing 24 Grand Slam titles. And how he earned it - overturning a crushing loss to Alcaraz three weeks ago in the Wimbledon final to become the first man to win the Olympic singles title without dropping a set.\n\nIncredible fight\n\nDjokovic joins an elite group of Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafa Nadal and Serena Williams, the latter watching from the front row, in the Golden Slam club, and many will say this settled the G.O.A.T argument once and for all.\n\nIt takes something pretty special to upstage the men's 100 meters final taking place later at the Stade de France, but this near three-hour red-dirt duel arguably came close.\n\nThe opening four games spanned 30 mesmerizing minutes, every rally a battle of skill and wills. Alcaraz saved three break points in the fourth game and looked menacing as he threw everything in his arsenal at Djokovic as the Serb served at 4-4.\n\nSeveral times Djokovic could only smile at the athleticism of his opponent who piled on the pressure to earn five break points, and somehow he survived.\n\nAlcaraz saved a set point at 5-6 but the Spaniard's level dipped in the tiebreak and Djokovic pounced to grab the lead. Sensing his moment, Djokovic's intensity went even higher deep in the second set but Alcaraz hung on.\n\nREAD MORE: Tennis: China narrowly miss mixed doubles gold; Alcaraz, Djokovic set for final\n\nDjokovic was relentless though and an outrageous forehand winner at 2-2 in the breaker snapped Alcaraz's resistance and the end then came quickly as he claimed the 99th, and perhaps most valuable, title of his glittering career.\n\nA memorable week ended with Italy's Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini beating Russian neutral players Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider 2-6 6-1 (10-7) to win the women's gold, adding to compatriot Lorenzo Musetti's men's singles bronze.", "source": {"uri": "chinadailyasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "China Daily Asia"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8258885421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:49:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:49:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:47:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/djokovic-fights-alcaraz-finally-strike-gold-4525921", "title": "Djokovic fights off Alcaraz to finally strike gold", "body": "PARIS :Novak Djokovic completed his career Golden Slam as the 37-year-old Serb fought off Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in a magnificent Olympic men's singles final battle at Roland Garros on Sunday.\n\nAfter heartbreak in Beijing, London, Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo, Djokovic simply would not be denied the one title that had eluded him for so long, winning 7-6(3) 7-6(2) in front of an enthralled crowd on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nTop seed Djokovic delivered one of the finest performances of his career to deny a man 16 years his junior and become only the fifth player to win all four singles Grand Slams and the Olympic title during a career.\n\nWith points being celebrated by soccer-style chants that shattered the calm of the adjacent Bois de Boulogne, neither player took a backward step in a ferocious contest.\n\nThe first set alone lasted one hour 33 minutes as the two gladiators wrestled for control in a series of spellbinding games, one at 4-4 in which Djokovic repelled five break points.\n\nAlcaraz blinked first in the tiebreak to allow Djokovic to move ahead and when another tiebreak was required to decide the second set, again Djokovic found another gear, moving 6-2 in front and sealing victory with a stunning forehand winner.\n\nDjokovic roared to the sky and after consoling a stunned Alcaraz at the net he then fell to his knees and sobbed into the Parisian clay in the centre of the court before climbing into the crowd where he was swamped by his family, friends and team.\n\nWhile Djokovic, the oldest player to win the Olympic singles title since the sport returned to the Games in 1988, sobbed tears of joy, the 21-year-old Alcaraz was inconsolable after falling short of adding the gold medal to this year's French Open and Wimbledon crowns.\n\nDjokovic, had lost three times in Olympic singles semi-finals and knew arriving in Paris that this was his last realistic chance to fill the last remaining space in a trophy cabinet that contains a men's record 24 Grand Slam titles.\n\nAnd how he earned it - overturning his crushing loss to Alcaraz three weeks ago in the Wimbledon final to become the first man to win the Olympic singles without dropping a set.\n\n\"It was an incredible fight and I had to play my best tennis,\" an emotional Djokovic said before the medals ceremony as flag-waving Serbian fans celebrated in the stands.\n\n\"It was fair that the two sets finished in tiebreaks. I put my heart, my soul, everything to win gold.\n\n\"I did it for my country first, for Serbia.\"\n\nDjokovic joins an elite group of Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafa Nadal and Serena Williams, the latter watching from the front row, in the Golden Slam club.\n\nIt takes something pretty special to upstage the men's 100 metres final which was taking place later at the Stade de France, but a seventh career clash between Alcaraz and Djokovic arguably came close as they served up a blockbuster.\n\nThe opening four games alone spanned 30 mesmerizing minutes, with virtually every rally a battle of wills.\n\nAlcaraz saved three break points in the fourth game but began to look dangerous as he threw everything in his arsenal at Djokovic when the Serb served at 4-4.\n\nSeveral times the Spaniard's level dipped slightly in the tiebreak and Djokovic needed no second invitation to grab the lead.\n\nSensing his moment, Djokovic's intensity levels went even higher deep in the second {"uri": "8258924266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:33:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:33:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:29:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/djokovic-completes-tennis-beating-alcaraz-161340285.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic completes tennis by beating Carlos Alcaraz to win Olympic gold in Paris", "body": "Novak Djokovic has completed tennis. The only empty space in his trophy cabinet - the one waiting for an Olympic gold medal - has now been filled, after a phenomenal near three-hour battle with his young rival Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nDjokovic was visibly emotional after claiming a prize he had been seeking since he took bronze in the Olympic singles event of 2008. After clinching victory with a forehand winner, he knelt down on the court for an extended moment, and then pulled a Serbian flag out of his bag and roared as waved it to his fans.\n\n\"To win Olympic gold at 37, I finally did it,\" said Djokovic in an interview with Eurosport's Alex Corretja at the side of the court. \"Most of all, it's my country. The pride of playing for Serbia. I know Carlos and Rafa [Nadal] love to play for Spain, Andy [Murray] loves to play for Great Britain. Roger [Federer] for Switzerland. Alex Zverev won at Tokyo for Germany. You saw the reactions of all these guys when they win; it's something special.\"\n\nWith the exception of Federer, all the names that Djokovic mentioned were on show in this Olympic tennis event. Yet Murray and Nadal were shadows of their former selves, their bodies rebelling against the sheer workload of two decades of top-level tennis.\n\nDjokovic, extraordinarily, is still fresh. Yes, he might have been wearing a sleeve on the knee that underwent surgery on a torn meniscus fewer than two months ago. But his movement was slick and his unrivalled strategic instincts - surely the most powerful weapon in his armoury - came through with a series of inspired choices under pressure.\n\nThere were no breaks of serve in this 7-6, 7-6 victory, but the quality of tennis and drama reached rare heights, particularly when Alcaraz made a strong push towards the end of the first set.\n\nDjokovic was on the back foot against a more explosive opponent, but he fell back on his courtcraft. Even when his shots were not as good as Alcaraz's, his decision-making was far sharper, and his nerve held strong on the biggest points.\n\nAlcaraz was emotional after the match, breaking down in tears as he gave his own interview to Eurosport. Seldom has a man played as well in defeat as Alcaraz did here, striking more than 40 clean winners in just two sets. But Alcaraz is 21, and his time will come again. The silver medal is one better than Djokovic - then exactly the same age - had managed in Beijing.\n\n\"This is now my fifth Olympic Games,\" said Djokovic. \"Three out of four I played semi-finals and never managed to overcome that hurdle for some reason. When I entered the court for the semi-finals against [Lorenzo] Musetti I was thinking about it and said 'let's get through this one'. That's why at the beginning of this match I was not as nervous as I had secured a medal but of course I was going for gold. It was intense on the court and I wanted to give it my best. I think the fact I qualified for the final already helped.\"\n\nAlcaraz had recently swatted Djokovic aside in a Wimbledon final that saw the younger man serve at a career-best level. But it was also true that Djokovic's movement was \"half-a-step\" - in his own words - behind where it needed to be, thanks to the after-effects of his knee operation.\n\nHere Djokovic took revenge in a match that gives him a narrow 4-3 edge in this fascinating head-to-head rivalry. Given the physicality of a wonderful contest, he must have been grateful that this was best-of-three sets rather than best-of-five.\n\nOne interesting subplot now relates to the upcoming US Open, which is only three weeks away. Will Djokovic take strength from his ability to land big titles, even in the face of young challengers like Alcaraz and Jannik Sinner? Or will he find it difficult to remotivate himself after ticking off the final box on the tennis to-do list? New York will reveal all.\n\nThanks for tuning in for one of the greatest tennis match's in Olympics history, and the sport in general. There was so little separating these two and yet somehow, some way, Djokovic tapped into that otherworldly instinct and finally got his gold. You could see just how much it meant to him.\n\nAlcaraz is very emotional, now in tears and unable to give his interview. He gave everything here and lost by such a fine margin.\n\nDjokovic is sobbing uncontrollably on his bench here. He finally gets up to hoist the Serbian flag aloft and goes to celebrate with his family. What an incredible moment.\n\nHe's done it! Djokovic is in tears, broken on the court. He's only the fifth player to win it all. Djokovic has shown why he is the greatest to ever play the game.\n\nAnother one into the net and Djokovic will have 4 points to earn him that elusive gold medal. You've got to feel for Alcaraz here as he breaks at the crucial moment.\n\nAn unforced error from Alcaraz and that could be it. He was in a good position and nevertheless hit it too low into the net. Djokovic is in the driver's seat here.\n\nWhat a forehand from Djokovic which sends Alcaraz sliding again. He somehow gets something on it this time, but it's only enough to gift Djokovic the easy smash.\n\nWow! One of the best shots of the match. Djokovic again battling on the back foot but somehow manages to hit a missile of a forehand which Alcaraz at full stretch can't get anything on.\n\nThe crowd can hardly contain itself as the umpire is forced again to try helplessly to intervene.\n\nAlcaraz's serve is massive, forcing Djokovic to stretch and scream, setting him up for an easy winner\n\nAnother long rally and this time it's Alcaraz who comes out on top. Djokovic hits a forehand inches long and the Spaniard is back in it.\n\nSome shouts from the crowd delays Djokovic here. The crowd claps but Novak is less than amused.\n\nDjokovic on the defensive somehow survives an onslaught from Alcaraz, returning some absolute rockets and somehow reposturing to win the point. This is one of the all-time great performances from Djokovic.\n\nAlcaraz serves first but it's Djokovic who draws first blood, hitting a gorgeous forehand cross-court and out of reach.\n\nDjokovic has come to the net here to dispute the umpire's call. He's convinced the serve was in and that the umpire was looking at the wrong ball. Both seem unlikely to yield, but Alcaraz breaks the tension and gives the Serb his first serve back. He's thanked by a thumbs up from his opposition.\n\nDjokovic is playing his service games at such a high level. He serves hard, sets up his shot, and then executes. It's cold and clinical, each point more incisive than the next. 40-0.\n\nDjokovic win's the game and we're going into yet another tiebreak. I think anyone could have predicted this - there almost nothing separating these super-athletes\n\nDjokovic has saved eight break points up until this stage. Alcaraz has saved six. Somehow, we are yet to have a single break as we watch two of the world's greatest returners refuse to give their opposition an inch.\n\nAlcaraz swiftly builds up a 40-0 lead in this game. He makes no mistake, refusing to allow Djokovic to mount another tricky comeback and taking the lead in the set.\n\nAlcaraz is starting to establish himself in Djokovic's service games now, but Djokovic will not give anything up. He predicts the drop-shot, and times his run perfectly, giving himself time to place his return out of Alcaraz's reach and go up 30-15.\n\nAlcaraz hits a gorgeous backhand down the line which lands right in the back corner, saving himself game point at 40-30.\n\nIt's clear to see why they call him a machine. This performance has been masterful and without hitches. Djokovic forces Alcaraz out wide to his right, stretching to return it high and too long.\n\nWhat a fantastic point! Djokovic scrambles all over the court as Alcaraz drops and then lobs and somehow he continues to return. Finally Alacaraz puts the point to bed. Both have had some ridiculous defensive points taking every single one intensley personally.\n\nThat one took a lot of of Djokovic, who drops the next two points with some unforced errors.\n\nHe's back in it though, giving Alcaraz a chance to run. He's battled his way back to 30-40 in this pivotal game.\n\nA gorgeous drop-shot from Djokovic is met by Alcaraz who can only tip it over. The Serb thinks it was a double bounce but makes sure by blasting it past Alcaraz and saving his third game point in a row.\n\nAt deuce here and the bludgeoning continues. Back and forth some huge shots and gobble dup like they're nothing. Alcaraz finally blinks first and slices one short, forcing Djokovic to bend and lean. He smashes the return in style and goes 40-AD up.\n\nAvoiding disaster, Alcaraz plays the final point of the game beautifully, setting himself up to smash and roar to the adoring crowd.\n\nBoth players frustrated with the crowd here with the umpire having to warn them again at the request of Djokovic.\n\nDjokovic has only dropped one point on his serve thus far in this set, winning the first point quickly and decisively.\n\nAnother miraculous defensive point from Alcaraz who returns one far out to his left-hand side. Djokovic lines up to crack one down the line but the net had other ideas and clipped it wide - 15-15.\n\nAlcaraz has stepped it up here and its his turn to send Djokovic scampering wide after a stunning forehand cross-court. He somehow returns, but Alcaraz finishes.\n\nBack the other way now and Alcaraz growls at his team having given up an easy one.\n\nThis has been his toughest service game by far here as he goes up AD-40. Djokovic continues to wrongfoot the young Spaniard as he plays smarter and smarter. Both players are playing such a high difficulty level of tennis.\n\nDjokovic wins the game - are we going to see a break today?\n\nDjokovic is incensed with his team here as he drops the game to Alcaraz without much resistance.\n\nThat was much better from Carlos who made no mistakes.\n\nWhat a start to this game! A rally goes on and on before Djokovic goes for the kill with a drop shot. Alcaraz uses his pace to make up the ground before feinting a cross-court shot and hitting down the line. Gorgeous tennis.\n\nIt's Djokovic's turn to get frustrated as on the next point he hits long and belts out an expletive. 15-15.\n\nThat seems to have fired him up as he hits his first ace of the game to the dismay of Alcaraz who can only watch.\n\nAnother ridiculous rally favours Djokovic at 40-15 as the Serb somehow manages to defend some brutal strokes sending his return high and long. Alcaraz is too nonchalant, not smashing with enough pace and allowing Djokovic back into the point before hitting into the net.\n\nDjokovic takes the game.\n\nDjokovic's face tells all. Eyes wide open in a steely grimace. He wants this.\n\nAlcaraz hits another drop-shot which Djokovic meets, using the angle on his return. Somehow Alcaraz gets there and hooks it round, turning a tight angle into an impossible one and winning the point.\n\nAnother long and brutal rally ends in Alcaraz's favour as he lets out an almighty bellow on a forehand crusher down the line.\n\nA gorgeous backhand down the line form Djokovic at game-point forces Alcaraz to loop a forehand long. This is incredible tennis from the veteran who is showing no signs of slowing down.\n\nNevertheless, Alcaraz does not relent, holding firm with some fantastic serving and refusing to be broken.\n\nA fantastic rally at 15-0 as both athletes send bludgeoning strikes across the net. Eventually the tension breaks as Alacaraz's forehand creeps out.\n\nA couple more misses from Alcaraz and Djokovic wins the game.\n\nThe frustration is setting in as Alcaraz waves his arms following a scuffed forehand. The crowd are getting behind him but he can't afford any more unforced errors like that as Djokovic postures.\n\nHe responds gloriously hitting a forehand to the far right-hand corner of the court with incredible precision, saving the break. Alcaraz then gets Djokovic running with a firm forehand down the line before putting it on the other side of the court.\n\nHe wins the game and roars like he's won the set. He needed that one.\n\nAlcaraz has made an adjustment in his serve return, positioning himself closer and more central on the baseline. Djokovic responds in kind, serving shorter to counter the counter, and it works.\n\nDjokovic goes up 30-0 with the Serbian contingent of the crowd roaring in support. The precision on his forehand winners are unbelievable.\n\nHe looks relaxed and confident here. Alcaraz bounces into a blasted forehand down the line, but Djokovic gives him the eyes and wrongfoots the Spaniard, sending it back from whence it came and holding his serve without dropping a point.\n\nAlcaraz is fired up here, eager to get himself back into rhythm quickly. He comes out firing and goes 40-0 up immediately.\n\nDjokovic stumbles when Alcaraz sends a shot destined to wrongfoot him - unluckily for the Spaniard it can't get over the net. Djokovic seems to enjoy making things harder for himself as he battles his way to deuce.\n\nAlcaraz hits an audacious forehand volley drop-shot, which, despite running for it, Djokovic simply can't reach.\n\nDjokovic refuses to die but Alcaraz's furious power gives sends him 40-AD up for the second time this game. Finally, Djokovic sends his backhand long and the game relents. Unsurprisingly, the intensity has not dropped from either player here.\n\nThat was an hour and thirty-three minutes of pure tennis brilliance. Alcaraz has won three of his matches quicker than that first set. Amazing stuff and we're about to get going for the second already!\n\nDjokivic wins the set! Alcaraz hits a drop shot that he's clearly unhappy with and visibly resigns before Djokovic can even reach it. Novak hits down the line, but Alcaraz snaps into action swinging a forehand cros-scourt. Somehow, Djokovic reaches it and volleys into the empty court.\n\nWhat an intense and tight set there. Both players refused to give up ground and Djokovic edged it purely on execution right at the end.\n\nDjokovic's serve is wide and out of reach of the young Spaniard and you can see the frustration set in. He has to visibly hold himself back from smashing his racket into the ground.\n\nThis could be the moment for Djokovic here as he takes a two-point lead.\n\nWhat a serve return from Djokovic who uses the momentum to crash the ball into the service box and away from Alcaraz's reach.\n\nAlcaraz's serve is too strong and Djokovic can't return. Again, we are level.\n\nA fantastic forehand from the left-hand side of the court from Djokovic sets up an easy volleyed return to a gaping hole on the other side of the court.\n\nThis time the backhand is a tad long from Alcaraz. There is nothing to separate these two.\n\nAlcaraz takes the lead with a crushing backhand.\n\nDjokovic wins the first point of the tiebreak after a nice rally but Alcaraz comes storming back in the second point. He launches a brutal forehand down the line which nobody could reach.\n\nDjokovic goes 0-15 up as he looks to steal this set. So far there's been almost nothing separating the two here but Novak senses blood in the water. He advances aggressively, hitting a crosscourt backhand low and true as he approaches mid-court. Alcaraz isn't having any of it though, and returns down the line and out of reach, earning a clap from Djokovic who knows he's been bested there.\n\nAlcaraz follows that up with another forehand slice which Djokovic, at 37 years old, has no intention of wasting his energy on. 30-15 Alcaraz.\n\nA nice rally gives Alcaraz an opportunity to volley into a gaping right-hand side of the court. Somehow he gets it wrong, dropping it into the net and given Djokovic set point.\n\nOf course, he's not doen there though, hitting a gorgeous sweeping forehand out of reach of the stretching Serb. Deuce.\n\nAlcaraz gets a couple of serves right and we're into the tiebreak. This set deserved it.\n\nThe crowd liked that one. Alcaraz rocks back, shaping up for a huge forehand and then cuts through the ball, placing the perfect drop-shot.\n\nDjokovic hesitates a couple of times before his serve as the silenced is pierced by the sound of a baby crying. No doubt as a father of young children that noise has become a daily battle for him. When he does finally get his serve off it's inch pefect and sets up an easy winner following Alcaraz's stretched return - clearly not too distracted.\n\n40-30 up, Djokovic has to sprint to reach one of Alcaraz's torturous short slices. He manages to return this one, and the Spaniard's lob is long, giving Novak the game. He'll have a tie-break at the least.\n\nDjokovic is livid here as he commits an unforced error at the end of a long rally - he knows he can't afford to give up anything easy here.\n\nThere is no such thing as a drop-shot to Alcaraz. Djokovic continues to test him, but the Spaniard is meeting everything at the net. Nevertheless, he sends this one too wide as he tries to give Djokovic no chance of returning.\n\nAnother rare unforced error from Djokovic there as he sends a fairly straightforward backhand long. Alcaraz senses weakness and finishes the game off. Djokovic almost never makes those mistakes and will be furious.\n\nAlcaraz predicts the drop-shot from Djokovic there. The Serb holds his ground though, putting the Spaniard off as he scuffs it in between the tramlines.\n\nThe defence from Alcaraz is impregnable. Djokic blasts a forehand to the far right corner which forces a sliding Alcaraz to return high. Djokovic smashes, but Alcaraz returns, resulting in a stunned Novak hitting an easy one into the net. Again Alcaraz defends, showing off his wheels as he somehow returns a short one despite starting from the other side of the court. Djokovic wins the point and can't help but laugh at the sheer speed of his opponent.\n\nAlcaraz forces break point and almost delivers after again returning a couple of smashes from Djokovic which I'm convinced only he could do. No shot is too hard or too far for this man.\n\nDjokovic continues to shake his head. His forehand clips the net giving Alcaraz time to think. Expecting it to come hard and fast, he cups it over the net, giving Djokovic no chance.\n\nWe're going back and forth here as Djokovic saves break-point after break-point. he simply cannot believe some of the returns his opponent is conjuring up.\n\nThe Serb starts to push back, earning a couple of game-points of his own but Alcaraz holds on, coming up with some ingenious manoeuvres to get himself back in it.\n\nDjokovic finally converts after a long game - it feels like this will be a pivotal one as somehow Alcaraz walks away without a break.\n\nOnly seven unforced errors from Djokovic to Alcaraz's eleven, but that's two in this game alone. He goes for a backhand slice to get the Spaniard running but it won't creep over the net. Next he tries a cross-court forehand which again falls too short.\n\nIt's all tied up here as Djokovic has been the only one to threaten a break thus far.\n\nAlcaraz lets out a yell of frustration as he mishits Djokovic's serve sending it vertical. It's Djokovic's turn to up the ante, matching Alcaraz's rampaging forehand with his own two-handed crusher.\n\nThat'll be seven holds so far as Djokovic exorcizes whatever demons caused him such trouble at Wimbledon - perhaps the extra couple of weeks post operation has returned the power that he was so clearly missing.\n\nHow are you supposed to return that forehand? Alcaraz makes quick work of that game and is strutting his stuff, bumping his head to the music.\n\nIt's Alcaraz's turn to complain here as Djokovic sends him scampering to his right before smashing a forehand volley down the line.\n\nHe comes back straight away though, darting forward to return a short one, placing it just on the line. The athleticism is on full display as he follows this rapid movement with a crashing backhand which wrongfoots Djokovic and earns him a break point.\n\nDjokovic saves three break-points as this turns into a chess match with both players making adjustments after each point, countering the other's. He finally gets his serve spot on, setting up an easy smash to win the game.\n\nA fantastic rally at 15-0 here as both players blast shots cross-court with immense power. The Spaniard goes 30-0 up looking to break.\n\nNovak does not feel the pressure. He wins all the remaining points in the game and holds his serve. The power he generates is beggar's belief. The quality on display is fantastic.\n\nAlcaraz saves break point and then finally wins the game as Djokovic misdirects a backhand.\n\nA couple of unforced errors to start here from Alcaraz as he sends a straightforward forehand long in the first point, and then another into the net in the third.\n\nDjokovic looks strong as he manipulates the Spaniard around the court and goes 40-0 up. Nevertheless, Alcaraz shows off his youthful speed, reaching an attempted drop-shot with ease and sending it out of reach.\n\nThe Serb converts with a fast serve wide to the right hand side of the court, winning the first game 40-30.\n\nThey'll take a moment to settle in before Djokovic serves the first ball of this match. This is a truly historic moment.\n\nThe first time he competed in the Olympics was in 2008. Alcaraz was five years old at the time...\n\nHe gets a huge reception - he'll prefer that to Wimbledon.\n\nHe receives a warm welcome for the crowd in Roland-Garros today.\n\nThe youngest versus the oldest at these Olympics.\n\nThe best two tennis players in the world are about to take the court.\n\nAs Nadal comes close to hanging up his racket, and Federer is already a distant memory, father time has finally come for Britain's darling.\n\nCompeting in the doubles after a defiant display at Wimbledon earlier this summer, Andy Murray teamed up with Dan Evans in an effort to do the impossible and compete for one last medal.\n\nThey managed to conjure up not one but two great escapes showing off that relentless desire to win at all costs.\n\nFirst it was Japan and then Belgium in a super tie-break comeback which was something out of a child's imagination.\n\nAs they don't play deciding sets in the Olympics it came down to a first-to-ten but win-by-two scenario it was all the more intense. But when Evans smashed it straight into the ground to win the game the euphoria was overwhelming.\n\nThey celebrated like they had won it all. And to us, they had.\n\nThe road had to end somewhere and sadly it was the two Americans, Fritz and Paul, who stood in the way.\n\nThey were outmatched and ultimately overcome, but it was a tournament to remember and a sensational way to wrap up a legendary career.\n\nDjokovic is in a red shirt with white shorts whilst Alcaraz dons yellow shorts and a red top.\n\nBoth look loose and calm at this stage.\n\nIt's easy to make comparisons between the two. It sometimes seems Alcaraz is following Nadal's script.\n\nBoth young Spanish stars burst onto the scene and audaciously started winning right away. They both made taking down legends their wheelhouse speciality.\n\nIf we are witnessing the reemergence of a Nadal-esque talent we could well be in for a long road of dominance and titles. I've already seen enough to think he could surpass him - a tall order but one that Alcaraz is fully capable of fulfilling\n\nBut instead of standing one up against the other, these Olympics gave us the gift of seeing them compete together for their country.\n\nAnd it was glorious. They beat Argentinian duo Molteni and Gonzalez in two close sets before taking on and defeating the Dutch pair Griekspoor and Koolhof in the super tie-break.\n\nAs all good things do, it came to an end in the quarter-finals when the Americans, Rajeev Ram and Austin Krajicek, asserted their superiority in spite of the 15,000 disappointed fans who were staunchly behind the Spanish team.\n\nI think that will be Nadal's legacy. A player nobody ever wanted to see lose because to see him play for just one more point was worth it. Alcaraz will no doubt carry the mantle and adhere to his predecessor's example.\n\n...this is Djokovic's first Olympic finals!\n\nThe Serb has lost his last three semi-finals at the Olympics, only winning bronze once. Can he finally get that gold medal he has so relentlessly coveted.\n\nThis was one of tennis's longest and most spectacular rivalries which has never failed to entertain. Two true legends who always knew how to perform and played tennis the right way.\n\n60 contests, Djokovic leading 31-29, there really isn't much separating them. Nadal was always the king of the clay but Djokovic ruled the grass - and for a while pretty much everything else.\n\nWhilst there was certainly the usual hype building up for their match, it did feel bittersweet as Nadal looks to be at the back end of his career, no longer the imperious savant we were accustomed to.\n\nThe Spaniard had lost just four times in these hallowed grounds demonstrating just how at home he is here.\n\nNevertheless, Djokovic is not one for long drawn-own goodbyes. He dismantled Nadal 6-1, 6-4, refusing to play with his food. He is on a mission and isn't interested in any niceties.\n\nNadal was valiant, but admitted he doesn't have the legs of his youth.\n\n\"Playing against Novak without creating damage to him, without having the legs of 20 years ago, is almost impossible now,\" he lamented afterwards.\n\nDjokovic had accepted the possibility that this was the so-called 'last dance' between the pair. But Nadal was more defensive when that suggestion was put to him a few days ago. \"Who says it's the last dance?\" he said, with a quizzical raised eyebrow, sending the tennis rumour mill whirring.\n\nCarlos Alcaraz has won all four major finals he has taken part in, including Wimbledon in 2022, and 2024, the US Open in 2022, and the French Open this year.\n\nEarlier this summer he faced Djokovic in the Wimbledon finals, winning in straight sets and displaying a level of dominance over the Serb we have never seen before.\n\nNovak underwent surgery on a torn meniscus just five weeks before the tournament and yet still steamrolled his way through the tournament to reach the finals.\n\nAnd yet, he was totally outclassed. Alcaraz beamed 42 clean winners to Djokovic's 26 and was manipulating him across the court. He was superior in every department and gave up nothing.\n\n\"He played every single shot better than I did,\" acknowledged Djokovic after his 6-2, 6-2, 7-6 defeat. \"He just was better than me in every aspect of the game: in movement, in the way he was striking the ball beautifully, serving great, everything.\"\n\nAsked about the aftermath of his knee surgery, Djokovic said \"That probably had an effect, particularly in the opening rounds. As the tournament progressed, I felt better and better. But yeah, today I was half a step behind him.\"\n\nNovak will need to play at a much higher level if he is to stand a chance in this one.\n\nIn the first of three contests scheduled to be played on Court Phillipe-Chatrier it was the Women's Doubles bronze medal match. The Spanish duo Busca and Sorribes Tormo won 6-2, 6-2, against Czech players Muchova and Noskova in a fairly one-sided affair.\n\nThe Spaniards hit 18 winners and lulled the Czechs into 26 unforced errors with a classy performance. They were impeccable at the net, displaying inhumane reactions and clinical placement.\n\n\"We are speechless,\" said Christina Busca. \"We are crying. This is a dream that has just come true. There are so many people I would like to thank. I am just speechless.\n\n\"After the semi-final I was sure that we would play for the bronze medal and win it.\"\n\nSara Sorribes said, \"It's really incredible what we've achieved to get a bronze medal - it's crazy.\n\n\"After the match we lost I knew we were going to make it.\"\n\nThis is the dream. First seed up against second seed. The two best tennis players in the world. An established legend who refuses to age versus a young champion hungry for more. A rematch of the Wimbledon finals. Are you not entertained?\n\nDjokovic comes into this match having dominated all would-be contenders, including beating Alcaraz's doubles teammate and fading legend Rafael Nadal.\n\nHe began the tournament against Matthew Ebden, dispatching the Australian in straight sets and only dropping a single game. Ebden won gold in the men's doubles yesterday in a tie-break which ended 10-8.\n\nIn the second round, he took on Nadal, again winning in two sets. Djokovic-Nadal at Roland Garros has been one of the great fixtures of modern sport. They've faced each other 60 times, with Djokovic now leading Nadal 31-29. The Spanish stalwart is in the twilight of his career and Djokovic was able to make easy work of this one. Sadly, it's likely to be the last.\n\nAfter beating the German Dominik Koepfer and the Greek Stefanos Tsitsipas respectively, he faced Lorenzo Musetti in the semi-finals.\n\nSpeaking after his victory, the one-time Olympic medalist said, \"It was such a tense match, there were a lot of emotions, so much expectations and stress particularly as a win meant I would secure a medal for my country and it's my first Olympic final. I'm thrilled.\n\n\"I was very nervous before the match because I lost three out of four of my semi-finals in the Olympic Games, so I really wanted to get over this hurdle.\n\n\"I lost quite comfortably to Carlos [Alcaraz] at Wimbledon but this is a different surface and I'm playing better and moving better than I was at Wimbledon, and in a way I have nothing to lose as I already have a medal, so I'm going to go for it.\"\n\nHe faces the stiffest of challenges in his first Olympic finals in Carlos Alcaraz who already holds the past two Wimbledon finals over his head.\n\nAlcaraz has dominated on his way to the finals, juggling playing doubles with Nadal at the same time. {"uri": "8258786311", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:08:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:08:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:06:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamzagoria/2024/08/04/novak-djokovic-wins-elusive-olympic-gold-medal-to-cap-goat-rsum/", "title": "Novak Djokovic Wins Elusive Olympic Gold Medal To Cap GOAT R\u00e9sum\u00e9", "body": "Before Sunday, Novak Djokovic had accomplished virtually everything else there was to do in tennis except win an Olympic gold medal.\n\nNow the 37-year-old Serb has added that to his r\u00e9sum\u00e9 as the GOAT of men's tennis.\n\nIn a thrilling match of incredibly high-quality tennis, No. 1 Djokovic defeated No. 2 Carlos Alcaraz, 7-6, 7-6, in the gold-medal match at Roland Garros. It was the Serb's first title in 2024. He was coming off meniscus surgery a little more than a month ago.\n\n\"He was already a mythological creature in Serbia and this only adds gold to his resume,\" Mary Carillo said on Peacock.\n\nDjokovic, the all-time men's leader with 24 Grand Slam singles titles, joined an elite club of people who have won all four majors and Olympic gold: Steffi Graf (1988), Andre Agassi (1999), Rafael Nadal (2010) and Serena Williams (2012).\n\nDjokovic's one previous medal was a bronze in 2008 at Beijing after losing to Nadal in the semifinals; Djokovic also was beaten in the semifinals by the eventual champions at London in 2012 (Andy Murray) and at Tokyo three years ago.\n\n\"I played four Olympic games, this is my fifth and I never passed semifinals,\" Djokovic said after his semifinal win over Lorenzo Musetti. \"I lost three out of four semifinals in my first four Olympic games and I managed to overcome this big hurdle.\"\n\nIn a game that took more than 14 minutes and featured several break chances by Alcaraz, Djokovic held for 5-4 in the first.\n\nServing at 5-6, Alcaraz fended off a set point to force a tiebreak.\n\nWith Alcaraz serving at 3-6 in the breaker, he smashed a potential forehand pass winner but Djokovic lunged to stab it back over the net and seize the first set.\n\nThe Serb saved eight break points to win the first set in 1 hour, 32 minutes. When Djokovic left the court for a break, Alcaraz had his head in his hands and had a lengthy conversation with his player box.\n\nIn the second set tiebreak, Djokovic earned an early mini-break for 1-0 and then went up 3-2 with a stretching forehand winner that Alcaraz could not return.\n\nAlcaraz netted a forehand to give Djokovic a 5-2 lead in the breaker. He then hit a two-handed backhand into the net to bring it to 2-6 on his serve.\n\nOn his first match point, Djokovic drilled a forehand winner down the line and then hugged Alcaraz at the net.\n\nDjokovic and Alcaraz had split their six previous career matches, with the Spaniard dominating their most recent match in straight sets in the Wimbledon final last month. They were 1-1 on clay, with Djokovic winning their most recent encounter in the 2023 Roland Garros semifinals when Alcaraz cramped badly and limped to the finish line.\n\nAlcaraz was seeking to become just the second man after his countryman and Olympic doubles partner Rafael Nadal to win the French Open, Wimbledon and Olympic gold in the same year. He had won 12 consecutive matches at Roland Garros dating to the French Open.\n\n\"It's going to be difficult for sure but I will try to be focused on myself,\" Alcaraz said ahead of the match. I try not to hear all the fans, or all the people that say I'm going to win. I'm just going to give my 100%, my best tennis and hopefully I reach my goal to get the gold.\"\n\nDuring his quarterfinal win over Stefanos Tsitsipas, Djokovic twice called the physio for his right knee, the same knee on which he had surgery in early June after withdrawing from Roland Garros. He said he was \"very worried\" about his knee but he rebounded to take out Musetti in straight sets in the semifinals.\n\nAnd then he defeated Alcaraz to win the elusive gold medal.", "source": The Serbian star now joins the Golden Slam club: players who have won all four major tournaments: the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon and US Open, and an Olympic gold medal. He joins Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams.\n\nWith the second-set tiebreaker at 2-2, Djokovic, 37, unleashed a devastating cross-court winner on a service game from Alcaraz that gave him all the momentum. Alcaraz then made a couple of unforced errors. He looked up in disbelief from the stands after Djokovic's fierce match-point winner. After shaking hands with Alcaraz, he fell to the clay court at Roland Garros and knelt for a moment. Djokovic, overcome with emotion, returned to his bench, put his head in a white towel and wept.\n\nDjokovic has achieved everything you can think of in tennis. But the Olympics does that to you. Representing your country does that to you.\n\nRead more: Which Olympic sport is the toughest on the body?\n\nDjokovic has made no secret of his desire for an Olympic gold medal to cap off his career. He has it now.\n\n\"I didn't know until today that there is an even better feeling, which is winning a gold medal for your country,\" Djokovic said after his victory. \"I couldn't be more proud and happy. Playing for Serbia has always been my biggest, real pleasure, priority.\n\nAt 4-4 in the first set and Djokovic serving, Alcaraz, 21, had several chances to break his opponent. After executing a beautiful drop shot to hold Alcaraz off in that game, Djokovic let out a roar, his most emphatic gesture on court to that point. Djokovic's drop shot was a hit all day. He won that first-set tiebreaker in surprisingly easy fashion.\n\nAll day long, Alcaraz had sauce on his shots. But he couldn't tackle the man who is arguably the best defensive player in tennis history. Djokovic maintained his stamina, even after a handful of points that had him running for his water bottle. Djokovic visibly frustrated Alacaraz, who at one point fired a ball into the net in anger.\n\nThe Spanish flags that flew and hung around Roland Garros outnumbered the Serbian ones. But Djokoic still deserved his fair share of support. No no! the grateful fans in the stands chanted. You could hear cheers for Novak outside Court Philippe-Chatrier during the bronze medal match in the women's doubles. Djokovic will always have his detractors. But his stellar performances towards the end of his career and his friendlier demeanor on court in the last few years have done much to convince the crowd that has been skeptical of his Behavior in the Covid Era and anti-vax stance. Playing in the Olympic tournament that many tennis pros skipped should continue to boost his popularity.\n\nRead more: What Olympic Athletes Eat to Have All That Energy\n\nThe victory comes a few weeks after Alcaraz defeated Djokvic in straight sets in the Wimbledon final. \"I feel like I'm a different player than I was at Wimbledon,\" Djokovic said before the final. \"The way I move, the way I hit the ball. Not to take anything away from the fact that he won the Wimbledon final, he was dominant and deserved a winner, but I feel more confident in myself and my chances in the final.\"\n\nHis self-assessment was quite accurate. Djokovic moved and hit. He proved that he can still win more majors.\n\nAnd he has just taken part in the rare Olympic air.\n\nThis is something else, says Djokovic. This is beyond anything I have ever felt on the tennis court after winning major trophies. He joins tennis legends Andre Agassi, Stefanie Graf, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams as the only players to have achieved the feat.\n\nThe match came just two months after Alcaraz won the French Open title on the courts at Roland-Garros.\n\nBut Djokovic's extensive experience on clay gave him the advantage as the 24-time Grand Slam winner fended off Alcaraz.\n\nDjokovic was able to claim the win after expressing concern after the quarterfinals about pain in his surgically-repaired right knee.\n\nDespite that worry, Djokovic dominated Italy's Lorenzo Musetti in the semifinals to reach Alcaraz, then played confidently against his 21-year-old opponent.\n\nSunday's match marked the seventh time Djokovic and Alcaraz have faced one another in competition.\n\nMost recently it was Alcaraz who evened the matchup series with a dominant three-set victory over Djokovic in Wimbledon final.\n\nWith Djokovic finding redemption in the rematch, he now leads the head-to-head series against Alcaraz, {"uri": "8259483356", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:38:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:38:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:36:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/sports/20240805/djokovic-wins-first-olympic-gold-medal", "title": "Djokovic wins first Olympic gold medal", "body": "Serbia's Novak Djokovic reacts after defeating Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in the men's singles tennis final at the Roland Garros stadium during the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris, yesterday.\n\nFor all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia, the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37 yesterday, beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men's tennis singles final at the 2024 Games.\n\nIn a sense, it doesn't matter one bit how long it took, of course. Djokovic is now an Olympic champion and forever will be. And in another sense, the years of waiting, the stumbles along the journey, made him appreciate this triumph as much as - no, make that more than - every other, which is why his hands trembled when he knelt on Court Philippe Chatrier's red clay at the end and why his tears flowed.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I ever had in my career,\" said Djokovic, who didn't drop a set in Paris and is the oldest man to win the Summer Games tennis title since 1908. \"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience, that I could feel.\"\n\nWith margins so thin that any mistake felt as if it could tilt things, Djokovic was at his best when the stakes were highest, dominating each of the two tiebreakers against Alcaraz, who beat him in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreaks, he played an impressive game,\" said silver medallist Alcaraz, the 21-year-old from Spain who sobbed, too, after falling short of becoming the youngest male singles gold medallist. \"That's why I saw that he's hungry for the gold medal. He was going to go for it.\"\n\nDjokovic already owns a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. He also already owned an Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze - and he made it clear that that simply wasn't sufficient. He kept talking over the past week, but also the past months, about what a priority the gold was for him - and Alcaraz said yesterday that he kept hearing about it.\n\nUntil getting past Paris bronze medallist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy on Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in Olympic semi-finals, losing to the gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Djokovic said, \"I was ready.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets.\n\nThe two-hour, 50-minute final featured one of the best to ever do it, in Djokovic - and the \"highest mountain to climb at the moment,\" in Alcaraz, as Djokovic put it.", "source": {"uri": "jamaica-gleaner.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jamaica Gleaner"}, "authors": [], "concepts": playing in his fifth Olympic Games - beat Spain's Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2) in the men's singles final at Paris 2024 on Sunday afternoon.\n\nDjokovic had previously won 10 Australian Opens, seven Wimbledon titles, four US Opens and three French Opens.\n\nBut a bronze medal in Beijing in 2008 had been his best Olympic result until Sunday.\n\nThe only other players to have won all four Grand Slam singles titles and an Olympic gold in singles are Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi, Steffi Graf and Serena Williams - who was among the crowd.\n\nNovak Djokovic sunk to his knees after winning the men's singles gold medal match on Sunday\n\nDjokovic was emotional as he held up a Serbian flag after ending his long wait for Olympic gold\n\nNew Olympic champion Djokovic pictured hugging Carlos Alcaraz after beating him 7-6 7-6\n\nSerena Williams, who has four Olympic gold medals, was among the crowd for Sunday's final\n\nDjokovic sunk to his knees after converting match point against Alcaraz - a player who has beaten him in each of the last two Wimbledon finals.\n\nBoth players were in tears after the match.\n\nAfter getting to his feet, Djokovic climbed into the crowd to join his family and support team.\n\nAlcaraz struggled to hide his disappointment at having to settle for silver. But the 21-year-old will likely get plenty more chances to go for gold, while this was probably Djokovic's final shot at Olympic glory.\n\nSpeaking to Eurosport after his victory, Djokovic said: 'It was an incredible fight and I had to play my best tennis.'\n\nDjokovic was in tears moments after his victory at Roland Garros in Paris on Sunday afternoon\n\nShortly after the match, Djokovic climbed into the crowd and made a beeline for his family\n\nDjokovic pictured kissing wife Jelena after he completed a career Golden Slam on Sunday\n\nA grinning Djokovic pictured standing on top of an Olympic podium, flanked by runner-up Alcarez (left) and Lorenzo Musetti (right) - who won the bronze medal for Italy\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nDjokovic added: 'I put my heart, my soul, everything to win gold. {"uri": "8259321265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:40:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:40:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:39:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://thesun.ng/djokovic-wins-first-olympic-gold-medal-beats-alcaraz-in-mens-tennis-final/", "title": "Djokovic wins first Olympic gold medal, beats Alcaraz", "body": "For all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia, the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37. Doesn't matter a bit how long it took. Djokovic beat Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men\u00b4s tennis singles final at the 2024 Games on Sunday.\n\n\"I put my heart, my soul, my body, my family - my everything - on the line to win Olympic gold,\" Djokovic said. \"Incredible battle. Incredible fight.\"\n\nHis impressive career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze - and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient.\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nBefore facing Musetti, Djokovic said, \"I was like, 'OK, let\u00b4s get through this one.' That's why today, before the match, I did not feel as nervous as I would normally feel, because I had secured a medal.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 - and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\nWhen the victory was his, when the gold was his, thanks to one last forehand winner, Djokovic turned toward his team in the stands - sitting in front of his wife and their two children - dropped his racket and knelt on the clay. As emotional as ever, he cried and covered his face, then rose and grabbed a red-white-and-blue Serbian flag.\n\nAfter hugs in the stands, Djokovic waved that flag.\n\n\"In the tough moments, he gave it an extra push,\" silver medalist Alcaraz said through his own tears. \"It hurts to lose like this.\"\n\nThe final, which lasted 2 hours, 50 minutes despite being decided in only two sets, was a rematch of the Wimbledon title match three weeks ago that Alcaraz won to follow up his French Open title in June.\n\nSunday\u00b4s contest featured one of the best to ever do it in Djokovic, and the best at the moment in Alcaraz. Indeed, could have been frustrating for Djokovic to find himself once again across the net from a younger, speedier version of himself. Maybe that\u00b4s why Djokovic frequently looked up and gesticulated and muttered toward his guest box.\n\n\"Honestly, when the last shot went through him, past him, that was the only moment I actually thought I can win the match,\" Djokovic said.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.ng", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun Nigeria"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259586108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:03:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:03:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:03:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/aug/05/djokovic-adds-an-olympic-gold-to-his-resume/", "title": "Djokovic adds an Olympic gold to his resume", "body": "PARIS -- For all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia, the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37 on Sunday, beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men's tennis singles final at the 2024 Games.\n\nIn a sense, it doesn't matter one bit how long it took, of course. Djokovic is now an Olympic champion and forever will be. And in another sense, the years of waiting, the stumbles along the journey, made him appreciate this triumph as much as every other, which is why his hands trembled when he knelt on Court Philippe Chatrier's red clay at the end and why his tears flowed.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I ever had in my career,\" said Djokovic, who didn't drop a set in Paris and is the oldest man to win the Summer Games tennis title since 1908. \"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience, that I could feel.\"\n\nWith margins so thin that any mistake felt as if it could tilt things, Djokovic was at his best when the stakes were highest, dominating each of the two tiebreakers against Alcaraz, who beat him in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreaks, he played an impressive game,\" said silver medalist Alcaraz, the 21-year-old from Spain who sobbed, too, after falling short of becoming the youngest male singles gold medalist. \"That's why I saw that he's hungry for the gold medal. He was going to go for it.\"\n\nDjokovic already owns a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. He also already owned an Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient. He kept talking over the past week, but also the past months, about what a priority the gold was for him -- and Alcaraz said Sunday he kept hearing about it.\n\nUntil getting Paris bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy on Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in Olympic semifinals, losing to the gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Djokovic said, \"I was ready.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets.\n\nThe 2-hour, 50-minute final featured one of the best to ever do it, in Djokovic -- and the \"highest mountain to climb at the moment,\" in Alcaraz, as Djokovic put it.\n\nThere was superb ball-striking, deft drop shots and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense. The No. 1 seed Djokovic saved eight break points, No. 2 Alcaraz saved six. Pressure? Ha. What pressure?\n\n\"We both played at a very high level,\" Djokovic said. \"We really went toe-to-toe.\"\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, Alcaraz -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Those in the stands became part of the show, breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. As Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters chanted \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\").\n\nYet the place was as quiet as a theater between points; play was delayed briefly when a young child's crying pierced the air that was thick with anticipation.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes on the way to that tiebreaker, when Djokovic grabbed the last four points, then turned to face his guest box -- which included his tennis team and his wife and their two children -- with a fist held high.\n\nIn the second tiebreaker, after Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point for a 3-2 lead, he waved his arms to encourage the folks standing and screaming. Soon, thanks to one last forehand winner, he had earned that prize he wanted, at long last.\n\nWhen the Serbian national anthem finished ringing out, Djokovic reached for his gold and brought it to his lips for a kiss.\n\nWas he worried that moment would never arrive?\n\n\"There are always doubts. Absolutely, I had doubts,\" Djokovic said. \"But the belief and the conviction that I can make it is stronger than my doubts. It always has been. I knew that it's going to happen. It was just a matter of when it's going to happen.\"\n\nSpain's Carlos Alcaraz returns the ball to Serbia's Novak Djokovic during the men's singles tennis final at the Roland Garros stadium during the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Paris, France.
