{"uri": "8259071201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:32:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:32:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:30:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/ap/sports/novak-djokovic-finally-adds-an-olympic-gold-to-his-resume-by-beating-carlos-alcaraz-in/article_25cc3437-efab-5fb2-9971-a0554254d190.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic finally adds an Olympic gold to his resume by beating Carlos Alcaraz in a taut final", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- For all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia, the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37 on Sunday, beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men's tennis singles final at the 2024 Games.\n\nIn a sense, it doesn't matter one bit how long it took, of course. Djokovic is now an Olympic champion and forever will be. And in another sense, the years of waiting, the stumbles along the journey, made him appreciate this triumph as much as -- no, make that more than -- every other, which is why his hands trembled when he knelt on Court Philippe Chatrier's red clay at the end and why his tears flowed.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I ever had in my career,\" said Djokovic, who didn't drop a set in Paris and is the oldest man to win the Summer Games tennis title since 1908. \"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience, that I could feel.\"\n\nWith margins so thin that any mistake felt as if it could tilt things, Djokovic was at his best when the stakes were highest, dominating each of the two tiebreakers against Alcaraz, who beat him in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreaks, he played an impressive game,\" said silver medalist Alcaraz, the 21-year-old from Spain who sobbed, too, after falling short of becoming the youngest male singles gold medalist. \"That's why I saw that he's hungry for the gold medal. He was going to go for it.\"\n\nDjokovic already owns a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. He also already owned an Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient. He kept talking over the past week, but also the past months, about what a priority the gold was for him -- and Alcaraz said Sunday he kept hearing about it.\n\nUntil getting Paris bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy on Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in Olympic semifinals, losing to the gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Djokovic said, \"I was ready.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets.\n\nThe 2-hour, 50-minute final featured one of the best to ever do it, in Djokovic -- and the \"highest mountain to climb at the moment,\" in Alcaraz, as Djokovic put it.\n\nThere was superb ball-striking, deft drop shots and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense. The No. 1 seed Djokovic saved eight break points, No. 2 Alcaraz saved six. Pressure? Ha. What pressure?\n\n\"We both played at a very high level,\" Djokovic said. \"We really went toe-to-toe.\"\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, Alcaraz -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Those in the stands became part of the show, breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. As Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters chanted \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\").\n\nYet the place was as quiet as a theater between points; play was delayed briefly when a young child's crying pierced the air that was thick with anticipation.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes on the way to that tiebreaker, when Djokovic grabbed the last four points, then turned to face his guest box -- which included his tennis team and his wife and their two children -- with a fist held high.\n\nIn the second tiebreaker, after Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point for a 3-2 lead, he waved his arms to encourage the folks standing and screaming. Soon, thanks to one last forehand winner, he had earned that prize he wanted, at long last.\n\nWhen the Serbian national anthem finished ringing out, Djokovic reached for his gold and brought it to his lips for a kiss.\n\nWas he worried that moment would never arrive?\n\n\"There are always doubts. Absolutely, I had doubts,\" Djokovic said. \"But the belief and the conviction that I can make it is stronger than my doubts. It always has been. I knew that it's going to happen. It was just a matter of when it's going to happen.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "yakimaherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yakima The Serbian is also eyeing to play the Los Angeles Olympics in 2028, when he would turn 41. The 37-year-old already became the oldest to win an Olympic gold in the history of singles tennis event. Djokovic beat Spain's Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (7/3), 7-6 (7/2) in an enthralling final at the Court Phillippe Chartier in Paris.\n\n\"This is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had and the most special feeling,\" the 37-year-old Serb said. \"I want to play in Los Angeles, I enjoy playing for my country in the Olympic Games, in the Davis Cup,\" he added. Djokovic won a bronze medal in the Beijing Olympics 2008 and lost three semi-finals before clinching the gold medal at the Paris Games.\n\nParis Olympics 2024: India Schedule | Full Coverage | Medal Tally\n\nWith the historic win, Djokovic joined Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf and Serena Williams in an elite club. These are the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold, completing the career Golden Slam.\n\n\"I thought carrying the flag at the opening ceremony for my country at the 2012 Olympics was the best feeling an athlete could have until today.\"\n\nDjokovic, who has won a men's record 24 majors and swept up every title there is in tennis, finally clinched Olympic gold at his fifth Games. He also managed to beat Alcaraz, who got the better of him in two consecutive Wimbledon finals.\n\nThe 37-year-old said that he was not assured of a win until the final shot and gave his everything thinking that this could be his last shot at the Olympic gold.\n\n\"Now at the age of 37 and facing a 21-year-old who is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back, I can say that this is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had.\"\n\n\"We almost played three hours, the final shot was the only moment when I was sure I could win the match,\" said Djokovic.\n\n\"I knew that this could be my last chance of a gold medal,\" added Djokovic at his post-final press conference still draped in his country's flag and with his medal hanging proudly around his neck.\n\n\"I did everything I possibly could to prepare myself for this period. The injury sidetracked me a little bit. But coming into the Olympic Games, I felt like a different player in terms of how I moved, how I played.\n\nAlcaraz, 21, was also in tears after the match, but became the youngest to win a silver {"uri": "8258892759", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:59:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:59:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:56:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/olympics/story/paris-olympics-novak-djokovic-gold-medal-final-biggest-success-2576825-2024-08-04", "title": "Novak Djokovic thrilled after 'unprecedented' Olympic gold: Biggest success I had", "body": "Novak Djokovic won the gold medal in Paris Olympics 2024Djokovic beat Carlos Alcaraz in straight setsDjokovic also completed a career golden slam\n\nNovak Djokovic was over the moon after he fulfilled his dream of winning an Olympic gold. The 37-year-old finished on top in Paris after he defeated Carlos Alcaraz in the men's singles final on Centre Court. He won the match 7-6 (7-4), 7-6 (7-3) at Philippe Chatrier. It also happened to be his second medal in the Olympics after he clinched bronze back in Beijing 2008.\n\nDjokovic also completed the career golden glam after Steffi Graf (1998), Andre Agassi (1999), Andre Agassi (1999), Rafael Nadal (2010) and Serena Williams (2012). Djokovic had to fight for nearly three hours to get the better of Alcaraz, who earlier defeated him in the final of Wimbledon 2024.\n\nBoth the sets went right down to the wire, but once they went into tie-breaks, Djokovic showed why he is deemed as of the greats of the game.\n\n\"I don't know. I'm overwhelmed with everything I'm feeling right now. Feeling different emotions. Too proud. Too happy. Thrilled with the possibility to win gold for the first time in my career for my country,\" Djokovic said in the on-court interview.\n\nDjokovic has won numerous tournaments around the world, including 24 Grand Slam titles, the most by any player. However, he rated the Olympic gold as the 'biggest success' of his career.\n\n\"Arguably the biggest success I had. I won probably everything there is to win in my individual career. Winning Davis Cup and particularly a golden medal at age 37 for Serbia is unprecedented. I'm just starting my celebration. I can't wait for what's coming up in the next 48 hours,\" Djokovic added.\n\nAfter the match, Djokovic broke down in tears as he celebrated with his family. {"uri": "8258996229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:54:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:54:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:53:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/novak-djokovic-says-that-olympic-gold-supersedes-everything-as-he-defeats-carlos-alcaraz-in-thrilling/article_5f955b0e-f8be-5f8e-9f90-c89c40ac09d3.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic says that Olympic gold 'supersedes everything' as he defeats Carlos Alcaraz in thrilling final", "body": "Roland Garros, Paris (CNN) -- On his fifth time trying, after a match of extraordinary quality, Novak Djokovic has a late addition to his near-perfect tennis resum\u00e9: Olympic gold medalist.\n\nDjokovic outdueled Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in a brilliant, exhausting men's singles final at Roland Garros on Sunday, triumphing 7-6(3) 7-6(2) in two hours and 50 minutes.\n\nWith the victory, Djokovic became the fifth player to own what has been dubbed the career golden slam by winning all four majors and an Olympic singles title. That exclusive group also features Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi, Steffi Graf and Serena Williams, who was in the stands to witness this pulsating contest.\n\nHow much this triumph meant to Djokovic was immediately evident. Upon winning match point, he roared with delight, dropped to his knees, then tearfully embraced his family and coaching team.\n\nA Serbian flag was soon brought out, and the 37-year-old - the oldest man to win an Olympics singles gold medal - still seemed shaken with joy when he returned to his courtside chair. This is the first title that Djokovic has won all year, but arguably the one he wanted the most.\n\n\"I couldn't be prouder and happier,\" said Djokovic, who won a bronze medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.\n\n\"Playing for Serbia has always been my utmost, real pleasure, my priority ... I'm just so proud to be a part of an elite number of athletes that managed to win gold for their countries in their respective sports.\"\n\nOlympic tennis competitions can be a strange thing, arriving at awkward times in the calendar and often missing some of the sport's top players. This, however, was an exception, a thrilling sequel to Alcaraz's straight-sets victory in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\nAt the Paris Olympics, Djokovic has returned to the court on which he sustained a knee injury while playing at the French Open in June. That seems a lifetime ago now, and one meniscus surgery and one grand slam final later, he has now filled a notable gap in his remarkable trophy cabinet.\n\nStill playing with a brace on his right knee, Djokovic started the match promisingly, creating a break point on Alcaraz's first service game.\n\nThe 21-year-old shut out the opening, which would become a common theme through the early part of the match. Djokovic had five break points in the first set and Alcaraz eight, yet neither man could edge in front.\n\nOr looking at it another way, both seemed to raise their standard when the pressure increased. That was best demonstrated at 2-1 in the first set, with Alcaraz 0-40 down on his own serve. After a quick change of rackets, he reeled off the next three points before wrapping up the game a few points later with an exquisite drop volley.\n\nThe roles reversed several games later. With the set locked at 4-4, Alcaraz's booming forehand heaped the pressure on Djokovic's serve, and the break points came thick and fast - five in that game alone. But the world No. 2 stood firm, roaring to the crowd when a volley winner denied Alcaraz the chance to get ahead.\n\nIt was fitting and probably fair that this absorbing set would be decided by a tie-break, and with the scores locked at 3-3, it was Alcaraz who cracked first. Back-to-back errors handed Djokovic three set points before another cute forehand volley completed the marathon first set in an hour and 33 minutes.\n\nUnsurprisingly, little changed in the second set, only that break points became fewer and farther between.\n\nAs the match wore on, the standard remained unrelentingly high. At 4-4, Djokovic came from 40-0 down to deuce on Alcaraz serve, prompting chants of \"Nol\u00e9! Nol\u00e9!\" from the stands. But Alcaraz had a response, winning a marathon point by sliding a shot past Djokovic at the net, then raising a finger to his ear in celebration.\n\nAn inevitable tie-break followed soon after and, once again, the 24-time grand slam champion's experience and mettle came to the fore.\n\nA stunning cross-court forehand, bringing to an end one of the longest rallies of the match, had the crowd on their feet, and Djokovic didn't lose a point from there. Another forehand winner completed the victory, which was sealed with a huge roar of delight.\n\nThereafter, the emotions flowed freely as Djokovic kissed and hugged his wife and children in the stands. This was only Serbia's second medal of the Games, and the country's sporting talisman had achieved it without dropping a set in the competition.\n\n\"I was so blessed to win everything pretty much there is to win in my sport, but this is something different,\" said Djokovic. \"This supersedes everything that I've ever felt on the tennis court after winning big trophies. It's just incredible joy.\"\n\nAt 21, Alcaraz had been aiming to become the youngest man to win an Olympic singles gold medal. Despite falling short, he played a wonderful role in this spectacle, dazzling the crowd with 25 forehand winners.\n\nHis unforced error count may have cost him - 33 to Djokovic's 25 - as well as an inferiority to his opponent in the two tie-breaks. But heading into the US swing, the world No. 3 can nonetheless reflect on a stellar two-month period: a first French Open title, a second Wimbledon title and now an Olympic silver medal.\n\n\"I'm really happy about my performance today,\" Alcaraz told reporters. \"I'm a little bit disappointed about not playing my best tennis in some situations, in difficult situations. Tie-breaks, for example, he increased his level at the top and I couldn't do it, so probably a bit sad thinking about those moments.\"\n\nIt just happened to be one of those days that Alcaraz found himself up against an opponent who was inspired and determined like never before.\n\n\"In front of me, I had a really angry Novak,\" he added, \"An impressive player today. His level was really, really high.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8259082216", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:46:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:46:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:45:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/sports/tennis/god-is-great-djokovic-after-capturing-maiden-mens-singles-olympic-gold20240805020243/", "title": "\"God is great...\": Djokovic after capturing maiden men's singles Olympic gold", "body": "Paris [France], August 5 (ANI): Following his Olympic gold medal win, Serbian tennis legend Novak Djokovic expressed his happiness by thanking god for helping him achieving this big landmark in his illustrious career.\n\nDjokovic turned his ultimate dream into reality by winning his first Olympic gold by overcoming Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in the men's singles final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nSpeaking to ANI, Djokovic said, \"God is great. Thank God. I am super proud, super happy.\"\n\nHe also celebrated his moment by holding the Serbian flag in his hand with pride.\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam Champion was down on his knees and tears of joy fell from his eyes after taking the game point. With the name Djokovic echoing around the stadium, the Serbian climbed the stairs and went into the stands to celebrate with his family. After Djokovic's 7-6, 7-6 win in the gold medal match, the emotions got the better of Alcaraz as he settled for the silver medal.\n\nNow after this win, he has won 24 Grand Slam titles, the most by anyone across both men's and women's tennis. Djokovic has won 10 Australian Open titles, three French Open titles, seven Wimbledon titles and four US Open titles.\n\nBesides all this, he now finally has an Olympic gold medal, which is required for a player to complete a career golden slam.\n\nAside from his dominance at Grand Slam level, Djokovic has a total of 72 big titles in tennis. After spending years trying to catch up with stars like Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, he has outshined them to become the leader of the modern-day 'Big Three' in tennis. This includes 40 ATP Masters titles as well and seven ATP Finals championship titles.\n\nNadal is second among the 'Big Three', with a total of 59 big titles, including 22 Grand Slams, which also includes a record 14 French Open titles, 36 ATP Masters titles and one Olympic gold medal in singles competition.\n\nFederer is at number three, with 20 Grand Slam titles, including a record eight Wimbledon titles, 28 ATP Masters titles and six ATP Finals titles. This all combines and make 54 big titles. He has no Olympic singles gold medal though, having one silver medal in the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nThe blockbuster gold medal clash had its fair share of highlights, with Alcaraz flaunting his ace and Djokovic shinning with his precision.\n\nIn a neck-to-neck battle, Djokovic sealed the first game and stood inches away from breaking Alcaraz's serve.\n\nThroughout the first set, fierce rallies unfolded with Alcaraz, quick as lightning, pulling off slapshots backhand and forehand shots from his arsenal. Djokovic relied on using the court to his advantage and negating the threat that Alacaraz carried.\n\nAlcaraz and Djokovic stood steps away from breaking each other's serve numerous times. Eventually, Djokovic managed to take away Alcaraz's advantage during the breakpoint and smiled. Each time Alcaraz denied the Serbian to go ahead in the game, the Spaniard was more aggressive and animated in his reaction.\n\nWith the first set level at 6-6, the game went into a tiebreak. Djokovic took the first point after Alcaraz's attempt to slice a forehand shot went wide.\n\nThe Spaniard fought back to take the next point. The duo seemed inseparable until Djokovic upped the ante to take four consecutive points to seal the first set in his favour.\n\nIn the second set, the uncanny resemblance to the opening set continued to keep the packed audience in a state of trance.\n\nDjokovic ensured that Alcaraz had no room to get close to the net and take control of their intense rallies. The second set featured some delightful rallies, forcing the fans to stand on their feet and appreciate the spectacle that the two produced. Drop shot was a common theme throughout those rallies, which was used by both tennis stars to overcome each other.\n\nWith the second set going right down the wire at 6-6, Alcaraz needed to take the second set home to keep his hopes of standing at the top of the podium alive.\n\nDjokovic raced to a 2-0 lead but Alcaraz fought back to level the scoreline. Djokovic relied on his strong forehand play to turn his dream into reality and win his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe heartbreak that Djokovic suffered in the Wimbledon final last month at the hands of Alcaraz became a distant memory. {"uri": "8260058794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:12:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:12:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:11:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.sunstar.com.ph/network/djokovic-quenches-thirst-for-olympic-gold-medal", "title": "Djokovic quenches thirst for Olympic gold medal", "body": "PARIS -- For all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia, the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37 on Sunday (Monday, Aug. 5, 2024, PH time), beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men's tennis singles final at the 2024 Games.\n\nIn a sense, it doesn't matter one bit how long it took, of course. Djokovic is now an Olympic champion and forever will be. And in another sense, the years of waiting, the stumbles along the journey, made him appreciate this triumph as much as -- no, make that more than -- every other, which is why his hands trembled when he knelt on Court Philippe Chatrier's red clay at the end and why his tears flowed.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I ever had in my career,\" said Djokovic, who didn't drop a set in Paris and is the oldest man to win the Summer Games tennis title since 1908. \"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience, that I could feel.\"\n\nWith margins so thin that any mistake felt as if it could tilt things, Djokovic was at his best when the stakes were highest, dominating each of the two tiebreakers against Alcaraz, who beat him in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreaks, he played an impressive game,\" said silver medalist Alcaraz, the 21-year-old from Spain who sobbed, too, after falling short of becoming the youngest male singles gold medalist. \"That's why I saw that he's hungry for the gold medal. He was going to go for it.\"\n\nDjokovic already owns a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. He also already owned an Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient. He kept talking over the past week, but also the past months, about what a priority the gold was for him -- and Alcaraz said Sunday he kept hearing about it.\n\nUntil getting Paris bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy on Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in Olympic semifinals, losing to the gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Djokovic said, \"I was ready.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets.\n\nThe 2-hour, 50-minute final featured one of the best to ever do it, in Djokovic -- and the \"highest mountain to climb at the moment,\" in Alcaraz, as Djokovic put it.\n\nThere was superb ball-striking, deft drop shots and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense. The No. 1 seed Djokovic saved eight break points, No. 2 Alcaraz saved six. Pressure? Ha. What pressure?\n\n\"We both played at a very high level,\" Djokovic said. \"We really went toe-to-toe.\"\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, Alcaraz -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Those in the stands became part of the show, breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. As Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters chanted \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\"). / AP", "source": {"uri": "sunstar.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sun.Star {"uri": "8259323322", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:44:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:44:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:42:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/sports/tennis/i-am-super-proud-novak-djokovic-after-winning-gold-medal-at-paris-olympics20240805080236/", "title": "\"I am super proud\": Novak Djokovic after winning gold medal at Paris Olympics", "body": "Paris [France], August 5 (ANI): Serbian Tennis player Novak Djokovic said that he is feeling super proud after winning the gold medal in the ongoing Paris Olympics on Sunday.\n\nDjokovic turned his ultimate dream into reality by winning his first Olympic gold by overcoming Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in the men's singles final in Paris.\n\nSpeaking to ANI, Djokovic said, \"God is great. Thank God. I am super proud, super happy.\"\n\nHe also celebrated his moment by holding the Serbian flag in his hand with pride.\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam Champion was down on his knees and tears of joy fell from his eyes after taking the game point. With the name Djokovic echoing around the stadium, the Serbian climbed the stairs and went into the stands to celebrate with his family. After Djokovic's 7-6, 7-6 win in the gold medal match, the emotions got the better of Alcaraz as he settled for the silver medal.\n\nNow after this win, he has won 24 Grand Slam titles, the most by anyone across both men's and women's tennis. Djokovic has won 10 Australian Open titles, three French Open titles, seven Wimbledon titles and four US Open titles.\n\nBesides all this, he now finally has an Olympic gold medal, which is required for a player to complete a career golden slam.\n\nAside from his dominance at Grand Slam level, Djokovic has a total of 72 big titles in tennis. After spending years trying to catch up with stars like Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, he has outshined them to become the leader of the modern-day 'Big Three' in tennis. This includes 40 ATP Masters titles as well and seven ATP Finals championship titles.\n\nNadal is second among the 'Big Three', with a total of 59 big titles, including 22 Grand Slams, which also includes a record 14 French Open titles, 36 ATP Masters titles and one Olympic gold medal in singles competition.\n\nFederer is at number three, with 20 Grand Slam titles, including a record eight Wimbledon titles, 28 ATP Masters titles and six ATP Finals titles. This all combines and makes 54 big titles. He has no Olympic singles gold medal though, having one silver medal in the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nThe blockbuster gold medal clash had its fair share of highlights, with Alcaraz flaunting his ace and Djokovic shinning with his precision.In a neck-to-neck battle, Djokovic sealed the first game and stood inches away from breaking Alcaraz's serve.\n\nThroughout the first set, fierce rallies unfolded with Alcaraz, quick as lightning, pulling off slapshots backhand and forehand shots from his arsenal. Djokovic relied on using the court to his advantage and negating the threat that Alacaraz carried.\n\nAlcaraz and Djokovic stood steps away from breaking each other's serve numerous times. Eventually, Djokovic managed to take away Alcaraz's advantage during the breakpoint and smiled. Each time Alcaraz denied the Serbian to go ahead in the game, the Spaniard was more aggressive and animated in his reaction.\n\nWith the first set level at 6-6, the game went into a tiebreak. Djokovic took the first point after Alcaraz's attempt to slice a forehand shot went wide.\n\nThe Spaniard fought back to take the next point. The duo seemed inseparable until Djokovic upped the ante to take four consecutive points to seal the first set in his favour.\n\nIn the second set, the uncanny resemblance to the opening set continued to keep the packed audience in a state of trance.\n\nDjokovic ensured that Alcaraz had no room to get close to the net and take control of their intense rallies. The second set featured some delightful rallies, forcing the fans to stand on their feet and appreciate the spectacle that the two produced. Drop shot was a common theme throughout those rallies, which was used by both tennis stars to overcome each other.\n\nWith the second set going right down the wire at 6-6, Alcaraz needed to take the second set home to keep his hopes of standing at the top of the podium alive.\n\nDjokovic raced to a 2-0 lead but Alcaraz fought back to level the scoreline. Djokovic relied on his strong forehand play to turn his dream into reality and win his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe heartbreak that Djokovic suffered in the Wimbledon final last month at the hands of Alcaraz became a distant memory. {"uri": "8258805152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:25:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:25:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:25:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/novak-djokovic-epic-last-stand-150956676.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic's epic last stand ends long quest for Olympic gold medal against Carlos Alcaraz", "body": "In the aftermath of his Wimbledon final defeat to Carlos Alcaraz, Novak Djokovic found it remarkably easy to come to terms with the battering he had just taken on Centre Court.\n\nAs a chance to make further history slipped away and Alcaraz demonstrated his supremacy over a one-sided final, Djokovic reached peace by reminding himself that a bigger goal and more important opportunity would quickly arrive. After all, if there was one tennis match Djokovic could have picked to win at the start of the year, it wouldn't have been the Wimbledon final.\n\nJust 21 days later, an inspired Djokovic earned revenge and ended his long quest for a first Olympic gold medal, defeating Alcaraz 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2) in an all-time final at Roland Garros.\n\nAt 37 and at his fifth Olympics, Djokovic captured the one title that had far so long evaded him to complete the career golden slam. Two months after tearing his meniscus in his right knee and appearing to be a doubt for the Olympics when he underwent surgery, Djokovic returned to the same court on Philippe-Chatier to record one of the greatest victories of his career against his young rival, delivering a gold medal for Serbia that will rank highly among his record 24 grand slam titles.\n\nIn doing so, he managed to suppress Alcaraz just as the Spaniard was appearing to be a level above what Djokovic was able to produce at this stage of his career. Djokovic dug deep into his reserves, first denying and then outlasting Alcaraz in an titanic 93-minute opening set. Djokovic withstood Alcaraz's powers of athleticism and shot-making in an epic last stand that displayed a vintage look at his greatest qualities as a tennis player. Djokovic endured, remaining solid in all aspects of his game, and delivered when the biggest moments arrived to claim a historic victory in one of the most memorable Olympics finals ever staged.\n\nAnd with 10 Australian Opens, three French Opens, seven Wimbledon, four US Opens, seven ATP Finals, 40 ATP 1000 titles, Djokovic now has the Olympic gold to tick the final box that was missing in his career. By becoming just the fifth player to complete the career grand slam in singles, he joins Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi, Serena Williams and Steffi Graf to claim another major milestone. Djokovic needed to be at his very best to beat Alcaraz and with history on the line, but found a level that had looked beyond him for much of the season. With the name Djokovic echoing around the stadium, the Serbian climbed the stairs and went into the stands to celebrate with his family. After Djokovic's 7-6, 7-6 win in the gold medal match, the emotions got the better of Alcaraz as he settled for the silver medal.\n\nAlso Read | Hockey India Highlights 'Umpiring' and 'Decision-Making' Concerns at Paris Olympics 2024, Points Out Amit Rohidas' Red Card Among Others in Indian Men's Hockey Team's Quarterfinal Win Over Great Britain.\n\nNow after this win, he has won 24 Grand Slam titles, the most by anyone across both men's and women's tennis. Djokovic has won 10 Australian Open titles, three French Open titles, seven Wimbledon titles and four US Open titles.\n\nBesides all this, he now finally has an Olympic gold medal, which is required for a player to complete a career golden slam.\n\nAside from his dominance at Grand Slam level, Djokovic has a total of 72 big titles in tennis. After spending years trying to catch up with stars like Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, he has outshined them to become the leader of the modern-day 'Big Three' in tennis. This includes 40 ATP Masters titles as well and seven ATP Finals championship titles.\n\nNadal is second among the 'Big Three', with a total of 59 big titles, including 22 Grand Slams, which also includes a record 14 French Open titles, 36 ATP Masters titles and one Olympic gold medal in singles competition.\n\nFederer is at number three, with 20 Grand Slam titles, including a record eight Wimbledon titles, 28 ATP Masters titles and six ATP Finals titles. This all combines and makes 54 big titles. He has no Olympic singles gold medal though, having one silver medal in the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nBesides Djokovic, no other player has won an Olympic singles gold, Grand Slams and all nine ATP Masters 1000 titles.\n\nNotably, Djokovic won all four grand slams in 2021 but failed to touch the rare feat of winning all four grand slams as well as the Olympic gold. Fast forward three years later, the Serbian legend finally has his hands on the elusive gold.\n\nThe blockbuster gold medal clash had its fair share of highlights, with Alcaraz flaunting his ace and Djokovic shinning with his precision.\n\nIn a neck-to-neck battle, Djokovic sealed the first game and stood inches away from breaking Alcaraz's serve.\n\nThroughout the first set, fierce rallies unfolded with Alcaraz, quick as lightning, pulling off slapshots backhand and forehand shots from his arsenal. Djokovic relied on using the court to his advantage and negating the threat that Alacaraz carried.\n\nAlcaraz and Djokovic stood steps away from breaking each other's serve numerous times. Eventually, Djokovic managed to take away Alcaraz's advantage during the breakpoint and smiled. Each time Alcaraz denied the Serbian to go ahead in the game, the Spaniard was more aggressive and animated in his reaction.\n\nWith the first set level at 6-6, the game went into a tiebreak. Djokovic took the first point after Alcaraz's attempt to slice a forehand shot went wide.\n\nThe Spaniard fought back to take the next point. The duo seemed inseparable until Djokovic upped the ante to take four consecutive points to seal the first set in his favour.\n\nIn the second set, the uncanny resemblance to the opening set continued to keep the packed audience in a state of trance.\n\nDjokovic ensured that Alcaraz had no room to get close to the net and take control of their intense rallies. {"uri": "2024-08-444174768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:05:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:05:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:53:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://omaha.com/eedition/sunrise/articles/djokovic-adds-coveted-gold-to-complete-his-r-sum/article_2e7fd05f-3db9-5cf5-9706-8016f0bd541d.html", "title": "Djokovic adds coveted gold to complete his r\u00e9sum\u00e9", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- For all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia, the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37 on Sunday, beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men's tennis singles final at the 2024 Games.\n\nIn a sense, it doesn't matter one bit how long it took, of course. Djokovic is now an Olympic champion and forever will be. And in another sense, the years of waiting, the stumbles along the journey, made him appreciate this triumph as much as -- no, make that more than -- every other, which is why his hands trembled when he knelt on Court Philippe Chatrier's red clay at the end and why his tears flowed.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I ever had in my career,\" said Djokovic, who didn't drop a set in Paris and is the oldest man to win the Summer Games tennis title since 1908. \"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience, that I could feel.\"\n\nWith margins so thin that any mistake felt as if it could tilt things, Djokovic was at his best when the stakes were highest, dominating each of the two tiebreakers against Alcaraz, who beat him in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreaks, he played an impressive game,\" said silver medalist Alcaraz, the 21-year-old from Spain who sobbed, too, after falling short of becoming the youngest male singles gold medalist. \"That's why I saw that he's hungry for the gold medal. He was going to go for it.\"\n\nDjokovic already owns a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. He also already owned an Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient. He kept talking over the past week, but also the past months, about what a priority the gold was for him -- and Alcaraz said Sunday he kept hearing about it.\n\nUntil getting Paris bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy on Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in Olympic semifinals, losing to the gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Djokovic said, \"I was ready.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets.\n\nThe 2-hour, 50-minute final featured one of the best to ever do it, in Djokovic -- and the \"highest mountain to climb at the moment,\" in Alcaraz, as Djokovic put it.\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, Alcaraz -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Those in the stands became part of the show, breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\"\n\nYet the place was as quiet as a theater between points; play was delayed briefly when a young child's crying pierced the air that was thick with anticipation.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes on the way to that tiebreaker, when Djokovic grabbed the last four points.\n\nIn the second tiebreaker, after Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point for a 3-2 lead, he waved his arms to encourage the folks standing and screaming. Soon, thanks to one last forehand winner, he had earned that prize he wanted, at long last.\n\nWhen the Serbian national anthem finished ringing out, Djokovic reached for his gold and brought it to his lips for a kiss.", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Omaha.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz", "type": "person", {"uri": "8258792456", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:13:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:13:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:12:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5679444/2024/08/04/novak-djokovic-gold-olympics-tennis-carlos-alcaraz/", "title": "Game, Set, Match: Novak Djokovic beats Carlos Alcaraz for Olympic gold in Paris", "body": "Relive how Novak Djokovic won Olympic gold against Carlos Alcaraz with game-by-game live coverage from the match\n\nPARIS -- Novak Djokovic beat Carlos Alcaraz 7-6(3), 7-6(2) in the men's singles Olympic final at Roland Garros in Paris on Sunday.\n\nThe No 1 seed prevailed over the No 2 seed in an epic of intensity and tactical fortitude, ultimately decided by Djokovic's adaptability behind serve, and two completely flawless tiebreaks, which have become a calling card of his game through 24 Grand Slam singles titles and now, finally, one Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe Athletic's Matt Futterman and James Hansen, analyze the final and what it means for tennis.\n\nIt happens so rarely, especially on the biggest stages when tension and nerves are running so high. Two all-time great players matching each other's level for a long stretch, and arguably nearly an entire match.\n\nFrom the first balls Sunday afternoon, it was clear that Djokovic and Alcaraz had come to play -- and nothing less than their highest intensity would do. This wasn't always a contest of the best technical level, with a few flubs and lazily errant returns on important points. But it was a contest: bruising, captivating, and at times, reaching the peaks that only these two can hope to ascend, pretty much when playing each other.\n\nIt was far removed from the Wimbledon final last month, when Djokovic, 39 days removed from knee surgery, came out flat and Alcaraz blew him off the court.\n\nIt was far removed from the last time these two played on Court Philippe-Chatrier at Roland Garros, in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open. That time, Alcaraz came out filled with nerves, played a tough but shaky second set, then succumbed to nerves and cramps. Djokovic won in four.\n\nOn Sunday, the Alcaraz who blasts nearly every backhand and forehand he can and mixes in the world's softest and most deceptive drop shot came out. The Djokovic who chases down more balls than anyone, and gets them back with the quality that switches him from defense to offense in a blink, came out too. This was a case of shared intensity raising things up, less so than shared stakes. Alcaraz has many more Olympic Games in him; this is likely Djokovic's last.\n\nThey matched pressure serves. They traded drop-shot returns that traveled nearly parallel to the net. Djokovic moaned with effort when a chance arose. The only way Alcaraz could survive was with one of high-decibel grunting forehands that lashed into the deepest corner of the court.\n\nThe first set lasted 93 minutes. What did it take for Djokovic to prevail? Nothing less than one of his signature, mistake-free tiebreakers and a lunging forehand drop volley that not even perhaps the fastest player in the game bothered to chase. He repeated the trick in the second set, with two screaming forehands into the corners.\n\nThe Wimbledon 2023 final was a five-set thriller that had them taking turns of being at their best, rather than matching each other's heights, even if not their highest. This was more reminiscent of their Cincinnati final last August, a three-set, four-hour sweatfest that Djokovic won in championship-deciding tiebreak.\n\nMatt Futterman\n\nAfter the Wimbledon final, Djokovic was largely sanguine about how soundly he had been beaten, saying that Alcaraz was simply better in every department. He did have one point of surprise: just how well Alcaraz had served.\n\nThat same quality -- and more visibly, speed -- wasn't quite there at Roland Garros, but Alcaraz compensated by using body serves to reliable effect, especially in pressure moments, saving three break points in a game in the first set. He then used his kick serve to the ad-side to draw short balls out of Djokovic, crunching forehands into the open court.\n\nDjokovic, by contrast, was relying on the precision of his placement, particularly swinging serves down the T when serving to the advantage court, which Alcaraz struggled to return. But the real battle was on the deuce side, between Djokovic's wide serve and Alcaraz's deep return position. Djokovic could reliably extract a playable ball out of the Alcaraz forehand, striking it on the rise into the open court.\n\nUntil, he couldn't. In the dramatic 4-4 game that would eventually propel him to the first set, Djokovic came in off that tactic at 30-30, and flubbed an overhead back to Alcaraz. He lost the point.\n\nAt 40-40, he went to the well again, but hesitated in coming in behind the forehand, allowing Alcaraz to laser a ball back deep and draw an error. And then at deuce again, he hit the forehand with little conviction, the ball rearing up off the tape for Alcaraz to dispatch. Slightly chastened, Djokovic kept playing the pattern, but was less vociferous in moving in behind the ball.\n\nDjokovic brought in something different as a result. Able to use Alcaraz's scarcely believable foot speed against him, he peppered the Spaniard with balls back behind his backhand, feeding off Alcaraz's ability to anticipate and retrieve a ball into the open court.\n\nJames Hansen\n\nIt's incredible to think that a player with 24 Grand Slam titles could ever suffer from doubts about his abilities, but few great players have ever been as honest about confidence demons as Djokovic.\n\nIt doesn't take much, in a sport with so much mental strife: Djokovic came by his doubts honestly heading into Sunday's final. He hadn't won a tournament all year and had never won a gold medal. Alcaraz had won the last two Grand Slam titles and Djokovic knew he hadn't played at his level or even at Jannik Sinner's since last fall, a lifetime ago in tennis. They have been setting the standard in the sport. Not him.\n\nBut late Friday night, after winning his semifinal against Lorenzo Musetti, Djokovic, known for having the strongest brain in the game, delivered a masterclass on talking himself into contention and shifting the pressure to Alcaraz.\n\nAlcaraz was clearly the favorite, he said, just as he had ahead of their semifinal at Roland Garros last year, when Alcaraz was the world No. 1 and top seed.\n\n\"He has proven himself to be the best player in the world at the moment,\" Djokovic said of Alcaraz. \"He won Roland Garros, he won Wimbledon, beat me in the finals quite comfortably there, reached the finals without dropping a set.\"\n\nBut then came the pivot and the window into his mind. He was a different player now, he said, three more weeks removed from knee surgery. He was moving and striking the ball better.\n\n\"Not to take anything, of course away from his win in Wimbledon finals,\" he said. \"He was dominating and deservedly a winner. But I feel more confident about myself and my chances in the finals.\"\n\nIn other words, the world had completely changed in less than a month, even if it really hadn't.\n\nPlus, it was the Olympics, he said. \"Anybody's game.\"\n\nAnd then it was his, as it hadn't been before. The ball rocketed off his racket throughout, the noise crisp and clean and loud. It was a confidence and a quality not seen since that French Open final in 2023, perhaps the US Open final in the same year.\n\nMatt Futterman\n\nWe'll bring your their on-court quotes and press conference reflections as they come in.\n\n\"It was three hours of great fight, incredible tennis.\n\n\"They were very difficult moments for me... I just couldn't raise my level in the tiebreaks.\"", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "matthew_futterman@nytimes.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-08-443380330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "07:33:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T07:33:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T07:23:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/djokovic-alcaraz-meet-in-the-mens-final/article_94caa977-5e8a-5884-8816-9f3a9b069c87.html", "title": "Djokovic, Alcaraz meet in the men's final", "body": "HOWARD FENDRICH\n\nAssociated Press\n\nPARIS -- Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz will meet for the men's tennis singles gold medal at the Paris Olympics on Sunday in the latest installment of a fascinating old-vs.-young rivalry that included a matchup in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\nAlcaraz won that one -- \"Quite comfortably,\" Djokovic acknowledged -- just like he did when they played each other for last year's trophy at the All England Club.\n\nWhen Alcaraz's semifinal in Paris ended Friday afternoon -- before Djokovic played in his later semifinal that night -- the 21-year-old Spaniard was asked what it might be like to possibly take on the 37-year-old Serbian again.\n\n\"Hopefully,\" Alcaraz said with a chuckle, \"the same as Wimbledon.\"\n\nHere is what else to know about the men's tennis singles final:\n\nWhy does it matter?\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nValparaiso University to eliminate 30 academic programs Mind on Money: For the economy, time will tell UPDATE: Valpo woman identified as deceased in fatal U.S. 20 crash Portillo's set to open Orland Park drive-thru by 2025 Man identified in fatal motorcycle crash, Lake County coroner says Region native captures Olympic medal in Paris Pierogi Fest grew from one vendor who sold out in an hour to a wall-to-wall crush of starch-seeking revelers, expects record attendance Police release photos of woman sought in check scam Davich: Behold, the finest lakefront beach and park in Northwest Indiana 5-year-old dies after being found in pool, Griffith police say Pastor seeks to dump video of him allegedly battering child Michigan City gearing up for lakefront power boat race Man found in Region basement beaten with ax handle, cops say State police arrest 19 during blitzes on I-94, I-65, department says McDonald's same-store sales fall for 1st time since 2020 as tapped-out customers hold on to cash\n\nDjokovic is the oldest man in an Olympic tennis singles final; Alcaraz is the youngest.\n\nDjokovic is considered by many to be the greatest men's tennis player in history, a stance bolstered by statistics such as his 24 Grand Slam titles (more than any other man) and his 400-plus weeks spent at No. 1 in the rankings (more than any man or woman).\n\nThere is basically just one thing missing from his resume: an Olympic gold. Before beating Lorenzo Musetti in Paris on Friday, Djokovic had been 0-3 in Summer Games semifinals, losing to the eventual champion each time -- Rafael Nadal in Beijing, Andy Murray in London, Alexander Zverev in Tokyo.\n\nDjokovic left the 2008 Olympics with a bronze, but he really wanted to improve on that now.\n\n\"I know,\" Musetti said, \"how much it means for (him) to win a gold.\"\n\nAlcaraz is the best thing going right now in the sport, having added his recent Wimbledon triumph to the one that came in June at the French Open, which is contested annually at Roland Garros, the clay-court facility being used for the Paris Games' tennis competition.\n\nIn 2022, he became the first teenager to reach No. 1 in the ATP rankings and now has four Grand Slam titles -- the first man to win at least one on clay, grass and hard courts before age 22.\n\n\"Alcaraz has proven the best player in the world at the moment,\" said Djokovic, who was seeded No. 1 at the Olympics after top-ranked Jannik Sinner withdrew because of tonsillitis.\n\nAlcaraz was seeded No. 2, but other players tend to agree with Djokovic's assessment.\n\n\"It's not a secret that, right now,\" said American Tommy Paul, who lost to the Spanish star in the quarterfinals at Wimbledon and the Olympics, \"Alcaraz is kind of like the golden standard.\"\n\nWhy the gray sleeve? Djokovic tore the meniscus in his right knee during a fourth round victory at the French Open on June 3, then had surgery in Paris two days later. Most people figured he would need to skip Wimbledon, which started on July 1, and the Olympics.\n\nNope. He showed up at the All England Club, wearing a gray sleeve on his right knee, and while it took him a few matches to get going, eventually Djokovic looked very much like himself. Until, that is, he took on Alcaraz for the title.\n\nAt the Summer Games, there was only one match where the knee was an issue -- when he felt pain in the second set of a victory over Stefanos Tsitsipas in the quarterfinals Thursday night. But he put in plenty of work with his physiotherapist between then and his match against Musetti, when all was OK.\n\n\"I feel like I'm a different player than I was in Wimbledon. The way I move. The way I'm striking the ball,\" said Djokovic, who eliminated Nadal in the second round in Paris.\n\n\"I feel more confident about myself and chances in the final\" on Sunday, he said.\n\nWho is the favorite?\n\nAlcaraz is favored to win the men's singles final, according to BetMGM Sportsbook, which lists him with a -250 money line. Djokovic is at +195. If Djokovic manages to win in straight sets, that would pay off at +360.\n\n\"The way he's playing,\" Djokovic said, \"he's definitely a favorite.\"\n\nHow to watch\n\nThe men's final is scheduled to be the second match at Court Philippe Chatrier on Sunday and won't start before 2 p.m. local time (8 a.m. EDT). To find the right channel, check NBC's online schedule.\n\nHead-to-head record\n\nThey have met a total of six times previously and each man has won three of those matches.\n\nThe only time they played at Court Philippe Chatrier was in the 2023 French Open semifinals. Djokovic won that one 6-3, 5-7, 6-1, 6-1 when Alcaraz succumbed to full-body cramps during the last two sets.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to {"uri": "8258783558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:05:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:05:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:04:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.newsbytesapp.com/news/sports/djokovic-vs-alcaraz-men-s-singles-tennis-final-paris-olympics-stats/story", "title": "Paris Olympics: Novak Djokovic wins gold in men's singles tennis", "body": "Serbia's Novak Djokovic has won the men's singles tennis gold medal at the 2024 Paris Olympics on Sunday. Djokovic took down his Wimbledon nemesis Carlos Alcaraz on Court Phillipe-Chatrier at Roland Garros. The veteran has won his maiden gold at the Olympics and second medal (bronze in 2008 Beijing). He also became the oldest gold medal winner in tennis singles at the Olympics.\n\nAlcaraz has raced to a 38-7 win-loss record on the ATP Tour this season. He had won three titles before the Olympics. The young Spaniard, who is 18-3 at Roland Garros (French Open), owns a 59-10 win-loss record overall at Grand Slams, including 18-1 this season. Alcaraz was on a 12-match unbeaten run at Roland Garros (French Open and Olympic silver).\n\nDjokovic owns a 96-16 win-loss record at Roland Garros (French Open). He has already bagged three French Open honors. He holds the record for the most Grand Slams won in men's singles (24). By winning his quarter-final clash in 2024 Paris, he completed 100 wins at Roland Garros (now 102). Djokovic owns a 29-7 win-loss record this season on the ATP Tour.\n\nAlcaraz took down Hady Habib of Lebanon in the first round, winning 6-3, 6-1. Netherlands' Tallon Griekspoor was Alcaraz next scalp (6-1, 7-6). Roman Safiullin, who was under the Individual Neutral Athletes category, was beaten 6-4, 6-2. Alcaraz beat USA's Tommy Paul 6-4, 7-6 in the quarters. Alcaraz dispatched Felix Auger-Aliassime 6-1, 6-1 next. And now, Djokovic took down Alcaraz 7-6, 7-6.\n\nDjokovic took down Matthew Ebden in the first round, winning 6-0, 6-1. In the second round, the Serb beat arch-rival Rafael Nadal 6-1, 6-4. In the 3rd round, Djokovic beat Germany's Dominic Koepfer 7-5, 6-3. Djokovic won his quarter-final clash against Stefanos Tsitsipas (6-3, 7-6). Djokovic beat eventual bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti in the semis (6-4, 6-2). He beat Alcaraz in the final.\n\nDjokovic has completed a Career Golden Slam by winning the 2024 Paris Olympics gold. The Golden Slam is someone who wins all four career Grand Slams and the Olympic gold. Among singles in tennis, Djokovic joins the likes of Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Stefi Graff and Serena Williams.\n\nThe two players came into this match with a 3-3 win-loss record each in their head-to-head meetings. Alcaraz took down Djokovic twice at the Wimbledon finals. He also beat him at ATP Masters 1000 Madrid in 2022. Djokovic beat Alacaraz in the semis at Roland Garros in 2023. He also beat Alcaraz in the final of ATP Masters 1000 Cincinnati and ATP Finals semis.\n\nAs per Opta, Alcaraz became the second-youngest men's singles finalist at the Olympic Games in tennis history, older only than Robert LeRoy in St. Louis 1904. Later on, Djokovic became the 3rd player to reach the Olympic final in singles after having turned 30 since tennis returned to the Summer Olympic program in 1988. {"uri": "8258938403", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:46:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:46:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:45:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-novak-djokovic-wins-first-olympic-gold-medal-becomes-most-dominant-big-two-star-6163683.html", "title": "Sports News | Novak Djokovic Wins First Olympic Gold Medal, Becomes Most Dominant 'Big Two' Star | LatestLY", "body": "Paris [France], August 4 (ANI): Following his Paris Olympics gold medal win in the men's singles competition, Serbian legend Novak Djokovic joined the big two: Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.\n\nDjokovic turned his ultimate dream into reality by winning his first Olympic gold by overcoming Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in the men's singles final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nAlso Read | Mohammed Shami Meets Daughter Aaira in Kolkata, Star Indian Cricketer Gets to Fulfill Rare Opportunity of Father's Role Following Separation With Estranged Wife Hasin Jahan.\n\nIn a clash between the experienced tennis icon and the young Alcaraz, who brims with talent, Djokovic realised his ultimate dream by getting his hands on the first Olympic gold medal of his illustrious career.\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam Champion was down on his knees and tears of joy fell from his eyes after taking the game point. With the name Djokovic echoing around the stadium, the Serbian climbed the stairs and went into the stands to celebrate with his family. After Djokovic's 7-6, 7-6 win in the gold medal match, the emotions got the better of Alcaraz as he settled for the silver medal.\n\nAlso Read | Hockey India Highlights 'Umpiring' and 'Decision-Making' Concerns at Paris Olympics 2024, Points Out Amit Rohidas' Red Card Among Others in Indian Men's Hockey Team's Quarterfinal Win Over Great Britain.\n\nNow after this win, he has won 24 Grand Slam titles, the most by anyone across both men's and women's tennis. Djokovic has won 10 Australian Open titles, three French Open titles, seven Wimbledon titles and four US Open titles.\n\nBesides all this, he now finally has an Olympic gold medal, which is required for a player to complete a career golden slam.\n\nAside from his dominance at Grand Slam level, Djokovic has a total of 72 big titles in tennis. After spending years trying to catch up with stars like Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, he has outshined them to become the leader of the modern-day 'Big Two' in tennis. This includes 40 ATP Masters titles as well and seven ATP Finals championship titles.\n\nNadal is second among the 'Big Three', with a total of 59 big titles, including 22 Grand Slams, which also includes a record 14 French Open titles, 36 ATP Masters titles and one Olympic gold medal in singles competition.\n\nFederer is at number three, with 20 Grand Slam titles, including a record eight Wimbledon titles, 28 ATP Masters titles and six ATP Finals titles. This all combines and makes 54 big titles. He has no Olympic singles gold medal though, having one silver medal in the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nBesides Djokovic, no other player has won an Olympic singles gold, Grand Slams and all nine ATP Masters 1000 titles.\n\nNotably, Djokovic won all four grand slams in 2021 but failed to touch the rare feat of winning all four grand slams as well as the Olympic gold. Fast forward three years later, the Serbian legend finally has his hands on the elusive gold.\n\nThe blockbuster gold medal clash had its fair share of highlights, with Alcaraz flaunting his ace and Djokovic shinning with his precision.\n\nIn a neck-to-neck battle, Djokovic sealed the first game and stood inches away from breaking Alcaraz's serve.\n\nThroughout the first set, fierce rallies unfolded with Alcaraz, quick as lightning, pulling off slapshots backhand and forehand shots from his arsenal. Djokovic relied on using the court to his advantage and negating the threat that Alacaraz carried.\n\nAlcaraz and Djokovic stood steps away from breaking each other's serve numerous times. Eventually, Djokovic managed to take away Alcaraz's advantage during the breakpoint and smiled. Each time Alcaraz denied the Serbian to go ahead in the game, the Spaniard was more aggressive and animated in his reaction.\n\nWith the first set level at 6-6, the game went into a tiebreak. Djokovic took the first point after Alcaraz's attempt to slice a forehand shot went wide.\n\nThe Spaniard fought back to take the next point. The duo seemed inseparable until Djokovic upped the ante to take four consecutive points to seal the first set in his favour.\n\nIn the second set, the uncanny resemblance to the opening set continued to keep the packed audience in a state of trance.\n\nDjokovic ensured that Alcaraz had no room to get close to the net and take control of their intense rallies. The second set featured some delightful rallies, forcing the fans to stand on their feet and appreciate the spectacle that the two produced. Drop shot was a common theme throughout those rallies, which was used by both tennis stars to overcome each other.\n\nWith the second set, going right down the wire at 6-6, Alcaraz needed to take the second set home to keep his hopes of standing at the top of the podium alive.Djokovic raced to a 2-0 lead but Alcaraz fought back to level the scoreline. Djokovic relied on his strong forehand play to turn his dream into reality and win his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe heartbreak that Djokovic suffered in the Wimbledon final last month at the hands of Alcaraz became a distant memory. {"uri": "8259385101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:57:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:57:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:56:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://businessday.ng/sports/article/djokovic-completes-golden-slam-with-olympic-gold/", "title": "Djokovic completes golden slam with Olympic gold - Businessday NG", "body": "Novak Djokovic etched his name into tennis history by capturing the Olympic gold medal, defeating Carlos Alcaraz in a thrilling final at the Paris Olympic Games. The Serbian superstar's 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (7-2) victory completed the coveted Golden Slam, adding the Olympic title to his collection of Grand Slam trophies.\n\nDjokovic had previously fallen short in three Olympic singles finals. This triumph marks a significant milestone in his already illustrious career, solidifying his status as one of the greatest tennis players of all time.\n\nThe match was a showcase of exceptional talent, with both Djokovic and Alcaraz displaying extraordinary skill and athleticism. The two-hour, 50-minute encounter was a fitting climax to an unforgettable Olympic tournament.\n\nDjokovic's impressive career already featured a record 24 Grand Slam titles and the most weeks spent at No. 1 in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he has made clear that simply was not sufficient.\n\nCompeting in his fifth Olympic Games, Djokovic overcame Alcaraz in an enthralling final at Roland Garros to add Olympic gold to his 24 Grand Slam triumphs.\n\n\"This is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had and the most special feeling,\" said the 37-year-old said.\n\n\"I thought carrying the flag at the opening ceremony for my country at the 2012 Olympics was the best feeling an athlete could have until today. Now, at the age of 37 and facing a 21-year-old who is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back, I can say that this is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had.\"\n\nVictory on Sunday allowed Djokovic to join Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf, and the watching Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold, completing the career Golden Slam.\n\nBefore defeating Alcaraz on Sunday, his best performance at the Olympics had been in 2008 in Beijing when he won bronze. He had also lost three semi-finals.\n\nDjokovic is the oldest singles champion since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, and he shattered Alcaraz's bid to add gold to the French Open and {"uri": "8258792064", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:13:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:13:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:12:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/novak-djokovic-carlos-alcaraz-olympics-gold-medal-b2590972.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic's epic last stand ends long quest for Olympic gold medal", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nIn the aftermath of his Wimbledon final defeat to Carlos Alcaraz, Novak Djokovic found it remarkably easy to come to terms with the battering he had just taken on Centre Court.\n\nAs a chance to make further history slipped away and Alcaraz demonstrated his supremacy over a one-sided final, Djokovic reached peace by reminding himself that a bigger goal and more important opportunity would quickly arrive. After all, if there was one tennis match Djokovic could have picked to win at the start of the year, it wouldn't have been the Wimbledon final.\n\nJust 21 days later, an inspired Djokovic earned revenge and ended his long quest for a first Olympic gold medal, defeating Alcaraz 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2) in an all-time final at Roland Garros.\n\nAt 37 and at his fifth Olympics, Djokovic captured the one title that had far so long evaded him to complete the career golden slam. Two months after tearing his meniscus in his right knee and appearing to be a doubt for the Olympics when he underwent surgery, Djokovic returned to the same court on Philippe-Chatier to record one of the greatest victories of his career against his young rival, delivering a gold medal for Serbia that will rank highly among his record 24 grand slam titles.\n\nIn doing so, he managed to suppress Alcaraz just as the Spaniard was appearing to be a level above what Djokovic was able to produce at this stage of his career. Djokovic dug deep into his reserves, first denying and then outlasting Alcaraz in an titanic 93-minute opening set. Djokovic withstood Alcaraz's powers of athleticism and shot-making in an epic last stand that displayed a vintage look at his greatest qualities as a tennis player. Djokovic endured, remaining solid in all aspects of his game, and delivered when the biggest moments arrived to claim a historic victory in one of the most memorable Olympics finals ever staged.\n\nAnd with 10 Australian Opens, three French Opens, seven Wimbledon, four US Opens, seven ATP Finals, 40 ATP 1000 titles, Djokovic now has the Olympic gold to tick the final box that was missing in his career. By becoming just the fifth player to complete the career grand slam in singles, he joins Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi, Serena Williams and Steffi Graf to claim another major milestone. Djokovic needed to be at his very best to beat Alcaraz and with history on the line, but found a level that had looked beyond him for much of the season. Alcaraz, 21, is the youngest player in history to reach the Olympics final and is attempting to add the gold medal to French Open and Wimbledon titles this season.\n\nThe final at Roland Garros is an immediate rematch of last month's Wimbledon final, where Alcaraz denied Djokovic a record-equalling eighth title in SW19 and record 25th grand slam. The Spaniard won in straight-sets in one of the heaviest defeats of Djokovic's career, and was the second year in a row in which he had beaten the Serbian in the Wimbledon final.\n\nAlcaraz is competing at his first Olympics while Djokovic is at his fifth. The gold medal is the only honour that is missing from his record-breaking career and this could be Djokovic's last chance to do so. He will be 41 by the time of the next Olympics in Los Angeles in 2028.\n\nFollow live score updates from the Olmypic final at Roland Garros, below\n\nThe gold medal match in the men's singles at the Olympics will be played on Sunday 4 August.\n\nDjokovic and Alcaraz will be the second match of the day on Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nIt will follow the women's doubles bronze medal match and could start at around 1pm BST (UK time), although it could be slightly earlier depending on the previous match.\n\n08:58 , Jamie Braidwood\n\nCarlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic do battle again in the Olympics final at Roland Garros with history on the line. {"uri": "8259095749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:05:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:05:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:04:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.newsx.com/olympics-2024/tennis-legend-olympic-gold-medalist-novak-djokovic-says-god-is-great/", "title": "Tennis Legend, Olympic Gold Medalist Novak Djokovic Says, 'God Is Great..'", "body": "Paris Olympics 2024: Parul Chaudhary Fails To Qualify For Women's 3000m Steeplechase Medal Race\n\nFollowing his Olympic gold medal win, Serbian tennis legend Novak Djokovic expressed his happiness by thanking God for helping him achieving this big landmark in his illustrious career.\n\nDjokovic turned his ultimate dream into reality by winning his first Olympic gold by overcoming Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in the men's singles final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nSpeaking to ANI, Djokovic said, \"God is great. Thank God. I am super proud, super happy.\"\n\nHe also celebrated his moment by holding the Serbian flag in his hand with pride.\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam Champion was down on his knees and tears of joy fell from his eyes after taking the game point. With the name Djokovic echoing around the stadium, the Serbian climbed the stairs and went into the stands to celebrate with his family. After Djokovic's 7-6, 7-6 win in the gold medal match, the emotions got the better of Alcaraz as he settled for the silver medal.\n\nNow after this win, he has won 24 Grand Slam titles, the most by anyone across both men's and women's tennis. Djokovic has won 10 Australian Open titles, three French Open titles, seven Wimbledon titles and four US Open titles.\n\nBesides all this, he now finally has an Olympic gold medal, which is required for a player to complete a career golden slam.\n\nAside from his dominance at Grand Slam level, Djokovic has a total of 72 big titles in tennis. After spending years trying to catch up with stars like Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, he has outshined them to become the leader of the modern-day 'Big Three' in tennis. This includes 40 ATP Masters titles as well and seven ATP Finals championship titles.\n\nNadal is second among the 'Big Three', with a total of 59 big titles, including 22 Grand Slams, which also includes a record 14 French Open titles, 36 ATP Masters titles and one Olympic gold medal in singles competition.\n\nFederer is at number three, with 20 Grand Slam titles, including a record eight Wimbledon titles, 28 ATP Masters titles and six ATP Finals titles. This all combines and make 54 big titles. He has no Olympic singles gold medal though, having one silver medal in the 2012 London Olympics.\n\nThe blockbuster gold medal clash had its fair share of highlights, with Alcaraz flaunting his ace and Djokovic shinning with his precision.\n\nIn a neck-to-neck battle, Djokovic sealed the first game and stood inches away from breaking Alcaraz's serve.\n\nThroughout the first set, fierce rallies unfolded with Alcaraz, quick as lightning, pulling off slapshots backhand and forehand shots from his arsenal. Djokovic relied on using the court to his advantage and negating the threat that Alacaraz carried.\n\nAlcaraz and Djokovic stood steps away from breaking each other's serve numerous times. Eventually, Djokovic managed to take away Alcaraz's advantage during the breakpoint and smiled. Each time Alcaraz denied the Serbian to go ahead in the game, the Spaniard was more aggressive and animated in his reaction.\n\nWith the first set level at 6-6, the game went into a tiebreak. Djokovic took the first point after Alcaraz's attempt to slice a forehand shot went wide.\n\nThe Spaniard fought back to take the next point. The duo seemed inseparable until Djokovic upped the ante to take four consecutive points to seal the first set in his favour.\n\nIn the second set, the uncanny resemblance to the opening set continued to keep the packed audience in a state of trance.\n\nDjokovic ensured that Alcaraz had no room to get close to the net and take control of their intense rallies. The second set featured some delightful rallies, forcing the fans to stand on their feet and appreciate the spectacle that the two produced. Drop shot was a common theme throughout those rallies, which was used by both tennis stars to overcome each other.\n\nWith the second set going right down the wire at 6-6, Alcaraz needed to take the second set home to keep his hopes of standing at the top of the podium alive.\n\nDjokovic raced to a 2-0 lead but Alcaraz fought back to level the scoreline. Djokovic relied on his strong forehand play to turn his dream into reality and win his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe heartbreak that Djokovic suffered in the Wimbledon final last month at the hands of Alcaraz became a distant memory.\n\nAlso Read: Will Perform Better Next Time: Indian Archer Ankita Bhakat On Missing Medal At Paris Olympics 2024\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not
