{"uri": "8258822207", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:44:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:44:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:42:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/sports/olympics-and-paralympics/novak-djokovic-wins-his-first-olympic-gold-medal-by-beating-carlos-alcaraz-in-the-mens/article_51695371-38ed-5ba2-9298-0d05784f4b1e.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic wins his first Olympic gold medal by beating Carlos Alcaraz in the men's tennis final", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Novak Djokovic won his first Olympic gold medal by beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling men's tennis singles final Sunday, giving the 37-year-old from Serbia the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nDjokovic's impressive career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam titles and the most weeks spent at No. 1 in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he has made clear that simply was not sufficient.\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 -- and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\nWhen the victory was his, when the gold was his, thanks to one last forehand winner, Djokovic turned toward his team in the stands -- sitting in front of his wife and their two children -- and dropped his racket as he knelt on the clay. As emotional as ever, he cried and covered his face, then rose and grabbed a red-white-and-blue Serbian flag. After hugs in the stands, Djokovic waved that flag. Alcaraz wept afterward, too.\n\nThe final, which lasted 2 hours, 50 minutes despite being decided in only two sets, was a rematch of the Wimbledon title match three weeks ago that Alcaraz won to follow up his French Open title in June.\n\nAlcaraz also defeated Djokovic in last year's final at the All England Club, but Djokovic won when they met in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open, the annual clay-court tournament held at Roland Garros, the site used for tennis during these Olympics.\n\nSunday's contest was an enthralling matchup, featuring one of the best to ever do it in Djokovic, and the best at the moment in Alcaraz. Indeed, could have been frustrating for Djokovic to find himself once again across the net from a younger, speedier version of himself. Maybe that's why Djokovic frequently looked up and gesticulated and muttered toward his guest box.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nStill, he came out on top.\n\nIt required long exchanges filled with superb ball-striking at the baseline, deft drop shots -- Alcaraz's tended to be more successful, sometimes so good Djokovic declined to even give chase -- and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense at both ends. They served so well that neither got broken even once: Djokovic saved eight break points, Alcaraz six.\n\nMost remarkable, perhaps, was how cleanly both men played, despite the talent of the opposition and pressure of the occasion. Unforced errors were rare.\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, the loser -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Make no mistake, this encounter between the No. 1-seeded Djokovic and No. 2-seeded Alcaraz was worthy of a major final, and no one fortunate enough to hold a ticket could complain about not getting their money's worth.\n\nThose in the stands became part of the show, repeatedly breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. In the second set, as Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters began chanting, \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\") while shaking their red-and-yellow flags. Chair umpire Damien Dumusois occasionally reminded folks to remain silent during the action.\n\nYet it also became as quiet as a theater between points, enough so that play was delayed briefly in the first set when the air thick with anticipation was pierced by a young child's crying.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBoth men played to the crowd. When Alcaraz raced to reach one drop shot and deposit it over the net for a winner, he basked in the raucous reaction by pointing his right index finger to his ear. When Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point to lead 3-2 in the second tiebreaker, he waved both arms overhead to encourage folks who already were on their feet, screaming.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, chock full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes, including five break chances for Alcaraz, before Djokovic managed to hold for a 5-4 lead. In the tiebreaker, Djokovic was superior in crunch time, as he so often is, taking the last four points.\n\nAt 3-all, Alcaraz delivered a body serve, but Djokovic slid just enough to his left to smack a cross-court forehand return winner. After two mistakes by Alcaraz, Djokovic produced a volley winner and turned to face his family with a fist held high.\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "8258849768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:13:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:13:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:10:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.si.com/olympics/novak-djokovic-overcome-by-emotion-after-defeating-carlos-alcaraz-to-win-gold-medal", "title": "Novak Djokovic Overcome by Emotion After Defeating Carlos Alcaraz to Win Gold Medal", "body": "Serbia's Novak Djokovic was overcome with emotion after defeating Spain's Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (7-2) to win the gold medal in men's tennis singles at the 2024 Paris Olympics on Sunday.\n\nIt's not hard to see why.\n\nDjokovic, at 37 years old, became the oldest player in tennis history to win an Olympic gold medal in singles. Not only that, but the Serbian tennis star also became just the fifth player in tennis history to complete the Golden Slam (Winning all four major championships and a gold medal), a career achievement that had previously eluded Djokovic.\n\nAnd it was instantly apparent just how much the win meant to Djokovic, who with tears flying, put his head in his hands in disbelief before shaking hands with Alcaraz, then collapsed onto Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nSo emotional was Djokovic that his hands were shaking as he knelt on the court at Roland Garros.\n\nThen, in a truly special moment, Djokovic celebrated the gold medal victory with his family.\n\nIt's rare to see Djokovic this emotional, but it's rare to see a victory mean so much to a player with seemingly little else to conquer in the sport.\n\nDjokovic, with 24 major championship wins, is the most decorated men's tennis player of all-time. But after 16 years of waiting, including a bronze medal win at Beijing in 2008 and three straight Olympics of falling shy of the medal stand, Djokovic finally got his gold.\n\nWhen asked if it was the missing piece to the puzzle in his career, Djokovic had this to say.\n\n\"Yes it is,\" Djokovic said. \"It is. I'm telling myself always that I am enough. Because I can be very self-critical. I don't know. That's one of the biggest internal battles I keep on fighting with myself.\"\n\n\"That I feel like I haven't done enough or been enough in my life on and off the court. So it's a big lesson for me. I'm super grateful for the blessing to win a historic gold medal for my country. To complete the golden slam. To complete all the records.\"\n\nWhen asked if it was all enough, the slams, the medals, the countless iconic moments he produced, Djokovic simply said, \"I think so.\"", "source": {"uri": "si.com", {"uri": "2024-08-443695825", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:28:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:28:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:06:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240804-%F0%9F%94%B4-djokovic-wins-his-first-olympic-gold-after-beating-alcaraz-in-men-s-singles-final", "title": "Djokovic wins his first Olympic gold after beating Alcaraz in men's singles final", "body": "Djokovic's impressive career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam titles and the most weeks spent at No. 1 in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he has made clear that simply was not sufficient.\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 -- and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\nWhen the victory was his, when the gold was his, thanks to one last forehand winner, Djokovic turned toward his team in the stands -- sitting in front of his wife and their two children -- and dropped his racket as he knelt on the clay. As emotional as ever, he cried and covered his face, then rose and grabbed a red-white-and-blue Serbian flag. After hugs in the stands, Djokovic waved that flag. Alcaraz wept afterward, too.\n\nThe final, which lasted 2 hours, 50 minutes despite being decided in only two sets, was a rematch of the Wimbledon title match three weeks ago that Alcaraz won to follow up his French Open title in June.\n\nAlcaraz also defeated Djokovic in last year's final at the All England Club, but Djokovic won when they met in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open, the annual clay-court tournament held at Roland Garros, the site used for tennis during these Olympics.\n\nSunday's contest was an enthralling matchup, featuring one of the best to ever do it in Djokovic, and the best at the moment in Alcaraz. Indeed, could have been frustrating for Djokovic to find himself once again across the net from a younger, speedier version of himself. Maybe that's why Djokovic frequently looked up and gesticulated and muttered toward his guest box.\n\nStill, he came out on top.\n\nIt required long exchanges filled with superb ball-striking at the baseline, deft drop shots -- Alcaraz's tended to be more successful, sometimes so good Djokovic declined to even give chase -- and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense at both ends. They served so well that neither got broken even once: Djokovic saved eight break points, Alcaraz six.\n\nMost remarkable, perhaps, was how cleanly both men played, despite the talent of the opposition and pressure of the occasion. Unforced errors were rare.\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, the loser -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Make no mistake, this encounter between the No. 1-seeded Djokovic and No. 2-seeded Alcaraz was worthy of a major final, and no one fortunate enough to hold a ticket could complain about not getting their money's worth.\n\nThose in the stands became part of the show, repeatedly breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. In the second set, as Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters began chanting, \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\") while shaking their red-and-yellow flags. Chair umpire Damien Dumusois occasionally reminded folks to remain silent during the action.\n\nYet it also became as quiet as a theater between points, enough so that play was delayed briefly in the first set when the air thick with anticipation was pierced by a young child's crying.\n\nBoth men played to the crowd. When Alcaraz raced to reach one drop shot and deposit it over the net for a winner, he basked in the raucous reaction by pointing his right index finger to his ear. When Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point to lead 3-2 in the second tiebreaker, he waved both arms overhead to encourage folks who already were on their feet, screaming.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, chock full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes, including five break chances for Alcaraz, before Djokovic managed to hold for a 5-4 lead. In the tiebreaker, Djokovic was superior in crunch time, as he so often is, taking the last four points.\n\nAt 3-all, Alcaraz delivered a body serve, but Djokovic slid just enough to his left to smack a cross-court forehand return winner. After two mistakes by Alcaraz, Djokovic produced a volley winner and turned to face his family with a fist held high.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "France 24"}, Just weeks after losing to Carlos Alcaraz for the second consecutive year in the Wimbledon final, Djokovic completed a career golden slam at Roland Garros by defeating Alcaraz in the Olympics' gold medal match.\n\nIn his quest for his first Olympic gold medal, Djokovic bested Alcaraz in back-to-back tiebreakers to win in straight sets today at Roland-Garros. After winning the final point and shaking hands with Alcaraz, Djokovic got down on his hands and knees, visibly shaking.\n\nThe victory not only made Djokovic the oldest player to win an Olympic gold medal in tennis, but he also became the fifth player in history to win the career golden slam, which consists of an Olympic singles gold medal, the Australian Open, Wimbledon, French Open, and U.S. Open.\n\nDjokovic joins longtime rival Rafael Nadal, who completed his golden slam in 2010 when he won the U.S. Open, as well as Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, and Serena Williams as the only players to win all five competitions.\n\nReactions to Novak Djokovic's Olympic gold medal victory\n\nThere was no shortage of reactions to Novak Djokovic's golden slam victory, with many crowning Djokovic as the greatest of all time -- or GOAT -- after earning the one thing that had always eluded him.\n\nTennis TV listed the many, many accomplishments Djokovic has earned throughout his illustrious career:\n\nA Djokovic fan did something similar but expanded it to the many different events he has won:\n\n\"Novak Djokovic is the only player in tennis history to win every big event.\n\nThe same fan posted a video that shows Djokovic's thumb twitching after he won the Olympic gold medal:\n\n\"Novak Djokovic shaking as he wins the Olympic gold medal.\n\nHe gave everything he had. \u2764\ufe0f\"\n\nTennis great and broadcaster Chris Evert praised Djokovic after his historic victory:\n\n\"Novak..... His love for the game and his country is unprecedented. The strength of his mind is incomparable. His GOAT status is cemented. So happy for him...\"\n\nSportsCenter also showed moments from Djokovic's gold medal celebration at Roland-Garros:\n\n\"Gold. {"uri": "8259060486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:18:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:18:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:16:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/olympics-tennis-djokovic-fights-off-alcaraz-to-finally-strike-gold/2207807/", "title": "Olympics-Tennis-Djokovic fights off Alcaraz to finally strike gold", "body": "Top seed Djokovic had to deliver one of the finest performances of his career to deny a man 16 years his junior and become only the fifth player to win all four singles Grand Slams and the Olympic title during their careers.\n\n\"It was an incredible fight and I had to play my best tennis,\" an emotional Djokovic said on court as flag-waving Serbian fans sang his name. \"I put my heart, my soul, everything to win gold. I did it for my country first, for Serbia.\"\n\nIn a raucous atmosphere, with soccer-style chants shattering the calm of the adjacent Bois de Boulogne, neither player took a backward step in a ferocious contest.\n\nThe first set alone lasted one hour 33 minutes as the two wrestled for control in a series of spellbinding games, one at 4-4 in which Djokovic repelled five break points.\n\nAlcaraz blinked first in the tiebreak to allow Djokovic to move ahead and when another tiebreak was required to decide the second set, again Djokovic found inspiration, moving 6-2 in front and sealing victory with a stunning forehand winner.\n\nDjokovic roared to the sky and after consoling a crestfallen Alcaraz at the net, then fell to his knees and sobbed into the Parisian clay in the centre of the court before climbing into the crowd where he was swamped by his family, friends and team.\n\nWhile Djokovic became the oldest Olympic singles champion since tennis returned to the Games in 1988, the 21-year-old Alcaraz looked inconsolable after failing to add the gold medal to this year's French Open and Wimbledon crowns.\n\n\"I think I did a really great tournament, I think I did a really great match,\" the four-time Grand Slam champion said. \"Obviously in front of me, I had a really hungry Novak.\"\n\nDjokovic had lost three times in Olympic singles semi-finals with a solitary bronze medal to show from four previous Games.\n\nHe knew Paris was his last realistic chance to fill the remaining space in a bulging trophy cabinet containing 24 Grand Slam titles. And how he earned it -- overturning a crushing loss to Alcaraz three weeks ago in the Wimbledon final to become the first man to win the Olympic singles title without dropping a set.\n\nDjokovic joins an elite group of Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafa Nadal and Serena Williams, the latter watching from the front row, in the Golden Slam club, and many will say this settled the G.O.A.T argument once and for all.\n\nIt takes something pretty special to upstage the men's 100 metres final taking place later at the Stade de France, but this near three-hour red-dirt duel arguably came close.\n\nThe opening four games spanned 30 mesmerizing minutes, every rally a battle of skill and wills. Alcaraz saved three break points in the fourth game and looked menacing as he threw everything in his arsenal at Djokovic as the Serb served at 4-4.\n\nSeveral times Djokovic could only smile at the athleticism of his opponent who piled on the pressure to earn five break points, and somehow he survived.\n\nAlcaraz saved a set point at 5-6 but the Spaniard's level dipped in the tiebreak and Djokovic pounced to grab the lead. Sensing his moment, Djokovic's intensity went even higher deep in the second set but Alcaraz hung on.\n\nDjokovic was relentless though and an outrageous forehand winner at 2-2 in the breaker snapped Alcaraz's resistance and the end then came quickly as he claimed the 99th, and perhaps most valuable, title of his glittering career.\n\nA memorable week ended with Italy's Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini beating Russian neutral players Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider 2-6 6-1 (10-7) to win the women's gold, adding to compatriot Lorenzo Musetti's men's singles bronze.\n\n(Reporting by Martyn Herman; additional reporting by Sybille de la Hamaide; Editing by Alison Williams, Toby Davis and Hugh Lawson)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": {"uri": "8259016011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:17:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:17:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:17:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13707987/Alcaraz-says-pressure-playing-Spain-got-loss-Djokovic-Olympics-final.html", "title": "Alcaraz says pressure of playing for Spain got to him in loss to...", "body": "PARIS (AP) - Emotional and unable to hold back tears, Carlos Alcaraz needed a moment to compose himself after losing to Novak Djokovic in the men's tennis singles final at the Paris Olympics on Sunday.\n\nThere would be no youngest-ever champion and no repeating Rafael Nadal\u00b4s feat of winning a gold medal for Spain in his first attempt in singles.\n\nAlcaraz settled for silver after a 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) loss to Djokovic at Court Philippe Chatrier, saying the pressure of playing for his country got to him.\n\n\"I think I put more pressure on myself because I was playing for Spain, for the Spaniards,\" he said. \"I felt that I let the Spanish people down by not winning the gold.\"\n\nThe 21-year-old Alcaraz said he had not felt that type of pressure in the four Grand Slam finals that he played - and won - so far in his career.\n\n\"It was a different type of pressure,\" he said. \"Everyone in Spain wanted me to win the gold, and I wanted to win the gold as well.\"\n\nSpain's Carlos Alcaraz waves while wearing his silver medal after losing to Serbia's Novak Djokovic in the men's singles tennis final at the Roland Garros stadium during the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Paris, France. Djokovic has won his first Olympic gold medal by beating Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in the 2024 Games men's tennis singles final. (AP Photo/Louise Delmotte)\n\nAlcaraz said the extra pressure cost him especially in the decisive moments of the game.\n\n\"In those difficult moments I usually raise my level, but I wasn't able to do that today,\" he said. \"Probably I felt the pressure in those situations. You play four Grand Slams every year, the Olympics is only once every four years.\"\n\nAlcaraz said there was still reason for him to be proud after \"knowing that I gave everything.\"\n\n\"Obviously this week, this tournament has been really special for me,\" he said. \"I\u00b4m going to take it for the rest of my life, for the rest of my career, for sure. Playing with Rafa, getting my first Olympics medal - hopefully not the last one - it's been a special one.\"\n\nAlcaraz arrived in Paris amid the hype of playing the doubles tournament alongside his childhood idol Nadal, who won the singles gold in his Olympic debut in Beijing in 2008.\n\nAlcaraz and Nadal lost 6-2, 6-4 to the fourth-seeded American duo of Austin Krajicek and Rajeev Ram in last week\u00b4s quarterfinals.\n\nThe game against Djokovic was a rematch of the past two Wimbledon finals, both won by Alcaraz, including last month.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreakers, he played an impressive game,\" Alcaraz said of Djokovic. \"He was hungry for the gold medal. He was going to go for it.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nSpain's Carlos Alcaraz waves with his silver medal after losing to Serbia's Novak Djokovic in the men's singles tennis final at the Roland Garros stadium during the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Paris, France. I feel they were waiting for the gold medal,\" said Alcaraz after his 7-6 (7/3), 7-6 (7/2) defeat.\n\n\"I got emotional because I couldn't make the Spanish people proud. That's (why) I got emotional.\"\n\nVictory would have continued Alcaraz's golden summer in which he won a first French Open on the same Roland Garros courts which hosted the Olympics and then successfully defended his Wimbledon title by sweeping Djokovic off the court last month.\n\nREAD MORE: Novak Djokovic Becomes 5th to Complete Career Golden Slam After Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal & Serena Williams\n\nIn Sunday's final, which stretched to almost three hours, neither player dropped serve with a total of 14 break points carved out and successfully saved.\n\nAlcaraz saw eight break points come and go on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\n\"I'm a bit sad but I did a great tournament. It was a really great match and I'm really proud of myself,\" he added.\n\n\"I was facing a hungry Novak, he was very impressive today. He didn't let me have many chances so credit to him and he deserves victory.\"\n\nDespite his disappointment, Alcaraz said he will learn from Sunday's loss as he heads to North America and an assault on the US Open which he won in 2022.\n\nThe New York title is the only Grand Slam crown currently in the possession of Djokovic.\n\n\"I'll leave with my head held high,\" said the Spaniard.\n\n\"Last year, when I lost to Novak at the French Open, I said I'd learn from that. I will learn from this again, become a better player and not make the same mistakes. I will be more mature.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Novak Djokovic Says Paris 2024 Gold 'Probably Biggest Success', Eyes 2028 Olympics\n\nAlcaraz said the Paris Olympics will remain a special memory especially as it gave him the chance to play doubles with Rafael Nadal for the first time.\n\n\"The tournament has been really special for me and I will remember it for the rest of my life,\" he said.", "source": He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 -- and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\nSteffi Graf was the first player to win all four Grand Slam titles as well as an Olympic gold, when she managed the feat in 1988. Andre Agassi became the first man to complete a career Golden Slam, in 1999, when he won his first and last French Open title.\n\nRafael Nadal is the youngest to achieve a career Golden Slam, when he achieved the feat in 2010 at the age of 24. {"uri": "8259231984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "00:29:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T00:29:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:28:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.bbntimes.com/society/novak-djokovic-wins-historic-olympic-gold-medal-at-paris-2024", "title": "Novak Djokovic Wins Historic Olympic Gold Medal at Paris 2024", "body": "Serbian tennis legend Novak Djokovic clinched the gold medal in the men's singles tennis event at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nThis momentous victory marked the culmination of Djokovic's illustrious career, as he finally secured the one major accolade that had eluded him for years.\n\nNovak Djokovic, who has dominated the sport of tennis for over a decade, has amassed an impressive collection of titles, including 24 Grand Slam singles titles, making him the most successful male player in the history of the sport. However, the Olympic gold medal had remained out of his grasp until the Paris Games.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serbian faced off against Carlos Alcaraz, the rising star from Spain, in the gold medal match. Alcaraz, who had defeated Djokovic in the Wimbledon final just weeks before the Olympics, was eager to prove himself against the tennis legend once again.\n\nThe match was a nail-biting affair, with both players showcasing their exceptional skills and determination. Djokovic, known for his mental resilience and strategic prowess, managed to edge out Alcaraz in two closely contested sets, winning 7-6(3), 7-6(2).\n\nThe victory was particularly significant for Djokovic, as it completed his collection of major titles. He is now one of only five players in history to achieve the \"Golden Slam,\" which includes winning all four Grand Slam tournaments and an Olympic gold medal. The other players to have achieved this feat are Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, and Serena Williams.\n\nNovak Djokovi's Olympic triumph was even more remarkable considering the challenges he faced leading up to the Games. He had suffered a knee injury during the French Open, which required surgery and forced him to take a break from the sport. Many doubted whether he would be able to recover in time for the Olympics, but Djokovic proved his doubters wrong with his exceptional performance in Paris.\n\nThe Serbian's victory was met with an outpouring of emotion, both from Djokovic himself and from his fans around the world. After the match, Djokovic was seen lying on the court, overcome with joy and relief. He later described the win as \"one of the happiest moments of my career.\"\n\nDjokovic's Olympic gold medal win also solidified his status as one of the greatest tennis players of all time. While his Grand Slam titles have long been a testament to his skill and dominance, the Olympic gold medal adds another layer of prestige to his already impressive resume.\n\nThe significance of Djokovic's victory extends beyond his personal achievements. It also represents a major milestone for Serbian tennis, as Djokovic is the first player from his country to win an Olympic gold medal in tennis. His success has inspired a new generation of Serbian tennis players and has helped to raise the profile of the sport in the country.\n\nAs Djokovic stood on the podium, clutching his gold medal, he was filled with gratitude for the opportunity to represent his country on the Olympic stage. \"This is a dream come true for me,\" he said. \"To win an Olympic gold medal for Serbia is something I will cherish for the rest of my life.\"\n\nNovak Djokovic's Olympic gold medal win is a testament to his unwavering dedication, perseverance, and love for the sport of tennis. It is a fitting conclusion to a career that has already cemented his place in the annals of tennis history. As he looks ahead to the future, Djokovic can take pride in knowing that he has achieved the ultimate goal in his sport and has left an indelible mark on the game of tennis.", "source": {"uri": Djokovic took the first point after Alcaraz's attempt to slice a forehand shot went wide.\n\nThe Spaniard fought back to take the next point. The Serbian won gold at the 2024 Paris Olympics, defeating Carlos Alcaraz in the final, to become only the fifth player to win a career Golden Slam.\n\nDjokovic was sublime in the gold medal match as he defeated Alcaraz - who beat him in straight sets in the Wimbledon final just over a month ago - 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (7-2) to win his second Olympic medal to go with the bronze he won at Beijing in 2008.\n\nIt was a vintage display from Djokovic with a first-serve percentage of 74% over the two sets while he saved eight break points to defeat the four-time Grand Slam winner Alcaraz.\n\nWith the win, Djokovic joined Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slams and gold in the singles at the Olympics.\n\nThe Serbian also set a new record for the oldest tennis player to win a gold medal since tennis returned to the Olympic programme in 1988.\n\nAndy Murray was the oldest singles player as he was 29 years and 91 days when he won gold at the 2016 Rio Games while Matthew Ebden from Australia was the oldest overall as he was 36 years and 251 days when he won gold in the men's doubles in Paris this year.\n\nTennis at the Olympic Games: The 7 greatest moments - ranked!\n\nWho are Novak Djokovic's parents? {"uri": "2024-08-443798022", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:19:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:19:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:15:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/sports/20240804-djokovic-beats-alcaraz-to-olympic-gold-in-tennis", "title": "Djokovic beats Alcaraz to claim Olympic gold for Serbia in men's tennis", "body": "Novak Djokovic knelt on the clay of centre court and wept. The elusive trophy had been claimed. At 37-years-old, he was the Olympic champion in the men's singles tennis competition. The triumph for himself and Serbia came 16 years after winning bronze at the Beijing Olympics.\n\nDjokovic claimed the prize with an intense 7-6, 7-6 victory over Spain's Carlos Alcaraz, the man who beat him in straight sets on 14 July to win the Wimbledon title for a second time at his expense.\n\nBut that was on grass in south-west London. On Court Philippe Chatrier at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris, Djokovic had the psychological advantage of a success last year in the semi-final of the French Open.\n\nBilled as a clash of generations, that match fizzled out into a Djokovic stroll as the then 20-year-old Alcaraz suffered with cramps due to the pressure of entering a tournament as world number one and playing a crunch tie against legend of the sport.\n\nAlcaraz vowed to learn from his four-set defeat. Two Wimbledon titles and a French Open crown suggest an upward curve.\n\nChange\n\nFourteen months on from that French Open meeting, Djokovic and Alcaraz engaged in the gladitoral combat predicted for that sultry afternoon in June 2023.\n\nThe augurs came early. It took them 25 minutes to reach 2-2 in the first set.\n\nJust over an hour later, they were in a tiebreak after Alcaraz saved a set point on his way to levelling at 6-6.\n\nThey changed ends at 3-3 in the shoot-out. But Djokovic was steadier. He clocked up the next four points to pocket the first set after one hour and 33 minutes.\n\n\"I had a hungry Novak in front of me,\" said Alcaraz. \"He played at an impressive level. He did not let me take the chances I had. I gave everything I had on the court.\"\n\nPredictably the match wended its way to another shoot-out. And Djokovic started it with a thunderous forehand cross court winner.\n\nDjokovic unloaded a similar bludgeon to lead 3-2. And Alcaraz had no more answers.\n\nRecord\n\nDjokovic, who has won a record 24 Grand Slam tournaments, moved inexorably towards his grail and concluded the quest with a forehand winner down the line.\n\n\"When I saw that last forehand pass him, the intensity of the emotions that I felt at that moment was just something I never felt on the tennis court before,\" said Djokovic.\n\n\"The fact that I'm 37, I don't know how many more chances I would have had to win gold,\" he added.\n\n\"I'm super thrilled that I managed to do it here in a way that I did it against a guy who is the best in the world at the moment.\"\n\nIt was Serbia's second gold medal of the Paris Games after their win in the mixed team air pistol.\n\n\"Representing my country has been always the greatest priority, an honour for me, whether it's Olympic Games or Davis Cup or anywhere that I can carry proudly the Serbian flag,\" added Djokovic.\n\n\"This is something that really drives me and motivates me like nothing else.\"", "source": {"uri": "rfi.fr", "dataType": "news", "title": "RFI"}, "authors": [{"uri": "paul_myers@rfi.fr", "name": "Paul Myers", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-08-443838287", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:41:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:41:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:35:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.heraldonline.com/sports/article290742199.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic Goes From Hobbled to Heroic to Win Elusive Olympic Gold Medal", "body": "PARIS - There is no good explanation for what Novak Djokovic did here Sunday afternoon except that he is Novak Djokovic. At 37 years old, two months after surgery to repair a torn meniscus, Djokovic was clearly hobbling and frequently appeared to be in pain. Carlos Alcaraz, who happens to be the best player in the world, taunted Djokovic with drop shots, forcing him to go where his knee did not want to take him. Alcaraz never lost a service game, and he finished 33 with winners, compared to 15 for Djokovic. What he did not finish with was a gold medal.\n\nDjokovic beat Alcaraz, 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (7-2). Djokovic has always been an expressive player, but there were times in this match when he seemed especially frustrated by forces beyond his control. His problem was not hitting shots; it was getting to them. Djokovic is the best in history at seizing control of a point he seems sure to lose. But in this match, there were balls he would normally track down that he didn't even bother to chase-or when he did, he got there later than we have come to expect.\n\nThis sounds contradictory, but it's true: Djokovic did not look his best, yet he played some of his best tennis. Alcaraz summed it up: \"Hungry Novak ... an impressive player today.\" Someday, when Alcaraz's grandkids ask him what made Djokovic great, this performance at Roland Garros would be a fine place to start.\n\nBoth men said afterward that the pressure of the Olympics was even greater than what they feel at Grand Slams. Djokovic said, \"The fact I lost as easy as I did in the finals at Wimbledon probably worked in my favor because I knew that I couldn't do worse than that.\" With the first set in Paris tied 4-4, Djokovic fended off five break points. In both tiebreakers, Djokovic was the superior player. Alcaraz acknowledged that afterward: \"I felt the pressure in those situations, that I couldn't play my best tennis.\"\n\nWhen the match ended, Djokovic seemed as stunned as he was happy-he ended up prone on the ground, face down, his right hand shaking against the clay. When he got up, he found a towel, sat in his chair and covered his sobbing face.\n\n\"I thought that 2012 opening ceremony, carrying the flag for my country, was the best feeling that an athlete could have,\" the best male tennis player in history said Sunday. \"This supersedes everything that I imagined, and everything I hoped I could experience and feel.\"\n\nThis article was originally published {"uri": "2024-08-444147816", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:34:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:34:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:29:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.surinenglish.com/sport/spains-carlos-alcaraz-comes-up-just-short-20240804174306-nt.html", "title": "Spain's Carlos Alcaraz comes up just short in battle for Olympic gold | Sur in English", "body": "At the fifth attempt, Serbia's Novak Djokovic claimed his first-ever Olympic gold medal on Sunday afternoon after a gruelling battle in the final against Spain's Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nThe two superstars faced off just three weeks earlier in London in the Wimbledon final. That time, it was Alcaraz who claimed victory; on this occasion, Djokovic could exact his revenge, beating the 21-year-old 7-6 (7-3) 7-6 (7-2) in front of a packed crowd at Roland Garros.\n\nDjokovic, now 37, may have won a record 24 majors, but he has always come up short at the Olympics, winning singles bronze in Beijing in 2008 and finishing fourth at London 2012.\n\nIn Paris, however, Djokovic didn't drop a set. In the final, he saved all eight break points he faced and took advantage as Alcaraz faltered in both tie-breaks.\n\nDjokovic becomes just the fifth player to win the Golden Slam (all four majors and the Olympic title), following in the footsteps of Rafael Nadal, Serena Williams, Andre Agassi and Steffi Graf.\n\nFor Alcaraz, he returns home from his first Games as the youngest player to win a silver medal in the singles.\n\nIn the doubles, he and Nadal ultimately came unstuck at the quarter-final stage.", "source": {"uri": "surinenglish.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-08-443819359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:01:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:01:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:31:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://keyt.com/sports/national-sports/cnn-sports/2024/08/04/novak-djokovic-says-that-olympic-gold-supersedes-everything-as-he-defeats-carlos-alcaraz-in-thrilling-final/", "title": "Novak Djokovic says that Olympic gold 'supersedes everything' as he defeats Carlos Alcaraz in thrilling final", "body": "Djokovic outdueled Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in a brilliant, exhausting men's singles final at Roland Garros on Sunday, triumphing 7-6(3) 7-6(2) in two hours and 50 minutes.\n\nWith the victory, Djokovic became the fifth player to own what has been dubbed the career golden slam by winning all four majors and an Olympic singles title. That exclusive group also features Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi, Steffi Graf and Serena Williams, who was in the stands to witness this pulsating contest.\n\nHow much this triumph meant to Djokovic was immediately evident. Upon winning match point, he roared with delight, dropped to his knees, then tearfully embraced his family and coaching team.\n\nA Serbian flag was soon brought out, and the 37-year-old - the oldest man to win an Olympics singles gold medal - still seemed shaken with joy when he returned to his courtside chair. This is the first title that Djokovic has won all year, but arguably the one he wanted the most.\n\n\"I couldn't be prouder and happier,\" said Djokovic, who won a bronze medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.\n\n\"Playing for Serbia has always been my utmost, real pleasure, my priority ... I'm just so proud to be a part of an elite number of athletes that managed to win gold for their countries in their respective sports.\"\n\nOlympic tennis competitions can be a strange thing, arriving at awkward times in the calendar and often missing some of the sport's top players. This, however, was an exception, a thrilling sequel to Alcaraz's straight-sets victory in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\nAt the Paris Olympics, Djokovic has returned to the court on which he sustained a knee injury while playing at the French Open in June. That seems a lifetime ago now, and one meniscus surgery and one grand slam final later, he has now filled a notable gap in his remarkable trophy cabinet.\n\nStill playing with a brace on his right knee, Djokovic started the match promisingly, creating a break point on Alcaraz's first service game.\n\nThe 21-year-old shut out the opening, which would become a common theme through the early part of the match. Djokovic had five break points in the first set and Alcaraz eight, yet neither man could edge in front.\n\nOr looking at it another way, both seemed to raise their standard when the pressure increased. That was best demonstrated at 2-1 in the first set, with Alcaraz 0-40 down on his own serve. After a quick change of rackets, he reeled off the next three points before wrapping up the game a few points later with an exquisite drop volley.\n\nThe roles reversed several games later. With the set locked at 4-4, Alcaraz's booming forehand heaped the pressure on Djokovic's serve, and the break points came thick and fast - five in that game alone. But the world No. 2 stood firm, roaring to the crowd when a volley winner denied Alcaraz the chance to get ahead.\n\nIt was fitting and probably fair that this absorbing set would be decided by a tie-break, and with the scores locked at 3-3, it was Alcaraz who cracked first. Back-to-back errors handed Djokovic three set points before another cute forehand volley completed the marathon first set in an hour and 33 minutes.\n\nUnsurprisingly, little changed in the second set, only that break points became fewer and farther between.\n\nAs the match wore on, the standard remained unrelentingly high. At 4-4, Djokovic came from 40-0 down to deuce on Alcaraz serve, prompting chants of \"Nol\u00e9! Nol\u00e9!\" from the stands. But Alcaraz had a response, winning a marathon point by sliding a shot past Djokovic at the net, then raising a finger to his ear in celebration.\n\nAn inevitable tie-break followed soon after and, once again, the 24-time grand slam champion's experience and mettle came to the fore.\n\nA stunning cross-court forehand, bringing to an end one of the longest rallies of the match, had the crowd on their feet, and Djokovic didn't lose a point from there. Another forehand winner completed the victory, which was sealed with a huge roar of delight.\n\nThereafter, the emotions flowed freely as Djokovic kissed and hugged his wife and children in the stands. This was only Serbia's second medal of the Games, and the country's sporting talisman had achieved it without dropping a set in the competition.\n\n\"I was so blessed to win everything pretty much there is to win in my sport, but this is something different,\" said Djokovic. \"This supersedes everything that I've ever felt on the tennis court after winning big trophies. It's just incredible joy.\"\n\nAt 21, Alcaraz had been aiming to become the youngest man to win an Olympic singles gold medal. Despite falling short, he played a wonderful role in this spectacle, dazzling the crowd with 25 forehand winners.\n\nHis unforced error count may have cost him - 33 to Djokovic's 25 - as well as an inferiority to his opponent in the two tie-breaks. But heading into the US swing, the world No. 3 can nonetheless reflect on a stellar two-month period: a first French Open title, a second Wimbledon title and now an Olympic silver medal.\n\n\"I'm really happy about my performance today,\" Alcaraz told reporters. \"I'm a little bit disappointed about not playing my best tennis in some situations, in difficult situations. Tie-breaks, for example, he increased his level at the top and I couldn't do it, so probably a bit sad thinking about those moments.\"\n\nIt just happened to be one of those days that Alcaraz found himself up against an opponent who was inspired and determined like never before.\n\n\"In front of me, I had a really angry Novak,\" he added, \"An impressive player today. His level was really, really high.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Carlos Alcaraz"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8258988925", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:49:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:49:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:44:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/novak-djokovic-winning-olympic-gold-183646477.html", "title": "For Novak Djokovic, winning Olympic gold for Serbia supersedes all else", "body": "PARIS - He has won longer matches, but none he had to wait this long to achieve. He's improbably won more tournaments, but none that seemed this improbable. And he's collected bigger pieces of metal, but the medal may be the one he loves the most.\n\nOnce the gold was finally around his neck Sunday, after 2 hours and 50 minutes of grueling tennis against the current best player on the planet, Novak Djokovic kept kissing it. Once, twice, a third time. Then he let it hang over his chest for a few seconds before picking it up again and smiling.\n\nAt age 37, in the midst of a season where he has been in a race against the clock of his tennis mortality, it's possible that even the most accomplished player in history started to lose a little belief that his Olympic dream would come true. That he could win something not just for his trophy case, but for all of Serbia. That he could complete the last piece of the puzzle before the compounding realities of age and injury made this career-long chase impossible.\n\n\"Bringing the gold medal to Serbia, this may be the greatest sports achievement in my life,\" Djokovic said on Serbian television moments after a 7-6, 7-6 victory over Carlos Alcaraz that will go down as one of the most impressive of his career.\n\nBecause this is no longer the Djokovic who has won 24 Grand Slam titles, who could glide around the court for five hours and contort his joints in ways that didn't seem humanly possible and then do it again 48 hours later. This is a player who began the year with flagging motivation and poor fitness, a player who rushed back from surgery after tearing his meniscus at the French Open and a player who looked a little helpless just a few weeks ago against the very same opponent in a Wimbledon final. This is a player who hadn't even won a tournament this year.\n\nAnd it also, for all intents and purposes, is Alcaraz's sport now. He's already won four Grand Slams, including the rare French Open-Wimbledon double. He's only 21 and already almost complete, whizzing around the court with speed and creativity and competitive fire that evokes the best traits of Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer all in one.\n\nWatching him now is a little bit like what it felt like a quarter-century ago when Tiger Woods would play majors: The numbers aren't there yet, and the historical conversations are years away, but you know you're seeing somebody do things you've never quite seen before.\n\nWhen you have those kind of rare athletes in your sport, their path is marked by pivot points. We saw the first a year ago at Wimbledon, when Alcaraz did what many thought was impossible by beating Djokovic in five seats. We saw another on the same court a few weeks ago, when Alcaraz was so thoroughly dominant that it seemed a legitimate question whether Djokovic could beat him again.\n\nAnd here in Paris, when he wasn't taking selfies at the athletes' village and soaking in the pageantry of his first Olympics, Alcaraz was crushing everyone in his wake.\n\n\"I knew it was going to be the highest mountain to climb,\" Djokovic said.\n\nDjokovic's prospects of beating Alcaraz in a final never looked particularly promising. Though he had easily handled a clearly diminished Nadal in the second round, perhaps delivering the final loss at Roland Garros to his 15-year rival, the knee was becoming a problem again. In the quarterfinals, Djokovic's mobility seemed so limited at one point that it was questionable whether he could even finish the match against Stefanos Tsitsipas. Down two breaks in the second set, Djokovic somehow managed to claw back and escape without even having to play a third.\n\nAnd so he arrived in the final guaranteed the silver - his best ever finish at the Summer Games, and there was some relief in that. But in a sport where the Grand Slams are clearly the pinnacle and there's no real consensus on how much an Olympic gold really means, Djokovic went completely the other direction.\n\nAfter four brutal Olympics - a third-set disappointment to Nadal in Beijing, a razor-thin loss to Andy Murray in London, a first-round upset to Juan Martin del Potro in Rio and an inexplicably flat performance in Tokyo against Alexander Zverev - this was Djokovic's last chance.\n\nHe knew it. He said it. He embraced it. He built his entire year around it, and suddenly it was right in front of him.\n\n\"I didn't need too much motivation,\" he said. \"I knew in the opening two rounds, the way I was playing, that this is my chance. If it's ever going to be, it's going to be now.\"\n\nAnd as only the all-time greats can do, he made it happen.\n\n\"I heard many, many times that Novak wanted to win the gold medal,\" Alcaraz said. \"Every Olympic Games he had played, at the end he said it. And I knew that before the match. I had a hungry Novak in front of me.\"\n\nIt is hard, at this point in Djokovic's career after so many big matches and Grand Slam finals, to still be wowed at the amount of willpower, concentration and competitive endurance he is capable of summoning. And yet, perhaps because of the player he had in front of him, Djokovic managed to play one of the most impressive matches of his career.\n\nAt times, his movement labored. After a few of their more demanding rallies, he hunched over and gasped for oxygen. When he decided to chase something down, the pain and fatigue was written all over his face. And when he had a chance to end a point, he went for it - particularly in the tiebreaks when Djokovic played bolder tennis and Alcaraz was more content to counterpunch well behind the baseline.\n\nThose little moments, those micro decisions, were all that separated them. Djokovic said he had never played a three-hour match packed with so much intensity, where the margins were so thin at every turn. But whereas Djokovic felt unburdened to go for dramatic angles and pick his moments to play high-risk tennis, Alcaraz felt something that was foreign to him in the four Grand Slam finals he has won in the last 24 months.\n\n\"In the difficult moments, in the tough situations, I increased my level and pulled out really great tennis,\" he said. \"Today, probably, I felt more pressure. I don't know. Maybe other players aren't feeling the same way about playing for the flag, but I felt the pressure in those situations that I couldn't play my best tennis.\"\n\nPerhaps there has never been more of a validating moment for Olympic tennis itself. No, it's not a Grand Slam. There will always be top players who skip it for one reason or another, be it surface changes, inconvenient travel between Wimbledon and the US Open or the lack of prize money and ranking points that go to the winner.\n\nBut here you had the best ever who put together Djokovic's masterpiece, with a prize he desperately wanted on the line, on the only day remaining in his career that he could possibly do it. And on the other side of the court, you had the current best player in the game, unable to meet the moment in a way that had become routine on the biggest stages in the sport.\n\nThen, a moment after the match ended on an inside-in forehand Djokovic slapped through the court, he dropped his racket and covered his mouth in disbelief. He went across the net to embrace Alcaraz and dropped to his knees, looking at the ground for nearly a minute. And then, he charged into the stands to embrace his family in a more emotional moment than we have seen from Djokovic in years as the winning of Grand Slams became almost routine.\n\n\"The intensity of emotions I felt at that moment was something I never felt on the tennis court before,\" Djokovic said.\n\nMeanwhile, as the Spanish television cameras swarmed him, Alcaraz sobbed in a way he's never shown publicly after losses - not that there have been too many of them. But to this point in Alcaraz's career, every setback has been a lesson, even a blessing to help him maintain humility and sharpen his focus on his inevitable path to the top.\n\nAlcaraz, like Djokovic, is eventually going to win every big prize this sport has to offer. But the realization that he has to wait four more years for this one hit differently for a young man in a big hurry.\n\n\"I thought that I let all the Spanish people down a little bit in some way,\" Alcaraz said. \"I know that the Spanish people were waiting for my gold medal and myself, I worked for it, I went for it and it could have happened. That's why I got emotional at the end. I couldn't make the Spanish people proud. But right now, thinking, more relaxed, I think I made them proud and made them believe in a certain way, and I'm proud about the way I represented my flag.\"\n\nEven for superstars who have all the money, all the trophies, all the adulation they'll ever want around the world, there's something unique about that little piece of gold. Alcaraz will have more years to chase it. Djokovic just had one shot. And as the Serbian flag went up over Roland Garros, it meant everything.\n\n\"It supersedes everything that I've ever felt on the tennis court after winning big trophies,\" Djokovic said. \"When I take everything in consideration, this is probably the biggest sporting success I've ever had in my career.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Just three weeks after the Spaniard defended his Wimbledon title by beating his Serb in straight sets, they'll face off in the men's tennis singles gold medal match at the Paris Olympics 2024. Neither have lost a set and are hunting for their first gold. The difference is that Alcaraz is 21 and Djokovic is 37.\n\nPlaying in his fifth Olympics as the 24-time Grand Slam champion, winning the gold is the only accomplishment left for the Serb, and he'll give him all to tick the final box off. That dream won't come true that easily. Alcaraz is in red-hot form. He won the French Open almost two months ago at the very same venue where he'll face Djokovic today.\n\nThey have a 3-3 head-to-head with a 1-1 record on clay. But Djokovic would be confident. {"uri": "2024-08-443845583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:58:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:58:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:36:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/columnist/dan-wolken/2024/08/04/novak-djokovic-carlos-alcaraz-gold-heart/74666184007/", "title": "For Novak Djokovic, winning Olympic gold for Serbia supersedes all else", "body": "Across Paris individual countries have made spaces for fans to eat, drink, dance and celebrate their countries medals during the Olympic Games.\n\nPARIS - He has won longer matches, but none he had to wait this long to achieve. He's improbably won more tournaments, but none that seemed this improbable. And he's collected bigger pieces of metal, but the medal may be the one he loves the most.\n\nOnce the gold was finally around his neck Sunday, after 2 hours and 50 minutes of grueling tennis against the current best player on the planet, Novak Djokovic kept kissing it. Once, twice, a third time. Then he let it hang over his chest for a few seconds before picking it up again and smiling.\n\nAt age 37, in the midst of a season where he has been in a race against the clock of his tennis mortality, it's possible that even the most accomplished player in history started to lose a little belief that his Olympic dream would come true. That he could win something not just for his trophy case, but for all of Serbia. That he could complete the last piece of the puzzle before the compounding realities of age and injury made this career-long chase impossible.\n\n\"Bringing the gold medal to Serbia, this may be the greatest sports achievement in my life,\" Djokovic said on Serbian television moments after a 7-6, 7-6 victory over Carlos Alcaraz that will go down as one of the most impressive of his career.\n\nBecause this is no longer the Djokovic who has won 24 Grand Slam titles, who could glide around the court for five hours and contort his joints in ways that didn't seem humanly possible and then do it again 48 hours later. This is a player who began the year with flagging motivation and poor fitness, a player who rushed back from surgery after tearing his meniscus at the French Open and a player who looked a little helpless just a few weeks ago against the very same opponent in a Wimbledon final. This is a player who hadn't even won a tournament this year.\n\nAnd it also, for all intents and purposes, is Alcaraz's sport now. He's already won four Grand Slams, including the rare French Open-Wimbledon double. He's only 21 and already almost complete, whizzing around the court with speed and creativity and competitive fire that evokes the best traits of Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer all in one.\n\nWatching him now is a little bit like what it felt like a quarter-century ago when Tiger Woods would play majors: The numbers aren't there yet, and the historical conversations are years away, but you know you're seeing somebody do things you've never quite seen before.\n\nWhen you have those kind of rare athletes in your sport, their path is marked by pivot points. We saw the first a year ago at Wimbledon, when Alcaraz did what many thought was impossible by beating Djokovic in five seats. We saw another on the same court a few weeks ago, when Alcaraz was so thoroughly dominant that it seemed a legitimate question whether Djokovic could beat him again.\n\nAnd here in Paris, when he wasn't taking selfies at the athletes' village and soaking in the pageantry of his first Olympics, Alcaraz was crushing everyone in his wake.\n\n\"I knew it was going to be the highest mountain to climb,\" Djokovic said.\n\nDjokovic's prospects of beating Alcaraz in a final never looked particularly promising. Though he had easily handled a clearly diminished Nadal in the second round, perhaps delivering the final loss at Roland Garros to his 15-year rival, the knee was becoming a problem again. In the quarterfinals, Djokovic's mobility seemed so limited at one point that it was questionable whether he could even finish the match against Stefanos Tsitsipas. Down two breaks in the second set, Djokovic somehow managed to claw back and escape without even having to play a third.\n\nAnd so he arrived in the final guaranteed the silver - his best ever finish at the Summer Games, and there was some relief in that. But in a sport where the Grand Slams are clearly the pinnacle and there's no real consensus on how much an Olympic gold really means, Djokovic went completely the other direction.\n\nAfter four brutal Olympics - a third-set disappointment to Nadal in Beijing, a razor-thin loss to Andy Murray in London, a first-round upset to Juan Martin del Potro in Rio and an inexplicably flat performance in Tokyo against Alexander Zverev - this was Djokovic's last chance.\n\nHe knew it. He said it. He embraced it. He built his entire year around it, and suddenly it was right in front of him.\n\n\"I didn't need too much motivation,\" he said. \"I knew in the opening two rounds, the way I was playing, that this is my chance. If it's ever going to be, it's going to be now.\"\n\nAnd as only the all-time greats can do, he made it happen.\n\n\"I heard many, many times that Novak wanted to win the gold medal,\" Alcaraz said. \"Every Olympic Games he had played, at the end he said it. And I knew that before the match. I had a hungry Novak in front of me.\"\n\nIt is hard, at this point in Djokovic's career after so many big matches and Grand Slam finals, to still be wowed at the amount of willpower, concentration and competitive endurance he is capable of summoning. And yet, perhaps because of the player he had in front of him, Djokovic managed to play one of the most impressive matches of his career.\n\nAt times, his movement labored. After a few of their more demanding rallies, he hunched over and gasped for oxygen. When he decided to chase something down, the pain and fatigue was written all over his face. And when he had a chance to end a point, he went for it - particularly in the tiebreaks when Djokovic played bolder tennis and Alcaraz was more content to counterpunch well behind the baseline.\n\nThose little moments, those micro decisions, were all that separated them. Djokovic said he had never played a three-hour match packed with so much intensity, where the margins were so thin at every turn. But whereas Djokovic felt unburdened to go for dramatic angles and pick his moments to play high-risk tennis, Alcaraz felt something that was foreign to him in the four Grand Slam finals he has won in the last 24 months.\n\n\"In the difficult moments, in the tough situations, I increased my level and pulled out really great tennis,\" he said. \"Today, probably, I felt more pressure. I don't know. Maybe other players aren't feeling the same way about playing for the flag, but I felt the pressure in those situations that I couldn't play my best tennis.\"\n\nPerhaps there has never been more of a validating moment for Olympic tennis itself. No, it's not a Grand Slam. There will always be top players who skip it for one reason or another, be it surface changes, inconvenient travel between Wimbledon and the US Open or the lack of prize money and ranking points that go to the winner.\n\nBut here you had the best ever who put together Djokovic's masterpiece, with a prize he desperately wanted on the line, on the only day remaining in his career that he could possibly do it. And on the other side of the court, you had the current best player in the game, unable to meet the moment in a way that had become routine on the biggest stages in the sport.\n\nThen, a moment after the match ended on an inside-in forehand Djokovic slapped through the court, he dropped his racket and covered his mouth in disbelief. He went across the net to embrace Alcaraz and dropped to his knees, looking at the ground for nearly a minute. And then, he charged into the stands to embrace his family in a more emotional moment than we have seen from Djokovic in years as the winning of Grand Slams became almost routine.\n\n\"The intensity of emotions I felt at that moment was something I never felt on the tennis court before,\" Djokovic said.\n\nMeanwhile, as the Spanish television cameras swarmed him, Alcaraz sobbed in a way he's never shown publicly after losses - not that there have been too many of them. But to this point in Alcaraz's career, every setback has been a lesson, even a blessing to help him maintain humility and sharpen his focus on his inevitable path to the top.\n\nAlcaraz, like Djokovic, is eventually going to win every big prize this sport has to offer. But the realization that he has to wait four more years for this one hit differently for a young man in a big hurry.\n\n\"I thought that I let all the Spanish people down a little bit in some way,\" Alcaraz said. \"I know that the Spanish people were waiting for my gold medal and myself, I worked for it, I went for it and it could have happened. That's why I got emotional at the end. I couldn't make the Spanish people proud. But right now, thinking, more relaxed, I think I made them proud and made them believe in a certain way, and I'm proud about the way I represented my flag.\"\n\nEven for superstars who have all the money, all the trophies, all the adulation they'll ever want around the world, there's something unique about that little piece of gold. Alcaraz will have more years to chase it. Djokovic just had one shot. And as the Serbian flag went up over Roland Garros, it meant everything.\n\n\"It supersedes everything that I've ever felt on the tennis court after winning big trophies,\" Djokovic said. \"When I take everything in consideration, this is probably the biggest sporting success I've ever had in my career.\"", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA Today"}, "authors": {"uri": "8259410958", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "04:27:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T04:27:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:23:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3041858-djokovic-clinches-first-olympic-gold-in-thrilling-final-over-alcaraz", "title": "Djokovic Clinches First Olympic Gold in Thrilling Final Over Alcaraz | Sports-Games", "body": "Serbian tennis star Novak Djokovic expressed immense pride after winning his first Olympic gold medal in a gripping match against Spain's Carlos Alcaraz at the Paris Olympics. This victory adds to Djokovic's already impressive record, making him the most decorated tennis player in history with 24 Grand Slam titles.\n\nSerbian tennis legend Novak Djokovic has captured his first-ever Olympic gold medal, defeating Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in a tense men's singles final at the Paris Olympics on Sunday.\n\nExpressing his elation, Djokovic told ANI, 'God is great. Thank God. I am super proud, super happy.' The champion celebrated holding the Serbian flag with pride.\n\nDjokovic, who now has a staggering 24 Grand Slam titles, dropped to his knees in tears after securing the game point. Amid chants of 'Djokovic' resonating in the stadium, he climbed the stairs to share the moment with his family. His opponent Alcaraz, who lost 7-6, 7-6, settled for silver.\n\nWith 10 Australian Open titles, three French Opens, seven Wimbledon championships, and four U.S. Open titles, Djokovic now joins the ranks with an Olympic gold, making him the most decorated player in modern tennis history. His accolades also include 40 ATP Masters titles and seven ATP Finals championships, outshining rivals Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.\n\nThe showdown with Alcaraz was a nail-biter, with both athletes showcasing their strengths. Djokovic excelled in precision while Alcaraz impressed with quick, powerful shots. The match saw multiple breakpoints, aggressive rallies, and a near-seamless performance by Djokovic, sealing his triumph in two tiebreak sets.\n\nDjokovic's win is more than just a personal achievement; it solidifies his status at the pinnacle of the sport, leaving fans and experts in awe of his relentless pursuit of greatness.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8258880280", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:45:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:45:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:41:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/sports/2811802/", "title": "Novak Djokovic finally wins Olympic gold in tennis, Carlos Alcaraz takes silver in thrilling two-setter - ExBulletin", "body": "Novak Djokovic has finally completed the career Golden Slam, defeating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6(3), 7-6(2) in a thrilling and competitive match that was exciting from start to finish. He now holds the Olympic gold medal that he has been striving for his entire 20-year career.\n\nAlcaraz, 21 and in his first Olympics, fought hard, but he wasn't as disciplined as the more experienced Djokovic. As the match wore on and Alcaraz couldn't find any breathing room between himself and Djokovic, he began to get frustrated and talk to himself (and sometimes yell at himself) between points. That's always a red flag for Alcaraz, who's at his best when he's laughing and enjoying the match. But this one was out of control, and Djokovic, playing his best tennis since 2023, refused to give in.\n\nDjokovic had not won a single title this season. And for the first time in 14 years, the 37-year-old had not won any of the first three Grand Slams of the year. But he showed a show of grit and patience, and combined with Alcaraz's athleticism and showmanship, it was a match for the ages. Alcaraz can be proud of his silver medal and how hard he played against Djokovic, who seemed to have regained his old magic. {"uri": "8258942919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:51:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:51:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:51:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/sports/tennis/emotional-novak-djokovic-breaks-down-in-tears-of-joy-after-winning-long-awaited-olympic-gold-watch-2024-08-04-945254", "title": "Emotional Novak Djokovic breaks down in tears of joy after winning long-awaited Olympic Gold | Watch", "body": "Novak Djokovic fulfilled his long-awaited dream of winning Olympic gold for Serbia and burst into emotions after beating Carlos Alcaraz at the Paris Olympics 2024 final on Sunday, August 4. After a long wait of 16 years, the tennis legend finally earned the only piece missing from his glorious career and did not hold himself from showing emotions.\n\nThe 37-year-old Djokovic descended on his knees after winning a thrilling final by 7-6, 7-6 at the packed iconic Philippe-Chatrier court in Paris. He was literally shaking with emotions and then ran into the stands to join his family. He cried out loud to show his never-seen-before emotional side. He was crying loudly while celebrating with his family and support staff as the thousands cheered loudly.\n\nTermed as one of the biggest events of the 33rd Summer Games, both Djokovic and Alcaraz produced an absolute thriller. Both were unable to break each other's serves throughout the match as the Serbian claimed both set tiebreakers comfortably to claim his first Gold and second Olympic medal.\n\nWith 24 Grand Slam titles, a record 428 weeks as no.1 and now with an Olympic gold, Djokovic achieved everything there is in tennis. He also became the only fifth tennis player after Steffi Graf (1988), Andre Agassi (1999), Rafael Nadal (2010) and Serena Williams (2012) to complete a 'Career Golden Slam', a term given to players who have won all four Grand Slam titles and an Olympic gold.\n\nMeanwhile, Carlos Alcaraz, 21, was the youngest finalist in the men's singles in Olympics history. Many tipped the Spanish star favourite over Djokovic after his famous win in the Wimbledon 2024 final last month. Alcaraz kept Djokovic on his toes throughout the match but lost his focus during the set tiebreakers.\n\nAlcaraz, playing in his maiden Olympics, also burst into tears during his post-match speech.\n\n\"I gave everything,\" Alcaraz said. \"It's painful to lose the way I lost this match,\" he added. \"I had my chances to probably be up in the match. I couldn't take it. Novak was playing great. He deserves this. In the tough moments, he increased his level.\n\n\"He played unbelievable shots... an unbelievable game. I'm a bit disappointed but honestly, I'll leave the court with my head really really high. Fighting for Spain was everything to me. I'm proud of the way I played today.\"", "source": {"uri": "indiatvnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "India TV News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sumeet_kavthale@indiatvnews.com", "name": "Sumeet Kavthale", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Carlos Alcaraz"}}, {"uri": {"eng": "Tennis"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": {"uri": "8258794260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:15:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:15:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:14:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3041609-novak-djokovic-clinches-historic-olympic-gold-in-mens-tennis", "title": "Novak Djokovic Clinches Historic Olympic Gold in Men's Tennis | Sports-Games", "body": "Novak Djokovic captured his first Olympic gold medal by defeating Carlos Alcaraz in a gripping final. This victory solidifies Djokovic's illustrious career, now including an Olympic gold to his record 24 Grand Slam titles. Surpassing previous Olympic performances, he becomes the oldest gold medalist in men's tennis since 1908.\n\nNovak Djokovic won his first Olympic gold medal by beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling men's tennis singles final Sunday, giving the 37-year-old from Serbia the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nDjokovic's impressive career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam titles and the most weeks spent at No. 1 in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he has made clear that simply was not sufficient.\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago. In Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 -- and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com",
