{"uri": "8258536876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "11:07:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T11:07:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T11:06:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Carlos_Alcaraz/147129/mcnamee-explains-what-can-help-novak-djokovic-against-carlos-alcaraz-/", "title": "McNamee explains what can help Novak Djokovic against Carlos Alcaraz", "body": "Carlos Alcaraz will be clearly favored in the final for the gold medal\n\nCarlos Alcaraz will be clearly favored in the final for the gold medal at the Olympics in Paris. The Spanish champion manages to express his best tennis on red clay of the French Open, He is much younger than Novak Djokovic and has beaten him in the final of the Wimbledon Championships not long ago.\n\nThe four-time Grand Slam champion never hid his coming to Paris to win a gold medal, which would allow him to enter even more into the history of this sport. Carlitos has already won the French Open and Wimbledon this year, as well as winning the Masters 1000 in Indian Wells for the second consecutive time.\n\nDjokovic - on the other hand - will try to finally realize his dream of winning the gold medal for his country. The former world number 1 is not at the top of his form, but he still reached the final without losing a set. The 24-time Grand Slam champion has admitted that Alcaraz is the best player in the world right now and will need his best tennis if he wants to have a chance on the iconic Philippe Chatrier. The 37-year-old from Belgrade is happy because he is already sure to win a medal, but a legend of his caliber will give the maximum to achieve yet another feat in his career.\n\nThe bookmakers are all agreed that Carlos Alcaraz is clearly favored over Novak Djokovic in the final of the Paris Olympics. Australian legend Paul McNamee analysed the keys to the final through his X profile: \"Djokovic vs. Alcaraz, a landmark Olympic final. On red clay, given the results and injuries of this year, and their age, Carlitos is the big favorite. However, the fact that it is in 3 sets instead of 5 and playing with more freedom as an outsider helps Novak. The question is whether that's enough. A twist-off final.\" Fans and experts are hoping to see a much more balanced final than the Wimbledon Championships, where Alcaraz literally crushed Djokovic.\n\nThe 21-year-old from Murcia is eagerly awaiting this challenge: \"It's going to be a really special moment for me, in my life, in my career, so I'm going to try and enjoy this moment, because it's going to be really difficult. It's going to be difficult, but it's going to be special. I will try to be focused on myself and try not to hear all this, all the fans, all the people that say 'I'm going to win'. I just want to give 100 per cent my best tennis and hopefully I reach my goal to get the gold.\"\n\nAlcaraz showed an impressive performance against Aliassime in the first semi-final of the Olympic tournament, but he will have to be careful not to underestimate a legend like Nole Djokovic.\n\n\"We both are going to be very happy with a day off with no match tomorrow. He played a lot of matches with doubles and singles. Me, at this age, I'm really grateful to have a day off and recover my body and get ready for Sunday\" - Djokovic said during the press conference.\n\n\"That's going to be the biggest challenge that I can have at the moment, playing him on this court. He won Roland-Garros a month ago on this court.\" Despite the stakes, Djokovic feels a sense of freedom, adding, \"I have nothing to lose as I've already secured a medal, so I'm going to go for it\" - he added.\n\nNovak Djokovic is not going through the best of his career and has not yet won a title this year, but the Olympics have always been his biggest goal. The Serbian will miss the Masters 1000 in Montreal next week and focus on the US Open (waiting to see if he plays in Cincinnati).\n\n\"I'm disappointed to announce my withdrawal from the National Bank Open in Montreal,\" Djokovic explained. \"I have a lot of great memories from Montreal, winning two titles there (and two others in Toronto). However, as I'm recovering from my injury in a very busy calendar this summer, I need to make hard choices. I really hope I can return to Canada and Montreal in the coming years to play in front of their amazing fans.\" The 24-time Grand Slam champion has not played in Canada since 2018. \"While we're disappointed that Novak will be unable to take part in this year's tournament, we understand his decision and wish him the best at the Olympics and the remainder of his season,\" National Bank Open {"uri": "8258962527", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:13:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:13:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:12:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.tennis365.com/?p=168558", "title": "Novak Djokovic makes 'biggest success' admission after winning Olympic gold", "body": "Olympic gold delight for Novak Djokovic as he kisses his medal\n\nNovak Djokovic has now won everything there is to win in tennis and he admits his latest achievement - winning gold for his country at the Paris Games to complete the career Golden Slam - might just top the list.\n\nThe tennis great defeated Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (7-2) in the finale at Roland Garros to join Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams as the only players to win the four Grand Slams and Olympic gold.\n\nHaving already completed career Grand Slams (winning the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon and US Open) three times, Djokovic had made no secret of the fact that winning gold for Serbia at the Olympics was No 1 on his list of goals.\n\nIn 2016 he lost in the first round of the Rio Games and at the 2020 Tokyo Games he lost in the semi-final.\n\nAfter beating Lorenzo Musetti in the semi-final of the Paris Games, Djokovic reached his first-ever Olympic gold medal match as his previous best was a third-place at the 2008 Beijing Games.\n\nAnd on Sunday he realised his dream with victory over Alcaraz and, although he had achieved a lot during his illustrious career - including winning a record 24 Grand Slams and setting a new record for most weeks at No 1 in the ATP Rankings - he described it as \"arguably the biggest success I had\".\n\n\"I'm overwhelmed with everything I'm feeling right now,\" he said. \"Feeling different emotions. Too proud. Too happy. Thrilled with the possibility to win a gold for the first time in my career for my country. Arguably the biggest success I had.\n\n\"I won probably everything there is to win in my individual career. Winning the Davis Cup and particularly a golden medal at age 37 for Serbia is unprecedented. I'm just starting my celebration. I can't wait for what's coming up in the next 48 hours.\n\n\"I'm super grateful for the blessing to win a historic gold medal for my country. To complete the [career] Golden Slam. To complete all the records.\"\n\nNovak Djokovic becomes first man to achieve unique Olympic feat as he matches Serena Williams for overall singles record\n\nThe 5 players to complete a career Golden Slam as Novak Djokovic joins Rafael Nadal on list\n\nDjokovic and Alcaraz slugged it out for nearly three hours and he became the first man to win the Olympics without dropping a set while he is also the oldest Olympic gold medallist aged 37 years and 76 days.\n\n\"It was an incredible fight and I had to play my best tennis,\" the Serbian said.\n\n\"It was fair that the two sets finished in tiebreaks. {"uri": "8259354449", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:21:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:21:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:20:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://larrybrownsports.com/olympics/novak-djokovic-incredible-reaction-olympic-gold-medal/637115", "title": "Novak Djokovic had incredible reaction to winning gold medal", "body": "Novak Djokovic has finally claimed the missing piece to complete his legendary tennis resume. The Serb's reaction to nabbing his first Olympic gold medal on Sunday showed just how much the moment meant to him.\n\nThe 37-year-old bested Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz in straight sets to win a dramatic Olympic men's singles final at Roland Garros Stadium in Paris, France. The two sets were each decided by a tie-break, which Djokovic dominated both times.\n\nAfter calmly shaking hands with Alcaraz at the net, Djokovic let out all his emotions and was even moved to tears as he celebrated with his family.\n\nHeading into the Paris Olympics, a gold medal was the only major prize Djokovic had yet to attain. The 24-time Grand Slam winner called his victory over Alcaraz potentially \"the biggest sporting success\" he's ever achieved.\n\n\"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped could experience, and that I could feel,\" said Djokovic during his postmatch press conference. \"And the fact that I won the Bronze in my first Olympic games and ever since then failed to win a medal ... I couldn't overcome that obstacle.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this is probably the biggest sporting success I've ever had in my career.\"\n\nAfter winning Bronze during the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Djokovic had fallen short of the podium in his two subsequent Olympic stints. He finished fourth in both London (2012) and Tokyo (2020).\n\nOnly four other tennis players have achieved the tennis feat called the \"golden slam,\" which refers to winning all four Grand Slam events plus an Olympic gold medal. {"uri": "8258879498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:43:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:43:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:41:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/novak-djokovic-inflicts-carlos-alcaraz-163519958.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic inflicts Carlos Alcaraz revenge to complete career Golden Slam with long-awaited Olympic title", "body": "Novak Djokovic gained revenge on Carlos Alcaraz in a pulsating men's singles final to claim his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe Serbian first played in the Games back in 2008 but he arrived in Paris with only one bronze medal to show for his efforts and a burning desire to finally take his last chance to stand on the top step of the podium.\n\nHe lost in straight sets to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final only three weeks ago and had not won a title all season but, playing in the red of Serbia, the 37-year-old produced a superb performance to win 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2).\n\nWhen his final forehand found the corner, Djokovic dropped his racket and turned to his family in delight and disbelief before lying on the court, his ultimate goal finally realised.\n\nThe 37-year-old then climbed into the stands and cried uncontrollably as he embraced his family and supporters.\n\nSpeaking to Eurosport, Djokovic said: \"I put my heart, my soul, my body, my family, everything on the line. To win Olympic gold at 37, I finally did it. Most of all, it's my country. The pride of playing for Serbia.\"\n\nHe joins Serena Williams, Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi and Steffi Graf as just the fifth player to complete the career Golden Slam of all four Grand Slam titles and Olympic singles gold.\n\nThe boxing finals are due to take place next week at Roland Garros but this was a true heavyweight contest between the oldest and youngest Olympic men's singles finalists since tennis returned to the Games in 1988.\n\nAnticipation fizzed around a packed Court Philippe-Chatrier, with Serena Williams among those watching from the stands as well as Djokovic's two children, who waved Serbian flags and home-made signs.\n\nDjokovic said after finally breaking his Olympic semi-final hoodoo that he felt like a different player to the one who lost rather tamely to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final.\n\nThe Serbian's right knee no longer appears to be limiting him, bar a brief scare in the quarter-finals against Stefanos Tsitsipas, and it was he who had the first chances of the final.\n\nAlcaraz trailed 0-40 in the fourth game as Djokovic stuck like glue to the baseline and piled on the pressure but the Spaniard was up to the task.\n\nIt was an extraordinary level of tennis, the pair outdoing each other with outrageous shot-making, but it was Alcaraz's enormous power that began to take charge.\n\nHe created eight break points, three at 2-2 then five more at 4-4, but Djokovic, on the ropes but not panicking, somehow withstood the onslaught.\n\nAs the clock ticked past the hour mark, Alcaraz saved a first set point, but Djokovic was not to be denied in the tiebreak, winning the final four points.\n\nWhen his final lunging forehand volley landed in after 93 minutes of action, the 37-year-old stood for several seconds with his fist in the air, soaking in the cheers from his fans.\n\nAlcaraz had started to over-hit a little in a search of a way through Djokovic's defences, and his frustration grew in the second set as the finish line approached with nothing to split them.\n\nGoing into the tiebreak, Djokovic knew one final effort would deliver the longed-for prize and two fizzing forehand winners gave him an early advantage that Alcaraz could not {"uri": "8259281838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:45:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:45:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:44:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/sports/olympics/sachin-tendulkar-cant-keep-calm-after-novak-djokovic-wins-gold-at-paris-olympics-serves-key-carlos-alcaraz-analysis-101722819447792.html", "title": "Sachin Tendulkar can't keep calm after Novak Djokovic wins gold at Paris Olympics, 'serves' key Carlos Alcaraz analysis", "body": "Novak Djokovic completed tennis on Sunday after adding the elusive Olympic gold to his all-time great career. The Serb battled past his rival Carlos Alcaraz with a vintage display to win 7-6(3) 7-6(2) and complete his career Golden Slam in spectacular fashion, not dropping a set in six matches at Roland Garros in the 2024 Paris Olympics. With the win, he became the oldest man to win to finish top of the podium at the Games since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988 and achieved it less than a month after being thrashed in straight sets at the Wimbledon final by Alcaraz.\n\nFormer Inia cricketer Sachin Tendulkar has always been an avid follower of the game of tennis, and following Djokovic's memorable and emotional win on Court Philippe Chatrier, he not only dropped a congratulatory post for the 37-year-old, but also made his piece of analysis on where Djokovic managed to outclass Alcaraz in the final and where the Spaniard could still improve on his game.\n\nHe tweeted: \"Well done, @DjokerNole, on winning the gold medal at #Paris2024.@carlosalcaraz put up a strong fight and obviously has a bright future ahead, but Djokovic had an ace up his sleeve whenever he was serving. That was the key to his success today, in my opinion. Alcaraz has what it takes, but to truly dominate for years on all surfaces, he'll need to step up his serve!\"\n\nThe gold medal at the Olympics was his only missing puzzle in his illustrious career. Having made his debut at the Games in 2008, when he won the bronze medal, Djokovic suffered a shocking round-one exit in the 2016 Rio Olympics and finished fourth in both London and Tokyo. However, in a season where Djokovic has struggled to win a single trophy, the Olympic gold in Paris helped him become the fifth player - after Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams -- to complete the 'Golden Slam' of winning all four majors and an Olympic gold medal in singles.\n\n\"Everything [about this is special], but most of all it is my country,\" said Djokovic. \"It's my pride to play for Serbia. {"uri": "8259087136", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:53:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:53:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:52:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/aikenstandard/sports/novak-djokovic-finally-adds-an-olympic-gold-to-his-resume-by-beating-carlos-alcaraz-in/article_33557f6a-1adf-5dc7-9575-78d7ef238ada.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic finally adds an Olympic gold to his resume by beating Carlos Alcaraz in a taut final", "body": "PARIS -- For all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia, the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37 on Sunday, beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men's tennis singles final at the 2024 Games.\n\nIn a sense, it doesn't matter one bit how long it took, of course. Djokovic is now an Olympic champion and forever will be. And in another sense, the years of waiting, the stumbles along the journey, made him appreciate this triumph as much as -- no, make that more than -- every other, which is why his hands trembled when he knelt on Court Philippe Chatrier's red clay at the end and why his tears flowed.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I ever had in my career,\" said Djokovic, who didn't drop a set in Paris and is the oldest man to win the Summer Games tennis title since 1908. \"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience, that I could feel.\"\n\nWith margins so thin that any mistake felt as if it could tilt things, Djokovic was at his best when the stakes were highest, dominating each of the two tiebreakers against Alcaraz, who beat him in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreaks, he played an impressive game,\" said silver medalist Alcaraz, the 21-year-old from Spain who sobbed, too, after falling short of becoming the youngest male singles gold medalist. \"That's why I saw that he's hungry for the gold medal. He was going to go for it.\"\n\nDjokovic already owns a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. He also already owned an Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient. He kept talking over the past week, but also the past months, about what a priority the gold was for him -- and Alcaraz said Sunday he kept hearing about it.\n\nUntil getting Paris bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy on Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in Olympic semifinals, losing to the gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Djokovic said, \"I was ready.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets.\n\nToday's Top Headlines Third Lulu's Car Wash opens in Aiken Traffic delays anticipated as resurfacing begins on Aiken's Whiskey Road One person dead following fatal hit-and-run in Barnwell County Aiken-trained Post Time runs third in Whitney Stakes ARTS AND HUMANITIES: A lost Carolina novel is found New facility for Children's Place almost complete SC's Tax Free Weekend begins today. Here's what you need to know before shopping. Guest column: Biden administration should protect S.C.s prescription drug access Aiken funeral home owner, former employee arraigned on federal bank fraud charges What could be achieved with a renewed Penny Sales Tax? Corey Murphy shares insights with community leaders\n\nThe 2-hour, 50-minute final featured one of the best to ever do it, in Djokovic -- and the \"highest mountain to climb at the moment,\" in Alcaraz, as Djokovic put it.\n\nThere was superb ball-striking, deft drop shots and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense. The No. 1 seed Djokovic saved eight break points, No. 2 Alcaraz saved six. Pressure? Ha. What pressure?\n\n\"We both played at a very high level,\" Djokovic said. \"We really went toe-to-toe.\"\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, Alcaraz -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Those in the stands became part of the show, breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. As Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters chanted \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\").\n\nYet the place was as quiet as a theater between points; play was delayed briefly when a young child's crying pierced the air that was thick with anticipation.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes on the way to that tiebreaker, when Djokovic grabbed the last four points, then turned to face his guest box -- which included his tennis team and his wife and their two children -- with a fist held high.\n\nIn the second tiebreaker, after Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point for a 3-2 lead, he waved his arms to encourage the folks standing and screaming. Soon, thanks to one last forehand winner, he had earned that prize he wanted, at long last.\n\nWhen the Serbian national anthem finished ringing out, Djokovic reached for his gold and brought it to his lips for a kiss.\n\nWas he worried that moment would never arrive?\n\n\"There are always doubts. Absolutely, I had doubts,\" Djokovic said. \"But the belief and the conviction that I can make it is stronger than my doubts. It always has been. I knew that it's going to happen. {"uri": "2024-08-443701409", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:35:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:35:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:02:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.aol.com/paris-olympics-novak-djokovic-fills-150227860.html", "title": "Paris Olympics: Novak Djokovic fills the only hole on his resum\u00e9  --  Olympic gold", "body": "Paris Olympics: Novak Djokovic fills the only hole on his resum\u00e9 -- Olympic gold\n\nKendall Baker\n\nAugust 4, 2024 at 5:11 PM\n\nMedal table | Olympic schedule |How to watch | Olympic news\n\nPARIS -- The most anticipated gold medal match in Olympic tennis history -- and one of the hottest tickets in Paris -- delivered on its promise with a wildly entertaining two-setter and a legendary champion.\n\nSerbia's Novak Djokovic defeated Spain's Carlos Alcaraz, 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (7-2) in a thriller on Sunday at Court Philippe-Chatrier to win his first gold medal and become the oldest men's Olympic singles champion at age 37.\n\nDjokovic is coming off minor meniscus surgery, but you wouldn't have known that watching the first set, which was a truly epic back-and-forth. He saved eight break points against the 21-year-old Alcaraz, who beat him in the Wimbledon final just three weeks ago.\n\nThe second set was just as thrilling, with the crowd alternating between \"Novak! Novak!\" and \"Carlos! Carlos!\" chants as the two men traded points.\n\nAppropriately, it came down to a second tiebreak, with Djokovic powering a forehand out of Alcaraz's reach for the victory. At that point, he fell to his knees in celebration, before making his way into the stands to celebrate with his family.\n\nWith a record 24 Grand Slam singles titles, 98 career titles and a record 428 weeks atop the ATP rankings, Djokovic has soared to the mountaintop of men's tennis. The Olympics were the only real hole on his resum\u00e9. He won bronze in 2008 (Beijing) before missing the podium three straight times, finishing fourth in 2012 (London) and 2021 (Tokyo) and suffering a shocking first-round exit in 2016 (Rio).\n\nThis victory -- over the reigning French Open and Wimbledon champion, no less -- surely solidifies his case as the Greatest of All Time (G.O.A.T.) over Roger Federer, who never won Olympic singles gold, and Rafael Nadal, who won in 2008. Nadal, who lost to Djokovic last week, can no longer hold his gold medal over him.\n\nWithin tennis circles, winning a gold medal doesn't hold the same weight as winning a Grand Slam due in part to the sport's 64-year absence from the Games (1924-1988) and the best-of-three sets format. But perhaps Djokovic's title will be looked at differently given he won at a Grand Slam venue against a four-time Grand Slam champion.\n\nThen again, maybe it won't: He didn't face a single Top-10 player en route to the gold medal match (No. 11 Stefanos Tsitsipas was his highest-ranked opponent), and the men's singles field -- while relatively strong -- didn't feature world No. 1 Jannik Sinner, who withdrew with tonsillitis.\n\nAlcaraz, the youngest man to ever play in a men's singles final, now adds Olympic silver to his four major titles -- all before his 22nd birthday. While he failed to win in Paris, it was a tournament he'll never forget: playing Djokovic in the final and playing alongside Nadal in what were perhaps his idol's final matches at Roland-Garros.\n\nWith Sunday's victory, Djokovic improved to 4-3 against the young Spaniard, who is surely the future face of the sport and would likely be the present face if not for the legendary {"uri": "8258786647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:07:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:07:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:07:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/novak-djokovic-vs-carlos-alcaraz-080311461.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic vs Carlos Alcaraz LIVE: Olympics score and tennis updates from historic gold medal match", "body": "Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic do battle again in the Olympics final at Roland Garros with history and a gold medal on the line.\n\nDjokovic, 37, is through to the Olympics final for the first time and is biding to end his wait for an elusive gold medal to complete the set of major titles. Alcaraz, 21, is the youngest player in history to reach the Olympics final and is attempting to add the gold medal to French Open and Wimbledon titles this season.\n\nThe final at Roland Garros is an immediate rematch of last month's Wimbledon final, where Alcaraz denied Djokovic a record-equalling eighth title in SW19 and record 25th grand slam. The Spaniard won in straight-sets in one of the heaviest defeats of Djokovic's career, and was the second year in a row in which he had beaten the Serbian in the Wimbledon final.\n\nAlcaraz is competing at his first Olympics while Djokovic is at his fifth. The gold medal is the only honour that is missing from his record-breaking career and this could be Djokovic's last chance to do so. He will be 41 by the time of the next Olympics in Los Angeles in 2028.\n\nFollow live score updates from the Olmypic final at Roland Garros, below\n\n15:47 , Harry Latham-Coyle\n\nAnd that's a mighty good time to collect a hold to love. Carlos Alcaraz conserves energy with rock solid tennis.\n\n15:45 , Harry Latham-Coyle\n\nNeither player will submit. {"uri": "2024-08-444200576", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:32:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:32:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:29:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://crickettimes.com/2024/08/sachin-tendulkar-hails-novak-djokovics-gold-medal-win-shares-key-to-success-over-carlos-alcaraz-at-the-paris-olympics/?fbclid=IwZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAAR1yPt8EcPlaNZhYA4rMBkIUZ-A2MYgYPMuwE7cKqIpAHQ4FCw8wUu_iCYw_aem_-xHgmWP6eG3cepnna2YeVQ", "title": "Sachin Tendulkar hails Novak Djokovic's gold medal win; shares key to success over Carlos Alcaraz at the Paris Olympics", "body": "Tennis star Novak Djokovic has finally secured the elusive Olympic gold medal, triumphing over Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in the final of the Paris Olympics 2024. This victory allowed Djokovic to complete the career 'Golden Slam,' a feat achieved by only four other players: Rafael Nadal, Serena Williams, Andre Agassi and Steffi Graf.\n\nThe Serbian legend, already a record-holder with 24 major titles, won the final in straight sets: 7-6(3), 7-6(2).\n\nA historic milestone for Novak Djokovic\n\nDjokovic's gold medal win cements his place in tennis history, marking him as one of the few to win all four Grand Slam titles and the Olympic gold. His Olympic journey began with a bronze medal in singles at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Subsequent attempts saw him finish fourth in London 2012, endure an early exit in Rio 2016, and fall short in the bronze-medal match at Tokyo 2020.\n\nThe final showdown against Carlos Alcaraz\n\nFacing French Open and Wimbledon champion Alcaraz, Djokovic delivered his best performance of the year. The match was tightly contested, with Djokovic demonstrating exceptional composure and resilience, particularly in the first set where he faced eight breakpoints.\n\nHis clinical performance in both tie-breaks underscored his experience and mental fortitude, proving decisive in the match. This victory comes after Djokovic's recent loss to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final, where he was defeated in five sets: 6-1, 6-7, 1-6, 6-3, 4-6. However, in Paris, Djokovic outclassed Alcaraz, capitalizing on key moments and showcasing his strategic acumen.\n\nAlso READ: Sachin Tendulkar discloses his ideal Tennis batting partner and top cricketers for doubles\n\nSachin Tendulkar's insight\n\nFormer Indian cricketer Sachin Tendulkar, an avid tennis follower, congratulated Djokovic and offered his analysis on the match and reason behind Novak's edge over Alcaraz in the summit-clash.\n\n\"Well done, @DjokerNole on winning the gold medal at #Paris2024 @carlosalcaraz put up a strong fight and obviously has a bright future ahead, but Djokovic had an ace up his sleeve whenever he was serving. That was the key to his success today, in my opinion. Alcaraz has what it takes, but to truly dominate for years on all surfaces, he'll need to step up his serve,\" Sachin wrote.\n\nAlso READ: Rohit Sharma reveals his all-time favourite Tennis player and Even without the gold medal, Djokovic was still widely considered to be one of the greatest tennis players ever.\n\nHe didn't settle, however. He already had a career grand slam, but the gold medal would give him the rare golden grand slam. Djokovic delivered at the 2024 Paris Olympics, earning the men's singles gold medal for Serbia.\n\nDjokovic defeated 21-year-old Carlos Alcaraz to become the oldest men's singles player to win gold since 1908. Here's how the 37-year-old overcame injury to complete the golden grand slam at the Olympics.\n\n2024 PARIS OLYMPICS\n\nFull Olympics schedule | How to watch in USA | Meet NBC's broadcasters\n\nDjokovic had been eyeing a gold medal since debuting at the 2008 Olympics. The Serbian won a bronze medal at the Beijing Summer Games but has missed out on the hardware in each of the previous three Olympic Games.\n\n\"I put my heart, my soul, my body, my family -- my everything -- on the line to win Olympic gold,\" Djokovic said. \"Incredible battle. Incredible fight.\"\n\nThe 37-year-old secured a medal in Paris, but he had a familiar face on the other side of the clay. Alcaraz, a 21-year-old Spanish tennis player, has taken over the sport with four grand slam titles in his short career.\n\nAlcaraz and Djokovic have faced off six times prior to the Paris Olympics, with both sides earning three wins apiece. Two of Alcaraz's wins came in back-to-back Wimbledon Finals.\n\nBEST U.S. OLYMPIANS\n\nTop 33 rankings | Simone Biles | Katie Ledecky | Jesse Owens\n\nDjokovic broke the tie and now owns a 4-3 advantage over the youngster. He becomes the oldest men's singles player to win gold at the Olympics since 1908 while simultaneously preventing Alcaraz from becoming the youngest to win gold.\n\nHe did this all while battling an injury at the 2024 Olympics. Djokovic believed he may have re-injured his right knee just a couple of months after tearing his meniscus.\n\nDjokovic left the French Open due to the meniscus tear, opting for surgery ahead of the Olympics. He felt a \"sharp pain\" in his right knee during the quarterfinals in Paris.\n\n\"I'm concerned about the state of the knee,\" Djokovic said after the quarterfinal. \"I cannot give you exact information because I don't have it.\"\n\nHe ultimately played in the semifinal the next day and secured at least a silver medal with his win over Italy's Lorenzo Musetti. {"uri": "8259063047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:21:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:21:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:19:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.newagebd.net/post/tennis/241700/djokovic-says-gold-probably-biggest-success-eyes-2028-olympics", "title": "Djokovic says gold 'probably biggest success', eyes 2028 Olympics", "body": "Novak Djokovic described his Olympic gold medal triumph on Sunday as 'probably' his 'biggest sporting success' and revealed he may defend the title at the 2028 Los Angeles Games when he will be 41.\n\nDjokovic, competing in his fifth Games, came through 7-6 (7/3), 7-6 (7/2) against Carlos Alcaraz in an enthralling final at Roland Garros to add Olympic gold to his 24 Grand Slam triumphs.\n\n'This is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had and the most special feeling,' said the 37-year-old Serb.\n\n'I thought carrying the flag at the opening ceremony for my country at the 2012 Olympics was the best feeling an athlete could have until today.\n\n'Now at the age of 37 and facing a 21-year-old who is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back, I can say that this is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had.'\n\nVictory on Sunday allowed Djokovic to join Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf and the watching Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold, completing the career Golden Slam.\n\nBefore defeating Alcaraz on Sunday, his best performance at the Olympics had been in 2008 at Beijing when he won bronze. He had also lost three semi-finals.\n\nNow he wants to keep playing and has not ruled out trying to win back-to-back golds at Los Angeles in four years' time.\n\n'I want to play in Los Angeles, I enjoy playing for my country in the Olympic Games, in the Davis Cup,' he added.\n\nDjokovic is the oldest singles champion since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988 and he shattered Alcaraz's bid to add gold to the French Open and Wimbledon titles he has already pocketed this summer.\n\nAn emotional Djokovic fell to his knees on Court Philippe Chatrier, where he has won three French Opens, before holding aloft the Serbian flag and clambering into the players' box to embrace his wife and children.\n\n'We almost played three hours, the final shot was the only moment when I was sure I could win the match,' said Djokovic.\n\nHis title on Sunday was the 99th of his career and first of 2024 after a difficult season in which Jannik Sinner succeeded him as Australian Open champion and eventually took his world number one spot.\n\nAlcaraz then relieved him of the French Open before denying him the chance to equal Roger Federer's record of eight Wimbledon titles.\n\nA knee injury suffered at the French Open required surgery and his participation in the semi-finals of the Olympics looked briefly in danger when he appeared to aggravate the problem.\n\n'I knew that this could be my last chance of a gold medal,' added Djokovic at his post-final press conference still draped in his country's flag and with his medal hanging proudly around his neck.\n\n'I did everything I possibly could to prepare myself for this period. The injury sidetracked me a little bit. But coming into the Olympic Games I felt like a different player in terms of how I moved, how I played.\n\n'In a way losing heavily to Alcaraz at Wimbledon probably worked in my favour as I knew I {"uri": "8259043480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:55:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:55:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:54:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/sports/report/djokovic-claims-olympic-gold-calls-it-career-peak/20240805.htm", "title": "Djokovic claims Olympic gold, calls it career peak", "body": "IMAGE: Novak Djokovic of Serbia gestures while holding his Gold medal at the Paris Olympics. Photograph: Claudia Greco/Reuters\n\nNovak Djokovic described beating Carlos Alcaraz to claim the Olympic singles gold medal at the fifth attempt as the biggest achievement of his career on Sunday.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serb ended an eight-month trophy drought with a vintage display to win 7-6(3) 7-6(2) and complete his career Golden Slam in memorable fashion, not dropping a set in six matches at Roland Garros.\n\nHe is the oldest man to win the Olympic singles title since tennis returned to the Games in 1988 and remarkably he did it 21 days after being pummelled by Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final and two months after undergoing knee surgery.\n\n\"I won the bronze in my first Olympic Games (2008) and ever since then failed to win the medal and played three out of four Olympic Games in semi-finals and couldn't overcome that obstacle,\" Djokovic, proudly wearing his medal, told reporters.\n\n\"And then now at age 37, with a 21-year-old that is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back and playing incredible tennis.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I've ever had in my career.\"\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam champion produced a level of tennis that has been missing this year to fight off Alcaraz.\n\nAfter belting away a forehand winner to end a ferocious, near three-hour battle, the emotion poured out of Djokovic as he sobbed on court before climbing into the stands to embrace his family, including wife Jelena and son Stefan, and his team.\n\n\"Until today I thought that carrying the Serbian flag at the 2012 opening ceremony in London is the best feeling that an athlete could have,\" he said.\n\n\"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience and that I could feel.\"\n\nIMAGE: Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz react after their match.Photograph: Violeta Santos Moura / Reuters\n\nDjokovic did not rule out playing at the Los Angeles Olympics in 2028, but said the realisation that Paris was probably his last swing at gold had motivated him.\n\n\"I was ready for this tournament and I didn't drop a set the entire tournament,\" he said. \"I knew in the opening two rounds the way I was playing that this is my chance. If it's ever going to be, it's going to be now.\n\n\"When I qualified for the finals, I felt a big relief because that's the hurdle I wasn't able to surpass. I did celebrate like I won the tournament. But of course I wanted gold and I knew that I would have to climb the highest mountain there is at the moment, playing Alcaraz.\"\n\nDjokovic saved eight break points during a match of stunning quality and intensity -- the Serb describing the duel as like few others he had ever experienced.\n\n\"I don't think I've ever played, maybe a few times in my life, such a high level for three hours for only two sets,\" he said. \"Credit to him, congratulations to him for a great tournament, great fighting spirit.\"\n\nTHE OLYMPICS, 2024", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", "Novak Djokovic defeated Carlos Alcaraz in a thrilling manner to win the long-awaited Olympic title, making the 'Golden Slam' a reality.\n\nDjokovic, who has won a record 24 men's majors and every tennis title to his name, finally captured Olympic gold at his fifth Games.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serb produced his best performance of the year by beating Roland Garros and Wimbledon champion Alcaraz 7-6 (7-3) 7-6 (7-2) in front of a packed house in Paris.\n\nHe secured the title with a forehand winner and then turned to his box, arms outstretched in disbelief, before throwing his racket to the ground after a gruelling match that lasted just under three hours.\n\nAfter hugging Spaniard Alcaraz, Djokovic immediately burst into tears and fell to his knees in the middle of the court.\n\nHe then unfurled a Serbian flag and climbed into the stands to celebrate with his family and support team.\n\nDjokovic is only the fifth player to win the 'Golden Slam' in singles - all four majors and the Olympic title - after Rafael Nadal, Serena Williams, Andre Agassi and Steffi Graf.\n\n\"Everything I felt the moment I won was beyond anything I could have imagined or hoped for,\" Djokovic said.\n\n\"When I stand on that court, with the Serbian flag, singing the Serbian anthem and the gold around my neck, I think there is nothing in professional sport that can beat that.\n\n\"It is {"uri": "8258846175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:08:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:08:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:07:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.thehansindia.com/sports/paris-olympics-djokovic-clinches-career-golden-slam-with-straight-sets-victory-over-alcaraz-896805", "title": "Paris Olympics: Djokovic clinches career 'Golden Slam' with straight sets victory over Alcaraz", "body": "Novak Djokovic secured the elusive Olympic gold medal, defeating Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in the final of the Paris Olympics to complete the career...\n\nNovak Djokovic secured the elusive Olympic gold medal, defeating Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in the final of the Paris Olympics to complete the career 'Golden Slam.' The Serbian legend, already a record-holder with 24 major titles, won 7-6(3), 7-6(2) in straight sets.\n\nThis victory cements his place in tennis history as one of only five players to achieve the 'Golden Slam' -- winning all four Grand Slam titles and the Olympic gold -- alongside Rafael Nadal, Serena Williams, Andre Agassi, and Steffi Graf.\n\nDjokovic won a bronze medal in singles at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, finished just off the podium in fourth place in London in 2012, and experienced a devastating early exit in Rio de Janeiro in 2016.\n\nMost recently, he fell short in the bronze-medal match at the Tokyo Olympics.\n\nFacing French Open and Wimbledon winner Carlos Alcaraz, the Serbian star delivered his best performance of the year. Djokovic was pushed to the limit, particularly in the first set where he faced eight breakpoints.\n\nHowever, he displayed remarkable composure and resilience, saving each one and capitalising on Alcaraz's mistakes in the tie-breaks. His clinical performance in both tie-breaks highlighted his experience and mental fortitude, proving decisive in the tightly contested match.\n\nDjokovic has recently lost to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon {"uri": "8259092083", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:01:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:01:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:00:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/novak-djokovic-finally-adds-an-olympic-gold-to-his-resume-by-beating-carlos-alcaraz-in-a-taut-final/2I2NS6U2RFEITBTA7VIPZAQBJE/", "title": "Novak Djokovic finally adds an Olympic gold to his resume by beating Carlos Alcaraz in a taut final", "body": "In a sense, it doesn't matter one bit how long it took, of course. Djokovic is now an Olympic champion and forever will be. And in another sense, the years of waiting, the stumbles along the journey, made him appreciate this triumph as much as -- no, make that more than -- every other, which is why his hands trembled when he knelt on Court Philippe Chatrier's red clay at the end and why his tears flowed.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I ever had in my career,\" said Djokovic, who didn't drop a set in Paris and is the oldest man to win the Summer Games tennis title since 1908. \"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience, that I could feel.\"\n\nWith margins so thin that any mistake felt as if it could tilt things, Djokovic was at his best when the stakes were highest, dominating each of the two tiebreakers against Alcaraz, who beat him in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreaks, he played an impressive game,\" said silver medalist Alcaraz, the 21-year-old from Spain who sobbed, too, after falling short of becoming the youngest male singles gold medalist. \"That's why I saw that he's hungry for the gold medal. He was going to go for it.\"\n\nDjokovic already owns a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. He also already owned an Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient. He kept talking over the past week, but also the past months, about what a priority the gold was for him -- and Alcaraz said Sunday he kept hearing about it.\n\nUntil getting Paris bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy on Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in Olympic semifinals, losing to the gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Djokovic said, \"I was ready.\"\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets.\n\nThe 2-hour, 50-minute final featured one of the best to ever do it, in Djokovic -- and the \"highest mountain to climb at the moment,\" in Alcaraz, as Djokovic put it.\n\nThere was superb ball-striking, deft drop shots and tremendous sprinting, sliding, stretching defense. The No. 1 seed Djokovic saved eight break points, No. 2 Alcaraz saved six. Pressure? Ha. What pressure?\n\n\"We both played at a very high level,\" Djokovic said. \"We really went toe-to-toe.\"\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, Alcaraz -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Those in the stands became part of the show, breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. As Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters chanted \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\").\n\nYet the place was as quiet as a theater between points; play was delayed briefly when a young child's crying pierced the air that was thick with anticipation.\n\nThe first set alone lasted more than 1 1/2 hours, full of epic shots and epic games. One lasted 18 points spread over more than a dozen mesmerizing minutes on the way to that tiebreaker, when Djokovic grabbed the last four points, then turned to face his guest box -- which included his tennis team and his wife and their two children -- with a fist held high.\n\nIn the second tiebreaker, after Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point for a 3-2 lead, he waved his arms to encourage the folks standing and screaming. Soon, thanks to one last forehand winner, he had earned that prize he wanted, at long last.\n\nWhen the Serbian national anthem finished ringing out, Djokovic reached for his gold and brought it to his lips for a kiss.\n\nWas he worried that moment would never arrive?\n\n\"There are always doubts. Absolutely, I had doubts,\" Djokovic said. \"But the belief and the conviction that I can make it is stronger than my doubts. It always has been. I knew that it's going to happen. It was just a matter of when it's going to happen.\"", "source": {"uri": "daytondailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dayton Daily News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The success in the French capital also helped him become only the fifth tennis player in history after Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, and Serena Williams to win all four Grand Slam titles and a gold medal at the Olympics.\n\nAfter Djokovic's win in the final, Surya took to Instagram to post a picture of the legendary tennis player and captioned it, \"This man is on fire! I feel they were waiting for the gold medal,\" said Alcaraz.\n\n\"I got emotional because I couldn't make the Spanish people proud. {"uri": "8258899026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:04:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:04:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:02:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/sports/tennis-news/olympics-2024-tennis-novak-djokovic-emotional-moment-with-family-watch-video-13800799.html", "title": "Paris Olympics 2024: Novak Djokovic breaks down into tears as he celebrates Olympic gold with family; Watch", "body": "An emotional Novak Djokovic celebrated his Olympic gold medal with his family after the men's singles final in Paris on Sunday. Reuters\n\nSerbia's Novak Djokovic could not control his emotions after he clinched his maiden Olympic gold medal on Sunday, beating Carlos Alcaraz in the men's singles tennis final of the 2024 Paris Olympics. Djokovic defeated the Spaniard 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (7-2) to clinch the only major title that had been missing from his stellar trophy cabinet.\n\nOn winning the men's singles gold medal contest, Djokovic shared a customary hand shake with Alcaraz. However, Djokovic could not hold his tears as he began crying with joy. The winner of 24 Grand Slams then carried the Serbian flag around the court.\n\nAnd just a few seconds later, Djokovic could be seen going into his player's box to join the celebrations with his family and his team. That moment was made even more special when the 37 year-old shared an emotional hug with his daughter Tara.\n\nParis Olympics 2024: Day 9 LIVE Updates\n\n\"We almost played three hours in two sets. It was an incredible battle,\" the Belgrade born athlete said after the match.\n\n\"I believed that I could win, but to actually win it; it's unbelievable. He keeps on coming back and keeps on asking me to play my best tennis. My first set I started well, I had chances, he had chances as well. It was probably fair to end both sets in a tiebreak. When it mattered I came up with big shots and big moments. I put my heart, my body, my soul, my family, my everything on the line here to win the Olympic gold at the age of 37,\" he added.\n\nDjokovic said that it was a special feeling to play for his country. \"The pride to play for Serbia. Carlos and Rafa [Nadal] love to play for Spain, Andy [Murray] for Britain, Roger [Federer] for Switzerland. You just see the reactions when they win. It's special. {"uri": "8258984811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:47:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:47:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:39:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13707971/Novak-Djokovik-says-Olympic-win-best--starts-dreaming-California.html", "title": "Novak Djokovik says Olympic win his best yet - and starts dreaming...", "body": "Novak Djokovic declared beating Carlos Alcaraz to finally win Olympic gold his biggest sporting achievement - and then set his sights on competing again in Los Angeles.\n\nThe Serbian first played in the Games back in 2008 but he arrived in Paris with only one bronze medal to show for his efforts and a burning desire to stand on the top step of the podium.\n\nHe lost in straight sets to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final only three weeks ago and had not won a title all season but, playing in the red of Serbia at Roland Garros, the 37-year-old produced a superb performance to win a pulsating final 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2).\n\nWhen his final forehand found the corner, Djokovic dropped his racket and turned to his corner in delight and disbelief before lying on the court, his ultimate goal finally realised.\n\nThe 37-year-old then climbed into the stands and cried uncontrollably as he embraced his family and supporters.\n\nAsked if he had doubted the moment would ever come, Djokovic said: \"Absolutely I had doubts but the belief and the conviction that I can make it is stronger than my doubts.\n\n\"It always has been the case throughout my career and I knew that it's going to happen, it was just a matter of when.\n\nNovak Djokovic shows off his gold medal (Manu Fernandez/AP)\n\n\"Olympic Games come every four years so the opportunity to win gold for your country is very rare and I knew the fact that I'm 37 and I don't know how many more chances I'll have, I knew everything.\n\n\"I have to deal with that, I have to try to silence all the noise around me and focus on what needs to be done on the court. And that's the biggest battle to win.\n\n\"I'm super thrilled that I managed to do it here in the way that I did it, against a guy who is the best in the world at the moment. I'm just over the moon.\n\n\"Everything that I felt in that moment when I won really surpassed everything I thought or hoped that it would. I thought that carrying the flag at the opening ceremony (in London) was the best feeling ever until I experienced this today.\n\nNovak Djokovic drops to his knees on the court (Andy Wong/AP)\n\n\"And being on that court with the Serbian flag raising, singing the Serbian anthem, with the gold around my neck, I think nothing can beat that in terms of professional sport. It definitely stands out as the biggest sporting achievement I had.\"\n\nDjokovic's powers had appeared to be waning this season, with Alcaraz and fellow young gun Jannik Sinner taking charge, but he has not ruled out playing into his 40s and having another shot at the Olympics in 2028.\n\n\"I still want to play in Los Angeles,\" he said. \"I enjoy playing for my country and the Olympic Games particularly and Davis Cup, being part of the team.\"\n\nHe joins Serena Williams, Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi and Steffi Graf as just the fifth player to complete the career Golden Slam of all four grand slam titles and Olympic singles gold.\n\nDjokovic still needs one more slam title to reach 25 and hold the all-time singles record, which could come at the US Open next month.\n\nOn whether he has 'completed' tennis, he added: \"Yes it's complete because I completed all the achievements with this gold medal but no because I love this sport. I don't play only to win the tournaments.\n\n\"I don't know about the future, I really want to be in the present moment to celebrate. It was a long journey, many, many years of dreaming to be holding the gold medal. So now it's about happiness, joy and celebration.\"\n\nThere was a remarkable intensity to the contest right from the start, with rallies of supreme quality and chances for both.\n\nAlcaraz recovered from 0-40 in the fourth game but then could not take any of eight break points, five of them at 4-4.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by Carlos Alcaraz Garfia (@carlitosalcarazz)\n\nDjokovic seized control in the tie-break, winning the last four points of a 93-minute set and ending it with his fist raised in the air. The second set was just as tight but again it was the Serbian who found something extra when it really mattered.\n\nAlcaraz broke down in tears during a TV interview on court but was able to reflect later with pride on taking silver on his Olympic debut.\n\n\"In front of me I had a really hungry Novak,\" said the 21-year-old, who has won each of his four slam finals.\n\n\"His level was really, really high. He didn't let me take the chances. I'm really proud and I'm leaving the court and leaving the tournament with my head really, really high, knowing that I gave everything that I could.\n\n\"This tournament has been really special for me, I'm going to take it for the rest of my life. Playing with Rafa (Nadal), having those feelings, getting my first Olympic medal - hopefully not the last one.\"\n\nBronze went to Lorenzo Musetti, and Italy were able to celebrate gold in the women's Mandatory Credit: Katie Stratman-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThe Olympics final of the men's singles event was a treat to the eyes of every single tennis fan as two superstar players came together to put up a great show at Roland Garros. There wasn't much of a difference between Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz throughout the match as both players could not break each other's serve except in tiebreaks.\n\nThough the game ended in Djokovic's favor, not even at one point was the game one-sided and the two stars kept everyone hooked to their seats till the last point. With this victory, Djokovic realised his dream of achieving the career Golden Slam and finally winning a title for his country.\n\nIt was indeed a special moment for the Serb who had to wait for around 16 years and 4 Olympics editions to finally clinch a gold medal and his second Olympic medal in the men's singles category. His last medal came in the year 2008, when he played his first-ever Olympics in Beijing and won a bronze medal.\n\nAfter the win, Djokovic was quoted as saying:\n\n\"I don't know what to say. I'm still in shock. I put my heart, soul, body, family, everything on the line to win the Olympic Gold at the age of 37. The pride to play for Serbia. Carlos and Rafa love to play for Spain, Andy for Britain, Roger for Switzerland. You just see the reactions when they win. It's special. It's different.\n\nHe also lauded Alcaraz for putting up an equal fight and added:\n\n\"Incredible battle, fight. I honestly when the last shot went past him it was the only moment I thought I could win the match. He keeps on coming back and asking me to play my best tennis. It was fair to finish both sets in tiebreak.\"\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam champion's reaction to the victory said it all and how much this meant to him. The tennis legend broke into tears and also kneeled down on the ground. While kneeling his hands could be seen shivering, displaying the burst of emotions inside him to have finally added the only achievement left, to his trophy cabinet.\n\nBut it wasn't only Djokovic who went viral with his reaction. Alcaraz, too, after the match, had a lot to express and that won hearts even amongst many fans of the Serb as well. The 21-year-old was left heartbroken as he failed to win a gold medal for Spain in his debut Olympics tournament.\n\nHowever, he couldn't fulfill his dream as he lost to the 37-year-old, despite having defeated him at Wimbledon a month back. That made Alcaraz cry and was inconsolable for a few minutes until he gave an interview.\n\nFans believe that Alcaraz will get another opportunity to win gold in the Olympics someday as they sympathised with him for having an understandable reaction.\n\nBut Alcaraz was sporting enough to laud Djokovic and blamed his inability to not step up on big moments for his loss.\n\nAlcaraz is next expected to play in the Cincinnati Open before the US Open later in August. Djokovic, too, will be skipping the Canadian Open and is yet to announce his next tournament.\n\nBut the way the duo is playing, any of them could reclaim the World No.1 ranking from Jannik Sinner in the near future. {"uri": "2024-08-443701693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:36:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:36:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:31:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://pragativadi.com/novak-djokovic-downs-carlos-alcaraz-for-first-olympic-gold-medal/", "title": "Novak Djokovic Downs Carlos Alcaraz for First Olympic Gold Medal | Pragativadi | Odisha News, Breaking News Odisha, Latest Odisha News", "body": "Novak Djokovic spectacularly filled a rare void in his tennis achievements on a Sunday afternoon in Paris. At 37, he put forth his finest performance of the 2024 season, defeating the formidable Carlos Alcaraz 7-6(3), 7-6(2) to secure his first Olympic gold medal. Djokovic navigated through two tie-breaks, including a monumental 94-minute first set, to triumph over his esteemed adversary and claim the Olympic title, a mere eight and a half weeks post meniscus surgery on his right leg.\n\nHis triumph on Court Philippe-Chatrier saw Djokovic realize a long-sought dream by capturing the elusive, significant singles tennis accolade. The record-setting 24-time Grand Slam champion was overtly moved, shedding tears after a forehand winner against Alcaraz confirmed his place at the pinnacle of the podium.\n\nLast month, Djokovic succumbed to Alcaraz at Wimbledon's final, his sole competition following knee surgery. However, he has now joined the elite ranks of Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, and Serena Williams as the fifth player to achieve the 'Golden Slam' -- winning all four major titles and an Olympic gold in singles.\n\nBoth Djokovic and Alcaraz displayed extraordinary fortitude under duress, with a first set featuring 13 break points (Djokovic 5, Alcaraz 8) progressing to a tie-break sans a service break. Noteworthy moments included Alcaraz's comeback from 0/40 in the fourth game and Djokovic's resilience in a fluctuating ninth game, brimming with thrilling play from both, despite facing five break points.\n\nDjokovic's ultimate break point in the set also served as a set point at 6-5, 30/40. Unable to capitalize, the Serbian maintained his poise, securing four consecutive points from 3/3 in the tie-break to advance on Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nContrary to the opening set, the second set offered few opportunities for returns for both players. However, this was not indicative of a decline in performance from two of the world's premier players. Djokovic continued to vary the pace to keep Alcaraz on the move, while the Spaniard, who saved the set's only break point in the third game, showcased his signature shot-making flair.\n\nDjokovic consistently managed to elicit errors from his formidable adversary and also delivered a series of top-tier winners. A sharp cross-court forehand winner at 2/2 in the second-set tie-break exemplified the Serbian's focus, and he confidently secured the next four points to win the match.\n\nAlcaraz sought to complement his remarkable summer with an Olympic title, having secured his third and fourth Grand Slam victories at Roland Garros and Wimbledon. At 21, the Spaniard was the youngest finalist in a singles gold-medal match since tennis's reintroduction to the Olympics in 1988, while Djokovic was the most senior.\n\nThe Sunday match marked the second meeting on Court Philippe-Chatrier for the PIF ATP Rankings' second-placed Djokovic and third-placed Alcaraz, following Djokovic's victory in the 2022 Roland Garros semi-finals. Djokovic now leads their Lexus ATP Head2Head series 4-3.", "source": {"uri": "pragativadi.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pragativadi: Leading Odia Dailly"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259010570", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:12:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:12:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:11:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Novak_Djokovic/147140/rennae-stubbs-stunned-by-the-level-of-carlos-alcaraz-and-novak-djokovic/", "title": "Rennae Stubbs stunned by the level of Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic", "body": "Djokovic achieved yet another feat in a simply legendary career\n\nNovak Djokovic achieved yet another feat in a simply legendary career. The Serbian champion won one of the few titles that were still missing in his immense palmar\u00e9s - the gold medal at the Olympics - beating Carlos Alcaraz in Paris and overturning the predictions of the eve. The 24-time Grand Slam champion pulled off his best performance of the season, shocking Alcaraz and winning two tiebreaks after almost three hours of battle. The final of the Paris Olympics was the most beautiful match of 2024, full of spectacle and incredible rallies.\n\nThanks to his victory at the Paris Olympics, the 37-year-old from Belgrade has fulfilled his greatest dream and completed the Career Golden Slam. Nole's numbers are truly impressive: 24 Grand Slam titles, 40 Masters 1000, 7 Nitto ATP Finals, 1 Davis Cup and an Olympic gold medal, besides becoming the oldest player to win gold medal since 1988.\n\nThe Serbian also became the first player in history to win an Olympic tournament without losing a set and the fifth player ever to complete the Career Golden Slam after Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi, Steffi Graf and Serena Williams. The final of the Olympic tournament between Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz was one of the best matches in recent months.\n\nTennis legend Rennae Stubbs has paid tribute to these two outstanding champions through her X profile: \"If you're not watching the final between Djokovic and Alcaraz, what's wrong with you! Oh my God! It's one of the best matches I've seen this year (if not the best).\"\n\nAlcaraz played a great match and proved once again to be a great champion, but he missed something compared to Djokovic in the decisive moments. Speaking with former ATP ace Alex Corretja after the match, Carlitos burst into tears: \"It's complicated. We fought a match of almost three hours, we didn't take advantage of the opportunities we had, and playing against Djokovic is never easy. He always brings a very high level in those moments. He also deserves this opportunity. It hurts to lose the way I've lost, but I leave with my head held high knowing that I gave it my all.\"\n\nDjokovic - on the other hand - expressed his happiness for having achieved his dream: \"It's been an incredible battle, a great fight. When the last shot went through Carlos' side, it was the only time I thought I could win the game. I don't know what to say, I'm still in shock. I put my heart, soul, body, family, everything on the line to win Olympic gold at 37. I am proud to play for Serbia. Carlos and Rafa love playing with Spain, Andy with Great Britain and Roger with Switzerland. You just see the reactions when they win and it's special, different.\"\n\nNovak has learned from his previous experiences at the Olympics and made no mistakes in Paris. A few days ago - during a long interview with Clay - the Serbian captain Viktor Troicki explained the changes adopted by Djokovic: \"Tokyo was a huge experience for him, you know, 6-1, 2-1 with the break, against Zverev in the semifinals. Everything going well, everything. But he's also a human. Zverev started playing better.\n\nHe started feeling a little bit of pressure and at the end it cost him the match. He won so many big titles, but this was the first time he felt the goal was there, so close. I think here in Paris he's more relaxed, more focused on the things he needs to do. He also made a mistake playing mixed doubles. I think he also lost energy playing mixed doubles for no reason.\n\nIt was extremely h*t there and here he's only focused on the singles title and he's doing everything to accomplish it. Here he has family with him, kids are with him. So I think he feels better here mentally and that is the most important thing for him at this moment. Well that's one of the many mistakes he learned from. He's like this. He's stubborn sometimes. Even if everyone tells him you shouldn't play, if he thinks he should play, he will do it. And will try to prove everyone wrong. And he was close. He was close.\"\n\nAfter this feat at 37, it's really hard not to argue that Djokovic is the best player ever. The former world number 1 has conquered everything a player can win in the professional tour and the circle is closed with this amazing victory. {"uri": "2024-08-444406169", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:38:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:38:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:50:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://wabcradio.com/2024/08/05/novak-djokovic-beats-carlos-alcaraz-to-capture-olympic-gold-medal/", "title": "Novak Djokovic beats Carlos Alcaraz to capture Olympic Gold Medal", "body": "Serbian Novak Djokovic defeated Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz in the Paris Olympics men's singles gold medal match on Sunday to make history and become just the fifth player ever to complete a career Golden Slam.\n\nDjokovic took nearly three hours to beat Alcaraz 7-6(3), 7-6(2) on Court Philippe-Chatrier, telling NBC Sports: \"We almost played three hours for two sets. It was an incredible battle, incredible fight. When the last shot went past him, that was the only moment I actually thought I could win the match. I mean I believed that I could win, but to actually win it, because he keeps on coming back. He keeps on asking me to play my best tennis. I don't know what to say. I'm still in shock, honestly. I put my heart, my soul, my body, my family, my everything on the line to win Olympic gold at age 37. I finally did it.\"\n\nAlcaraz said after the defeat: \"It is painful to lose the way that I lost this match. I had my opportunities. I couldn't take them. Novak is playing great. He really settled in his position. In the difficult moments, he increased his level. He played unbelievable. I'm really disappointed, but honestly, I'm going to leave the court with my head really high. I gave everything that I had fighting for Spain. It was everything to me so I'm proud the way that I played today.\"\n\nDjokovic, a three-time French Open champion on the same clay courts of Roland Garros, joins Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams as the only tennis players to complete a career Golden Slam -- wins of all four tennis Grand Slam tournaments and an Olympic gold medal.\n\nAlcaraz, who won the 2024 French Open at Roland Garros, earned the silver medal; while Italian Lorenzo Musetti beat Canadian Felix Auger-Aliassime to win the men's singles bronze medal on Saturday.\n\nEditorial credit: Victor Velter {"uri": "8259000547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:00:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:00:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:59:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/tennis/paris-olympics-2024-tennis-result-score-novak-djokovic-defeats-carlos-alcaraz-highlights-reaction/news-story/77a432dc0b4e68b2fb17a6b291e19190", "title": "'Probably my biggest success': Golden slam complete as Djoker turns table on Alcaraz for gold", "body": "Novak Djokovic has described his Olympic gold medal triumph as \"probably\" his \"biggest sporting success\" and revealed he may defend the title at the 2028 Los Angeles Games when he will be 41.\n\nDjokovic, competing in his fifth Games, came through 7-6 (7-3) 7-6 (7-2) against Carlos Alcaraz in an enthralling final at Roland Garros to add Olympic gold to his 24 Grand Slam triumphs.\n\n\"This is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had and the most special feeling,\" said the 37-year-old Serb.\n\n\"I thought carrying the flag at the opening ceremony for my country at the 2012 Olympics was the best feeling an athlete could have until today.\n\n\"Now at the age of 37 and facing a 21-year-old who is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back, I can say that this is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had.\"\n\nVictory on Sunday allowed him to join Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf and the watching Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold, completing the career Golden Slam.\n\nBefore defeating Alcaraz on Sunday, his best performance at the Olympics had been in 2008 at Beijing when he won bronze. He had also lost three semi-finals.\n\nNow he wants to keep playing and has not ruled out trying to win back-to-back golds at Los Angeles in four years' time.\n\n\"I want to play in Los Angeles, I enjoy playing for my country in the Olympic Games, in the Davis Cup,\" he added.\n\nDjokovic became just the fifth player to complete a career Golden Slam.\n\nVictory allowed him to join Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf and the watching Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold.\n\nHe also became the oldest singles champion since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988 and shattered Alcaraz's bid to add gold to the French Open and Wimbledon titles he has already pocketed this summer.\n\nAn emotional Djokovic celebrated by holding aloft the Serbian flag on court before clambering into the players' box to embrace his wife and children.\n\n\"We almost played three hours, the final shot was the only moment when I was sure I could win the match,\" said Djokovic, who had lost heavily to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final last month.\n\n\"I put my body, my family on the line to win gold and finally I did it.\" Alcaraz was distraught and wept as he attempted to conduct a TV interview. \"Three hours, a big battle with tough moments,\" said the 21-year-old after a final in which neither player dropped serve. \"It's very painful to lose.\" Djokovic carved out a break point in the second game of the opener and three more in the fourth, all saved by the Spaniard.\n\nThen it was the Serb's turn to demonstrate his famed powers of resilience, fighting off three break points in the fifth game and another five in a marathon ninth game.\n\nIn a rollercoaster duel, Alcaraz saved a set point in the 12th game but his veteran opponent dominated the tiebreak to claim the opener after a breathless 93 minutes on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nThere was no let-up in the second set, scintillating shot-making alongside rousing defence with Alcaraz fighting off the final's 14th break point in the third game.\n\nAgain the set was decided by a tie-break and it was Djokovic with history on the line again sweeping through to take victory after two hours and 50 minutes.\n\nLorenzo Musetti defeated Felix Auger-Aliassime in three sets on Saturday to claim the bronze medal, giving Italy its first men's tennis medal in 100 years.\n\nLater Sunday, Russian athletes can claim their first gold of the Games when Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider face the Italian team of Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini in the women's doubles.\n\nRussian competitors are taking part in the Olympics as neutrals following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine in February, 2022.\n\nIf Andreeva and Shnaider win gold, their achievement will not be recognised in the medals table while both the Russian flag and national anthem will be banned from the podium ceremony.\n\nCristina Bucsa and Sara Sorribes Tormo, the Spanish eighth seeds, defeated arms outstretched in disbelief - before throwing his racquet to the floor after a draining match which lasted just under three hours.\n\nAfter hugging Spain's Alcaraz, Djokovic immediately burst into tears and fell to his knees in the middle of the court.\n\nHe then unfurled a Serbian flag and clambered into the stands to celebrate with his family and support team.\n\nDjokovic is just the fifth player to win the 'Golden Slam' in singles - all four majors and the Olympic title - after Rafael Nadal, Serena Williams, Andre Agassi and Steffi Graf.\n\n\"Everything I felt in that moment when I won surpassed everything I thought or hoped that it would,\" said Djokovic.\n\n\"Being on that court with the Serbian flag raising, singing the Serbian anthem, with the gold around my neck, I think nothing can beat that in terms of professional sport.\n\n\"It definitely stands out as the biggest sporting achievement I have had.\"\n\nAlcaraz, 21, was also in tears after the match, but will leave with a silver medal on his Olympic debut.\n\nItaly's Lorenzo Musetti is the singles bronze medallist, having beaten Felix Auger-Aliassime of Canada on Friday. {"uri": "8258828204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:50:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:50:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:49:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://thewillnews.com/djokovic-defeats-alcaraz-for-first-olympic-tennis-gold/", "title": "Djokovic Defeats Alcaraz For First Olympic Tennis Gold", "body": "August 04, (THEWILL) - Novak Djokovic has won his first Olympic gold medal in men's singles tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The Serbian champion defeated Carlos Alcaraz of Spain in straight sets, 7-6(3) 7-6(2). This victory adds to Djokovic's already impressive career, making him the oldest man to win a Summer Games tennis gold and the fifth player to complete a \"golden slam\".\n\nThe match took place on the clay courts of Roland-Garros, where Alcaraz had won the French Open title just two months earlier. Despite concerns about his surgically-repaired right knee after the quarterfinals, Djokovic showed no signs of weakness. He dominated Lorenzo Musetti in the semi-finals and played with confidence against the 21-year-old Alcaraz in the final.\n\nThis Olympic triumph marks a significant milestone in the ongoing rivalry between Djokovic and Alcaraz. It was their seventh meeting in competition, with Djokovic now leading the head-to-head series 4-3. The victory also serves as redemption for Djokovic following his loss to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final earlier this year.\n\nDjokovic's Olympic gold adds to his impressive tally of 24 Grand Slam titles. He joins an elite group of tennis players who have achieved the \"golden slam\", including Andre Agassi, Stefanie Graf, Rafael Nadal, and Serena Williams. This accomplishment cements Djokovic's status as one of the greatest tennis players of all time.\n\nThe match highlighted the contrast between Djokovic's experience and Alcaraz's youth. While Alcaraz has been making waves in the tennis world with his recent Grand Slam victories, Djokovic's extensive experience on clay and in high-pressure situations proved decisive in this Olympic
