{"uri": "8259037836", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:49:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:49:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:47:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/08/04/olympic-roundup-djokovic-finally-captures-elusive-gold-medal/", "title": "Olympic roundup: Djokovic finally captures elusive gold medal", "body": "Serbia's Novak Djokovic celebrates after a winning a point Sunday during the men's singles tennis final against Spain's Carlos Alcaraz. Djokovic won in two sets, both decided by tiebreakers. Louise Delmotte/Associated Press\n\nPARIS -- For all of his Grand Slam championships and other titles, for all of his time at No. 1, Novak Djokovic really, really wanted an Olympic gold medal for Serbia - the only significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nHe finally got one at age 37. Doesn't matter a bit how long it took. Djokovic beat Spain's Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling and evenly matched men's tennis singles final at the 2024 Games on Sunday.\n\n\"I put my heart, my soul, my body, my family - my everything - on the line to win Olympic gold,\" Djokovic said. \"Incredible battle. Incredible fight.\"\n\nHis impressive career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam trophies and the most weeks spent atop in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze - and he made it clear that simply wasn't sufficient.\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nBefore facing Musetti, Djokovic said, \"I was like, 'OK, let's get through this one.' That's why today, before the match, I did not feel as nervous as I would normally feel, because I had secured a medal.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908, and he prevented Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\n\"In the tough moments, he gave it an extra push,\" silver medalist Alcaraz said through his own tears. \"It hurts to lose like this.\"\n\nThe final, which lasted 2 hours, 50 minutes despite being decided in only two sets, was a rematch of the Wimbledon title match three weeks ago that Alcaraz won to follow up his French Open title in June.\n\nAlcaraz also defeated Djokovic in last year's Wimbledon final, but Djokovic won when they met in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open, the annual clay-court tournament held at Roland Garros, the site used for tennis during these Olympics.\n\nGYMNASTICS: Kaylia Nemour of Algeria delivered the country's first Olympic gold medal in gymnastics, putting together a thrilling routine in the uneven bars final to edge Qiu Qiyuan of China.\n\nSunisa Lee of the U.S. picked up her third medal in Paris and sixth of her Olympic career by grabbing bronze, exactly where she finished in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nCYCLING: Kristen Faulkner, a former rower at Harvard who only made the Olympic team as a replacement, was a surprise winner in the women's road race, becoming the first American rider in 40 years to win a medal in the event.\n\nShe timed her attack to perfection against vastly more experienced riders. Among them was Dutch rider Marianne Vos, one of the greatest female cyclists of all time.\n\n\"It's a dream come true,\" Faulkner said. \"It's the best feeling in the world. I don't know how to describe it.\"\n\nFaulkner finished the 98-mile race 58 seconds clear of Vos, Lotte Kopecky of Belgium and Blanka Vas of Hungary, who were separated by a photo finish, with Vos taking silver and Kopecky getting the bronze.\n\nARCHERY: Brady Ellison of the U.S. was edged by South Korea's Kim Woo-jin in a shoot-off as he settled for another silver medal in the men's individual final.\n\nEllison, competing in his fifth Olympics, and Kim Woo-jin battled to a draw through four sets.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBoth scored 10 points on their single arrow in the shoot-off, but Kim's was closer to the center, giving him his third gold medal of the Paris Games.\n\nEllison claimed his second medal of the Games, following a bronze he won with Casey Kaufhold in the mixed team event on Friday. He extended his U.S. career record to five Olympic medals; three silvers and two bronzes.\n\n3\u00d73 BASKETBALL: The U.S. men's team was eliminated after a 21-6 loss to the Netherlands, finishing 2-5 in pool play while playing its last five games without star Jimmer Fredette.\n\nFredette was brought in to boost the team after it failed to qualify for the Tokyo Games, and his play helped the U.S. enter these Olympics as the No. 2 seed. But he sustained a lower extremity injury in the team's second game and didn't play again.\n\nTRIATHLON: Belgium's Olympic committee announced that it would withdraw its team from the mixed relay triathlon after one of its competitors who swam in the Seine River last week fell ill.\n\nClaire Michel, who competed in the women's triathlon Wednesday, \"is unfortunately ill and will have to withdraw from the competition,\" the Belgian Olympic and Interfederal Committee said in a statement.\n\nParis 2024 organizers had no immediate statement.\n\nThe mixed relay triathlon is scheduled to take place Monday. Belgium's statement did not elaborate on Michel's illness, but it comes after concerns over the river's water quality.\n\nSwiss officials said Saturday that triathlete Adrien Briffod, who also raced Wednesday, fell ill with a stomach infection. But they said it was \"impossible to say\" whether it was linked to swimming in the Seine, and reported that other delegations told them none of their triathletes had reported stomach problems.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nRelated Stories Latest Articles", "source": {"uri": "pressherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Portland Press {"uri": "2024-08-443795392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:15:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:15:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:15:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "http://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-olympics-2024-gold-medal-reaction", "title": "Novak Djokovic completes the Golden Slam at Paris 2024: 'I can't wait for the celebration'", "body": "Djokovic completes his Golden Slam puzzle: 'I can't wait for the celebration'\n\nThe long wait is over for Novak Djokovic.\n\nAfter nearly two decades of consistently winning the biggest titles and breaking some of the most difficult records that tennis has to offer, the Serbian on Sunday finally added an Olympic gold medal to his sizeable collection of honours. Djokovic, who has long spoken of winning Olympic gold for his country as one of his most sought-after goals, was visibly emotional after overcoming Carlos Alcaraz in a gripping encounter in Paris.\n\n\"I'm overwhelmed with everything that I'm feeling right now,\" said Djokovic in post-match comments to NBC. \"Millions of different emotions of course: positive, too proud, too happy. The possibility to fight for a gold and to win a gold for the first time in my career for my country is arguably the biggest success I ever had.\n\n\"Of course, I want everything there is to win in my individual career, but winning Davis Cup and particularly the golden medal at an Olympic Games for Serbia at the age of thirty-seven is unprecedented. Just starting my celebration, I can't wait for what's coming up in the next forty-eight hours.\"\n\nLong acknowledged as one of the greatest athletes the world has ever seen, Djokovic added an Olympic gold medal to his record 24 major singles titles by overcoming Alcaraz in a pair of tie-breaks. The Serbian is the fifth player to complete the Career Golden Slam by winning all four Grand Slam events and Olympic gold in singles, after Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams.\n\n\"Yes, [my] puzzle, it is [complete],\" acknowledged Djokovic, who has spent more weeks as No. 1 in the PIF ATP Rankings than any other player (428). \"I'm telling myself always that I am enough, because I can be very self-critical. It's probably one of the biggest internal battles that I keep on fighting with myself, that I don't feel like I've done enough. That I haven't been enough in my life, on the court and off the court, so it's a big lesson for me.\n\n\"I'm super grateful for the blessing to win a historic gold medal for my country, to complete {"uri": "8259047565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:01:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:01:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:00:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/paris-2024-olympics-djokovic-gold-medal-alcaraz-silver-pressure-playing-for-spain-loss/article68486125.ece", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Alcaraz says pressure of playing for Spain got to him in loss to Djokovic in Olympics final", "body": "Emotional and unable to hold back tears, Carlos Alcaraz needed a moment to compose himself after losing to Novak Djokovic in the men's tennis singles final at the Paris Olympics on Sunday.\n\nThere would be no youngest-ever champion and no repeating Rafael Nadal's feat of winning a gold medal for Spain in his first attempt in singles.\n\nAlcaraz settled for silver after a 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) loss to Djokovic at Court Philippe Chatrier, saying the pressure of playing for his country got to him.\n\n\"I think I put more pressure on myself because I was playing for Spain, for the Spaniards,\" he said. \"I felt that I let the Spanish people down by not winning the gold.\"\n\nThe 21-year-old Alcaraz said he had not felt that type of pressure in the four Grand Slam finals that he played -- and won -- so far in his career.\n\n\"It was a different type of pressure,\" he said. \"Everyone in Spain wanted me to win the gold, and I wanted to win the gold as well.\"\n\nAlcaraz said the extra pressure cost him especially in the decisive moments of the game.\n\n\"In those difficult moments I usually raise my level, but I wasn't able to do that today,\" he said. \"Probably I felt the pressure in those situations. You play four Grand Slams every year, the Olympics is only once every four years.\"\n\nAlcaraz said there was still reason for him to be proud after \"knowing that I gave everything.\"\n\n\"Obviously this week, this tournament has been really special for me,\" he said. \"I'm going to take it for the rest of my life, for the rest of my career, for sure. Playing with Rafa, getting my first Olympics medal -- hopefully not the last one -- it's been a special one.\"\n\nAlcaraz arrived in Paris amid the hype of playing the doubles tournament alongside his childhood idol Nadal, who won the singles gold in his Olympic debut in Beijing in 2008.\n\nAlcaraz and Nadal lost 6-2, 6-4 to the fourth-seeded American duo of Austin Krajicek and Rajeev Ram in last week's quarterfinals.\n\nThe game against Djokovic was a rematch of the past two Wimbledon finals, both won by Alcaraz, including last month.\n\n\"In the close moments, in the difficult situations, in the tiebreakers, he played an impressive game,\" Alcaraz said of Djokovic. \"He was hungry for the gold medal. {"uri": "2024-08-443732949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:24:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:24:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:26:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.wfxg.com/news/djokovic-wins-olympic-gold-to-complete-career-golden-slam/article_ab60a719-7655-56f5-af35-c560dea4b754.html", "title": "Djokovic wins Olympic gold to complete career Golden Slam", "body": "Novak Djokovic defeated Carlos Alcaraz on Sunday to claim a maiden Olympic title and become just the fifth player to complete a career Golden Slam.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serb, competing in his fifth Games, came through 7-6 (7/3), 7-6 (7/2) in an enthralling final at Roland Garros to add Olympic gold to his 24 Grand Slam triumphs.\n\nVictory allowed him to join Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf and the watching Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold.\n\nHe also became the oldest singles champion since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988 and shattered Alcaraz's bid to add gold to the French Open and Wimbledon titles he has already pocketed this summer.\n\nAn emotional Djokovic celebrated by holding aloft the Serbian flag on court before clambering into the players' box to embrace his wife and children.\n\n\"We almost played three hours, the final shot was the only moment when I was sure I could win the match,\" said Djokovic, who had lost heavily to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final last month.\n\n- 'Finally I did it' -\n\n\"I put my body, my family on the line to win gold and finally I did it.\"\n\nAlcaraz was distraught and wept as he attempted to conduct a TV interview.\n\n\"Three hours, a big battle with tough moments,\" said the 21-year-old after a final in which neither player dropped serve. \"It's very painful to lose.\"\n\nDjokovic carved out a break point in the second game of the opener and three more in the fourth, all saved by the Spaniard.\n\nThen it was the Serb's turn to demonstrate his famed powers of resilience, fighting off three break points in the fifth game and another five in a marathon ninth game.\n\nIn a rollercoaster duel, Alcaraz saved a set point in the 12th game but his veteran opponent dominated the tiebreak to claim the opener after a breathless 93 minutes on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nThere was no let-up in the second set, scintillating shot-making alongside rousing defence with Alcaraz fighting off the final's 14th break point in the third game.\n\nAgain the set was decided by a tie-break and it was Djokovic with history on the line again sweeping through to take victory after two hours and 50 minutes.\n\nLorenzo Musetti defeated Felix Auger-Aliassime in three sets on Saturday to claim the bronze medal, giving Italy its first men's tennis medal in 100 years.\n\nLater Sunday, Russian athletes can claim their first gold of the Games when Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider face the Italian team of Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini in the women's doubles.\n\nRussian competitors are taking part in the Olympics as neutrals following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine in February, 2022.\n\nIf Andreeva and Shnaider win gold, their achievement will not be recognised in the medals table while both the Russian flag and national anthem will be banned from the podium ceremony.\n\nCristina Bucsa and Sara Sorribes Tormo, the Spanish eighth seeds, defeated the Czech pair of Karolina Muchova and Linda Noskova 6-2, 6-2 in the bronze medal match.\n\ndj/jw", {"uri": "8259132610", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:58:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:58:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:56:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.dailyfinland.fi/sports/38885/Djokovic-completes-trophy-collection-with-Olympic-gold-at-Paris", "title": "Djokovic completes trophy collection with Olympic gold at Paris", "body": "Novak Djokovic claimed gold in the Olympic men's singles tournament, defeating second seed Carlos Alcaraz in straight sets 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2), while Italians Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini defeated Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider 2-6, 6-2, 10-7 in the women's doubles to claim gold, reported Xinhua.\n\nThe men's final, played at the absolute highest standard, was an immensely tight affair in which neither man was able to break the other and both sets were decided by tiebreaks.\n\nThe atmosphere inside Court Philippe-Chatrier was electric as fans flocked to see the culmination of the collision course both men had been on throughout the tournament.\n\nDjokovic, with three wins to Alcaraz's two in head-to-head battles, arrived on court with his usual dedicated support from his passionate traveling Serbian fans.\n\nThe Serbian number one seed immediately put Alcaraz under pressure. After cruising through the opening game, Djokovic took the young Spaniard to deuce in the second game. After a near five-minute fight for the point, the Spaniard finally held his serve.\n\nThe reality of Alcaraz's early game was equal parts sheer brilliance, with a series of effortless drop shots and precise winners, and frustrating errors, committing numerous unforced errors to give Djokovic free points.\n\nOn the other hand, Djokovic was relentless, machine-like, taking Alcaraz to deuce again in the fourth game before Alcaraz was once again forced to fight to hold his serve.\n\nYet, in the fifth game, it was Alcaraz's turn to take Djokovic into deuce on his serve as both men refused to give an inch. The battle between the relentless Djokovic and Alcaraz's pure talent and scrappiness was evident.\n\nIn the ninth game, Alcaraz missed five separate break points before Djokovic had to show some Alcaraz-like aggressiveness to secure his serve after an incredible 18 points in the game.\n\nNow the match had become a breathless fight over every point as each man looked to dominate from the baseline and at the net.\n\nDespite half chances and minor opportunities, neither was able to find the gap in the other's defense as the first set went to a tiebreak, which Djokovic won 7-3.\n\nMatching each other early in the tiebreak, Djokovic pulled away after Alcaraz hit three unforced errors before the Serb pounced on the set point to drop the ball out of Alcaraz's reach.\n\nThe fight continued in the second set with an unrelenting battle over each point. The third game once again saw Alcaraz fight from break point to save his serve, but both men maintained their service games and nullified the other's attacks.\n\nAs the level of tennis continued to rise, so did the volume inside Court Philippe-Chatrier as fans roared on their men.\n\nEqual to each other, the second set once again went to a tiebreak, with the gold medal on the line for Djokovic and a third set decider for Alcaraz. The tiebreak opened in Djokovic's favor with a threaded diagonal forehand winner as the bar continued to be set higher and higher. Another, even tighter forehand winner for the fifth point shifted the momentum straight in his favor.\n\nAfter another forehand winner down the line, a couple of Alcaraz unforced errors, and one final forehand ground stroke winner, Djokovic won his first Olympic gold.\n\nFollowing the win, Djokovic climbed into the crowd to hug his family and team before a wave of emotion crashed over him. The win represents Serbia's second gold medal at the Olympics.\n\nThe final day of tennis action also saw the medals for the women's doubles decided.\n\nIn the last match of the tournament, the women's doubles pair of Errani and Paolini came from behind to win gold, Italy's second medal following the bronze in the men's singles.\n\nAfter a slow start, the Italian pair steadily picked up their form and improved throughout the match, outlasting Andreeva and Shnaider in the third set tiebreak.", "source": {"uri": "dailyfinland.fi", "dataType": "news", "title": "clickittefaq"}, {"uri": "8258979414", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:34:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:34:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:32:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/uksport/2024/08/04/novak-djokovik-says-olympic-win-his-best-yet-and-starts-dreaming-of-california/", "title": "Novak Djokovik says Olympic win his best yet - and starts dreaming of California", "body": "Novak Djokovic declared beating Carlos Alcaraz to finally win Olympic gold his biggest sporting achievement - and then set his sights on competing again in Los Angeles.\n\nThe Serbian first played in the Games back in 2008 but he arrived in Paris with only one bronze medal to show for his efforts and a burning desire to stand on the top step of the podium.\n\nHe lost in straight sets to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final only three weeks ago and had not won a title all season but, playing in the red of Serbia at Roland Garros, the 37-year-old produced a superb performance to win a pulsating final 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2).\n\nWhen his final forehand found the corner, Djokovic dropped his racket and turned to his corner in delight and disbelief before lying on the court, his ultimate goal finally realised.\n\nThe 37-year-old then climbed into the stands and cried uncontrollably as he embraced his family and supporters.\n\nAsked if he had doubted the moment would ever come, Djokovic said: \"Absolutely I had doubts but the belief and the conviction that I can make it is stronger than my doubts.\n\n\"It always has been the case throughout my career and I knew that it's going to happen, it was just a matter of when.\n\n\"I have to deal with that, I have to try to silence all the noise around me and focus on what needs to be done on the court. And that's the biggest battle to win.\n\n\"I'm super thrilled that I managed to do it here in the way that I did it, against a guy who is the best in the world at the moment. I'm just over the moon.\n\n\"Everything that I felt in that moment when I won really surpassed everything I thought or hoped that it would. I thought that carrying the flag at the opening ceremony (in London) was the best feeling ever until I experienced this today.\n\nDjokovic's powers had appeared to be waning this season, with Alcaraz and fellow young gun Jannik Sinner taking charge, but he has not ruled out playing into his 40s and having another shot at the Olympics in 2028.\n\n\"I still want to play in Los Angeles,\" he said. \"I enjoy playing for my country and the Olympic Games particularly and Davis Cup, being part of the team.\"\n\nHe joins Serena Williams, Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi and Steffi Graf as just the fifth player to complete the career Golden Slam of all four grand slam titles and Olympic singles gold.\n\nDjokovic still needs one more slam title to reach 25 and hold the all-time singles record, which could come at the US Open next month.\n\nOn whether he has 'completed' tennis, he added: \"Yes it's complete because I completed all the achievements with this gold medal but no because I love this sport. I don't play only to win the tournaments.\n\n\"I don't know about the future, I really want to be in the present moment to celebrate. It was a long journey, many, many years of dreaming to be holding the gold medal. So now it's about happiness, joy and celebration.\"\n\nThere was a remarkable intensity to the contest right from the start, with rallies of supreme quality and chances for both.\n\nAlcaraz recovered from 0-40 in the fourth game but then could not take any of eight break points, five of them at 4-4.\n\nAlcaraz broke down in tears during a TV interview on court but was able to reflect later with pride on taking silver on his Olympic debut.\n\n\"In front of me I had a really hungry Novak,\" said the 21-year-old, who has won each of his four slam finals.\n\n\"His level was really, really high. He didn't let me take the chances. I'm really proud and I'm leaving the court and leaving the tournament with my head really, really high, knowing that I gave everything that I could.\n\n\"This tournament has been really special for me, I'm going to take it for the rest of my life. Playing with Rafa (Nadal), having those feelings, getting my first Olympic medal - hopefully not the last one.\"\n\nBronze went to Lorenzo Musetti, and Italy were able to celebrate gold in the women's The elusive trophy had been claimed. At 37-years-old, he was the Olympic champion in the men's singles tennis competition. The triumph for himself and Serbia came 16 years after winning bronze at the Beijing Olympics.\n\nDjokovic claimed the prize with an intense 7-6, 7-6 victory over Spain's Carlos Alcaraz, the man who beat him in straight sets on 14 July to win the Wimbledon title for a second time at his expense.\n\nBut that was on grass in south-west London. On Court Philippe Chatrier at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris, Djokovic had the psychological advantage of a success last year in the semi-final of the French Open.\n\nBilled as a clash of generations, that match fizzled out into a Djokovic stroll as the then 20-year-old Alcaraz suffered with cramps due to the pressure of entering a tournament as world number one and playing a crunch tie against legend of the sport.\n\nAlcaraz vowed to learn from his four-set defeat. Then, after an embrace with Alcaraz, he dropped to his knees in exhaustion and emotion and stayed down for nearly a minute. Then he went into the stands, embracing his team and family.\n\n\u27a4 Get Olympics updates in your texts! Join USA TODAY Sports' WhatsApp Channel\n\nEven for a man with 24 Grand Slam titles and nearly every significant record in the sport, this is the crowning achievement that he has long sought. Because this one wasn't just for himself, it was for his beloved Serbia.\n\nAfter gutting defeats in Rio and Tokyo, Djokovic wanted this badly. Even built his year around it. But after injuring his knee during the French Open and having meniscus surgery, it was unclear whether he would even be healthy enough to play the Olympics.\n\nBut Djokovic managed to return in time for Wimbledon, getting to the finals before Alcaraz crushed him in three sets.\n\nThis one was tightly played throughout, with no breaks of serve on either side. The Spanish superstar already has four Grand Slam titles to his name, and he's only 21 years old. But even he can't beat an all-time legend like Novak Djokovic, who was hellbent on achieving his greatest goal.\n\nSunday saw Alcaraz get taken to school by an experienced Djokovic in the men's gold medal singles final in Paris. For Djokovic, it's one of the crowning moments of his career, especially in taking apart a young phenom like Alcaraz to do it. For Alcaraz, he was the youngest man in the men's Olympic final in over a century, and it's a great accomplishment to attain silver.\n\nBut it still hurts to fall short for your country when you have a chance at ultimate glory:\n\nAfter the match, Alcaraz explained why he was moved to tears and why he'll ultimately hold his head high, understanding he'll likely have more opportunities for gold down the line:\n\nThat's exactly the right perspective.\n\nAlcaraz is a competitor, so losing is never easy when you reach the doorstep of a new achievement. But there's also no reason to wallow in sadness over what could've been. Recognizing that you gave it your all and still left the Olympics with a medal -- which is no small feat -- still means the world.\n\nAlcaraz's time for Olympic gold will come. {"uri": "8258826898", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:49:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:49:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:47:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/my-europe/2024/08/04/djokovic-wins-his-first-olympic-gold-medal-after-beating-alcaraz-in-mens-tennis-final", "title": "Djokovic wins his first Olympic gold after beating Alcaraz", "body": "Novak Djokovic won his first Olympic gold medal by beating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an enthralling men's tennis singles final Sunday, giving the 37-year-old from Serbia the last significant accomplishment missing from his glittering resume.\n\nDjokovic's career already featured a men's-record 24 Grand Slam titles and the most weeks spent at No. 1 in the rankings by any man or woman. It also already contained a Summer Olympics bronze medal from 2008 -- but he has made clear that simply was not sufficient.\n\nThe final in Paris, which lasted 2 hours, 50 minutes, was a rematch of the Wimbledon title match three weeks ago that Alcaraz, 21, won to follow up his French Open title in June.\n\nAlcaraz also defeated Djokovic in last year's final at the All England Club, but Djokovic won when they met in the semi-finals of the 2023 French Open.\n\nSunday's contest was an enthralling matchup. Most remarkable, was how cleanly both men played, despite the talent of the opposition and pressure of the occasion. Unforced errors were rare.\n\nThe only shame, perhaps, for the fans -- and, naturally, the loser -- was that the Olympics uses a best-of-three-set format, instead of the best-of-five at Grand Slam tournaments. Make no mistake, this encounter between the No. 1-seeded Djokovic and No. 2-seeded Alcaraz was worthy of a major final, and no one fortunate enough to hold a ticket could complain about not getting their money's worth.\n\nThose in the stands became part of the show, repeatedly breaking out into choruses of \"No-le! No-le!\" or \"Car-los! Car-los!\" that often overlapped, creating an operatic fugue. In the second set, as Alcaraz attempted to mount a comeback, his supporters began chanting, \"Si, se puede!\" (essentially, \"Yes, you can!\") while shaking their red-and-yellow flags.\n\nBoth men played to the crowd. When Alcaraz raced to reach one drop shot and deposit it over the net for a winner, he basked in the raucous reaction by pointing his right index finger to his ear. When Djokovic laced a cross-court forehand winner on the run to cap a 10-shot point to lead 3-2 in the second tiebreaker, he waved both arms overhead to encourage folks who already were on their feet, screaming.\n\nAfter winning, Djokovic turned toward his team in the stands -- sitting in front of his wife and their two children -- and dropped his racket as he knelt on the clay. As emotional as ever, he cried and covered his face, then rose and grabbed a red-white-and-blue Serbian flag. After hugs in the stands, Djokovic waved that flag. Alcaraz wept afterward, too.", "source": {"uri": "euronews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Euronews English"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz", {"uri": "2024-08-443829770", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:22:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:22:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:11:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/news/world/2024/08/05/olympics--djokovic-completes-trophy-collection-with-olympic-gold-at-paris", "title": "Olympics | Djokovic completes trophy collection with Olympic gold at Paris", "body": "PARIS, Aug. 4 (Xinhua) -- Novak Djokovic claimed gold in the Olympic men's singles tournament, defeating second seed Carlos Alcaraz in straight sets 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2), while Italians Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini defeated Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider 2-6, 6-2, 10-7 in the women's doubles to claim gold.\n\nThe men's final, played at the absolute highest standard, was an immensely tight affair in which neither man was able to break the other and both sets were decided by tiebreaks.\n\nThe atmosphere inside Court Philippe-Chatrier was electric as fans flocked to see the culmination of the collision course both men had been on throughout the tournament.\n\nDjokovic, with three wins to Alcaraz's two in head-to-head battles, arrived on court with his usual dedicated support from his passionate traveling Serbian fans.\n\nThe Serbian number one seed immediately put Alcaraz under pressure. After cruising through the opening game, Djokovic took the young Spaniard to deuce in the second game. After a near five-minute fight for the point, the Spaniard finally held his serve.\n\nThe reality of Alcaraz's early game was equal parts sheer brilliance, with a series of effortless drop shots and precise winners, and frustrating errors, committing numerous unforced errors to give Djokovic free points.\n\nOn the other hand, Djokovic was relentless, machine-like, taking Alcaraz to deuce again in the fourth game before Alcaraz was once again forced to fight to hold his serve.\n\nYet, in the fifth game, it was Alcaraz's turn to take Djokovic into deuce on his serve as both men refused to give an inch. The battle between the relentless Djokovic and Alcaraz's pure talent and scrappiness was evident.\n\nIn the ninth game, Alcaraz missed five separate break points before Djokovic had to show some Alcaraz-like aggressiveness to secure his serve after an incredible 18 points in the game.\n\nNow the match had become a breathless fight over every point as each man looked to dominate from the baseline and at the net.\n\nDespite half chances and minor opportunities, neither was able to find the gap in the other's defense as the first set went to a tiebreak, which Djokovic won 7-3.\n\nMatching each other early in the tiebreak, Djokovic pulled away after Alcaraz hit three unforced errors before the Serb pounced on the set point to drop the ball out of Alcaraz's reach.\n\nThe fight continued in the second set with an unrelenting battle over each point. The third game once again saw Alcaraz fight from break point to save his serve, but both men maintained their service games and nullified the other's attacks.\n\nAs the level of tennis continued to rise, so did the volume inside Court Philippe-Chatrier as fans roared on their men.\n\nEqual to each other, the second set once again went to a tiebreak, with the gold medal on the line for Djokovic and a third set decider for Alcaraz. The tiebreak opened in Djokovic's favor with a threaded diagonal forehand winner as the bar continued to be set higher and higher. Another, even tighter forehand winner for the fifth point shifted the momentum straight in his favor.\n\nAfter another forehand winner down the line, a couple of Alcaraz unforced errors, and one final forehand ground stroke winner, Djokovic won his first Olympic gold.\n\nFollowing the win, Djokovic climbed into the crowd to hug his family and team before a wave of emotion crashed over him. The win represents Serbia's second gold medal at the Olympics.\n\nThe final day of tennis action also saw the medals for the women's doubles decided.\n\nIn the last match of the tournament, the women's doubles pair of Errani and Paolini came from behind to win gold, Italy's second medal following the bronze in the men's singles.\n\nAfter a slow start, the Italian pair steadily picked up their form and improved throughout the match, outlasting Andreeva and Shnaider in the third set tiebreak.\n\nSpain's Cristina Bucsa and Sara Sorribes Tormo claimed bronze in straight sets, 6-2, 6-2, against Czechia's Karolina Muchova and Linda Noskova.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com.my", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star "}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8258975152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:28:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:28:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:27:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.somersetcountygazette.co.uk/sport/national/24496848.novak-djokovik-says-olympic-win-best-yet---starts-dreaming-california/", "title": "Novak Djokovik says Olympic win his best yet - and starts dreaming of California", "body": "Novak Djokovic declared beating Carlos Alcaraz to finally win Olympic gold his biggest sporting achievement - and then set his sights on competing again in Los Angeles.\n\nThe Serbian first played in the Games back in 2008 but he arrived in Paris with only one bronze medal to show for his efforts and a burning desire to stand on the top step of the podium.\n\nHe lost in straight sets to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final only three weeks ago and had not won a title all season but, playing in the red of Serbia at Roland Garros, the 37-year-old produced a superb performance to win a pulsating final 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2).\n\nWhen his final forehand found the corner, Djokovic dropped his racket and turned to his corner in delight and disbelief before lying on the court, his ultimate goal finally realised.\n\nThe 37-year-old then climbed into the stands and cried uncontrollably as he embraced his family and supporters.\n\nAsked if he had doubted the moment would ever come, Djokovic said: \"Absolutely I had doubts but the belief and the conviction that I can make it is stronger than my doubts.\n\n\"It always has been the case throughout my career and I knew that it's going to happen, it was just a matter of when.\n\n\"Olympic Games come every four years so the opportunity to win gold for your country is very rare and I knew the fact that I'm 37 and I don't know how many more chances I'll have, I knew everything.\n\n\"I have to deal with that, I have to try to silence all the noise around me and focus on what needs to be done on the court. And that's the biggest battle to win.\n\n\"I'm super thrilled that I managed to do it here in the way that I did it, against a guy who is the best in the world at the moment. I'm just over the moon.\n\n\"Everything that I felt in that moment when I won really surpassed everything I thought or hoped that it would. I thought that carrying the flag at the opening ceremony (in London) was the best feeling ever until I experienced this today.\n\n\"And being on that court with the Serbian flag raising, singing the Serbian anthem, with the gold around my neck, I think nothing can beat that in terms of professional sport. It definitely stands out as the biggest sporting achievement I had.\"\n\nDjokovic's powers had appeared to be waning this season, with Alcaraz and fellow young gun Jannik Sinner taking charge, but he has not ruled out playing into his 40s and having another shot at the Olympics in 2028.\n\n\"I still want to play in Los Angeles,\" he said. \"I enjoy playing for my country and the Olympic Games particularly and Davis Cup, being part of the team.\"\n\nHe joins Serena Williams, Rafael Nadal, Andre Agassi and Steffi Graf as just the fifth player to complete the career Golden Slam of all four grand slam titles and Olympic singles gold.\n\nDjokovic still needs one more slam title to reach 25 and hold the all-time singles record, which could come at the US Open next month.\n\nOn whether he has 'completed' tennis, he added: \"Yes it's complete because I completed all the achievements with this gold medal but no because I love this sport. I don't play only to win the tournaments.\n\n\"I don't know about the future, I really want to be in the present moment to celebrate. It was a long journey, many, many years of dreaming to be holding the gold medal. So now it's about happiness, joy and celebration.\"\n\nThere was a remarkable intensity to the contest right from the start, with rallies of supreme quality and chances for both.\n\nAlcaraz recovered from 0-40 in the fourth game but then could not take any of eight break points, five of them at 4-4.\n\nAlcaraz broke down in tears during a TV interview on court but was able to reflect later with pride on taking silver on his Olympic debut.\n\n\"In front of me I had a really hungry Novak,\" said the 21-year-old, who has won each of his four slam finals.\n\n\"His level was really, really high. He didn't let me take the chances. I'm really proud and I'm leaving the court and leaving the tournament with my head really, really high, knowing that I gave everything that I could.\n\n\"This tournament has been really special for me, I'm going to take it for the rest of my life. Playing with Rafa (Nadal), having those feelings, getting my first Olympic medal - hopefully not the last one.\"\n\nBronze went to Lorenzo Musetti, and Italy were able to celebrate gold in the women's doubles, with Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini beating Russian duo Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider, who were playing as neutral athletes.", "source": {"uri": "somersetcountygazette.co.uk", {"uri": "2024-08-443722834", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:11:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:11:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.espn.com.au/olympics/story/_/id/40718988/2024-paris-summer-olympics-live-updates-highlights-schedule-results-sunday", "title": "Djokovic, Scheffler strike gold and more from Sunday at the Paris Games", "body": "The second Sunday of the 2024 Paris Games includes a handful of Team USA's biggest names vying for medals.\n\nSuni Lee earned a bronze on uneven bars, the same event in which she earned bronze at the Tokyo Games in 2021. She's the first American to medal twice on bars in Olympic history.\n\nOn the track, Noah Lyles will look to earn a medal in the men's 100-meter final. But first he must advance past the semifinals. Lyles admitted he underestimated the field in his preliminary round run on Saturday, finishing second in the race.\n\nSunday marks the last day of the swimming events at the Paris Games with three finals. Team USA's Gretchen Walsh can win her fourth medal of Paris in the women's 50-meter freestyle, while American swimmer Kate Douglass looks for the same total as she competes in the women's 4x100-meter medley relay.\n\nAlso headlining Sunday's events was the men's singles gold medal match in Tennis. In a rematch of the Wimbledon 2024 final, Novak Djokovic dispatched Carlos Alcaraz at Roland Garros to give Djokovic, of Serbia, his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nScott Scheffler shot a course record-tying 62 to come from behind to win gold.\n\n11:26 a.m. ET -- Djokovic wins the one title missing from his resume ... Olympic gold\n\nNovak Djokovic is an Olympic gold medalist at last.\n\nAfter a career filled with history-making accomplishments and 24 major titles, the 37-year-old finally achieved the lone achievement that has eluded him in four previous Olympic appearances.\n\nAnd he did it with a statement-making win over Carlos Alcaraz, his young rival who defeated him in the Wimbledon final just three weeks ago. Needing tiebreaks in both sets, Djokovic ultimately got the job done, 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an epic battle full of electrifying rallies and highlight reel-worthy points.\n\nIt has been a tough season for Djokovic -- he hadn't won a title all year entering the Olympics, marking his worst start of a season since 2006 -- and he underwent knee surgery in June. He was understandably emotional at the match's conclusion on Sunday.\n\nWhen it was over he immediately crouched in near-disbelief, and then seconds later, after exchanging a warm hug with Alcaraz, he went back out onto the court and fell to his knees. He leaned over and remained there as the crowd -- even those who had been waving Spanish flags -- gave him a standing ovation.\n\nDjokovic then sobbed in his chair before running over to his family with a Serbian flag. He hugged his children while still crying.\n\nAfter advancing to Sunday's final -- already resulting in his best result at the Olympics -- Djokovic said he was ecstatic to know he was bringing home a medal.\n\n\"Just to secure a higher medal for the first time for my country, whatever happens on Sunday, [there's] huge pride, honor and happiness,\" Djokovic said. \"It's why I celebrated [on court] the way I did, and I still feel like I need to celebrate that because it's a big success.\"\n\nDjokovic now joins Serena Williams, who was in attendance for part of the match, as the only Olympic singles champions to not drop a set en route to the gold.\n\nThe silver marked the 21-year-old Alcaraz's first Olympic medal. Italy's Lorenzo Musetti earned the bronze medal on Friday with a three-set win over Canada's Felix Auger Aliassime.\n\n10:35 a.m. ET -- Suni Lee wins bronze, Kaylia Nemour makes history for Algeria\n\nThree days after earning her second Olympic all-around medal, Suni Lee earned her second bronze in uneven bars. She now holds six Olympic medals, with one more opportunity in Monday's balance beam final.\n\nLee was the last gymnast to compete in the uneven bars final and needed to score higher than 14.766 to bump Belgium's Nina Derwael, the reigning Olympic champ, off the podium. Lee qualified third into the final with a 14.866 and earned an identical score during Thursday's all-around. Just like in that meet, she mounted the bars knowing a medal was within her grasp.\n\nHer performance was nearly flawless until she took one step on her landing. The crowd erupted when her score appeared. She didn't match her qualifying score, but her 14.8 was once again good enough for bronze.\n\nAlgeria's Kaylia Nemour, 17, the reigning world silver medalist on uneven bars, won Africa's first ever Olympic medal in gymnastics. She scored a massive 15.7, earned by combining a 7.2 difficulty score with excellent execution. Born and raised in France, Nemour competed for France until 2022, and this crowd reacted with no less pride when she stuck her double-layout dismount than for every French gymnast who's competed here in Paris.\n\nSeventeen-year-old Qiu Qiyuan of China hit a flawless routine with gorgeous lines and time-stopping handstands and nailed her landing. She matched Nemour's incredible difficulty score but earned two-tenths lower in execution for a 15.5 and bronze.\n\nEarlier in the afternoon, China's Yang Liu won gold in the rings, followed by his teammate, Jingyuan Zou, who earned silver. Greece's Eleftherios Petrounias took bronze.\n\nFrance's Samir Ait Said dismounted to a Biles-like response from this majority French crowd. His score placed him just off the medals podium in fourth place and let's just say the crowd did not agree with the judging panel. -- Alyssa Roenigk\n\n9:58 a.m. ET -- Djokovic inches closer to golden glory\n\nJust one set stands between Novak Djokovic and his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe Olympic title has been perhaps the only thing in the sport Djokovic, the 24-time major champion, has yet to win and he's been open about just how much it would mean to him. On Sunday, facing Carlos Alcaraz, his young nemesis, Djokovic was pushed to the brink but ultimately held off the 21-year-old Spaniard in a tiebreak, 7-6 (3), to take the opening set.\n\nIt's so far been a far more compelling match than their lopsided clash in the Wimbledon final just three weeks ago. Alcaraz won that match in dominant fashion, 6-2, 6-2, 7-6 (4), and needed just two hours and 28 minutes. Today's opening set lasted 93 minutes.\n\nThe near-capacity crowd on Court Philippe-Chatrier, which includes Serena Williams, has been electric throughout with fan loyalty seemingly divided between the two superstars. At one point late in the first set, they simultaneously chanted \"No-vak\" and \"Car-los\" until neither name was identifiable.\n\nDjokovic, who had knee surgery less than two months ago and is still wearing a brace, called Alcaraz the \"favorite\" entering the match, and he has been animated throughout the match during the big points. In his four previous Olympic appearances, his best result was a bronze medal in 2008.\n\nSince tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, Williams (2012) is the only singles champion to have won the gold medal without dropping a set. Djokovic is on track to join her, but will he able to hold on? We'll find out soon enough. -- D'Arcy Maine\n\n9:43 a.m. ET -- Anthony Edwards continues to make the most of his time in Paris\n\nTeam USA men's basketball is on a mission in France to bring home gold and show the world that the road to basketball glory still runs through the U.S. But that doesn't mean they're not enjoying the ride along the way -- and no player is enjoying the ride more than Edwards.\n\nThe star Minnesota Timberwolves guard has thrived on the court -- highlighted by his 26-point outing in the squad's last game against Puerto Rico, windmill dunk and all. But off the court he's been getting the full Olympic experience as well: table tennis fandom and all. -- READ MORE\n\n9:27 a.m. ET -- Rahm looking to close things out\n\nJon Rahm was tied for first place entering men's golf's fourth and final round. Now, halfway through a gold-medal-deciding round, he stands alone in front of the pack. Through nine holes, he has shot a torrid 5-under par -- just one other competitor in the field has been better so far Sunday. Rahm's lead in first place has grown to three strokes with nine holes left to play.\n\n9:21 a.m. ET -- A star-studded men's tennis singles final\n\nIt would be difficult to prearrange a better gold medal match then the one that the Olympic men's tennis singles bracket delivered. Just weeks after meeting in the Wimbledon final, 37-year-old legend Novak Djokovic will square off once more with ascendant 21-year-old star Carlos Alcaraz. They have played each other six times head-to-head, entering their latest match with an even 3-3 record. Djokovic took home victory in their lone meeting at Roland Garros, with the win coming in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open.\n\n8:36 a.m. ET -- More trouble in the Seine\n\nThe saga of the Seine continues at the 2024 Games, as it was determined late Saturday night that training for the triathlon mixed relay event would be canceled due to concerns with the water's quality -- not the first time this Games where the river's quality has caused delays.\n\nRain leading up to Saturday created heightened levels of pollution in the river, a similar cause to the postponement of the men's triathlon competition earlier in the week.\n\n8:14 a.m. ET -- An unconventional racing strategy\n\nThe Olympics have marked the debut of the repechage round in certain track and field events, a second chance for competitors who failed to qualify for the semifinals from their preliminary heats. For American Freddie Crittenden, the new wrinkle offered a chance to alter his approach to the competition.\n\nWith his heat in the 110-meter hurdles looming, Crittenden knew he was nursing a minor injury that might hold him back. His solution? Intentionally jog out the initial heat to save energy for the repechage round.\n\nHad Crittenden gone all-in on the heat, he would have needed to finish third place or better to qualify automatically, and if that didn't happen, he would be running in the repechage round anyway. Why not take the opportunity to tax his still-not-100% body a little less than his competition ahead of the second-chance round, Crittenden reasoned.\n\n\"I decided to just not make an emotional choice,\" he said after the heat. \"Make a smart choice. Give my body time to recover a little bit from being aggravated.\"\n\n7:29 a.m. ET -- Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone starts off gold medal defense strong\n\nHaving just broken her own world record in the 400m hurdles earlier this summer -- the fifth time she's reset the world record in the event -- expectations couldn't have been much higher for McLaughlin-Levrone as she entered her first chance to run her signature event in Paris.\n\nShe still met them in stride though, leading the pack throughout her heat by a considerable margin en route to a comfortable first round success. McLaughlin-Levron will race in the event's semifinal round on Tuesday.\n\n7:14 a.m. ET -- 'Powerful' American 200m sprinters win heats\n\nTeam USA's women's sprinters got off to very strong start Sunday morning at Stade de France, when all three 200-meter runners won their respective opening-round heats.\n\nIt started with two-time Olympian Gabby Thomas. The current world's No. 2 in the event breezed through the second heat in 22.20 seconds, easing up in the final 10 meters after it was clear she would win and move on to the semifinal. Thomas' time held up as the fastest for the day.\n\nFollowing Thomas' run, 2024 NCAA champion McKenzie Long dominated her first round in 22.55 seconds, and fellow first-time Olympian Brittany Brown cruised to her own victory in 22.38 seconds.\n\nAll three Americans will be in Monday's semifinal.\n\n\"My coach wanted me to go out there and win, but be dominant and smooth and in control and that's what we did,\" Brown said.\n\nBrown ran a comfortable race, coming out the blocks quickly and owning the heat from start to finish. Her first few steps were filled with power -- just like her eyelids.\n\nSporting glittering nails and a purple and blue eye shadow, Brown raced in style. She said the fitting eye shadow was part of Danessa Myrick's \"I am\" palette series. The specific eye shadow Brown went with Sunday?\n\n\"I am powerful,\" Brown said.\n\nFor the semifinals, she said she plans on trotting out the \"I am brave\" color series, \"because I'm going to need to be brave.\"\n\nA first-time Olympian, the 29-year-old's top international accomplishment to this point was a silver earned at the 2019 world championships.\n\nMoments before the start of Sunday's 200-meter races, Jamaican favorite Shericka Jackson withdrew. It remains unclear why she pulled out of the race. Her non-start came one day after her countrywoman Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce also withdrew from the 100 meters due to an injury, her coach said.\n\nJackson also pulled out of the 100 meters just before the Olympics began, but indicated she was not injured. --Coley Harvey\n\n7:11 a.m. ET -- Scheffler finding his groove\n\nScottie Scheffler spent the first three rounds of the Olympic golf circuit lingering between sixth and 10th place. Now, the world No. 1 is heating up and making a move. Back-to-back birdies have fired Scheffler to a 3-under par start to the fourth and final round, and he's climbed up the standings to third position, just one stroke back from the first-place tie between Spain's Jon Rahm and American teammate Xander Schauffele. Rahm and Schauffele teed off for the final round roughly 20 minutes after Scheffler got underway.\n\n6:50 a.m. ET -- Holloway cruises in preliminary heat\n\nThe reigning back-to-back world champion in the 110-meter hurdles, Grant Holloway arrived in Paris with intentions of upgrading his silver medal from the 2020 Games to gold.\n\nHe looked on pace to just that in a dominant Round 1 showing, flying out of the blocks en route to a blistering 13.01 finish -- good for the best time from any first round heat.", "source": {"uri": "espn.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, But he defied odds by returning in time for Wimbledon, where he made the final.\n\nAnd he followed that up by defeating Alcaraz -- the French Open and Wimbledon champion -- in a thrilling Olympic final.\n\nDjokovic owns a men's record 24 Grand Slam titles but had never won the gold medal before. He joined an elite group that includes Steffi Graff (1988), Andre Agassi (1999), Rafael Nadal (2010) and Serena Williams (2012).\n\n\"This is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had and {"uri": "8259503826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:56:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:56:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:55:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/djokovic-paris-2024-olympics-tennis-gold-beat-alcaraz-hails-greatest-sporting-achievement/article68487213.ece", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Djokovic hails gold as his greatest sporting achievement", "body": "Novak Djokovic described beating Carlos Alcaraz to claim the Olympic singles gold medal at the fifth attempt as the biggest achievement of his career on Sunday.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serb ended an eight-month trophy drought with a vintage display to win 7-6(3), 7-6(2) and complete his career Golden Slam in memorable fashion, not dropping a set in six matches at Roland Garros.\n\nHe is the oldest man to win the Olympic singles title since tennis returned to the Games in 1988 and remarkably he did it 21 days after being pummelled by Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final and two months after undergoing knee surgery.\n\n\"I won the bronze in my first Olympic Games (2008) and ever since then failed to win the medal and played three out of four Olympic Games in semi-finals and couldn't overcome that obstacle,\" Djokovic, proudly wearing his medal, told reporters.\n\n\"And then now at age 37, with a 21-year-old that is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back and playing incredible tennis.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I've ever had in my career.\"\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam champion produced a level of tennis that has been missing this year to fight off Alcaraz.\n\nAfter belting away a forehand winner to end a ferocious, near three-hour battle, the emotion poured out of Djokovic as he sobbed on court before climbing into the stands to embrace his family, including wife Jelena and son Stefan, and his team.\n\n\"Until today I thought that carrying the Serbian flag at the 2012 opening ceremony in London is the best feeling that an athlete could have,\" he said.\n\n\"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience and that I could feel.\"\n\nDjokovic did not rule out playing at the Los Angeles Olympics in 2028, but said the realisation that Paris was probably his last swing at gold had motivated him.\n\n\"I was ready for this tournament and I didn't drop a set the entire tournament,\" he said. \"I knew in the opening two rounds the way I was playing that this is my chance. If it's ever going to be, it's going to be now.\n\n\"When I qualified for the finals, I felt a big relief because that's the hurdle I wasn't able to surpass. I did celebrate like I won the tournament. But of course I wanted gold and I knew that I would have to climb the highest mountain there is at the moment, playing Alcaraz.\"\n\nDjokovic saved eight break points during a match of stunning quality and intensity -- the Serb describing the duel as like few others he had ever experienced.\n\n\"I don't think I've ever played, maybe a few times in my life, such a high level for three hours for only two sets,\" he said. \"Credit to him, congratulations to him for a great tournament, great fighting spirit.\"\n\nLatest on SportstarPremier League Next Gen Cup 2024 Final: Stellenbosch {"uri": "8259734025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:47:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:47:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:45:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://ummid.com/news/2024/august/04-08-2024/novak-djokovic-wins-olympics-gold-at-37.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic wins Olympics Gold at 37", "body": "Paris: In a remarkable display of grit, top seed Novak Djokovic won his first Gold Medal at the Olympics defeating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in Men's Tennis Sunday August 04.\n\nWorld No. 2 Tennis Player Novak Djokovic has won a gigantic 24 Grand Slams in his long career.\n\nBut, despite a remarkable and astonishingly long career in Men's Tennis, one thing that the 37-yar-old Serbian Tennis Star, probably at the fag end of his career, wanted was the Olympics Gold for his country.\n\nHe finally got one in Paris Sunday.\n\n\"I put my heart, my soul, my body, my family -- my everything, on the line to win Olympic Gold,\" Djokovic, emotionally charged, said after the victory.\n\n\"Incredible battle. Incredible fight\", he added.\n\nNovak Djokovic, who spent the most weeks atop in the rankings by any man or woman, had earlier won Summer Olympics medal in 2008. But it was a Bronze.\n\nDjokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in Olympics Tennis since 1908 -- and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest.\n\nWhen the victory was his, when the gold was his, thanks to one last forehand winner, Djokovic turned toward his team in the stands -- sitting in front of his wife and their two children -- dropped his racket and knelt on the clay.\n\nAs emotional as ever, he cried and covered his face, then rose and grabbed a red-white-and-blue Serbian flag.\n\nAfter hugs in the stands, Djokovic waved that flag.\n\n\"In the tough moments, he gave it an extra push. It hurts to lose like this\", Silver medalist Alcaraz said through his own tears.\n\nNovak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz had clashed only 20 days ago at 2024 Men's Singles Final in Wimbledon. {"uri": "8260050900", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:07:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:07:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:06:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://technosports.co.in/novak-djokovic-paris-olympics-2024-novak-djokov/", "title": "Novak Djokovic - Paris Olympics 2024 : Novak Djokovic Wins Gold Medal at Paris Olympics 2024, Shares Emotional Moment with Daughter", "body": "Novak Djokovic - Paris Olympics 2024 : On Sunday, August 4, 2024, Serbian tennis star Novak Djokovic experienced a moment of pure joy and triumph as he clinched his maiden Olympic gold medal in the Men's Singles at the Paris Olympics. This victory not only marked a significant milestone in his illustrious career but also created a heartwarming moment that captivated the world.\n\nDjokovic's path to Olympic gold was anything but easy. He faced Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in a nail biting final, ultimately prevailing in two tightly contested sets, 7-6, 7-6. The match showcased the exceptional talent and resilience of both players, but it was Djokovic who emerged victorious, achieving a dream that had eluded him for years.\n\nAs the final point was won, the 37 year old Djokovic was overwhelmed with emotion. He broke down in tears, the weight of his accomplishment fully sinking in. This gold medal was more than just a personal victory; it was a moment of national pride for Serbia. Djokovic had previously won a bronze medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, but this gold solidified his status among the legends of the sport.\n\nDjokovic's emotional reaction reached its peak when he rushed to the stands to embrace his family. His daughter, Tara, was there to share the moment, holding up a sign that read, \"Tata je najbolji,\" meaning \"Dad is the best.\" The heartfelt hug between father and daughter quickly went viral, touching hearts around the globe.\n\nWith this victory, Djokovic joined the elite ranks of tennis players who have achieved the Career Golden Slam. This prestigious list includes Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, and Serena Williams. The Career Golden Slam is achieved when a player wins all four Grand Slam titles and an Olympic gold medal. Djokovic's triumph in Paris added another golden chapter to his already storied career, which includes 24 Grand Slam titles.\n\nDjokovic's journey to this point has been marked by unparalleled dedication and resilience. He has held the World No. 1 ranking for a record 428 weeks and finished as the year end No. 1 a record eight times. His 24 Grand Slam titles include an astounding 10 Australian Open victories. With his Olympic gold, Djokovic now has 72 major titles, including 40 Masters 1000 titles and 7 ATP Finals.\n\nThe 2024 Paris Olympics were a redemption of sorts for Djokovic. In the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, he narrowly missed out on a bronze medal, finishing fourth. In the 2016 Rio Olympics, he suffered a heartbreaking first round exit. This gold medal, therefore, was not just a win but a testament to his perseverance and indomitable spirit.\n\nThe internet exploded with reactions to the viral video of Djokovic's emotional celebration with his daughter. The sight of one of the greatest tennis players of all time, in tears and sharing a tender moment with his family, resonated deeply with fans and sports enthusiasts alike. Comments flooded social media, praising Djokovic's perseverance and the touching nature of the moment.\n\nOne user on X (formerly Twitter) encapsulated the sentiment perfectly: \"Wow - have never seen Djokovic this emotional ... incredible Sports.\" Another commented, \"He waited for this moment 16 years. Wow.\"\n\nAs Djokovic basked in the glory of his Olympic triumph, he also set his sights on the future. At 37, he continues to defy the odds, showing that age is merely a number when it comes to greatness. {"uri": "8258864419", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:25:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:25:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:25:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/djokovic-wins-olympic-gold-to-complete-career-golden-slam/article_6daed5c7-8e0e-5fe7-bc4e-83f0da6347b5.html", "title": "Djokovic wins Olympic gold to complete career Golden Slam", "body": "Novak Djokovic defeated Carlos Alcaraz on Sunday to claim a maiden Olympic title and become just the fifth player to complete a career Golden Slam.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serb, competing in his fifth Games, came through 7-6 (7/3), 7-6 (7/2) in an enthralling final at Roland Garros to add Olympic gold to his 24 Grand Slam triumphs.\n\nVictory allowed him to join Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf and the watching Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold.\n\nHe also became the oldest singles champion since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988 and shattered Alcaraz's bid to add gold to the French Open and Wimbledon titles he has already pocketed this summer.\n\nAn emotional Djokovic celebrated by holding aloft the Serbian flag on court before clambering into the players' box to embrace his wife and children.\n\n\"We almost played three hours, the final shot was the only moment when I was sure I could win the match,\" said Djokovic, who had lost heavily to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final last month.\n\n- 'Finally I did it' -\n\n\"I put my body, my family on the line to win gold and finally I did it.\"\n\nAlcaraz was distraught and wept as he attempted to conduct a TV interview.\n\n\"Three hours, a big battle with tough moments,\" said the 21-year-old after a final in which neither player dropped serve. \"It's very painful to lose.\"\n\nDjokovic carved out a break point in the second game of the opener and three more in the fourth, all saved by the Spaniard.\n\nMore from this section Vietnam's Communist Party names To Lam top leader Philippines says Chinatown fire kills 11 Colombia rebels to halt attacks during UN biodiversity summit\n\nThen it was the Serb's turn to demonstrate his famed powers of resilience, fighting off three break points in the fifth game and another five in a marathon ninth game.\n\nIn a rollercoaster duel, Alcaraz saved a set point in the 12th game but his veteran opponent dominated the tiebreak to claim the opener after a breathless 93 minutes on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nThere was no let-up in the second set, scintillating shot-making alongside rousing defence with Alcaraz fighting off the final's 14th break point in the third game.\n\nAgain the set was decided by a tie-break and it was Djokovic with history on the line again sweeping through to take victory after two hours and 50 minutes.\n\nLorenzo Musetti defeated Felix Auger-Aliassime in three sets on Saturday to claim the bronze medal, giving Italy its first men's tennis medal in 100 years.\n\nLater Sunday, Russian athletes can claim their first gold of the Games when Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider face the Italian team of Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini in the women's doubles.\n\nRussian competitors are taking part in the Olympics as neutrals following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine in February, 2022.\n\nIf Andreeva and Shnaider win gold, their achievement will not be recognised in the medals table while both the Russian flag and national anthem will be banned from the podium ceremony.\n\nCristina Bucsa and Sara Sorribes Tormo, the Spanish eighth seeds, defeated the Czech pair of Karolina Muchova and Linda Noskova 6-2, 6-2 in the bronze medal match.\n\ndj/jw", "source": I can't wait for what's coming up in the next 48 hours.\"\n\nAnd it was not long before fans could gain a glimpse into what the star meant by this, as he was later spotted dancing with his fellow Serbian athletes after arriving back in the Olympic village.\n\nIn a video, Djokovic can be seen dancing joyfully in the middle of a circle whilst draped in a Serbia flag, as his teammates skip around him with traditional music playing in the background.\n\nPrior to this, the 37-year-old had enjoyed the momentous occasion with some of his fans, embracing supporters gathered outside of the Philippe Chatrier court, and jumping up and down to their chanting of his name.\n\nThe jubilant scenes could arguably have been predicted ahead of the tournament, as Djokovic made it clear just how much he wanted to clinch the only prize that has eluded him in his career.\n\nIn a video uploaded on TikTok before his first match at the Paris Games, the all-time great is shown praying for a gold medal.\n\nDespite winning bronze whilst still 21 at Beijing 2008, he then failed to upgrade his medal in the three Olympic campaigns which followed, Djokovic's age meant that this summer was surely his last realistic chance of answering his prayers.\n\nAnd the sporting legend certainly had to be at his best to write his name into history, with Spain's Alcaraz coming into the final off the back of successive Grand Slam wins at Roland Garros and Wimbledon.\n\nThe latter major victory came against Djokovic just three weeks ago, where he was beaten convincingly in straight sets, but there was to be no repeat of this in the Games decider.\n\nAfter the match, Alcaraz also struggled to contain his emotions, as he was reduced to tears in his on-court interview.\n\nOn losing the final, he remarked: \"It's painful to lose the way I lost this match. The match was a thrilling display of skill and determination, with Djokovic showcasing his signature precision and resilience.\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam champion was visibly emotional, dropping to his knees with tears of joy as he celebrated the historic win. The crowd chanted his name as he climbed into the stands to share the moment with his family.\n\nThis victory not only added an Olympic gold to Djokovic's already impressive career but also marked his ascent to the top of modern tennis. {"uri": "8258801420", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:21:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:21:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:21:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.nbcdfw.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/novak-djokovic-defeats-carlos-alcaraz-gold-medal-2024-paris-olympics/3611307/", "title": "The GOAT wins gold! Djokovic secures career golden slam in Olympics win vs. Carlos Alcaraz", "body": "Djokovic secured the first gold medal of his illustrious tennis career\n\nNovak Djokovic has earned one of the most prestigious honors a tennis player can achieve: a career golden slam.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serbian took down Spain's Carlos Alcaraz 7-6, 7-6 on Sunday to win his first-ever gold medal at the Olympics.\n\nDjokovic is among an exclusive company with Steffi Graff (1988), Andre Agassi (1999), Rafael Nadal (2010) and Serena Williams (2012) to achieve the career golden slam feat. The honor is earned when a player wins all four Grand Slams and an Olympic gold in singles.\n\nTennis fans could truly see how much Sunday's match meant to the 24-time Grand Slam champion as he clearly displayed his best tennis of 2024. He sealed the victory with a forehand inside in winner and dropped to the Roland-Garros clay in tears.\n\nDjokovic has one other medal to his name. He earned a bronze medal in men's singles in 2008 Beijing.\n\nIn the last tennis match of the Games, Italy's Jasmine Paolini and Sara Errani will take on AIN's Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider for I'm building a great career, I guess, I hope it's gonna keep going.\n\n\"Obviously, I'm really proud to be in this position. I'm really proud to bring a medal to Spain,\" Alcaraz told NBC's Britney Eurton. \"I'm pretty sure my moment will come. {"uri": "8258787190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:08:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:08:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:07:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.express.co.uk/sport/tennis/1931920/Novak-Djokovic-Carlos-Alcaraz-Olympics-2024-final-gold-medal", "title": "Novak Djokovic in tears after winning Olympic gold as Serb gets Alcaraz revenge", "body": "History was on the line as Djokovic and Alcaraz took to Court Philippe-Chatrier for their seventh meeting. Djokovic sought the one accolade that has always evaded him. It was likely his last chance, given that he will be 41 years old for the LA 2028 Games. Meanwhile, Alcaraz hoped to continue an incredible summer after winning the French Open and Wimbledon.\n\nBoth men were playing for the gold medal for the first time. Before this year, Djokovic had a 0/3 record in Olympics semi-finals while Alcaraz had never played in the Games. Under the watchful eye of four-time gold medallist Serena Williams, seated in the front row, Alcaraz survived a marathon opening game, saving a break point to level at 1-1.\n\nThe fans were divided - they to-and-froed between chants of \"Nole\" and cries of \"Carlos\". After digging himself out of a 0-30 hole, the Serb had three more chances to break. He ripped a forehand return winner straight past Alcaraz and the 15,000-strong crowd responded with a chorus of \"Idemo\". But the 21-year-old saved them all and Djokovic could only laugh as the fickle fans turned, booing when he moaned towards his box after missing his chances.\n\nIt was the world No. 2's turn to save three break points but, like Alcaraz, he held on and the rollercoaster continued. The ninth game became a significant battle, lasting 15 minutes as Djokovic saved five more break points and roared in celebration. It looked like it could be crucial but Alcaraz held his nerve and kept himself in the set for 5-5.", "source": {"uri": "express.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "EXPRESS"}, "authors": [{"uri":
