{"uri": "8258836181", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:58:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:58:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:57:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://africa.espn.com/olympics/story/_/id/40718988/2024-paris-summer-olympics-live-updates-highlights-schedule-results-sunday", "title": "Djokovic, Scheffler strike gold and more from Sunday at the Paris Games", "body": "The second Sunday of the 2024 Paris Games includes a handful of Team USA's biggest names vying for medals.\n\nSuni Lee earned a bronze on uneven bars, the same event in which she earned bronze at the Tokyo Games in 2021. She's the first American to medal twice on bars in Olympic history.\n\nOn the track, Noah Lyles will look to earn a medal in the men's 100-meter final. But first he must advance past the semifinals. Lyles admitted he underestimated the field in his preliminary round run on Saturday, finishing second in the race.\n\nSunday marks the last day of the swimming events at the Paris Games with three finals. Team USA's Gretchen Walsh can win her fourth medal of Paris in the women's 50-meter freestyle, while American swimmer Kate Douglass looks for the same total as she competes in the women's 4x100-meter medley relay.\n\nAlso headlining Sunday's events was the men's singles gold medal match in Tennis. In a rematch of the Wimbledon 2024 final, Novak Djokovic dispatched Carlos Alcaraz at Roland Garros to give Djokovic, of Serbia, his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nHere's what to look out for on Sunday.\n\nScott Scheffler shot a course record-tying 62 to come from behind to win gold.\n\nNovak Djokovic is an Olympic gold medalist at last.\n\nAfter a career filled with history-making accomplishments and 24 major titles, the 37-year-old finally achieved the lone achievement that has eluded him in four previous Olympic appearances.\n\nAnd he did it with a statement-making win over Carlos Alcaraz, his young rival who defeated him in the Wimbledon final just three weeks ago. Needing tiebreaks in both sets, Djokovic ultimately got the job done, 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in an epic battle full of electrifying rallies and highlight reel-worthy points.\n\nIt has been a tough season for Djokovic -- he hadn't won a title all year entering the Olympics, marking his worst start of a season since 2006 -- and he underwent knee surgery in June. He was understandably emotional at the match's conclusion on Sunday.\n\nWhen it was over he immediately crouched in near-disbelief, and then seconds later, after exchanging a warm hug with Alcaraz, he went back out onto the court and fell to his knees. He leaned over and remained there as the crowd -- even those who had been waving Spanish flags -- gave him a standing ovation.\n\nDjokovic then sobbed in his chair before running over to his family with a Serbian flag. He hugged his children while still crying.\n\nAfter advancing to Sunday's final -- already resulting in his best result at the Olympics -- Djokovic said he was ecstatic to know he was bringing home a medal.\n\n\"Just to secure a higher medal for the first time for my country, whatever happens on Sunday, [there's] huge pride, honor and happiness,\" Djokovic said. \"It's why I celebrated [on court] the way I did, and I still feel like I need to celebrate that because it's a big success.\"\n\nDjokovic now joins Serena Williams, who was in attendance for part of the match, as the only Olympic singles champions to not drop a set en route to the gold.\n\nThe silver marked the 21-year-old Alcaraz's first Olympic medal. Italy's Lorenzo Musetti earned the bronze medal on Friday with a three-set win over Canada's Felix Auger Aliassime.\n\nThree days after earning her second Olympic all-around medal, Suni Lee earned her second bronze in uneven bars. She now holds six Olympic medals, with one more opportunity in Monday's balance beam final.\n\nLee was the last gymnast to compete in the uneven bars final and needed to score higher than 14.766 to bump Belgium's Nina Derwael, the reigning Olympic champ, off the podium. Lee qualified third into the final with a 14.866 and earned an identical score during Thursday's all-around. Just like in that meet, she mounted the bars knowing a medal was within her grasp.\n\nHer performance was nearly flawless until she took one step on her landing. The crowd erupted when her score appeared. She didn't match her qualifying score, but her 14.8 was once again good enough for bronze.\n\nAlgeria's Kaylia Nemour, 17, the reigning world silver medalist on uneven bars, won Africa's first ever Olympic medal in gymnastics. She scored a massive 15.7, earned by combining a 7.2 difficulty score with excellent execution. Born and raised in France, Nemour competed for France until 2022, and this crowd reacted with no less pride when she stuck her double-layout dismount than for every French gymnast who's competed here in Paris.\n\nSeventeen-year-old Qiu Qiyuan of China hit a flawless routine with gorgeous lines and time-stopping handstands and nailed her landing. She matched Nemour's incredible difficulty score but earned two-tenths lower in execution for a 15.5 and bronze.\n\nEarlier in the afternoon, China's Yang Liu won gold in the rings, followed by his teammate, Jingyuan Zou, who earned silver. Greece's Eleftherios Petrounias took bronze.\n\nFrance's Samir Ait Said dismounted to a Biles-like response from this majority French crowd. His score placed him just off the medals podium in fourth place and let's just say the crowd did not agree with the judging panel. -- Alyssa Roenigk\n\nJust one set stands between Novak Djokovic and his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe Olympic title has been perhaps the only thing in the sport Djokovic, the 24-time major champion, has yet to win and he's been open about just how much it would mean to him. On Sunday, facing Carlos Alcaraz, his young nemesis, Djokovic was pushed to the brink but ultimately held off the 21-year-old Spaniard in a tiebreak, 7-6 (3), to take the opening set.\n\nIt's so far been a far more compelling match than their lopsided clash in the Wimbledon final just three weeks ago. Alcaraz won that match in dominant fashion, 6-2, 6-2, 7-6 (4), and needed just two hours and 28 minutes. Today's opening set lasted 93 minutes.\n\nThe near-capacity crowd on Court Philippe-Chatrier, which includes Serena Williams, has been electric throughout with fan loyalty seemingly divided between the two superstars. At one point late in the first set, they simultaneously chanted \"No-vak\" and \"Car-los\" until neither name was identifiable.\n\nDjokovic, who had knee surgery less than two months ago and is still wearing a brace, called Alcaraz the \"favorite\" entering the match, and he has been animated throughout the match during the big points. In his four previous Olympic appearances, his best result was a bronze medal in 2008.\n\nSince tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, Williams (2012) is the only singles champion to have won the gold medal without dropping a set. Djokovic is on track to join her, but will he able to hold on? We'll find out soon enough. -- D'Arcy Maine\n\nTeam USA men's basketball is on a mission in France to bring home gold and show the world that the road to basketball glory still runs through the U.S. But that doesn't mean they're not enjoying the ride along the way -- and no player is enjoying the ride more than Edwards.\n\nThe star Minnesota Timberwolves guard has thrived on the court -- highlighted by his 26-point outing in the squad's last game against Puerto Rico, windmill dunk and all. But off the court he's been getting the full Olympic experience as well: table tennis fandom and all. -- READ MORE\n\nJon Rahm was tied for first place entering men's golf's fourth and final round. Now, halfway through a gold-medal-deciding round, he stands alone in front of the pack. Through nine holes, he has shot a torrid 5-under par -- just one other competitor in the field has been better so far Sunday. Rahm's lead in first place has grown to three strokes with nine holes left to play.\n\nIt would be difficult to prearrange a better gold medal match then the one that the Olympic men's tennis singles bracket delivered. Just weeks after meeting in the Wimbledon final, 37-year-old legend Novak Djokovic will square off once more with ascendant 21-year-old star Carlos Alcaraz. They have played each other six times head-to-head, entering their latest match with an even 3-3 record. Djokovic took home victory in their lone meeting at Roland Garros, with the win coming in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open.\n\nThe saga of the Seine continues at the 2024 Games, as it was determined late Saturday night that training for the triathlon mixed relay event would be canceled due to concerns with the water's quality -- not the first time this Games where the river's quality has caused delays.\n\nRain leading up to Saturday created heightened levels of pollution in the river, a similar cause to the postponement of the men's triathlon competition earlier in the week.\n\nThe Olympics have marked the debut of the repechage round in certain track and field events, a second chance for competitors who failed to qualify for the semifinals from their preliminary heats. For American Freddie Crittenden, the new wrinkle offered a chance to alter his approach to the competition.\n\nWith his heat in the 110-meter hurdles looming, Crittenden knew he was nursing a minor injury that might hold him back. His solution? Intentionally jog out the initial heat to save energy for the repechage round.\n\nHad Crittenden gone all-in on the heat, he would have needed to finish third place or better to qualify automatically, and if that didn't happen, he would be running in the repechage round anyway. Why not take the opportunity to tax his still-not-100% body a little less than his competition ahead of the second-chance round, Crittenden reasoned.\n\n\"I decided to just not make an emotional choice,\" he said after the heat. \"Make a smart choice. Give my body time to recover a little bit from being aggravated.\"\n\nHaving just broken her own world record in the 400m hurdles earlier this summer -- the fifth time she's reset the world record in the event -- expectations couldn't have been much higher for McLaughlin-Levrone as she entered her first chance to run her signature event in Paris.\n\nShe still met them in stride though, leading the pack throughout her heat by a considerable margin en route to a comfortable first round success. McLaughlin-Levron will race in the event's semifinal round on Tuesday.\n\nTeam USA's women's sprinters got off to very strong start Sunday morning at Stade de France, when all three 200-meter runners won their respective opening-round heats.\n\nIt started with two-time Olympian Gabby Thomas. The current world's No. 2 in the event breezed through the second heat in 22.20 seconds, easing up in the final 10 meters after it was clear she would win and move on to the semifinal. Thomas' time held up as the fastest for the day.\n\nFollowing Thomas' run, 2024 NCAA champion McKenzie Long dominated her first round in 22.55 seconds, and fellow first-time Olympian Brittany Brown cruised to her own victory in 22.38 seconds.\n\nAll three Americans will be in Monday's semifinal.\n\n\"My coach wanted me to go out there and win, but be dominant and smooth and in control and that's what we did,\" Brown said.\n\nBrown ran a comfortable race, coming out the blocks quickly and owning the heat from start to finish. Her first few steps were filled with power -- just like her eyelids.\n\nSporting glittering nails and a purple and blue eye shadow, Brown raced in style. She said the fitting eye shadow was part of Danessa Myrick's \"I am\" palette series. The specific eye shadow Brown went with Sunday?\n\n\"I am powerful,\" Brown said.\n\nFor the semifinals, she said she plans on trotting out the \"I am brave\" color series, \"because I'm going to need to be brave.\"\n\nA first-time Olympian, the 29-year-old's top international accomplishment to this point was a silver earned at the 2019 world championships.\n\nMoments before the start of Sunday's 200-meter races, Jamaican favorite Shericka Jackson withdrew. It remains unclear why she pulled out of the race. Her non-start came one day after her countrywoman Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce also withdrew from the 100 meters due to an injury, her coach said.\n\nJackson also pulled out of the 100 meters just before the Olympics began, but indicated she was not injured. --Coley Harvey\n\nScottie Scheffler spent the first three rounds of the Olympic golf circuit lingering between sixth and 10th place. Now, the world No. 1 is heating up and making a move. Back-to-back birdies have fired Scheffler to a 3-under par start to the fourth and final round, and he's climbed up the standings to third position, just one stroke back from the first-place tie between Spain's Jon Rahm and American teammate Xander Schauffele. Rahm and Schauffele teed off for the final round roughly 20 minutes after Scheffler got underway.\n\nThe reigning back-to-back world champion in the 110-meter hurdles, Grant Holloway arrived in Paris with intentions of upgrading his silver medal from the 2020 Games to gold.\n\nHe looked on pace to just that in a dominant Round 1 showing, flying out of the blocks en route to a blistering 13.01 {"uri": "8259043739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:56:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:56:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:54:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.pehalnews.in/latest/alcaraz-admits-feeling-overwhelmed-by-pressure-of-representing-spain-in-loss-to-djokovic-at-olympics/4955/", "title": "Alcaraz admits feeling overwhelmed by pressure of representing Spain in loss to Djokovic at Olympics - Pehal News", "body": "PARIS -- Overwhelmed and unable to control his emotions, Carlos Alcaraz required a moment to gather himself after being defeated by Novak Djokovic in the men's tennis singles final at the Paris Olympics on Sunday.\n\nThere would be no record-breaking champion and no replicating Rafael Nadal's achievement of securing a gold medal for Spain in his initial try in singles.\n\nAlcaraz settled for silver after a 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) defeat to Djokovic at Court Philippe Chatrier, citing the burden of representing his country as a contributing factor.\n\n\"I believe I placed more stress on myself because I was playing for Spain, for the Spaniards,\" he expressed. \"I sensed that I disappointed the Spanish populace by failing to secure the gold.\"\n\nThe 21-year-old Alcaraz mentioned that he had not experienced that kind of strain in the four Grand Slam finals that he participated in -- and emerged victorious -- thus far in his career.\n\n\"It was a different kind of pressure,\" he remarked. \"Everyone in Spain was rooting for me to secure the gold, and I was eager to achieve that as well.\"\n\nAlcaraz noted that the added pressure hindered him, particularly during the critical junctures of the match.\n\n\"In those challenging moments, I typically elevate my performance, but I failed to do so today,\" he commented. \"Perhaps I succumbed to the pressure in those instances. You compete in four Grand Slams every year, whereas the Olympics occur only once every four years.\"\n\nDespite the outcome, Alcaraz found solace in \"knowing that I exerted my utmost effort.\"\n\n\"Undeniably, this week, this tournament has held significant meaning for me,\" he shared. \"I will carry it with me throughout my life, throughout my career, without a doubt. Competing with Rafa, securing my first Olympics medal -- hopefully not the final one -- has been a remarkable experience.\"\n\nAlcaraz arrived in Paris amidst the excitement of participating in the doubles tournament alongside his childhood idol Nadal, who clinched the singles gold in his Olympic premiere in Beijing in 2008.\n\nAlcaraz and Nadal suffered a 6-2, 6-4 defeat to the fourth-seeded American pair of Austin Krajicek and Rajeev Ram in last week's quarterfinals.\n\nThe showdown against Djokovic marked a rematch of the previous two Wimbledon finals, both secured by Alcaraz, including the most recent one.\n\n\"During the crucial moments, in the tough situations, in the tiebreaks, he exhibited remarkable gameplay,\" Alcaraz remarked about Djokovic. \"He was hungry for the gold medal. "Djokovic wins Olympic gold to complete career Golden Slam", "body": "Novak Djokovic defeated Carlos Alcaraz on Sunday to claim a maiden Olympic title and become just the fifth player to complete a career Golden Slam.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serb, competing in his fifth Games, came through 7-6 (7/3), 7-6 (7/2) in an enthralling final at Roland Garros to add Olympic gold to his 24 Grand Slam triumphs.\n\nVictory allowed him to join Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf and the watching Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold.\n\nHe also became the oldest singles champion since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988 and shattered Alcaraz's bid to add gold to the French Open and Wimbledon titles he has already pocketed this summer.\n\nAn emotional Djokovic celebrated by holding aloft the Serbian flag on court before clambering into the players' box to embrace his wife and children.\n\n\"We almost played three hours, the final shot was the only moment when I was sure I could win the match,\" said Djokovic, who had lost heavily to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final last month.\n\n- 'Finally I did it' -\n\n\"I put my body, my family on the line to win gold and finally I did it.\"\n\nAlcaraz was distraught and wept as he attempted to conduct a TV interview.\n\n\"Three hours, a big battle with tough moments,\" said the 21-year-old after a final in which neither player dropped serve. \"It's very painful to lose.\"\n\nDjokovic carved out a break point in the second game of the opener and three more in the fourth, all saved by the Spaniard.\n\nThen it was the Serb's turn to demonstrate his famed powers of resilience, fighting off three break points in the fifth game and another five in a marathon ninth game.\n\nIn a rollercoaster duel, Alcaraz saved a set point in the 12th game but his veteran opponent dominated the tiebreak to claim the opener after a breathless 93 minutes on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nThere was no let-up in the second set, scintillating shot-making alongside rousing defence with Alcaraz fighting off the final's 14th break point in the third game.\n\nAgain the set was decided by a tie-break and it was Djokovic with history on the line again sweeping through to take victory after two hours and 50 minutes.\n\nLorenzo Musetti defeated Felix Auger-Aliassime in three sets on Saturday to claim the bronze medal, giving Italy its first men's tennis medal in 100 years.\n\nLater Sunday, Russian athletes can claim their first gold of the Games when Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider face the Italian team of Sara Errani and Jasmine Paolini in the women's doubles.\n\nRussian competitors are taking part in the Olympics as neutrals following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine in February, 2022.\n\nIf Andreeva and Shnaider win gold, their achievement will not be recognised in the medals table while both the Russian flag and national anthem will be banned from the podium ceremony.\n\nCristina Bucsa and Sara Sorribes Tormo, the Spanish eighth seeds, defeated the Czech pair of Karolina Muchova and Linda Noskova 6-2, 6-2 in the bronze medal match.\n\ndj/jw\n\nMore After a whole career dedicated to tennis, winning any kind of trophy that came before him, he managed to put on the gold medal at the Olympic Games. {"uri": "8258835570", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:57:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:57:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:56:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-08-05/paris-olympic-games-novak-djokovic-wins-first-olympic-gold-medal/104182360", "title": "From tears of misery to tears of joy as Novak Djokovic gets the one tennis accolade he was missing", "body": "For a man so accustomed to winning, Novak Djokovic's Olympic record simply didn't add up.\n\nNow, after a thrilling 7-6(7/3), 7-6(7/2) win over Carlos Alcaraz in the Paris Olympics gold-medal match, the 24-time grand slam champion finally has the only piece of hardware as yet missing from his trophy cabinet.\n\nDjokovic owned the Roland Garros court against an opponent 16 years his junior, not with outstanding athleticism, but with nerveless play in the biggest moment.\n\nThree years earlier, Djokovic's Tokyo campaign ended in a shocking on-court breakdown as he lost to Pablo Carre\u00f1o Busta in the bronze-medal match, pulling out of the mixed doubles bronze contest soon after.\n\nThis time, the emotions were perhaps just as raw and there were still plenty of tears as he fell to the red clay in Paris before leaping into the stands to embrace his family, but it was entirely understandable.\n\nSixteen years after claiming what we all assumed would be the first of many Olympic medals with bronze in Beijing, Djokovic finally earned his second and the first in the only colour he really wanted.\n\nFor a man who is often accused of being a bit too eager to be liked, the camera's close-up on his shaking hand after match point showed the reality of the moment for him.\n\nAfter Alcaraz's straight-sets win over Djokovic in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago signalled the official changing-of-the-guard in the men's game, Djokovic looked utterly unwilling to submit to that narrative. But nor would Alcaraz genuflect to the seniority of the Serb.\n\nAnd so the first set went on, for more than an hour-and-a-half.\n\nAlcaraz fought off five break points, including storming back from 0-40 down in the fourth game of the match, while Djokovic weathered eight, serving his way through six deuces to eventually reach 5-4.\n\nDjokovic appeared to be the one just hanging on in the match, with Alcaraz's athleticism, energy and shot-making drawing more than a few rounds of applause and approving wry smiles from the Serb.\n\nBut, when they reached the tie-break, Djokovic showed the poise of a man who's played 37 major finals, rattling off four straight points from the change of ends to take it 7-3.\n\nBoth players looked exhausted between sets -- Djokovic taking a comfort break to change clothes while Alcaraz sat on the court perhaps wondering how the man he so summarily dispatched on the London grass last month was suddenly taking his best shots on the clay at Roland Garros.\n\nAs the second set began, Alcaraz looked tired and uncharacteristically frustrated, but still neither player could break the other's serve.\n\nThe match carried on as it had started, although this time neither gave the other a sniff -- the only break point came in the third game and was quickly snuffed out by an Alcaraz forehand winner.\n\nAs the match approached the three-hour mark, the inevitable became clear once more as they traded holds to love and got back into the tie-break.\n\nAlcaraz, this year's French Open and Wimbledon champion, looked exhausted as his opponent rose to the occasion, powered by the knowledge this fifth Olympic campaign would surely be his last, and closed it out 7-2.\n\nAlcaraz will rue three unforced errors in the final breaker and while it is assumed the 21-year-old four-time grand slam winner will have plenty more chances, both his and Djokovic's post-match tears are evidence of the unique standing and challenge of Olympic glory.", The former world number 1 was not experiencing an exciting 2024 from a results point of view, having yet to win a title this year before today's feat.\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam champion was considered a clear underdog against Carlos Alcaraz in the gold medal final, but has once again proved to be an immortal legend of the sport. The 37-year-old from Belgrade has expressed his best tennis on the iconic Philippe Chatrier by reversing the predictions of the eve and finally realizing his dream of winning the gold medal for the his country. Nole prevailed in two tiebreaks, making a difference at decisive moments and punishing every mistake made by the young Spaniard. Carlitos was the big favorite on the eve of this final and played a great match, but he did not expect such a level from his opponent.\n\nThe 21-year-old from Murcia burst into tears at the end of the match, He wanted to win the gold medal for Spain and continue his unbeaten period after triumphs at the French Open and the Wimbledon Championships. Djokovic and Alcaraz will both miss the Montreal Masters 1000 next week and should return to the pitch in Cincinnati, the last test before the US Open at the end of August.\n\nThanks to this victory, Novak Djokovic achieved yet another feat of his legendary career. Looking at all his records, it's hard to argue that Nole isn't the greatest tennis player of all time. \"I'm overwhelmed with everything I'm feeling right now. Feeling different emotions. Too proud. Too happy. Thrilled with the possibility to win a gold for the first time in my career for my country,\" Novak Djokovic explained.\n\n\"Because I can be very self critical. I don't know. That's one of the biggest internal battles I keep on fighting with myself. That I feel like I haven't done enough or been enough in my life on and off the court. I know Carlos and Rafa (Nadal), they love to play for Spain. Andy (Murray) loved to play for Great Britain. Roger (Federer) for Switzerland. Alex Zverev won in Tokyo for Germany. You saw the reactions of all these guys when they win. It's something special,\" he added.\n\nThere are now few words to describe Novak Djokovic. When everyone seems to have finished it, he manages to impress again, win and convince as he has done in the last hours. The Serbian tennis player won the gold medal at the Paris Olympics, the last huge achievement that was missing from his immense palmar\u00e9s and now Nole has literally won everything possible and imaginable.\n\nSometimes critics of Djokovic find every means to denigrate his legend, Some even in the past has been able to say that Nole won Slam only thanks to lucky draws or episodic situations, the reality at 37 years is quite different. In the last few hours, an impressive figure has emerged on the Balkan tennis player, a figure that has returned to prominence after the victory against Alcaraz.\n\nWinning against the Spaniard at the Paris Olympics, Nole has once again made things clear and is now 4-3 ahead in the previous round with the Spanish, certainly not the only one in this situation. Novak Djokovic is ahead in the previous with all other tennis players present in the Top 15; it is 4 to 3 in front both against the world number one Jannik Sinner and against Carlos Alcaraz, The new one who advances but sees Nole still dominating. There are such clean dominance as the 9-0 in the previous match against Fritz or the 12-1 and 12-2 respectively against Grigor Dimitrov and Stefanos Tsitsipas.\n\nThe 37-year-old from Belgrade has beaten Carlos Alcaraz, who played a very good tournament and represents the future of this sport. \"Honestly, I always want to win. In receiving a silver medal, I have to be very proud. I suppose I am building a great career and I hope it continues. As I said, I am proud to be in this position and to bring a medal to Spain. I am quite certain that my time will come. Someday, I will bring the gold medal to Spain. I will wait for that moment and work towards it. {"uri": "8259014533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:18:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:18:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:16:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://home.nzcity.co.nz/news/article.aspx?id=403880&ref=rss", "title": "Paris Olympics: Novak Djokovic wins first gold medal in emotional final over Carlos Alcaraz", "body": "Novak Djokovic's Tokyo campaign ended in an on-court breakdown, and so too does his time in Paris, but this time his triumphant tears release 16 years of Olympic heartbreak.\n\nFor a man so accustomed to winning, Novak Djokovic's Olympic record simply didn't add up.\n\nNow, after a thrilling 7-6(7/3), 7-6(7/2) win over Carlos Alcaraz in the Paris Olympics gold-medal match, the 24-time grand slam champion finally has the only piece of hardware as yet missing from his trophy cabinet.\n\nDjokovic owned the Roland Garros court against an opponent 16 years his junior, not with outstanding athleticism, but with nerveless play in the biggest moment.\n\nThree years earlier, Djokovic's Tokyo campaign ended in a shocking on-court breakdown as he lost to Pablo Carre\u00f1o Busta in the bronze-medal match, pulling out of the mixed doubles bronze contest soon after.\n\nThis time, the emotions were perhaps just as raw and there were still plenty of tears as he fell to the red clay in Paris before leaping into the stands to embrace his family, but it was entirely understandable.\n\nSixteen years after claiming what we all assumed would be the first of many Olympic medals with bronze in Beijing, Djokovic finally earned his second and the first in the only colour he really wanted.\n\nFor a man who is often accused of being a bit too eager to be liked, the camera's close-up on his shaking hand after match point showed the reality of the moment for him.\n\nAfter Alcaraz's straight-sets win over Djokovic in the Wimbledon final three weeks ago signalled the official changing-of-the-guard in the men's game, Djokovic looked utterly unwilling to submit to that narrative. But nor would Alcaraz genuflect to the seniority of the Serb.\n\nAnd so the first set went on, for more than an hour-and-a-half.\n\nAlcaraz fought off five break points, including storming back from 0-40 down in the fourth game of the match, while Djokovic weathered eight, serving his way through six deuces to eventually reach 5-4.\n\nDjokovic appeared to be the one just hanging on in the match, with Alcaraz's athleticism, energy and shot-making drawing more than a few rounds of applause and approving wry smiles from the Serb.\n\nBut, when they reached the tie-break, Djokovic showed the poise of a man who's played 37 major finals, rattling off four straight points from the change of ends to take it 7-3.\n\nBoth players looked exhausted between sets -- Djokovic taking a comfort break to change clothes while Alcaraz sat on the court perhaps wondering how the man he so summarily dispatched on the London grass last month was suddenly taking his best shots on the clay at Roland Garros.\n\nAs the second set began, Alcaraz looked tired and uncharacteristically frustrated, but still neither player could break the other's serve.\n\nThe match carried on as it had started, although this time neither gave the other a sniff -- the only break point came in the third game and was quickly snuffed out by an Alcaraz forehand winner.\n\nAs the match approached the three-hour mark, the inevitable became clear once more as they traded holds to love and got back into the tie-break.\n\nAlcaraz, this year's French Open and Wimbledon champion, looked exhausted as his opponent rose to the occasion, powered by the knowledge this fifth Olympic campaign would surely be his last, and closed it out 7-2.\n\nAlcaraz will rue three unforced errors in the final breaker and while it is assumed the 21-year-old four-time grand slam winner will have plenty more chances, both his and Djokovic's post-match tears are evidence of the unique standing and challenge of Olympic glory.", {"uri": "2024-08-443801528", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:25:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:25:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:05:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2024-08-04-djokovic-triumphs-algerias-nemour-makes-history-in-gymnastics-and-scheffler-takes-golf-gold/", "title": "Djokovic triumphs, Algerian gymnast Nemour wins, Scheffler takes golf gold", "body": "In a breakthrough for gymnastics, an African competitor took gold in an apparatus final while Novak Djokovic and Scottie Scheffler triumphed in tennis and golf.\n\nAlgeria's Kaylia Nemour became the first African gymnast to win an Olympic medal when she secured the gold with a breathtaking routine on the asymmetric bars at the Paris Games on Sunday that wowed the crowd in Bercy Arena.\n\nIn tennis, Novak Djokovic completed his career Golden Slam as the 37-year-old Serb fought off Spain's Carlos Alcaraz in a magnificent Olympic men's singles final battle at Roland-Garros on Sunday.\n\nAfter heartbreak in Beijing, London, Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo, Djokovic simply would not be denied the one title that had eluded him for so long, winning 7-6(3) 7-6(2) in front of an enthralled crowd on Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nAnd at the Le Golf National course, World No 1 Scottie Scheffler won gold at the Olympic men's golf competition after matching the course record 62 in the final round to pip crowd favourite Tommy Fleetwood of Britain. Scheffler finished on 19-under, one stroke clear of Fleetwood.\n\nThe 17-year-old Nemour's fast-paced routine featuring complex release-and-catch manoeuvres delighted the crowd who came to support a gymnast who had previously represented France.\n\nFans roared and jumped to their feet as soon as Nemour completed her dismount. She immediately broke down in tears as she handed Algeria its first medal of the Paris Olympics, with her performance scoring a staggering 15.700 points.\n\nNemour was still in complete disbelief after the competition.\n\n\"I can't believe this is happening,\" the teenager said after winning her first gold medal at a major global competition. \"This is too much. I have no words.\"\n\nNemour was up after China's Qiu Qiyuan, the 2023 world champion, who had executed a spectacular routine to briefly top the standings with 15.500 points.\n\n\"When I saw her result of 15.500 points, I told myself that I would really need to fight,\" said Nemour. \"I refocused quickly and got the best mark of my life, and it was the right time to get it.\"\n\nThe Algerian Olympic Committee issued a statement calling Nemour a legend.\n\n\"You showed the world the strength and determination of Algeria with your wonderful victory,\" the statement said.\n\nUS gymnast Sunisa Lee, who claimed a second successive Olympic bronze on the apparatus with 14.800 points, could be seen cheering for Nemour throughout her routine.\n\n\"I was really aiming for the third place because I knew I actually really wanted Kaylia to win, just because she's so incredible,\" said Lee.\n\nNina Derwael of Belgium, the champion at the Tokyo Games, finished 0.034 of a point off the podium.\n\nTop seed Djokovic delivered one of the finest performances of his career to deny Alcaraz and become only the fifth player to win all four singles Grand Slams and the Olympic title.\n\nNeither player took a backward step in a ferocious contest in which the first set alone lasted one hour and 33 minutes as they wrestled for control in a series of spellbinding games.\n\nAlcaraz cracked first in the tiebreak and when another tiebreak was required to decide the second set, Djokovic again found another gear, sealing victory with a stunning forehand winner down the line.\n\nDjokovic roared to the sky and after consoling Alcaraz at the net he fell to his knees and sobbed in the centre of the court before climbing into the crowd to be swamped by his family, friends and team.\n\nWhile Djokovic, the oldest player to win the Olympic singles title since the sport returned to the Games in 1988, cried tears of joy, the 21-year-old Alcaraz was inconsolable after falling short of adding the gold medal to this year's French Open and Wimbledon crowns.\n\nDjokovic had lost three times in Olympic singles semifinals and knew this was his last realistic chance to fill the last remaining space in a trophy cabinet that contains a men's record 24 Grand Slam titles.\n\nAnd how he earned it -- overturning his crushing loss to Alcaraz in last month's Wimbledon final to become the first man to win the Olympic singles without dropping a set.\n\n\"It was an incredible fight and I had to play my best tennis,\" an emotional Djokovic told Eurosport before the medals ceremony as Serbian fans celebrated in the stands.\n\n\"It was fair that the two sets finished in tiebreaks. I put my heart, my soul, everything to win gold.\n\n\"I did it for my country first, for Serbia.\"\n\nDjokovic joins an elite club of Andre Agassi, Rafa Nadal, Serena Williams and Steffi Graf in winning all four Grand Slams and the Olympic title in their careers.\n\nScheffler shot a nine-under-par round of 62 to finish the tournament on 19 under par, one shot ahead of Fleetwood, who took silver.\n\nJapan's Hideki Matsuyama claimed the bronze medal a further shot back, improving on his tied fourth place on home soil in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThe Olympic title adds to a spectacular year for Scheffler, who bagged his second Masters title in April as part of six tour successes.\n\nHis scintillating bogey-free round let him overhaul a four-shot deficit against overnight joint leaders Xander Schauffele and Jon Rahm.\n\nSpaniard Rahm, a two-time major winner, surged into a four-shot lead after a sparkling front nine holes on Sunday before fading like US defending champion Schauffele.\n\nFleetwood stayed in contention until the end but a bogey on the 17th hole left him a shot behind Scheffler and he was unable to birdie the last hole to force a playoff.\n\nFleetwood was cheered on by the large crowds who remember him for starring in Europe's 2018 Ryder Cup win over the US at the same Le Golf National course, south of Paris.\n\nHome supporters were thrilled with a final-day surge by Victor Perez, who hit the second-best final round to end at 16 under in fourth place. {"uri": "8259031656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:39:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:39:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:38:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/paris-olympics-2024/novak-djokovic-says-gold-probably-biggest-success-eyes-2028-olympics/articleshow/112270603.cms", "title": "Novak Djokovic says gold 'probably biggest success', eyes 2028 Olympics | Paris Olympics 2024 News - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: Novak Djokovic, after securing a thrilling victory against Carlos Alcaraz in the Olympic final at Roland Garros, expressed his elation and termed this achievement as arguably the most significant in his illustrious career. The Serbian tennis star prevailed in a closely contested match, winning both sets through tiebreakers with scores of 7-6 (7/3) and 7-6 (7/2).\n\nHaving participated in five Olympic Games, Djokovic's pursuit of the elusive gold medal finally came to fruition.In a surprising revelation, he also hinted at the possibility of defending his title at the 2028 Los Angeles Games, by which time he will have reached the age of 41.\n\n\"This is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had and the most special feeling,\" said the 37-year-old Serb, as quoted by AFP.\n\n\"I thought carrying the flag at the opening ceremony for my country at the 2012 Olympics was the best feeling an athlete could have until today.\n\n\"Now at the age of 37 and facing a 21-year-old who is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back, I can say that this is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had.\"\n\nDjokovic's triumph on Sunday saw him achieve a remarkable feat, joining an elite group of tennis legends - Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf, and Serena Williams, who was present to witness the historic moment. These players have accomplished the rare distinction of securing victories in all four Grand Slam tournaments and clinching the Olympic singles gold medal, thereby completing the prestigious career Golden Slam.\n\nPrior to his victory over Alcaraz on Sunday, Djokovic's most notable Olympic performance was in 2008 at the Beijing Games, where he secured a bronze medal. Additionally, he had suffered defeats in three previous semi-final appearances.\n\nFollowing this momentous achievement, Djokovic has expressed his desire to continue competing and has not dismissed the possibility of attempting to win consecutive gold medals at the Los Angeles Olympics, which are scheduled to take place in four years.\n\n\"I want to play in Los Angeles, I enjoy playing for my country in the Olympic Games, in the Davis Cup,\" he added.\n\nDjokovic is the oldest singles champion since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988, and he thwarted Alcaraz's attempt to add Olympic gold to his French Open and Wimbledon titles from earlier this summer.\n\nOverwhelmed with emotion, Djokovic fell to his knees on Court Philippe Chatrier, where he has previously won three French Opens. He then proudly raised the Serbian flag before climbing into the players' box to embrace his wife and children.\n\n\"We almost played three hours, the final shot was the only moment when I was sure I could win the match,\" said Djokovic.\n\nHis title on Sunday was the 99th of his career and his first of 2024, coming after a challenging season. Jannik Sinner had taken his place as Australian Open champion and eventually claimed his world number one ranking.\n\nAlcaraz then edged him out at the French Open and prevented him from matching Roger Federer's record of eight Wimbledon titles.\n\nA knee injury sustained at the French Open required surgery, and his participation in the Olympic semi-finals briefly seemed in jeopardy when he appeared to aggravate the issue.\n\n\"I knew that this could be my last chance of a gold medal,\" added Djokovic at his post-final press conference still draped in his country's flag and with his medal hanging proudly around his neck.\n\n\"I did everything I possibly could to prepare myself for this period. The injury sidetracked me a little bit. But coming into the Olympic Games I felt like a different player in terms of how I moved, how I played.\n\n\"In a way losing heavily to Alcaraz at Wimbledon probably worked in my favour as I knew I couldn't play any worse than that.\"\n\nThe TOI Sports Desk excels in a myriad of roles that capture the essence of live sporting events and deliver compelling content to readers worldwide. From running live blogs for India and non-India cricket matches to global spectacles featuring Indian talents, like the Chess World Cup final featuring Praggnanandhaa and the Badminton World Championships semifinal featuring HS Prannoy, our live coverage extends to all mega sporting events. We extensively cover events like the Olympics, Asian Games, Cricket World Cups, FIFA World Cups, and more. Emotional and unable to hold back tears, Carlos Alcaraz needed a moment to compose himself after losing to Novak Djokovic in the men's tennis singles final at the Paris Olympics.\n\nParis, Aug 5 (AP) Emotional and unable to hold back tears, Carlos Alcaraz needed a moment to compose himself after losing to Novak Djokovic in the men's tennis singles final at the Paris Olympics.\n\nThere would be no youngest-ever champion and no repeating Rafael Nadal's feat of winning a gold medal for Spain in his first attempt in singles.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: Noah Lyles Takes Away Gold Medal by Whisker in Men's 100-Meter Final.\n\nAlcaraz settled for silver after a 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) loss to Djokovic at Court Philippe Chatrier, saying the pressure of playing for his country got to him.\n\n\"I think I put more pressure on myself because I was playing for Spain, for the Spaniards,\" he said. \"I felt that I let the Spanish people down by not winning the gold.\"\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: India To Take On Germany in Semifinals of Men's Hockey.\n\nThe 21-year-old Alcaraz said he had not felt that type of pressure in the four Grand Slam finals that he played -- and won -- so far in his career.\n\n\"It was a different type of pressure,\" he said. \"Everyone in Spain wanted me to win the gold, and I wanted to win the gold as well.\"\n\nAlcaraz said the extra pressure cost him especially in the decisive moments of the game.\n\n\"In those difficult moments I usually raise my level, but I wasn't able to do that today,\" he said. \"Probably I felt the pressure in those situations. You play four Grand Slams every year, the Olympics is only once every four years.\"\n\nAlcaraz said there was still reason for him to be proud after \"knowing that I gave everything.\"\n\n\"Obviously this week, this tournament has been really special for me,\" he said. \"I'm going to take it for the rest of my life, for the rest of my career, for sure. Playing with Rafa, getting my first Olympics medal -- hopefully not the last one -- it's been a special one.\"\n\nAlcaraz arrived in Paris amid the hype of playing the doubles tournament alongside his With the accomplishment, Djokovic joins an elite club of tennis players who have secured a Golden Slam.\n\nWhat is a Golden Slam?\n\nA Golden Slam is earned when an individual player wins all four Grand Slams (Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, U.S. Open) and an Olympic gold medal in singles.\n\nHow common are Golden Slams?\n\nPrior to Djokovic, only four players had achieved the feat.", {"uri": "2024-08-443740522", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:38:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:38:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:33:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://eu.jsonline.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/08/04/paris-olympics-live-updates-results/74190868007/", "title": "Paris Olympics live updates: Scottie Scheffler wins gold; Suni Lee medals", "body": "The Olympic swimming schedule for Sunday features four finals, including the women's 50m free and 4x100m medley relays.\n\nAt least three U.S. squads are competing across two team sports, 21 sports in total are in action, and USA TODAY Sports will bring you live results, medal count, highlights, and more throughout the day. Follow along.\n\nAmerican Kristen Faulkner wins women's road race gold\n\nKristen Faulkner used a late charge to pull away from the field and win gold in the women's road race Sunday.\n\nFaulkner, 31, is the first U.S. woman to win gold in the race since Connie Carpenter in 1984.\n\nShe covered the 158-km course in 3:59.23, pulling away from a four-racer pack in the final three kilometers.\n\nMarianna Vos of the Netherlands took silver and Lotte Kopecky of Belgium took bronze in a photo finish, 58 seconds behind Faulkner. - Dave Birkett\n\nScottie Scheffler wins gold medal in Olympic golf\n\nSAINT-QUENTIN-EN-YVELINES, France -- The legend of Scottie Scheffler keeps growing, and the latest addition is golden.\n\nWorld No. 1 Scheffler caught fire on the back nine at Le Golf National, coming from off the pace to swipe the gold medal for Team USA from a group of elite contenders in the final holes of a enthralling Paris Olympics competition.\n\nOpening the final round four shots back of the leaders, Scheffler tied a course record by firing a 9-under-par 62 on Sunday. He birdied his first three holes of the afternoon and then six of nine after the turn, including a pivotal run of four in a row to seize a place atop the leaderboard that he wouldn't lose.\n\nScheffler's tournament total of 19 under beat silver-medalist Tommy Fleetwood of Great Britain by one shot. Japan's Hideki Matsuyama (17 under) won the bronze medal. - Gentry Estes\n\nNovak Djokovic defeats Carlos Alcaraz to win tennis singles gold\n\nPARIS -- Novak Djokovic finally has an Olympic gold medal around his neck.\n\nAfter chasing this last prize his entire career - the only major accomplishment in tennis he hadn't been able to check off - the 37-year old Djokovic was down to his last chance here in Paris.\n\nSummoning every bit of energy he had left in the tank Sunday, against the 21-year old who has taken his place on top of the sport, Djokovic managed to play one of the best matches of his career to beat Carlos Alcaraz 7-6, 7-6 inside Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nWhen it was over after 2 hours, 37 minutes and one monster down-the-line forehand on match point, Djokovic dropped his racket and put his hands over his mouth. Then, after an embrace with Alcaraz, he dropped to his knees in exhaustion and emotion and stayed down for nearly a minute. Then he went into the stands, embracing his team and family.\n\nEven for a man with 24 Grand Slam titles and nearly every significant record in the sport, this is the crowning achievement that he has long sought. Because this one wasn't just for himself, it was for his beloved Serbia.\n\nAfter gutting defeats in Rio and Tokyo, Djokovic wanted this badly. Even built his year around it. But after injuring his knee during the French Open and having meniscus surgery, it was unclear whether he would even be healthy enough to play the Olympics.\n\nBut Djokovic managed to return in time for Wimbledon, getting to the finals before Alcaraz crushed him in three sets.\n\nThis one was tightly played throughout, with no breaks of serve on either side. In the end, Djokovic was better in both tiebreakers. - Dan Wolken\n\nOlympic golf: Scottie Scheffler blazes to top of leaderboard\n\nThanks to three straight birdies, American golfer Scottie Scheffler is 8-under on the day and now has a share of the lead in the Olympic golf tournament. Both he and Tommy Fleetwood sit at 18-under for the tournament.\n\nSpain's Jon Rahm has dropped a number of strokes on the day, falling off the podium for the time being.\n\nAmerican Austen Smith takes bronze medal in skeet shooting\n\nAusten Smith took bronze in women's skeet shooting Sunday, when she qualified for the six-person final and hit 45 out of 50 targets.\n\nIn her second Olympics experience, Smith, 23, survived stage 1 and the elimination stage of finals to stand on the podium.\n\nThe gold medal came down to a shoot-off between Francisca Crovetto Chadid of Chile and Great Britain's Amber Rutter. That sudden-death format went five rounds with both shooters matching each other until Crovetto Chadid finally bested Rutter.\n\nChile had never won an Olympic shooting gold medal. - Chris Bumbaca\n\nSuni Lee wins bronze medal in thrilling uneven bars final\n\nUSA's Suni Lee went last in the uneven bars final, scoring a 14.800 and winning bronze.\n\n2024 Olympic medals: Who is leading the medal count? Follow along as we track the medals for every sport.\n\nNovak Djokovic takes first set from Carlos Alcaraz\n\nNovak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz went back and forth during the first set of their men's singles gold medal match, but Djokovic earned the 7-6 win.\n\nWhat else would you expect from the finalists from last month's Wimbledon?\n\nDjokovic won the first-set tiebreaker, which happened after 13 unsuccessful break points. The second set is underway.\n\nUSA women's volleyball sweeps France\n\nThe Team USA women's volleyball team held off France in three sets, 29-27, 29-27, 25-20, during a preliminary round match.\n\nAndrea Drews led the way for the Americans with 15 points, while Chiaka Ogbogu added 13 and Haleigh Washington and Kathryn Plummer each had 11. Ogbogu and Plummer also combined for six blocks.\n\nThe U.S. improved its record to 2-1 at these Olympics and officially qualified for the quarterfinals.\n\nThe still rings final was the first event of the day, China's Liu Yang and Zou Jingyuan winning gold and silver, respectively, with Greece's Eleftherios Petrouinas rounding out the podium.\n\nIn the gold medal match of men's individual archery, American Brady Ellison fell to South Korea's Kim Woo-Jin in a shootoff - losing by a mere five millimeters.\n\nEllison will have to settle for silver, the third of his Olympics career to go with two bronze, one of which came earlier in these Olympics in mixed doubles with American Casey Kaufhold.\n\nWoo-Jin made it three gold medals in these Paris Games by narrowly winning a one-arrow shootoff to edge Ellison 6-5 on Sunday in one of the most dramatic gold-medal finishes in these Games.\n\nEach of the two archers shot a perfect score of 30 in the match's final set to force the one-arrow shootoff. Ellison went second, and his arrow was only slightly outside of his opponent's arrow, which had landed on the line to score a 10.\n\nEllison, a 35-year-old from Arizona who's a world-record holder and considered one of the sport's all-time best, won three consecutive matches Sunday to reach the gold medal final. -- Gentry Estes\n\nJon Rahm gets to 20 under in Olympic men's golf final\n\nSpain's Jon Rahm is threatening to rush for gold in Paris, opening up a four-stroke lead at 20-under par.\n\nRahm has shot 6 under for the day and his closest competitors at the moment are Japan's Hideki Matsuyama and Great Britain's Tommy Fleetwood at 16 under. Team USA's Scottie Scheffler and Xander Schauffele, the gold medal winner in Tokyo, are tied for fourth at 15 under.\n\nUSA women's hoops prepares for Germany\n\nTeam USA women's basketball's group-stage clash against Germany will determine who wins Group C, with both teams so far unbeaten in Paris. Both have assured themselves a place in the quarterfinals, but the group winner will theoretically receive an easier assignment once the final eight teams are paired for knockout play.\n\nTeam USA started its quest for an eighth consecutive gold medal with a 27-point win over Japan on July 29, and followed it up by beating Belgium by 13 on Thursday. Germany has had similar results, besting Belgium by 14 to open the tournament and then claiming an 11-point win over Japan in its second Group C game.\n\nThe first set is all tied up at 3-3 in the men's singles gold medal match between Serbia's Novak Djokovic and Spain's Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nDjokovic earned the first point and jumped out to a 2-1 lead before Alcaraz battled back to even the score.\n\nBrady Ellison will play for gold in Olympics archery\n\nBrady Ellison of the United States has moved on to the gold medal match in men's individual archery.\n\nEllison defeated Germany's Florian Unruh 7-3 in the semifinals to unofficially clinch his fifth career Olympics medal, but he's still searching for his first gold.\n\nEllison will take on No. 1 seed Kim Woojin of South Korea at around 8:45 a.m. ET.\n\nOlympics skeet shooting: Austen Smith moves on to final\n\nAusten Smith advanced to the women's skeet final by finishing first in qualifying with 122 points. Smith turned in three perfect rounds and missed three clay disks out of 125 total - two in the second round and one in the fifth. She and five others advanced to the final, meaning she'll have to do better than three competitors to make the podium.\n\nFellow American Dania Vizzi, the silver-medalist at last year's world championships, did not qualify for the finals.\n\nJon Rahm takes lead in Olympics men's golf final\n\nSpain's Jon Rahm moved to 3 under for the day and has taken a one-shot lead over the Paris Olympics field in search of a gold medal.\n\nAt 17 under par, Rahm leads USA's Xander Schauffele by one stroke, while Japan's Hideki Matsuyama and Great Britain's Tommy Fleetwood lurk at two shots back. Matsuyama has been especially good so far Sunday, shooting 4 under through six holes.\n\nNovak Djokovic vs. Carlos Alcaraz for Olympic gold medal\n\nIn a rematch of the men's final at Wimbledon, staged less than a month ago, Serbia's Novak Djokovic will get a chance at revenge against Spain's Carlos Alcarez.\n\nDjokovic, a 24-time Grand Slam champion, is taking aim at winning the \"Golden Slam,\" which encompasses all four Grand Slam titles and an Olympic gold medal. Steffi Graff, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams are in the exclusive club.\n\nFreddie Crittenden jogs through preliminary heat for 110m hurdles\n\nTeam USA's Freddie Crittenden jogged through a preliminary men's 110-meter hurdles round Sunday to finish with a time of 18.27 at the Paris Olympics, nearly five full seconds behind heat winner Louis Francois Mendy of Senegal.\n\nWhy? Strategy. And misfortune.\n\nCrittenden came up with a minor physical issue Saturday - so minor, in fact, he wouldn't even describe it as an injury - but it was enough to give him concern that it might cause an injury. So in order to save his body and give himself the best chance of recovery, he willfully finished last with a plan of taking the next two days to rest, then hopefully rebound to medal contention in Tuesday's repechage round. -- Chase Goodbread\n\nSydney McLaughlin-Levrone opens up with easy victory in 400 hurdles\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Sunday was just another day at the park for 400-meter hurdles world-record holder Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nMcLaughlin-Levrone ran a 53.60 like it was an afternoon stroll. She won her fifth and final heat by nearly three seconds. Morocco's Noura Ennadi placed second at 55.26.\n\n\"It's good to shake the rust off. I haven't raced since U.S. trials,\" McLaughlin-Levrone said. \"I feel good. The track is pretty fast ... It feels good to get back out there and compete.\"\n\nMcLaughlin-Levrone is defending her Olympic title in Paris. Her main competitor is expected to be Netherlands' Femke Bol who won her third heat, running a 53.38.\n\nThe world-record holder and defending Olympic champ was voted a U.S. track and field co-captain before the start of the track and field competition.\n\n\"Honor to have that role. I know Allyson (Felix) had that last time,\" McLaughlin-Levrone said. \"It's just great that my peers respect me as a competitor. I'm just hoping to represent Team USA the best I can.\"\n\nSundays always bring out the best golf in the world's best golfers. That's no different at the Olympics.\n\nAmerican star and Masters winner Scottie Scheffler is at 3-under par after five holes to get to 13 under for the tournament and within three shots of the lead -- which is held by Spain's Jon Rahm and Team USA teammate and defending Olympics gold medalist Xander Schauffele.\n\nGrant Holloway dominates first round of 110 hurdles\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Grant Holloway looks destined for a gold medal in Paris.\n\nHolloway ran smooth over 10 hurdles in the opening round and crossed the finish line at 13.01 to win the fifth heat in the 110-meter hurdles. He won by at least three meters. The next fastest in the race was 13.42 by Jamaica's Rasheed Broadbell.\n\n\"I love the consistency that I'm having and how everybody recognizes how consistent I am,\" Holloway said prior to the race.\n\nThe semifinals in the men's 110-meter hurdles are on Wednesday. Holloway has the fastest qualifying time entering the semis.\n\nHolloway was voted a USA track and field team co-captain before the start of the Olympic track and field action. - Tyler Dragon\n\nThree American women advance to 200 semis\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Gabby Thomas, McKenzie Long and Brittany Brown all won their opening round heats in the women's 200.\n\nThomas won with relative ease, running a 22.20. Long ran out of lane No. 9 but it didn't phase her as she crossed the line first at 22.55. In heat five, Brown clocked a 22.38 to win her opening-round race. - Tyler Dragon\n\nGabby Thomas advances to women's 200m semifinals\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Gabby Thomas had a relatively easy time halfway around the track in the women's 200.\n\nThomas easily won her first-round heat in the women's 200, running a time of 22.20. Thomas was in heat two and ran out of lane No. 5.\n\nJamaica's Niesha Burgher ran a 22.54 to finish second and Switzerland's Mujinga Kambundji took third, running a 22.75.\n\nThomas is part of USA TODAY Sports' 10 athletes to watch series.\n\nThe 27-year-old sprinter owns the fastest 200 time in the world this year at 21.78. She won the 200 at the USA Olympic track and field trials in June.\n\n\"Team USA is really deep. Getting to represent Team USA at the Olympics is incredibly special,\" Thomas said. \"I'm so glad that I have the opportunity to represent Team USA.\"\n\nThe top three in each round advance to the semifinals. All others have a chance to advance in the repechage round. - Tyler Dragon\n\nShericka Jackson scratches from women's 200\n\nThe Jamaican women sprinters are having a forgettable Olympics.\n\nShericka Jackson, the two-time world champion in the 200, withdrew from her signature event Sunday. Jackson was the favorite in the women's 200, but suffered an apparent injury last month. She scratched from the women's 100 before the start of Olympic track and field competition.\n\nJamaica's Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce scratched from the 100 semifinals on Saturday.\n\nElaine Thompson-Herah suffered a season-ending Achilles' injury earlier this season. - Tyler Dragon\n\nUSA athletes qualify for women's 3000m steeplechase final\n\nTeam USA's Valerie Constien and Courtney Wayment qualified for the final of the women's 3000m steeplechase Sunday morning at the Stade de France.\n\nWayment finished fourth in heat one with a time of 9:10.72. Constien finished third in heat two with a time of 9:16.33.\n\nTeam USA's Marisa Howard finished sixth in heat three with a time of 9:24.78 and did advance to the final.\n\nThe steeplechase final will be held on Tuesday, Aug. 6.\n\nNBC is airing and streaming the Paris Olympics from all angles: Peacock is streaming every sport and event live as it unfolds; NBC, USA Network, CNBC and E! are carrying various live events and replays throughout the day. Here are six tips and tricks for getting the most out of Peacock during the Olympics.\n\nOlympic swimming schedule today\n\nMedals in the men's 100 will be decided with Noah Lyles expected to be a favorite. Lyles won gold in the individual 100 and 200 at the 2023 world championships in Budapest. Jamaican sprinter Oblique Seville could be a challenger. In June he ran a personal-best 9.82 seconds to beat Lyles.\n\nShelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce issues statement about late scratch from 100m\n\nJamaican Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, a two-time gold medalist in the 100-meter dash, unexpectedly missed the semifinal of the race on Saturday.\n\nOn Sunday, Fraser-Pryce issued a statement on social media regarding her late scratch from the race due to an injury she sustained during warm-ups.\n\n\"It is difficult for me to find the words to describe the depth of my disappointment,\" she wrote. \"I know that my supporters share and should this disappointment with me.\"\n\nFraser-Pryce won gold in the 100m at the 2008 and 2012 Olympics, and then silver at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021. The 100 was going to be Fraser-Pryce's only individual event at the 2024 Paris Olympics, as she did not qualify in the 200.\n\nOlympic basketball today: What to watch\n\nIn women's hoops, the USA plays Germany in a group game. Forward Satou Sabally is expected to return for Germany after hurting her shoulder during Olympic qualifying and undergoing surgery. Sabally, who plays for the WNBA's Dallas Wings, sat out early in the season while recovering.\n\nOlympic shooting today: What to watch\n\nThe women's skeet finals will be held Sunday, an event in which the Americans have excelled. In Tokyo, Amber English won gold in her first Olympic appearance. In Paris keep an eye on American Dania Vizzi, the 2022 world champion.\n\nOlympic sailing today: What to watch\n\nWomen's kiteboarding begins and the USA's medal hopes rest on six-time world champion Daniela Moroz. The 23-year-old from Lafayette, California, competed in her first international event at age 14 and won her first world championship at 15.\n\nOlympic Muffin Man's fame not from swimming\n\nNANTERRE, France -- Norwegian swimmer Henrik Christiansen is one of the stars of the Paris Olympics, just maybe not in the way he imagined or hoped.\n\nThe three-time Olympian wishes he would make headlines for his distance swimming performances. But instead, Christiansen is the unofficial Muffin Man of the Paris Games, thanks to his numerous TikToks showcasing his love for the chocolate muffins in the Olympic Village. -- Michelle R. Martinelli\n\nAthletes can't stop talking about food at Olympic Village\n\nPARIS -- The food being served athletes at the Paris Games has remained a popular topic through the first week of competition. It all goes back to criticism -- \"Muffin Man\" notwithstanding -- that made headlines prior to the opening ceremony.\n\nSimone Biles was even asked about the food after the U.S. women's gymnastics team's gold medal victory Tuesday night. And Biles gave a thumbs down, saying it wasn't \"proper French cuisine.\" -- Gentry Estes\n\nParis street artists express their feelings about Olympics\n\nPARIS -- It's hard to visit Paris and not be inspired - or at least appreciative - of the rich history that lives throughout the city. With the Olympics underway in Paris, street artists have used their art to express their feelings on the Games. \"Javelin is with bread,\" says Eludut, \"Swimming is swimming through trash.\" -- {"uri": "8258902337", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:06:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:06:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:05:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/08/04/g-s1-15301/novak-djokovic-olympic-gold-medal-paris", "title": "At 37 and already a tennis superstar, Novak Djokovic wins first Olympic gold medal", "body": "NPR is in Paris for the 2024 Summer Olympics. For more of our coverage from the games head to our latest updates.\n\nPARIS -- Novak Djokovic is used to winning on tennis's biggest stages.\n\nHe's the all-time leader for most Grand Slam men's singles titles (24). He's just one of three men to hold all four Grand Slam championships simultaneously. When he won the French Open last year, he became the first man to win each Grand Slam event -- the Australian Open, the French Open, Wimbledon and U.S. Open -- at least three times.\n\nBut at 37, there was one elusive title that escaped him during his long and glorious career: Olympic champion.\n\nThat drought ended Sunday at famed Roland-Garros stadium where the number-two ranked player has had had so much success before. In straight sets (both won in a tiebreak), Djokovic ended the match when he swatted a forehand winner against Spain's Carlos Alcaraz. The crowd erupted.\n\nThe righthander, who started playing tennis when he was four and turned professional more than two decades ago in 2003, shook hands with Alcaraz and then fell down on the red clay court. On all fours, he began sobbing and shaking. It was a surprising amount of emotion from someone who rarely shows it.\n\nThis tennis superstar who has winning records against the greats like Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, and who had won so much in his career now had the one title that eluded him for far too long: an Olympic gold medal. He'd won a bronze at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. But the last thing missing from an otherworldly tennis resume had escaped him.\n\nAgainst the young Spaniard who won the French Open on this same court in June and who beat the Serbian last month at Wimbledon to claim his fourth grand slam, the victory here in Paris meant something to Djokovic.\n\nHe came achingly close at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021 when he attempted to do something no man had done before: claim the 'Golden' Slam. That's winning all four Grand Slam tournaments and an Olympic gold medal in a single year. Under pressure to do the unbelievable, he came up short, losing in the semifinals.\n\nIn Paris, none of the past mattered. {"uri": "8260171268", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "13:23:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T13:23:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:22:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.tennis365.com/news/novak-djokovic-makes-statement-of-intent-as-he-brushes-off-suggestions-his-goals-are-unrealistic", "title": "Novak Djokovic makes statement of intent as he brushes off suggestions his goals are 'unrealistic'", "body": "Novak Djokovic has achieved the \"biggest sporting success\" of his career and some might think now would be a good time to pack it in, but the tennis great has a warning for those who think he is \"unrealistic\" with his goals.\n\nWinning gold has been Djokovic's top priority for the past decade, but at the 2016 Rio Games he lost in the first round and at the 2020 Tokyo Games he finished fourth.\n\nFollowing his lacklustre start to the 2024 season that saw him fail to win a title during the first seven months of the season, many questioned whether or not it was time to throw in the towel and retire while he was still one of the leading players in men's tennis.\n\nHe refused to give up on his dream and at Roland Garros, the 37-year-old Djokovic became the oldest Olympic gold medallist when he defeated Carlos Alcaraz - who is 16 years younger than him - in the showpiece match at the 2024 Paris Games.\n\nNow that he has completed the career Golden Slam [winning the four Grand Slams and singles gold at the Olympics), has his retirement date edged closer?\n\n\"I want to play in Los Angeles,\" the Serbian said of the 2028 Olympics during his post-match press conference.\n\nAfter a member of his team started laughing at his ambitious goal, he added: \"He's making fun of my calendar goals, playing in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I don't know if he's laughing because he thinks it's unrealistic or he's thinking 'I've got another four years with this guy'.\"\n\nHe has proven many naysayers wrong over the years so don't be surprised if he plays at LA 2028.\n\nHaving won 24 Grand Slams, seven season-ending ATP Finals and set a record for most weeks at No 1, there are a lot of achievements to choose from in terms of his greatest, but his latest milestone sits at the top.\n\nParis 2024 men's singles winners & losers: Novak Djokovic gets his gold - but how will Carlos Alcaraz feel about silver lining?\n\nNovak Djokovic becomes first man to achieve unique Olympic feat as he matches Serena Williams for overall singles record\n\n\"I thought in 2012, carrying the flag of my country in the opening ceremony was the best feeling an athlete could have - until today,\" he said.\n\n\"This supersedes everything that I imagined and hoped I could experience and feel. The fact I won the bronze in my first Olympic Games and ever since then failed to win a medal despite playing in three semi-finals ... I couldn't overcome that obstacle.\n\n\"Now, at age 37 [I was able to beat] a 21-year-old that is probably the best player in the world right now. When I take everything into consideration, this is probably the biggest sporting success I've had in my career.\"\n\nHe added: \"Those other Olympic Games where I lost in the semi-finals and wasn't able to bring a medal for many years to my country, that was catching up to me and building the pressure even more and more.\n\n\"So that's why where I am at this moment in my career and life, it {"uri": "8259066339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:24:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:24:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:23:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/timellis/2024/08/04/djokovic-pushes-his-limits-to-defeat-alcaraz-for-paris-olympic-gold/", "title": "Djokovic Pushes His Limits To Defeat Alcaraz For Paris Olympic Gold", "body": "Novak Djokovic outlasted Carlos Alcaraz to claim the Olympic gold medal in the men's singles final at Roland Garros on Sunday. The 37-year-old overcame his Spanish rival in straight sets 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2) in just under three hours of brutal clay court tennis on Court Phillippe-Chatrier. It was the completion of the missing blue tick on his CV, ending 16 years of hurt - including three semi-final Olympic losses -to claim gold.\n\nDjokovic had visually been stunned by the manner of his defeat at Wimbledon to the same opponent. The return fixture was more like the rebirth of the cyborg brand of qualities he is known for; incredible metal (and mental) strength, clean hitting and the ability to go into tunnel vision mode when facing severe headwinds from the other side of the net.\n\nOn Centre Court Sunday three weeks ago, the Serb was two sets down after 77 minutes. Here, the first five games alone took 36. He wasn't going anywhere, nudging ahead constantly on the scoreboard despite being blitzed at times by the thunderbolts from Alcaraz's toy-like turbo wind-ups. Both men were in good spirits but also showed huge signs of frustration when shots went astray. This meant more.\n\nThe opening act finally ended after 93 minutes with a Djokovic stop volley at the net in a tiebreak that he won 7-3. Both men refused to be broken during the 24 games outside of the shootouts despite multiple chances. It was the Spaniard who looked world weary against a wall of total defiance, especially in the marathon 15-minute ninth game of the first set when he missed five chances to grab the advantage.\n\nThe second set saw Djokovic raise his game, having stoked the furnace by winning the opener. He now had total focus, cranking up the pressure with that extra comfort of scoreboard pressure. Alcaraz's service games were less secure, although he came on strong at the back end to set up tiebreak 2. An incredible Djokovic return from an explosive Alcaraz forehand at 2-2 was too much to bear for the Spaniard. He won no further points in the breaker to cede the match. There was simply nothing left to give from either man. Despite the bare facts of a straight sets win, the jeopardy was compelling.\n\nIf this had been a five-setter, Alcaraz would have still very much fancied the job, but the sprint format of three (which these two have a habit of extending into Marvel epics) favored the older man. Djokovic was in an unrelenting mood, the kind that eventually wears down a rival, even a 21-year-old who is threatening to burst the dam of records over the next decade. The only water that was falling were the tears of joy from the winner immediately after the match. The loser couldn't speak, It was Iga Swiatek all over again.\n\nThis was the No. 1 seed's final shot at the highest point of the Olympiad podium. The cumulative progress of a career that has seen so many highs but constant lows in 2024 elevated the importance of this contest. Djokovic claimed a bronze at Beijing in 2008, but the rematch with the Spaniard was perfectly pitched. He had done his homework on what went wrong at SW19 and was hitting the ball much cleaner. The main concern was to keep Alcaraz's forehand from pounding his forecourt, especially with the knee brace that impoverished his fitness and movement after the meniscus operation in June.\n\n\"I'm still in shock. I put my heart, my soul, my body, my family, my everything on the line to win Olympic gold at age 37. I've finally done it,\" an ecstatic and exhausted Djokovic said afterwards. Alcaraz put his head in his hands at the end, trying to work out how a man he dismantled so clinically had come back with the answers. Again. The 21-year-old was disconsolate as he had been after the Cincinnati Open loss when the Serb rose up from the disappointment of the 2023 Wimbledon final to wreak revenge.\n\nDjokovic said that Alcaraz just keeps coming. After this exhilarating contest between the two biggest stars in men's tennis, the Murcia man must be thinking the same. It could happen all again in New York next month. The episodes are running out but there's still enough fire in the oldest Olympic singles champion since 1988 to keep the sequels of the highest quality.", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8259660464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:56:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:56:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:55:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.globalvillagespace.com/djokovic-secures-career-golden-slam-with-olympic-gold/", "title": "Djokovic secures career Golden Slam with Olympic Gold", "body": "In a remarkable display of endurance and skill, Novak Djokovic clinched his first Olympic gold medal on Sunday, defeating Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) in a pulsating men's singles final at Roland Garros. The 37-year-old Serbian's victory marks the completion of the career Golden Slam -- a feat achieved by only five players in the history of tennis. Djokovic's triumph comes after a string of near misses in previous Olympics and completes his illustrious career that already includes a record 24 Grand Slam titles.\n\nThe final showcased an epic clash between two generations of tennis greatness. Alcaraz, the 21-year-old Spanish sensation, entered the match fresh off victories at the French Open and Wimbledon, while Djokovic was looking to avenge his recent Wimbledon defeat to Alcaraz and secure the elusive Olympic gold that had evaded him throughout his career. The match, which lasted nearly three hours, was a gripping contest filled with high-quality tennis and dramatic moments.\n\nRead More: Men beating up women at Olympics is 'madness' - Serbian president\n\nDespite concerns over his fitness due to a recent knee surgery, Djokovic demonstrated resilience and precision throughout the match. Both players held serve throughout the two sets, leading to tiebreaks in each. Djokovic's ability to elevate his game in crucial moments was evident, as he seized both tiebreaks with stunning shots and strategic play. The final point, a breathtaking forehand winner, sealed Djokovic's victory and his place in tennis history.\n\nThe final was a rematch of their recent Wimbledon encounter, and the tension was palpable as Djokovic and Alcaraz faced off once again. Alcaraz, known for his dynamic play and relentless energy, struggled to break Djokovic's serve, despite having multiple break point opportunities. Djokovic's serve-and-volley tactics and defensive prowess kept Alcaraz at bay, ultimately proving decisive in the tiebreaks.\n\nThe match was characterized by its clean play and minimal unforced errors from both players. The Olympic format, featuring best-of-three sets, added an extra layer of intensity, with each point and game carrying significant weight. The crowd at Court Philippe Chatrier was treated to a thrilling spectacle, with chants of \"No-le! No-le!\" and \"Car-los! Car-los!\" echoing throughout the stadium, adding to the electric atmosphere.\n\nRead More: Olympics committee face backlash after a woman is forced to fight transgender\n\nAfter securing the gold medal, Djokovic's emotions were palpable. In a heartfelt celebration, he knelt on the clay, tears streaming down his face as he clutched the Serbian flag. The sight of Djokovic, surrounded by his family and team, celebrating his long-awaited achievement, was a testament to the significance of this victory in his storied career. Alcaraz, too, was visibly emotional, reflecting on the narrow margin between triumph and defeat.", "source": {"uri": "globalvillagespace.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Global Village Space"},
