{"uri": "8258541744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "11:13:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T11:13:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T11:10:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/sports/2811650/", "title": "Tennis at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games: Men's Singles Final Preview (Djokovic vs. Alcaraz) - ExBulletin", "body": "While he said the 21-year-old Alcaraz was the favorite, Djokovic has a steely look in his eyes after the Spaniard badly beat him in last month's Wimbledon final. He knows this is his last chance at the golden piece he needs to complete his career jigsaw.\n\n\"He reached the final without losing a set. I mean, so did I, but I think with the way he's playing he's definitely the favorite,\" said Djokovic, the oldest player to reach the Olympic men's singles final since tennis returned to the Games in 1988.\n\n\"I feel like I'm a different player than I was at Wimbledon, the way I move, the way I hit the ball. Not to take anything away from the fact that he won the Wimbledon final, he was dominant and deserved to be a winner, but I feel more confident in myself and my chances in the final.\"\n\nDjokovic will have enjoyed a day off on Saturday to rest his right knee, which required surgery in June and appeared to be acting up during his quarter-final defeat to Greece. Stefanos Tsitsipas.\n\nHowever, he said his knee was no longer a problem and that he was looking forward to an exciting fight with Alcaraz.\n\n\"It didn't bother me at all (against Musetti),\" he said. \"So I'm very happy that there's nothing serious going on.\"\n\nDjokovic has won three of his six matches against Alcaraz, including the semi-finals at Roland Garros last year, but the Spaniard is the clear leader in the men's event this year, having won back-to-back victories at both France and Wimbledon.\n\nAlcaraz has carried a heavy burden on his shoulders this past week, not only reaching the singles final but also playing with his idol Nadal in an emotional doubles series that ended in the last eight.\n\nIf he wins and becomes the youngest Olympic singles champion, he would join Steffi Graf and Nadal who won the French, Wimbledon and Olympic titles in the same year.\n\n\"I saw that. We are one step closer. I would like to put my name next to Graff and Nadal, two legends of the sport in general. I'm going for it,\" he said.\n\n\"I will try not to think about all the statistics, the things I could achieve... I will try to avoid all that and keep improving myself, doing my best and making sure the Spanish people enjoy themselves and feel proud.\"", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", He also became the oldest singles champion since tennis returned to the Olympics in 1988 and shattered Alcaraz's bid to add gold to the French Open and Wimbledon titles he has pocketed this {"uri": "8259060403", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:19:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:19:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:16:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/olympics-tennis-djokovic-hails-gold-as-greatest-sporting-achievement/2207843/", "title": "Olympics-Tennis-Djokovic hails gold as greatest sporting achievement", "body": "He is the oldest man to win the Olympic singles title since tennis returned to the Games in 1988 and remarkably he did it 21 days after being pummelled by Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final and two months after undergoing knee surgery.\n\n\"I won the bronze in my first Olympic Games (2008) and ever since then failed to win the medal and played three out of four Olympic Games in semi-finals and couldn't overcome that obstacle,\" Djokovic, proudly wearing his medal, told reporters.\n\n\"And then now at age 37, with a 21-year-old that is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back and playing incredible tennis.\n\n\"When I take everything into consideration, this probably is the biggest sporting success I've ever had in my career.\"\n\nThe 24-time Grand Slam champion produced a level of tennis that has been missing this year to fight off Alcaraz.\n\nAfter belting away a forehand winner to end a ferocious, near three-hour battle, the emotion poured out of Djokovic as he sobbed on court before climbing into the stands to embrace his family, including wife Jelena and son Stefan, and his team.\n\n\"Until today I thought that carrying the Serbian flag at the 2012 opening ceremony in London is the best feeling that an athlete could have,\" he said.\n\n\"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined, that I hoped that I could experience and that I could feel.\"\n\nDjokovic did not rule out playing at the Los Angeles Olympics in 2028, but said the realisation that Paris was probably his last swing at gold had motivated him.\n\n\"I was ready for this tournament and I didn't drop a set the entire tournament,\" he said. \"I knew in the opening two rounds the way I was playing that this is my chance. If it's ever going to be, it's going to be now.\n\n\"When I qualified for the finals, I felt a big relief because that's the hurdle I wasn't able to surpass. I did celebrate like I won the tournament. But of course I wanted gold and I knew that I would have to climb the highest mountain there is at the moment, playing Alcaraz.\"\n\nDjokovic saved eight break points during a match of stunning quality and intensity -- the Serb describing the duel as like few others he had ever experienced.\n\n\"I don't think I've ever played, maybe a few times in my life, such a high level for three hours for only two sets,\" he said. \"Credit to him, congratulations to him for a great tournament, great fighting spirit.\"\n\n(Reporting by Martyn Herman; Editing by Toby Davis)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443682891", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:09:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:09:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:07:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://eu.azcentral.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/08/04/paris-olympics-live-updates-results/74190868007/", "title": "Paris Olympics live updates: Suni Lee medals, US archer misses gold by millimeters", "body": "The Olympic swimming schedule for Sunday features four finals, including the women's 50m free and 4x100m medley relays.\n\nAt least three U.S. squads are competing across two team sports, 21 sports in total are in action, and USA TODAY Sports will bring you live results, medal count, highlights, and more throughout the day. Follow along.\n\nNovak Djokovic defeats Carlos Alcaraz to win tennis singles gold\n\nPARIS -- Novak Djokovic finally has an Olympic gold medal around his neck.\n\nAfter chasing this last prize his entire career - the only major accomplishment in tennis he hadn't been able to check off - the 37-year old Djokovic was down to his last chance here in Paris.\n\nSummoning every bit of energy he had left in the tank Sunday, against the 21-year old who has taken his place on top of the sport, Djokovic managed to play one of the best matches of his career to beat Carlos Alcaraz 7-6, 7-6 inside Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nWhen it was over after 2 hours, 37 minutes and one monster down-the-line forehand on match point, Djokovic dropped his racket and put his hands over his mouth. Then, after an embrace with Alcaraz, he dropped to his knees in exhaustion and emotion and stayed down for nearly a minute. Then he went into the stands, embracing his team and family.\n\nEven for a man with 24 Grand Slam titles and nearly every significant record in the sport, this is the crowning achievement that he has long sought. Because this one wasn't just for himself, it was for his beloved Serbia.\n\nAfter gutting defeats in Rio and Tokyo, Djokovic wanted this badly. Even built his year around it. But after injuring his knee during the French Open and having meniscus surgery, it was unclear whether he would even be healthy enough to play the Olympics.\n\nBut Djokovic managed to return in time for Wimbledon, getting to the finals before Alcaraz crushed him in three sets.\n\nThis one was tightly played throughout, with no breaks of serve on either side. In the end, Djokovic was better in both tiebreakers. - Dan Wolken\n\nOlympic golf: Scottie Scheffler blazes to top of leaderboard\n\nThanks to three straight birdies, American golfer Scottie Scheffler is 8-under on the day and now has a share of the lead in the Olympic golf tournament. Both he and Tommy Fleetwood sit at 18-under for the tournament.\n\nSpain's Jon Rahm has dropped a number of strokes on the day, falling off the podium for the time being.\n\nAmerican Austen Smith takes bronze medal in skeet shooting\n\nAusten Smith took bronze in women's skeet shooting Sunday, when she qualified for the six-person final and hit 45 out of 50 targets.\n\nIn her second Olympics experience, Smith, 23, survived stage 1 and the elimination stage of finals to stand on the podium.\n\nThe gold medal came down to a shoot-off between Francisca Crovetto Chadid of Chile and Great Britain's Amber Rutter. That sudden-death format went five rounds with both shooters matching each other until Crovetto Chadid finally bested Rutter.\n\nChile had never won an Olympic shooting gold medal. - Chris Bumbaca\n\nSuni Lee wins bronze medal in thrilling uneven bars final\n\nUSA's Suni Lee went last in the uneven bars final, scoring a 14.800 and winning bronze.\n\n2024 Olympic medals: Who is leading the medal count? Follow along as we track the medals for every sport.\n\nNovak Djokovic takes first set from Carlos Alcaraz\n\nNovak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz went back and forth during the first set of their men's singles gold medal match, but Djokovic earned the 7-6 win.\n\nWhat else would you expect from the finalists from last month's Wimbledon?\n\nDjokovic won the first-set tiebreaker, which happened after 13 unsuccessful break points. The second set is underway.\n\nUSA women's volleyball sweeps France\n\nThe Team USA women's volleyball team held off France in three sets, 29-27, 29-27, 25-20, during a preliminary round match.\n\nAndrea Drews led the way for the Americans with 15 points, while Chiaka Ogbogu added 13 and Haleigh Washington and Kathryn Plummer each had 11. Ogbogu and Plummer also combined for six blocks.\n\nThe U.S. improved its record to 2-1 at these Olympics and officially qualified for the quarterfinals.\n\nThe still rings final was the first event of the day, China's Liu Yang and Zou Jingyuan winning gold and silver, respectively, with Greece's Eleftherios Petrouinas rounding out the podium.\n\nIn the gold medal match of men's individual archery, American Brady Ellison fell to South Korea's Kim Woo-Jin in a shootoff - losing by a mere five millimeters.\n\nEllison will have to settle for silver, the third of his Olympics career to go with two bronze, one of which came earlier in these Olympics in mixed doubles with American Casey Kaufhold.\n\nWoo-Jin made it three gold medals in these Paris Games by narrowly winning a one-arrow shootoff to edge Ellison 6-5 on Sunday in one of the most dramatic gold-medal finishes in these Games.\n\nEach of the two archers shot a perfect score of 30 in the match's final set to force the one-arrow shootoff. Ellison went second, and his arrow was only slightly outside of his opponent's arrow, which had landed on the line to score a 10.\n\nEllison, a 35-year-old from Arizona who's a world-record holder and considered one of the sport's all-time best, won three consecutive matches Sunday to reach the gold medal final. -- Gentry Estes\n\nJon Rahm gets to 20 under in Olympic men's golf final\n\nSpain's Jon Rahm is threatening to rush for gold in Paris, opening up a four-stroke lead at 20-under par.\n\nRahm has shot 6 under for the day and his closest competitors at the moment are Japan's Hideki Matsuyama and Great Britain's Tommy Fleetwood at 16 under. Team USA's Scottie Scheffler and Xander Schauffele, the gold medal winner in Tokyo, are tied for fourth at 15 under.\n\nUSA women's hoops prepares for Germany\n\nTeam USA women's basketball's group-stage clash against Germany will determine who wins Group C, with both teams so far unbeaten in Paris. Both have assured themselves a place in the quarterfinals, but the group winner will theoretically receive an easier assignment once the final eight teams are paired for knockout play.\n\nTeam USA started its quest for an eighth consecutive gold medal with a 27-point win over Japan on July 29, and followed it up by beating Belgium by 13 on Thursday. Germany has had similar results, besting Belgium by 14 to open the tournament and then claiming an 11-point win over Japan in its second Group C game.\n\nThe first set is all tied up at 3-3 in the men's singles gold medal match between Serbia's Novak Djokovic and Spain's Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nDjokovic earned the first point and jumped out to a 2-1 lead before Alcaraz battled back to even the score.\n\nBrady Ellison will play for gold in Olympics archery\n\nBrady Ellison of the United States has moved on to the gold medal match in men's individual archery.\n\nEllison defeated Germany's Florian Unruh 7-3 in the semifinals to unofficially clinch his fifth career Olympics medal, but he's still searching for his first gold.\n\nEllison will take on No. 1 seed Kim Woojin of South Korea at around 8:45 a.m. ET.\n\nOlympics skeet shooting: Austen Smith moves on to final\n\nAusten Smith advanced to the women's skeet final by finishing first in qualifying with 122 points. Smith turned in three perfect rounds and missed three clay disks out of 125 total - two in the second round and one in the fifth. She and five others advanced to the final, meaning she'll have to do better than three competitors to make the podium.\n\nFellow American Dania Vizzi, the silver-medalist at last year's world championships, did not qualify for the finals.\n\nJon Rahm takes lead in Olympics men's golf final\n\nSpain's Jon Rahm moved to 3 under for the day and has taken a one-shot lead over the Paris Olympics field in search of a gold medal.\n\nAt 17 under par, Rahm leads USA's Xander Schauffele by one stroke, while Japan's Hideki Matsuyama and Great Britain's Tommy Fleetwood lurk at two shots back. Matsuyama has been especially good so far Sunday, shooting 4 under through six holes.\n\nNovak Djokovic vs. Carlos Alcaraz for Olympic gold medal\n\nIn a rematch of the men's final at Wimbledon, staged less than a month ago, Serbia's Novak Djokovic will get a chance at revenge against Spain's Carlos Alcarez.\n\nDjokovic, a 24-time Grand Slam champion, is taking aim at winning the \"Golden Slam,\" which encompasses all four Grand Slam titles and an Olympic gold medal. Steffi Graff, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams are in the exclusive club.\n\nFreddie Crittenden jogs through preliminary heat for 110m hurdles\n\nTeam USA's Freddie Crittenden jogged through a preliminary men's 110-meter hurdles round Sunday to finish with a time of 18.27 at the Paris Olympics, nearly five full seconds behind heat winner Louis Francois Mendy of Senegal.\n\nWhy? Strategy. And misfortune.\n\nCrittenden came up with a minor physical issue Saturday - so minor, in fact, he wouldn't even describe it as an injury - but it was enough to give him concern that it might cause an injury. So in order to save his body and give himself the best chance of recovery, he willfully finished last with a plan of taking the next two days to rest, then hopefully rebound to medal contention in Tuesday's repechage round. -- Chase Goodbread\n\nSydney McLaughlin-Levrone opens up with easy victory in 400 hurdles\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Sunday was just another day at the park for 400-meter hurdles world-record holder Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nMcLaughlin-Levrone ran a 53.60 like it was an afternoon stroll. She won her fifth and final heat by nearly three seconds. Morocco's Noura Ennadi placed second at 55.26.\n\n\"It's good to shake the rust off. I haven't raced since U.S. trials,\" McLaughlin-Levrone said. \"I feel good. The track is pretty fast ... It feels good to get back out there and compete.\"\n\nMcLaughlin-Levrone is defending her Olympic title in Paris. Her main competitor is expected to be Netherlands' Femke Bol who won her third heat, running a 53.38.\n\nThe world-record holder and defending Olympic champ was voted a U.S. track and field co-captain before the start of the track and field competition.\n\n\"Honor to have that role. I know Allyson (Felix) had that last time,\" McLaughlin-Levrone said. \"It's just great that my peers respect me as a competitor. I'm just hoping to represent Team USA the best I can.\"\n\nSundays always bring out the best golf in the world's best golfers. That's no different at the Olympics.\n\nAmerican star and Masters winner Scottie Scheffler is at 3-under par after five holes to get to 13 under for the tournament and within three shots of the lead -- which is held by Spain's Jon Rahm and Team USA teammate and defending Olympics gold medalist Xander Schauffele.\n\nGrant Holloway dominates first round of 110 hurdles\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Grant Holloway looks destined for a gold medal in Paris.\n\nHolloway ran smooth over 10 hurdles in the opening round and crossed the finish line at 13.01 to win the fifth heat in the 110-meter hurdles. He won by at least three meters. The next fastest in the race was 13.42 by Jamaica's Rasheed Broadbell.\n\n\"I love the consistency that I'm having and how everybody recognizes how consistent I am,\" Holloway said prior to the race.\n\nThe semifinals in the men's 110-meter hurdles are on Wednesday. Holloway has the fastest qualifying time entering the semis.\n\nHolloway was voted a USA track and field team co-captain before the start of the Olympic track and field action. - Tyler Dragon\n\nThree American women advance to 200 semis\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Gabby Thomas, McKenzie Long and Brittany Brown all won their opening round heats in the women's 200.\n\nThomas won with relative ease, running a 22.20. Long ran out of lane No. 9 but it didn't phase her as she crossed the line first at 22.55. In heat five, Brown clocked a 22.38 to win her opening-round race. - Tyler Dragon\n\nGabby Thomas advances to women's 200m semifinals\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Gabby Thomas had a relatively easy time halfway around the track in the women's 200.\n\nThomas easily won her first-round heat in the women's 200, running a time of 22.20. Thomas was in heat two and ran out of lane No. 5.\n\nJamaica's Niesha Burgher ran a 22.54 to finish second and Switzerland's Mujinga Kambundji took third, running a 22.75.\n\nThomas is part of USA TODAY Sports' 10 athletes to watch series.\n\nThe 27-year-old sprinter owns the fastest 200 time in the world this year at 21.78. She won the 200 at the USA Olympic track and field trials in June.\n\n\"Team USA is really deep. Getting to represent Team USA at the Olympics is incredibly special,\" Thomas said. \"I'm so glad that I have the opportunity to represent Team USA.\"\n\nThe top three in each round advance to the semifinals. All others have a chance to advance in the repechage round. - Tyler Dragon\n\nShericka Jackson scratches from women's 200\n\nThe Jamaican women sprinters are having a forgettable Olympics.\n\nShericka Jackson, the two-time world champion in the 200, withdrew from her signature event Sunday. Jackson was the favorite in the women's 200, but suffered an apparent injury last month. She scratched from the women's 100 before the start of Olympic track and field competition.\n\nJamaica's Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce scratched from the 100 semifinals on Saturday.\n\nElaine Thompson-Herah suffered a season-ending Achilles' injury earlier this season. - Tyler Dragon\n\nUSA athletes qualify for women's 3000m steeplechase final\n\nTeam USA's Valerie Constien and Courtney Wayment qualified for the final of the women's 3000m steeplechase Sunday morning at the Stade de France.\n\nWayment finished fourth in heat one with a time of 9:10.72. Constien finished third in heat two with a time of 9:16.33.\n\nTeam USA's Marisa Howard finished sixth in heat three with a time of 9:24.78 and did advance to the final.\n\nThe steeplechase final will be held on Tuesday, Aug. 6.\n\nNBC is airing and streaming the Paris Olympics from all angles: Peacock is streaming every sport and event live as it unfolds; NBC, USA Network, CNBC and E! are carrying various live events and replays throughout the day. Here are six tips and tricks for getting the most out of Peacock during the Olympics.\n\nOlympic swimming schedule today\n\nMedals in the men's 100 will be decided with Noah Lyles expected to be a favorite. Lyles won gold in the individual 100 and 200 at the 2023 world championships in Budapest. Jamaican sprinter Oblique Seville could be a challenger. In June he ran a personal-best 9.82 seconds to beat Lyles.\n\nShelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce issues statement about late scratch from 100m\n\nJamaican Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, a two-time gold medalist in the 100-meter dash, unexpectedly missed the semifinal of the race on Saturday.\n\nOn Sunday, Fraser-Pryce issued a statement on social media regarding her late scratch from the race due to an injury she sustained during warm-ups.\n\n\"It is difficult for me to find the words to describe the depth of my disappointment,\" she wrote. \"I know that my supporters share and should this disappointment with me.\"\n\nFraser-Pryce won gold in the 100m at the 2008 and 2012 Olympics, and then silver at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021. The 100 was going to be Fraser-Pryce's only individual event at the 2024 Paris Olympics, as she did not qualify in the 200.\n\nOlympic basketball today: What to watch\n\nIn women's hoops, the USA plays Germany in a group game. Forward Satou Sabally is expected to return for Germany after hurting her shoulder during Olympic qualifying and undergoing surgery. Sabally, who plays for the WNBA's Dallas Wings, sat out early in the season while recovering.\n\nOlympic shooting today: What to watch\n\nThe women's skeet finals will be held Sunday, an event in which the Americans have excelled. In Tokyo, Amber English won gold in her first Olympic appearance. In Paris keep an eye on American Dania Vizzi, the 2022 world champion.\n\nOlympic sailing today: What to watch\n\nWomen's kiteboarding begins and the USA's medal hopes rest on six-time world champion Daniela Moroz. The 23-year-old from Lafayette, California, competed in her first international event at age 14 and won her first world championship at 15.\n\nOlympic Muffin Man's fame not from swimming\n\nNANTERRE, France -- Norwegian swimmer Henrik Christiansen is one of the stars of the Paris Olympics, just maybe not in the way he imagined or hoped.\n\nThe three-time Olympian wishes he would make headlines for his distance swimming performances. But instead, Christiansen is the unofficial Muffin Man of the Paris Games, thanks to his numerous TikToks showcasing his love for the chocolate muffins in the Olympic Village. -- Michelle R. Martinelli\n\nAthletes can't stop talking about food at Olympic Village\n\nPARIS -- The food being served athletes at the Paris Games has remained a popular topic through the first week of competition. It all goes back to criticism -- \"Muffin Man\" notwithstanding -- that made headlines prior to the opening ceremony.\n\nSimone Biles was even asked about the food after the U.S. women's gymnastics team's gold medal victory Tuesday night. And Biles gave a thumbs down, saying it wasn't \"proper French cuisine.\" -- Gentry Estes\n\nParis street artists express their feelings about Olympics\n\nPARIS -- It's hard to visit Paris and not be inspired - or at least appreciative - of the rich history that lives throughout the city. With the Olympics underway in Paris, street artists have used their art to express their feelings on the Games. \"Javelin is with bread,\" says Eludut, \"Swimming is swimming through trash.\" -- He has won each of the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon and US Open at least three times, but Olympic glory had eluded him as he headed to Roland Garros for the Paris Olympics\n\nAn epic first set went the distance, with Djokovic taking it on a tie-break after more than 90 minutes of play. Both players dug deep to avoid being broken, and that pattern continued well into set number two for what felt like an inevitable second tie-break, where the 37-year-old sealed the deal.\n\nThe stakes were high for both men going into the final at Roland Garros. Djokovic knew he could wrap up a career golden slam with victory, while a win for Alcaraz would continue his recent dominance over the Serb, and in the end it was the veteran who came out on top.\n\nDjokovic went into the tournament as top seed, and justified that with some dominant displays. He didn't drop a single set en route to the final as he overcame Matt Ebden, Rafael Nadal, Dominik Koepfer, Stefanos Tsitsipas and Lorenzo Musettin.\n\nAlcaraz, the second seed, was similarly comfortable. None of Hady Habib, Tallon Griekspoor, Roman Safiullin, Tommy Paul nor Felix Auger-Aliassime was able to take a set off the Spaniard, with Auger-Aliassime blown away 6-1, 6-1 in the semis.\n\nSomething had to give in the final, though. Alcaraz was the first of the pair to surrender a set, with Djokovic taking that first tie-break, and the veteran clinched a 7-6, 7-6 victory in a match of the highest quality.\n\nShare your thoughts on the men's final in the comments section\n\nEarlier, Musetti had beaten Auger-Aliassime in the bronze medal match. The Italian won 6-4, 1-6, 6-3, following up his Wimbledon semi-final run with another run to the final four.\n\nIt was Italy's first Olympic medal in tennis since the sport returned to the programme in 1988. \"I've been eating plain pasta and chicken for three months, basically, so I think eating a pizza is the least I can do tonight!\" Musetti said after earning bronze.\n\nIn the women's singles, Zheng Qinwen of China beat Donna Vekic in the final to win gold, while Iga Swiatek won bronze. There were also golds for Australia in the men's doubles and Czech Republic in the mixed doubles, while the women's doubles final pits Italy's third seeds against Mirra Andreeva and Diana Shnaider, who are competing in Paris as individual neutral athletes.\n\nFollow all the action from the Paris Olympics with Mirror Sport's live blog\n\nThis article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. losing to Novak Djokovic in the men's tennis singles final at the Paris Olympics.\n\nThere would be no youngest-ever champion and no repeating Rafael Nadal's feat of winning a gold medal for Spain in his first attempt in singles.\n\nAlcaraz settled for silver after a 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) loss to Djokovic at Court Philippe Chatrier, saying the pressure of playing for his country got to him.\n\n\"I think I put more pressure on myself because I was playing for Spain, for the Spaniards,\" he said. \"I felt that I let the Spanish people down by not winning the gold.\" The 21-year-old Alcaraz said he had not felt that type of pressure in the four Grand Slam finals that he played -- and won -- so far in his career.\n\n\"It was a different type of pressure,\" he said. \"Everyone in Spain wanted Photograph: Amber Searls-USA TODAY Sports/Reuters\n\nThe six-year-old stole hearts with a heartwarming gesture during the match, holding up a sign that read 'Tata je najbolji' (Dad is the best).\n\nHer message undoubtedly uplifted Djokovic's spirits as he faced the formidable challenge posed by Alcaraz.\n\nIMAGE: Novak Djokovic celebrates with his family after winning gold against Carlos Alcaraz. Photograph: Claudia Greco/Reuters\n\nTara has become an integral part of her father's tennis world, making her Wimbledon debut earlier this year. The duo shares an undeniable bond, often exchanging adorable moments that have captivated fans worldwide. Djokovic has even serenaded his daughter with violin performances after his victories.\n\nThe Olympic gold medal is the latest chapter in Djokovic's illustrious career. He overcame stiff competition from rivals like Rafael Nadal and Stefanos Tsitsipas to reach the final.\n\nHis triumph over Alcaraz, the world No. 3, solidifies his status as one of the greatest tennis players of all time.\n\nTHE OLYMPICS, 2024", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rediff.com India Ltd."}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8258911691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:17:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:17:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:15:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/novak-djokovic-completes-collection-with-inspired-gold-at-paris-olympics", "title": "Novak Djokovic completes collection with inspired gold at Paris Olympics", "body": "A gifted triathlete once made a list as a boy of the races he wanted to win. Every major race was on it. This is what the exceptional desire. Every box ticked, every record rewritten, every rival conquered. Greatness in sport is a kind of acceptable greed. It is a constant craving for more.\n\nIt is how Novak Djokovic has brilliantly lived. Everything with him is a record. The 24 Grand Slam singles titles. The 40 ATP Masters 1000s. The eight times as year-end No.1.\n\nBut no Olympic gold.\n\nAnd then on an afternoon in Roland Garros so rugged, so breathtaking and lung-busting, so intense that it made both men weep, Djokovic finally won the Olympic final against Spain's Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (7-3), 7-6 (7-2) in two hours and 50 minutes. He cried in his towel, waved his flag and went into the stands to find his people. You might think he has had enough of Spaniards on this court.\n\nIt's been a rough season for the Serb. Grand Slams eluded him and injury visited. People wondered if he was at pensionable age and spoke of torches being passed and it must have burnt. But perhaps it's exactly what a proud athlete required. A cause to hold tight, a world to defy.\n\nBefore the day's play began, French tennis star Yannick Noah appeared with a stick in his hand and thumped the ground thrice. This ritual, frequent at the Olympics, is inspired by French theatre. It symbolises the start of a performance and asks the audience for its attentiveness. But on this Sunday they immediately had the audience's attention. Both men, 3-3 in head-to-head meetings, arrived wearing the same colour as the shale court. This was red as fire and as warning.\n\nIn the fourth game, the Spaniard fell to 0-40 but used his nerve to extricate himself. In the fifth game, the Serb was down break point thrice and relied on his serve to save him. In the Olympic programme, one of the two venues set aside for boxing is Stade Roland Garros. Certainly for a while this court felt like a ring with two pummelling practitioners.\n\nDjokovic waved his arms in frustration. Alcaraz put his hands on his hips in disbelief. Their body language spoke of the heat of the scrap. The ninth game unspooled as a masterpiece of tension and in hindsight the match turned here. It stretched 18 points, with five break points for Alcaraz, but Djokovic held. He resembled an old, gnarled oak who would take some cutting down.\n\nThe effort of their art was clear on the canvas, for the court was a mess of scars from sliding feet. At 6-5, Djokovic had a set point, only for Alcaraz to hit a forehand winner. This wasn't a match but an interrogation. Then finally in the tie-breaker, the Serb prevailed, sealing it with an athletic forehand stretch volley after 93 minutes. He hadn't shaved for days but his game started to look razor sharp.\n\nOn a balcony fine fellows wielding a trumpet, saxophone and drums belted out music. Below them these two fellows produced an unforgettable concert. Third game of the second set, the Spaniard shanked a forehand long to be down break point. Trouble? Next point he saved it with a whipping forehand winner.\n\nBut the 37-year-old Djokovic started to look like the old Djokovic. That brilliant bully who used to play with a set square. The not-missing geometrician with a game of precision and calculation. He was even hectoring his box which is often a fine sign. He looked involved, Alcaraz animated.\n\nAccording to the Spanish law of on-court manners set down by Rafael Nadal, you don't throw your racket. After an awry backhand in the eighth game, you could tell Alcaraz wanted to break that rule. He didn't, of course, for everything in this match was about control. Of pace, spin, nerves, temperament.\n\nDjokovic chased a lob down, a figure of dedicated desperation, trying to make Alcaraz play an extra shot. The Serb was on the baseline, the Spaniard behind. They are separated by 16 years and you can read it how you want: the Spaniard has 16 years less of worn tissue, the Serb has 16 years more of experience.\n\nIt showed in the second tie-breaker. From his memory the Serb produced two forehands on the dead run of ferocious quality. They were the greatest shots of the day from the greatest player in the game. Alcaraz, deflated, fell to error. And Djokovic just fell to his knees in thanks.\n\nTennis is one of the original nine Olympics sports from 1896 and the first gold was won by a man who went into Irish politics. {"uri": "2024-08-443804643", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:32:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:32:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:30:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/tennis/novak-djokovic-gold-carlos-alcaraz-final-9495194/", "title": "Brutal, precise shotmaking, perfect combination of resolute defence and calculated aggression: how Djokovic defeated Alcaraz", "body": "On Sunday, Djokovic completed the set. In a vintage performance of brutal, precise shotmaking and the perfect combination of resolute defence and calculated aggression, he defeated Carlos Alcaraz, the reigning Roland Garros and Wimbledon champion, 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) to win the gold medal at the Paris Olympics - the one tennis achievement that has evaded a resume that contains 24 Majors, all nine Masters 1000 titles, and triumphs at the ATP Finals and Davis Cup.\n\nAs the top seed and most legendary presence on the tour, that may not come as a total surprise. But to put the achievement, given where his tennis has been over the last year, in context; to understand why he defies all convention as a tennis champion, go back to his favourite proverb.\n\nSome time around last year, Djokovic's shoes became a bit too comfortable. The Serb won three of the four Majors in 2023 and reached all four finals. He ended all debate by becoming the outright leader in the all-time Grand Slam leaderboard, winning at least three titles at each of the four tournaments. After reaching the highest of highs, the burning fire began to flicker.\n\nA few pesky pebbles would make it into his boots over the next six months. After a sluggish start to 2024, recovery from a knee injury, and subsequent surgery, a few weeks prior to Wimbledon may have been a big hurdle, but he responded by reaching the final. Humiliation from a 16-years-younger challenger in the summit clash may have fuelled all sorts of uncertainty, but Djokovic found a new source of motivation to thrive on.\n\nAdversity into steel\n\nFew players, if any, have shared Djokovic's aptitude of turning adversity into steel. The begrudgingly polite Parisian crowds would witness every bit of that aptitude this past week.\n\nAfter winning four Majors, including the French Open and Wimbledon back-to-back, Alcaraz's star has risen at a pace faster than the hefty expectations that have followed him ever since he became a teenaged World No. 1. On Sunday, he was not even mildly off the pace, but on an intense, high-wired afternoon, Djokovic found his very best at the crucial moments, and typically found another gear to go to in the two tiebreakers, to outplay him for the win.\n\nThis was an enthralling baseline contest; the first set alone lasted nearly 100 minutes. Unlike the beleaguered straight-sets loss at Wimbledon a month ago, Djokovic went toe-to-toe with Alcaraz from the baseline even when the Spaniard was finding big mileage behind his forehand and moving with speed to cover all corners of the court.\n\nBoth players failed to blink - Alcaraz saved five break points and Djokovic saved eight - but it was the mammoth ninth game of the first set in which Djokovic raised his level, saving five break points, and never looked back. As it went to a breaker, Djokovic locked down and Alcaraz let his level fall just enough for the Serb to take advantage.\n\nNeither player let their levels fall too much in the second, even as the Spaniard faced a mountain to climb. A few fascinating, intense exchanges followed and a second breaker ensued in which Alcaraz raised his baseline game only for Djokovic to up the ante further and slap a few huge groundstrokes and see out the win.\n\nUltimately, the precision of Djokovic's racquet - the pinpoint T-serves, the lunging forehand winners, the error-free tiebreakers - propelled him to a deserved win.\n\nThat same vague parlour debate may be triggered once again, a presumption that it had been put to bed last year itself would have been fair. But by finding his best tennis against the best player in the world to win the one title that has eluded him, there could be no louder statement of intent from Djokovic that he still belongs at the top of the pile in men's tennis - even if he is competing with those closer to his children's age than his. Djokovic-Nadal at Roland Garros has been one of the great fixtures of modern sport. They've faced each other 60 times, with Djokovic now leading Nadal 31-29. The Spanish stalwart is in the twilight of his career and Djokovic was able to make easy work of this one. {"uri": "2024-08-443798024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "18:19:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T18:19:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:58:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/olympic-games/20240804-djokovic-says-gold-probably-biggest-success-eyes-2028-olympics", "title": "Djokovic says gold 'probably biggest success', eyes 2028 Olympics", "body": "Paris (AFP) - Novak Djokovic described his Olympic gold medal triumph on Sunday as \"probably\" his \"biggest sporting success\" and revealed he may defend the title at the 2028 Los Angeles Games when he will be 41.\n\nDjokovic, competing in his fifth Games, came through 7-6 (7/3), 7-6 (7/2) against Carlos Alcaraz in an enthralling final at Roland Garros to add Olympic gold to his 24 Grand Slam triumphs.\n\n\"This is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had and the most special feeling,\" said the 37-year-old Serb.\n\n\"I thought carrying the flag at the opening ceremony for my country at the 2012 Olympics was the best feeling an athlete could have until today.\n\n\"Now at the age of 37 and facing a 21-year-old who is probably the best player in the world right now, winning Roland Garros and Wimbledon back-to-back, I can say that this is probably the biggest sporting success I have ever had.\"\n\nVictory on Sunday allowed him to join Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal, Steffi Graf and the watching Serena Williams as the only players to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic singles gold, completing the career Golden Slam.\n\nBefore defeating Alcaraz on Sunday, his best performance at the Olympics had been in 2008 at Beijing when he won bronze. He had also lost three semi-finals.\n\nNow he wants to keep playing and has not ruled out trying to win back-to-back golds at Los Angeles in four years' time.\n\n\"I want to play in Los Angeles, I El clasico. Congratulations to you and your team for an excellent Olympics. Considering your age, your energy and the way you play, you probably have 20 more Olympics ahead of you ??. Plus, every event streaming ad free, live and on demand with 4K on Stan Sport.\n\nA combined 13 break points went begging, with Alcaraz in particular left to rue the eight he left unconverted.\n\nIt wasn't until 3-3 in the tiebreak that Djokovic was able to blow the set open, claiming the mini-break and the subsequent three points to take the opener.\n\nThe second set wasn't much different.\n\nBoth men refused to allow the other an easy service game over nearly an hour and a half but equally failed to break, although there were far fewer clear-cut opportunities - only one break point, compared to the first set's 13.\n\nAgain, the tiebreak was the first time that Djokovic found some breathing space, getting the mini-break on the very first point and another shortly afterwards, which proved enough to finally secure his place at the top of an Olympic podium.\n\nEarlier, Italy's Lorenzo Musetti toppled Felix Auger-Aliassime in the bronze medal match to secure third Alcaraz responded to one in his first service game by pouring in an ace followed by a beautiful drop shot.\n\nIn his next service game he fell behind 0-40 before fighting off all three break points to stay on serve. Then with the first set tied, 2-2, Djokovic was the one with a timely response, rallying from 0-40 to eventually secure the game.\n\nWith the first set tied, 4-4, this duo submitted one of the most riveting games of this sparkling rivalry. There were constant swings during the 18-point game. Alcaraz pumped both fists and roared when he secured a break point of the game with a powerful backhand down the line. But Djokovic turned back that break opportunity for Alcaraz as well as five others in the game.\n\nBut the marathon finally ended with Djokovic finding a way on the 18th and final point, and the crowd rose to its feet in appreciation of a stunning sequence.\n\nDjokovic led, 6-5, when he lined up the first set point of the opening set. But Alcaraz was predictably unfazed, winning the next three to force a tiebreak.\n\nWith the tiebreak tied, 3-3, Djokovic finally created some separation during this tense and taut set, rolling off four points in a row and storming to the net to drop in a winner on his first set point, pumping his fist as he walked away after a marathon 93-minute opening set.\n\nAlcaraz seemed slightly less comfortable early in the second set, perhaps frustrated by his missed opportunities in the first and the realization that he had just two sets to rectify things.\n\nBut he is far too talented to crumble. He pushed away break point in his second service game, and in his third he shook off an early 30-15 deficit thanks to a beautiful rally at the net that ended with a well-placed ball near the sideline and a pump of the fist.\n\nHe tried to build on that momentum with a strong net finish the following game, putting his right hand to his ear to persuade the crowd to get even louder. But Djokovic had an answer, just as he did for most of the afternoon. He finished off the game and held his racket in the air, the second set knotted at 3.\n\nAt 4-all, Djokovic rallied from 40-0 to force deuce. A lengthy and pivotal groundstroke rally finally ended when both players moved to the net, with Alcaraz regaining control with a powerful forehand down the line. He put his hand to his ear once again while Djokovic bent over with his hands on his knees for several moments. Alcaraz won the game, but Djokovic was unbowed, eventually forcing another tiebreak.\n\nDjokovic started with a sweeping forehand that gave him a mini-break, then took a 2-0 lead on his serve when he It also already contained a Summer Olympics medal, from 2008, but it was a bronze -- and he has made clear that simply was not sufficient.\n\nAlso Read | Former Olympic Medallist Boxer Vijender Singh Opens Up On Nishant Dev's Controversial Loss in Paris Olympics 2024 Men's 71 Kg Quarterfinal, Says 'I Think Very Close Fight' (See Post).\n\nUntil he got past bronze medalist Lorenzo Musetti of Italy in the semifinals Friday, Djokovic was 0-3 in that round at the Games. He lost to the eventual gold winner each time: Rafael Nadal at Beijing in 2008, Andy Murray at London in 2012, and Alexander Zverev in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nIn Paris, wearing a gray sleeve over the right knee that required surgery for a torn meniscus two months ago, Djokovic faced Nadal in the second round and eliminated his longtime rival in straight sets. Now Djokovic is the oldest man to win the singles gold in his sport since 1908 -- and prevented Spain's Alcaraz, who is 21, from becoming the youngest. Novak Djokovic became the oldest gold medalist in the Olympic Tennis Event since 1988 at the age of 37 years.\n\nWhat is a Golden slam?\n\nA Golden Slam is when a player wins an Olympic gold medal in addition to each of the four Grand Slam competitions (Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, US Open). Steffi Graf is the only player to accomplish this feat in a single year (1988), however the Bryan brothers also won their games in a row. {"uri": "8258830077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:52:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:52:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:51:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://talksport.com/olympics/1996384/carlos-alcaraz-forced-stop-interview-tears-olympics-novak-djokovic/", "title": "Alcaraz forced to stop interview as he breaks down in tears after Olympics loss", "body": "Carlos Alcaraz gave it his absolute all against Novak Djokovic in the Olympic final on Sunday, but fell just short.\n\nAlcaraz was beaten 7-6 7-6 by Djokovic in a blockbuster final that was decided by two tie-breaks, with neither player able to break each other's serve.\n\nIt was the first major final that the Spaniard has lost in his career, having previously won all four of his Grand Slam finals so far.\n\nThe emotions told at the end of the match as he was being interviewed by compatriot Alex Corretja for Eurosport.\n\nThe 21-year-old needed to stop the interview as he broke down in tears.\n\nHe walked away for a few moments to compose himself before resuming the interview.\n\nOn losing the final, Alcaraz said: \"It's painful to lose the way I lost this match. I had my chances to probably be up in the match. I couldn't take it.\n\n\"Novak was playing great. He deserves this. In the tough moments he increased his level. He played unbelievable shots.. an unbelievable game.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed but honestly I'll leave the court with my head really really high. I gave everything I had. Fighting for Spain was everything to me. I'm proud with the way I played today.\"\n\nIt was a complete contrast of emotions on the court as Djokovic was completely overjoyed at completing the career 'Golden Slam'.\n\nAn Olympic gold medal was the only thing missing from his collection and becomes just the fifth person ever to win all five major titles.\n\nDjokovic cried tears of joy and made his way up to his family sitting in his box.\n\nThere he hugged his wife and two children and sobbed after finally completing his goal.\n\nSpeaking after his victory, he said: \"I'm overwhelmed with everything I'm feeling right now. Feeling different emotions. Too proud. Too happy.\n\n\"Thrilled with the possibility to win a gold for the first time in my career for my country. Arguably the biggest success I had. I won probably everything there is to win in my individual career.\n\n\"Winning Davis Cup and particularly a golden medal at age 37 for Serbia is unprecedented. I'm just starting my celebration. I can't wait for what's coming up in the next 48 hours.\"\n\nWhen asked if it was the missing piece of the puzzle, he said: \"Yes it is. It is.\n\n\"I'm telling myself always that I am enough. Because I can be very self critical. I don't know. That's one of the biggest internal battles I keep on fighting with myself. That I feel like I haven't done enough or been enough in my life on and off the court.\n\n\"So it's a big lesson for me. {"uri": "8260146365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "13:07:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T13:07:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:06:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://starofmysore.com/paris-summer-olympics-2024-finally-its-gold-for-djokovic/", "title": "Paris Summer Olympics - 2024: Finally, it's gold for Djokovic! - Star of Mysore", "body": "Paris: Tears flowed freely as Novak Djokovic sat in his chair, overwhelmed by the weight of his monumental achievement. The 37-year-old Serbian legend secured his place in the history as the oldest man to win an Olympic gold medal in tennis singles since Miloslav Mecir in 1988. His emotional moment came after a thrilling three-hour battle against Spain's rising star Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nThe match, held on the iconic clay courts of Roland Garros yesterday, was a testament to Djokovic's enduring skill and tenacity. In a dramatic display of tennis prowess, he triumphed in straight sets, 7-6(3), 7-6(2), marking the culmination of years of relentless pursuit. As Djokovic clinched the final point, he erupted in celebration, but the real tears came when he sat down, hugging his parents as he processed the magnitude of his victory.\n\nSurrounded by a chorus of cheers from fans and the supportive embrace of his team, Djokovic's tears were a poignant reminder of his journey -- one marked by relentless dedication and passion. The Olympic gold medal, a prize that had long eluded him, now completed his extraordinary collection of titles, which includes all four Grand Slams, all ATP Masters and the Davis Cup.\n\nDjokovic is the fifth player to complete a career Golden Slam after Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi, Rafael Nadal and Serena Williams. He is also the first to win the men's singles gold without dropping a set since 1988 Seoul Olympic Games.", "source": {"uri": "starofmysore.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Star of Mysore"}, {"uri": "8258930546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "17:37:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T17:37:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:36:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.10sballs.com/2024/08/04/mens-olympic-tennis-finals-%e2%80%a2-novak-djokovic-beats-carlos-alcaraz-for-the-gold-%e2%80%a2-and-so-much-more-by-alix-ramsay/", "title": "Men's Olympic Tennis Finals * Novak Djokovic Beats Carlos Alcaraz For the Gold * And so much more By Alix Ramsay - 10sBalls.com * TennisBalls.com", "body": "In his fifth Olympic Games, at the age of 37 and with a gammy right knee Novak Djokovic is finally the Olympic champion.\n\nHe becomes only the fifth player to win a Golden Career Slam after Andre Agassi, Rafa Nadal, Steffi Graf and Serena Williams. There is now not a tournament of note that Djokovic has not won.\n\nUntil this week, his Olympic reward for a lifetime of effort had been one bronze medal won back in 2008 in Beijing. He had never come close to the gold medal before - this was his first Olympic final.\n\nSo when, at last, he put away Carlos Alcaraz 7-6, 7-6, he fell to his knees and sobbed like a baby. He stood and gave thanks to the heavens, still blubbing, and then collapsed in his chair and howled into his towel. He could not stop.\n\nThe poor ball girl holding a neatly folded Serbia flag didn't know what to do. She had been told to give him the flag but here she was standing beside a grown man in floods of tears. She looked slightly panic stricken: Djokovic was temporarily lost in his own world. After what must have seemed like an eternity to that ball girl, he mopped his eyes and took the flag and held it up to the Serbian fans before running off to celebrate with his team and his family.\n\nHe knew this was his last chance to win gold. He will be 41 by the time the next Olympics come around and will, in all probability, be long retired by then. But to claim it, he had to get past the French Open and Wimbledon champion, the man who had given him a lesson in winning big finals just three weeks ago.\n\nThe final was the match the Olympic tennis tournament had been crying out for. In truth, it had been a pretty nondescript event until this point after a small herd of players withdrew at the eleventh hour through illness and injury. Add to that group the players who did not think the diversion back to red clay before the American hard court swing was worth the risk and the two singles fields looked pretty sparse.\n\nNo matter: Djokovic was a man on a mission. His problem was that Alcaraz was on a similar mission. From the very start, it was clear that the 24-time Grand Slam champion was playing lights out simply to stay in contention while Alcaraz still had a couple of gears to go through to reach his peak. Yet it came down to determination and steely focus: Djokovic simply would not let go of his dream.\n\nAlcaraz was in turn brilliant, powerful, aggressive and wasteful. There were clumping winners from his forehand - the forehand that Djokovic was trying so hard to keep away from - and careless errors. And his serve was not behaving itself. He repelled all six of the break points he faced but could not convert any of the eight he manufactured on soon-to-be champion's serve. The longer it went on, the more the nerves and the frustrations showed.\n\nAt the other end of the court, Djokovic looked like a spring coiled so tightly that it may snap at any moment. Somehow, he held himself together to take the first set and from there, he dug in as only he can. If Alcaraz ran him ragged, he gulped in air and stood up to take more punishment. If Alcaraz showed him the merest sign of weakness, he pounced. And after two hours and 52 minutes, he was the Olympic champion. The tears could flow.\n\n\"I'm telling myself always that I am enough,\" he told NBC. \"Because I can be very self critical. I don't know. That's one of the biggest internal battles I keep on fighting with myself. That I feel like I haven't done enough or been enough in my life on and off the court. So it's a big lesson for me. I'm super grateful for the blessing to win a historic gold medal for my country. To complete the golden slam. To complete all the records.\"\n\nAnd then he was asked, \"is this enough?\". The reply could be read many different ways: \"I think so,\" he said. Who knows what the golden champion's future holds after this. He will either be the all-conquering super hero in New York or he will be utterly spent.\n\nThe Olympics marked the end of the careers of Andy Murray and Angie Kerber and it may have been the last time we see Nadal at Roland-Garros. After being crushed by Djokovic in the second round, Rafa sounded very dubious about his chances of making the US Open. He is signed up for the Laver Cup in Germany in September but with his fragile body held together by bandages and will power, he might not go much further than Berlin.\n\nAnd as a few passing thoughts on the Olympics in general, what was that mascot all about? Over the years, most of the Olympic mascots have been incomprehensible mish-mashes of PR and marketing gobbledegook and the French one was no different. The red blob that snuck into every camera angle was called, officially, a Phryge (no, we don't know how to pronounce it either).\n\nIt is based on the Phrygian cap or \"bonnet phrygien\" as worn by the French Revolutionaries in 1789. In other words, a red hat but one that represents the revolutionary spirit of libert\u00e9, \u00e9galit\u00e9, fraternit\u00e9. But just as a camel was famously decribed by Sir Alec Issigonis as \"a horse designed by a committee\", the Olympic Phryge is neither hatlike nor revolutionary.\n\nIn concept, it is worthy and terribly French. But unless you happen to be French or well versed in French history, it resembles... how to put this delicately? Think of the poop emoji only in red. Nonetheless, it has been everywhere and it would seem that Phryges breed like rabbits. The BBC coverage was covered with the things and from having one or two in the main studio on day one, there was a whole family of them on the studio sofa come the start of the athletics programme: Mama and Papa Phryge with a host of little, baby Phrygelettes. They had been busy.\n\nRed blobs notwithstanding, the Paris Olympics has been a resounding success so far. The stands at all events have been packed, the crowds have been enthusiastic and - as they should be - partisan and everyone looks to be having a fabulous time. Once the rain relented on day two (and the athletes had dried out from their drenching during the opening ceremony), the sport has been excellent and the atmosphere electric. So get yourself a Phryge and vive la France.", "source": {"uri": "10sballs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "10sBalls.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "alix_ramsay@10sballs.com", "name": "Alix Ramsay", {"uri": "8258795950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:17:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:17:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:16:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.dimsumdaily.hk/novak-djokovic-clinches-elusive-olympic-gold-defeats-alcaraz-in-roland-garros-rematch/", "title": "Novak Djokovic clinches elusive Olympic gold, defeats Alcaraz in Roland Garros rematch", "body": "4th August 2024 - (Paris) Novak Djokovic achieved a career-defining moment by capturing the elusive Olympic gold medal. The Serbian tennis maestro, who has rewritten the records books with his unparalleled success, added the prestigious Olympic title to his impressive accolades by overcoming Carlos Alcaraz in a riveting showdown at Roland Garros.\n\nHaving suffered a disappointing defeat to Alcaraz in the Wimbledon final just three weeks prior, Djokovic seized the opportunity for redemption with a resounding 7-6 (3) 7-6 (2) victory in a 3-hour match. The triumph not only secured gold for Serbia but also etched Djokovic's name in history as the oldest Olympic men's singles champion at the age of 37.\n\nThe match's intensity peaked during a gripping 93-minute first set, where Djokovic's strategic prowess shone through as he claimed the crucial tiebreak. {"uri": "8258101263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "03:15:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T03:15:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T03:13:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/2024-olympic-schedule-for-aug-4-novak-djokovic-vs-carlos-alcaraz-suni-lee-and-noah-lyles-go-for-gold-032113401.html", "title": "2024 Olympic schedule for Aug. 4: Novak Djokovic vs. Carlos Alcaraz; Suni Lee and Noah Lyles go for gold", "body": "The U.S. women's basketball team is back in action on Sunday to wrap up group play, and Noah Lyles will attempt to win a medal in the men's 100-meter as track and field action continues at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Oh, and there's an incredible tennis final between Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic on tap in what should be a great day of action in France.\n\nHere's what we're looking forward to most on Sunday in Paris.\n\nIt's time for another battle between two of the top tennis players in the world. Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic will square off Sunday in the singles gold medal match at Roland Garros. At 21, Alcaraz is now the youngest to ever compete for an Olympic gold on the men's side while Djokovic, 37, is the oldest.\n\nThis will mark the seventh matchup between the two stars, and the first since Alcaraz beat Djokovic in straight sets to claim the Wimbledon title last month. Alcaraz has yet to drop a single set in the tournament.\n\nThe men's 100-meter final is set for Sunday afternoon, and American Noah Lyles is right in the mix for a medal despite a rough preliminary day on Saturday. Lyles finished his heat in second place which, while enough to move him into the semifinals, was his slowest run in more than a year.\n\nThe semifinals for the 100-meter will start at 2 p.m. ET, and if he makes it through the final will start just before 4 p.m.\n\nThe individual apparatus finals continue in gymnastics with the uneven bars. Suni Lee is the only American qualified for Sunday's final. She took bronze in the event at the Tokyo Olympics and will look to collect another medal in Paris.\n\nThe U.S. will have one last shot at trying to catch Australia in swimming golds in these Olympics. Australia swimmers enter the day with seven golds to USA's six.\n\nAmerican Gretchen Walsh will go for gold in the 50-meter freestyle, and the U.S. will also have a shot at winning both the men's and women's 4x100 medley relay races to cap the night.\n\nThe U.S. women's basketball team will wrap up group play on Sunday with a matchup against Germany, which will also enter the matchup with a perfect 2-0 record so far in France. Team USA has already clinched a quarterfinal berth after they beat Belgium on Thursday, which marked their 57th consecutive Olympics win. That streak dates back to 1992.\n\nGermany has also secured a quarterfinals berth already, so Sunday's game isn't a must-win for either side. But with the win streak and seeding for the knockout stage on the line, a 3-0 start in pool play would be huge for the Americans on their quest to another gold medal.\n\nThe final round of the men's golf tournament kicks off on Sunday morning outside of Paris, and Xander Schauffele is in a great spot to defend his gold medal.\n\nThe reigning British Open winner holds a share of the lead with Spain's Jon Rahm at 14-under entering the final round. Great Britain's Tommy Fleetwood will start just a shot back in third. Both Ireland's Rory McIroy and USA's Scottie Scheffler are within striking distance, too, though they'll start the day four shots back.\n\nThe final round will start at 3 a.m. ET and can be seen on Djokovic prevailed 7-6, 7-6 in Paris in a tight affair where the opening set lasted more than 90 minutes.\n\nThe 37-year-old cut an emotional figure after claiming the only title to elude him in tennis, having not lost a set in the competition. Djokovic also defeated Matt Ebden, Rafael Nadal, Dominik Koepfer, Stefanos Tsitsipas and Lorenzo Musetti on his way to the final\n\nThe 24-times grand slam winner might yet have more lofty ambitions, despite his advanced age. Djokovic has one eye on the next Olympics in four years time.\n\nThat provoked Serbia team captain and former world number 12 Troicki, to pop his head through the door. Djokovic's countryman could only laugh.\n\n\"Look, I still, I want to play in Los Angeles, said Djokovic. \"I enjoy playing for my country in Olympic Games particularly and Davis Cup. It's something that, being part of a team... [Troicki emerges]\n\n\"He's making fun of my calendar goals, playing in Los Angeles. I don't know if he's laughing because he thinks it's unrealistic or he's like, okay, another four years with this guy.\"\n\nDjokovic admitted that his Paris outing could be his last opportunity for success however. \"Olympic Games come every four years so the opportunity to win gold for your country is very rare and I knew the fact that I'm 37 and I don't know how many more chances I would have,\" he added.\n\nEven on this occasion, Djokovic knew it would be a difficult task. The Olympic champion new from the early stages of his time in France that he would earn the chance to play for gold\n\n\"I was ready for this tournament and I didn't drop a set [in the] entire tournament,\" he said. \"I knew already in the first opening two rounds the way I was playing that this is my chance. If it's ever going to be, it's going to be now.\n\n\"When I qualified for the finals I felt a big relief because that's the hurdle I wasn't able to surpass in the past. The German company dropped Djoko in 2009 and replaced him with Andy Murray.\n\nMeanwhile companied like Lacoste, Asics, Head, NetJets, Peugeot, Raiffeisen Bank International, Ultimate Software Group and Hublot have business deals with him. {"uri": "8259040470", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:51:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:51:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T19:50:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13708043/Olympics-Tennis-Ill-stronger-says-proud-Alcaraz-missing-gold.html", "title": "Olympics-Tennis-I'll be back stronger, says proud Alcaraz after...", "body": "By Martyn Herman and Sybille de La Hamaide\n\nPARIS, Aug 4 - Spain's Carlos Alcaraz said he could walk away with his head held high after coming up just short in his quest for gold in his debut Olympics, losing to Novak Djokovic in a superb men's final at Roland Garros on Sunday.\n\nTwo months ago Alcaraz walked off Court Philippe Chatrier all smiles after beating Alexander Zverev to win the French Open before going on to beat Djokovic in the Wimbledon final.\n\nThis time, on the same Parisian dirt, he was almost inconsolable after losing 7-6(3) 7-6(2) to the inspired Serb he described afterwards as 'hungry for gold'.\n\n\"He didn't let me take the chances, so I have to give credit to him as well,\" Alcaraz, who rued failing to convert any of the eight break points that came his way, told reporters.\n\n\"I'm really proud and I'm leaving the court and leaving the tournament with the head really high, knowing that I gave everything on the court.\n\n\"I'm really happy about my performance today, probably a little bit disappointed about not playing at my best status in some situations, in difficult situations. But I will be back stronger and learn from this.\"\n\nThe four-time Grand Slam champion said his tears after the match were because he felt like he \"let down Spain\", adding that the extra pressure of playing for the flag rather than himself had affected him at some crucial moments on Sunday.\n\nBut no one who has watched the passion the 21-year-old brought to his first Olympic tournament, in singles and doubles, alongside Rafa Nadal, could criticise him.\n\nCertainly not two-time Olympic gold-medallist Nadal.\n\n\"Carlos, although I know that today is a difficult day, appreciate a medal that is very important for the whole country,\" 22-time Grand Slam champion Nadal said in an Instagram post. \"Thank you for this incredible week and for a medal that you give to Spanish sport.\"\n\nDespite having to settle for silver, Alcaraz said his first taste of the Olympics had been special.\n\n\"This has been a different week, it's not what we're used to. There's the Olympic village, all the athletes. You can watch other sports, you can root for Spain in different disciplines,\" he said. \"Tennis is usually very lonely, you're usually by yourself but this week I played with Rafa, my idol.\n\n\"I've learnt from him so it's been a wonderful week. Djokovic has become the first man in the Open Era to win gold at the Olympics without dropping a set after defeating Carlos Alcaraz in straight sets in the Paris 2024 final.\n\nThe tennis great booked his place in the gold medal match at Roland Garros by beating Matthew Ebden 6-0, 6-1, Rafael Nadal 6-1, 6-4, Dominik Koepfer 7-5, 6-3, Stefanos Tsitsipas 6-3, 7-6 (7-3) and Lorenzo Musetti 6-4, 6-2.\n\nOn the back of beating those five players without dropping a set, he had to avoid going the distance against Alcaraz to join Serena Williams as the only players to win Olympic singles gold without a set.\n\nAnd he defeated his Spanish rival 7-6 (7-5), 7-6 (7-2) in just under three hours on Court Philippe-Chatrier to achieve the rare feat.\n\nDjokovic also notched up several other records as he became the oldest player to win gold at the Olympics as he was 37 years and 76 days at the time of the final while he became the fifth player to complete a career Golden Slam.\n\nBack in 2012, Williams defeated Jelena Jankovic, Urzula Radwa\u0144ska, Vera Zvonareva, Caroline Wozniacki, Victoria Azarenka and Maria Sharapova to win gold at the London Games.\n\nThe feat has been achieved three times in the doubles with Serena Williams doubling up at the 2012 London Olympics as she teamed up with sister Venus to win the women's doubles.\n\nThe Americans defeated Simona Halep and Sorana C\u00eerstea of Romania in the first round and followed it up with a win over Angelique Kerber and Sabine Lisicki of Germany. Hlavackova and Lucie Hradecka of the Czech Republic in teh gold medal match.\n\nNovak Djokovic sets Olympic record and matches Steffi Graf, Andre Agassi Rafael Nadal, Serena Williams with career at the Rio Games as they beat the Swiss part of Timea Bacsinszky and Martina Hingis 6-4, 6-4 in the final.\n\nBut the first players to win Olympic gold without dropping a set were the American pair of His emotional moment came after a thrilling three-hour battle against Spain's rising star, Carlos Alcaraz, at the Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\nThe match, held on the iconic clay courts of Roland Garros on Sunday, was a testament to Djokovic's enduring skill and tenacity. In a dramatic display of tennis prowess, he triumphed in straight sets, 7-6(3), 7-6(2), marking the culmination of years of relentless pursuit.\n\nAs Djokovic clinched the final point, he erupted in celebration, but the real tears came when he sat down, hugging his parents and siblings as he processed the magnitude of his victory.\n\nSurrounded by a chorus of cheers from fans and the supportive embrace of his team, Djokovic's tears were a poignant reminder of his journey -- one marked by relentless dedication and passion. The Olympic gold medal, a prize that had long eluded him, now completed his extraordinary collection of titles, which includes all four Grand Slams, all ATP Masters, and the Davis Cup.\n\nFor Alcaraz, the final marked a different narrative. Despite his valiant effort and recent triumph over Djokovic at Wimbledon, the 21-year-old Spaniard had to settle for silver in his Olympic debut. The young star's future remains bright, as he continues to promise a new chapter in tennis.\n\nAs Djokovic savored his historic win, the tears of triumph spoke volumes about a career defined by {"uri": "8259802969", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:31:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:31:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:30:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/tennis-shifts-from-the-olympics-to-the-us-open-after-golds-for-novak-djokovic-and/article_b4a44ba9-2ac0-5799-94f2-c85def930602.html", "title": "Tennis shifts from the Olympics to the US Open after golds for Novak Djokovic and Zheng Qinwen", "body": "Coco Gauff of United States cries after arguing with the umpires during her women's singles third round match against Donna Vekic of Croatia, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris, France.\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Hours after he knelt on the red clay, after his body shook as he cried, after he finally got to kiss an Olympic gold medal won for Serbia, Novak Djokovic was asked whether he can consider his tennis career complete.\n\nHe already had 24 Grand Slam trophies, after all, putting him ahead of rivals Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer -- and every other man who's played the game. He already had a record 400-plus weeks ranked No. 1. And now, at age 37, he collected the gold he desperately wanted, something Nadal (in singles in 2008 and doubles in 2016) and Federer (in doubles in 2008) had but Djokovic did not until Sunday's 7-6 (3), 7-6 (2) victory over Carlos Alcaraz.\n\n\"Yes and no,\" is how Djokovic's answer began. \"Yes, it's complete, because I completed all the achievements with this gold medal. But no, because I love this sport. I don't play it only to win the tournament -- I play it because I really love competition. I love the drive, every day, every week, of training my body, perfecting my game, proving myself, still at this age.\"\n\nIt is surely a mistake to view every step Djokovic takes, every prize he wins, as a statement in the ongoing and unnecessary conversation about which member of the Big Three of men's tennis is the best of the bunch. Still, those debates carry on.\n\nWho can possibly say what comes next for Djokovic -- or Nadal or Alcaraz or women's singles gold medalist Zheng Qinwen of China or No. 1 Iga Swiatek, for that matter. With the U.S. Open starting in three weeks, and the need to shift from the clay at Roland Garros to the hard courts at Flushing Meadows, there's not much time for rest or reflection.\n\n\"I don't know about the future, to be honest. I really want ... a moment to celebrate,\" Djokovic said. \"It was a long journey. \"\n\nZheng Qinwen is the latest addition to the list of young tennis stars\n\nStill just 21, the same age as Alcaraz, Zheng became the first player from China to win an Olympic tennis singles gold.\n\nHer run to the Australian Open final in January marked her as someone to watch. So did her rise into the top 10. This will make her a big star at home and, if she stays on this trajectory, there should be more to come.\n\nSwiatek is just 23. Reigning U.S. Open champion Coco Gauff is 20. Add Zheng to the youth movement.\n\nHer strokes were always there, and now her mind is, too, she says. Zheng showed patience and toughness while ending Swiatek's 25-match winning streak at Roland Garros, eliminating her in the semifinals.\n\nAfter defeating Donna Vekic in the final Saturday, Zheng said she thinks she'll play more relaxed now that she's an Olympic champion. If so, look out.\n\n\"I still have a long way to go,\" she said, \"because winning a Grand Slam is always my dream.\"\n\nWill Rafael Nadal play in the U.S. Open?\n\nNadal is 38 and lost to Djokovic in the second round of singles play, after bowing out in the first round of this year's French Open, where he has won 14 of his 22 major titles. Nadal and Alcaraz generated a ton of buzz as an old-and-young doubles team before losing in the quarterfinals.\n\nAfter that defeat, Nadal was asked about playing in New York -- he was on the entry list released last month -- and paused for a while before responding.\n\n\"Looks like not. But I'm going to let you know soon,\" Nadal said. \"For me, now, I can't give you a clear answer. I need some time, but for me, (it) looks difficult.\"\n\nCoco Gauff heads back to the U.S. Open\n\nThe trip to the U.S. Open for Gauff will mark the one-year anniversary of a big occasion: She won her first Grand Slam title there in 2023.\n\nIt will be her first defense of a major championship, although she insists she does not see it as a \"defense,\" just an opportunity.\n\nGauff often speaks about taking lessons away from losses. It should be fascinating to watch her at Flushing Meadows after her Olympics experience, which included joining LeBron James as a U.S. flag bearer at the opening ceremony along the Seine River, an impromptu breakfast with Noah Lyles just days before he wound up winning the 100-meter dash at the track -- and early exits in singles, women's doubles and mixed doubles.\n\n\"I'll try to take the positive out of it,\" Gauff said, \"and do better next time.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Yet despite his disappointment at his defeat to Novak Djokovic in the gold-medal match on Court Philippe-Chatrier, the Olympic flame inside the Spaniard remains well and truly alight.\n\n\"I always want to win, that's for sure, but taking the silver medal, I have to be really proud,\" said Alcaraz in post-match comments made to NBC. \"I'm building a really great career and I hope it's going to keep going.\n\n\"Honestly, I'm pretty proud to be in this position, I'm pretty proud to bring a medal to Spain. I'm pretty sure that my moment will come, and I will bring the gold medal to Spain one day. So I'm going to wait for that moment and I'm going to work for that moment, but right now I have to enjoy lifting the silver medal, it's pretty amazing as well.\"\n\nAlcaraz has good reason to feel confident about the future. Sunday's loss was a rare low moment in what has otherwise been a largely stellar year for the Spaniard. He lifted his third and fourth major titles at Roland Garros and Wimbledon, respectively, while he also lifted his fifth ATP Masters 1000 crown in Indian Wells in March.\n\nThe No. 3 in the PIF ATP Rankings also knows how close he was to Djokovic in Sunday's high-level encounter. Alcaraz forced the Serbian to fend off eight break points en route to victory, and he will leave Paris satisfied he gave his all in pursuit of Olympic glory.\n\n'It is painful to lose the way that I lost this match. I had my opportunities... I couldn't take them,\" said Alcaraz. \"Novak is playing great, he really settled in his position, in the difficult moments he increased his level, he played unbelievable. I'm really disappointed but honestly, I'm going to leave the court with my head really high. I gave everything that I had fighting for Spain, it was everything to me so I'm proud the way that I played today.\"\n\nThe next few months also promise plenty for Alcaraz, who is currently 38-7 for the season and second in the PIF ATP Live Race To Turin. He is next set to compete at the Cincinnati Open later this month, when he will resume his pursuit of rival and current Live Race leader Jannik Sinner.
