{"uri": "2024-08-444158638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:50:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:50:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/olympics/tennis-olympic-sport-novak-djokovic-tears-change-3209109", "title": "Tennis should not be an Olympic sport and Djokovic's tears won't change my mind", "body": "Novak Djokvoic dreamed of winning a gold medal, but few tennis players share his passion for the Games when it does not suit them\n\nPARIS -- It was undeniably moving to watching Novak Djokovic weep, tremble and convulse with national pride as he hugged his flag-waving wife and children in the stands of Roland Garros.\n\nWinning a gold medal for Serbia has been a lifelong ambition for the 37-year-old and he has now achieved it in what will probably be his last Olympic Games - although rule nothing out in this man's remarkable career.\n\n\"I want to play in Los Angeles,\" Djokovic said, to some surprise. \"I enjoy playing for my country in the Olympic Games particularly.\n\n\"I thought that 2012 opening ceremony, carrying the flag for my country, is the best feeling that an athlete could have, until today. This [winning gold] supersedes everything. Representing my country has always been the greatest priority and honour for me.\"\n\nThe tears alone do not tell the story. Djokovic is not averse to shedding a tear on a tennis court, and his reaction was in keeping with this most lachrymose of Games, probably because this is the first Olympics with full stands since Pyeongchang in 2018.\n\nAnd while the score was straight sets, the 7-6, 7-6 does not reflect the titanic effort required to overcome reigning French Open and Wimbledon champion Carlos Alcaraz, whom it took nearly three hours for Djokovic to dispatch.\n\nBut the magnitude of this final and what it meant to the two men, who both sobbed afterwards, will not change the fact that tennis is not a sport that belongs in the Olympic Games.\n\nAs he so often is, Djokovic is an outlier, rather than the norm.\n\n\"I don't play it only to win the tournament. I play it because I really love competition,\" Djokovic added.\n\n\"I love the drive, every day, every week of training my body, perfecting my game, improving myself still at this age.\"\n\nThis admirable pursuit of perfection is very much in the Olympic spirit. But the pursuit that dominates tennis - of money - is not.\n\nNow the amateur status of the Olympics is certainly fading. Its centrepiece sport athletics will pay each gold medallist $50,000 (\u00a339,000). The International Boxing Association (IBA), thanks to their Russian state energy company sponsor, will pay $100,000 (\u00a379,000) to gold medallists, $50,000 (\u00a339,000) for silver medals and $25,000 (\u00a320,000) for bronze (although it should be noted that the Russian-owned and Kremlin-linked IBA are banned by the Olympic authorities).\n\nIn time, most if not all Olympic athletes will be probably be paid something. It is naive to think that will not change gradually in time. But they will probably never be paid anything like the \u00a32m that Alcaraz earned last time he was in a final at Roland Garros.\n\nYou could argue that the lack of prize money makes Olympic tennis more, not less, pure, but that ignores the very nature of modern tennis. Cash is undeniably king in this sport. You only have to look at the Women's Tennis Association, founded in 1973 by openly gay Billie Jean King to land a huge blow in advocacy and equality for women in sport, which will in a few months hold its biggest tournament of the year in Saudi Arabia, an autocracy where women until 2018 were banned from driving, where they remain subject to a stringent set of male guardianship laws and where they are, along with men too, routinely thrown in prison for political dissent.\n\nOther Olympic sports are guilty of taking money from people who wish to use athletes as a means to a nefarious end of course, but at least those sports still have the decency to make this historic and ultimately worthy event their pinnacle.\n\nAnd that is what should define a sport as one that fits into the Olympics, one of the few events where the world comes together and has the goal of \"promoting peace, friendship and understanding through sport\".\n\nThe Olympic tennis tournament does not fit that mould. Barely a day went by this summer when some player or another declared they would not be playing the Games because it was inconvenient to switch to clay so close to the US Open, where the top players get around \u00a360,000 just for turning up and therefore took far higher priority.\n\nMost athletes regarding merely being selected for the Olympic Games a great honour, and the experience of actually spending time at them hugely enjoyable. Some tennis players do too. But they are increasingly few and far between.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, "authors": [{"uri": "james_gray@inews.co.uk", "name": "James Gray", {"uri": "2024-08-444053842", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "04:21:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T04:21:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:21:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "http://www.atptour.com/en/news/montreal-2024-djokovic-olympics-reactions", "title": "Rune, Tsitsipas, Monfils reflect on Djokovic's win: 'He's completed tennis in a way'", "body": "Rune, Tsitsipas, Monfils reflect on Djokovic's win: 'He's completed tennis in a way'\n\nWhile Novak Djokovic battled Carlos Alcaraz on Sunday in Paris for the Olympic singles gold medal, the rest of the ATP Tour's stars were in Montreal, preparing for the National Bank Open Presented by Rogers. Dozens watched the match in the players' lounge, including No. 1 in the PIF ATP Rankings Jannik Sinner and his team.\n\nAfter the match, the world's best players were in awe of Djokovic's accomplishment. The Serbian defeated Alcaraz to complete his set of 'Big Titles'. He has won all four Grand Slam tournaments, all nine ATP Masters 1000 events, the Nitto ATP Finals and now the Olympic singles gold medal.\n\nHolger Rune thought the match was \"incredible\".\n\n\"I think if there's one person that deserves it so much, it's Novak. He's completed tennis in a way,\" Rune told ATPTour.com. \"He's taking tennis to another level. He's just the greatest. I take massive inspiration from him and I think he's a very nice guy as well.\n\n\"Novak is 37 now and winning the gold medal, I think it shows a little bit on the level he is producing. I think it's completely incredible. Hopefully we'll still see him a few more years on the Tour so we can compete against him.\"\n\nStefanos Tsitsipas explained that he could tell how much Djokovic wanted the final crowning jewel in his collection.\n\n\"He visualised getting a gold medal,\" Tsitsipas said. \"I'm sure he's someone that has been putting a lot of effort into making that happen. It is probably one of the things that he was missing as World No. 1 and a multiple Grand Slam champion, the gold medal. It was something that was not part of his collection.\"\n\nEn route to the gold medal, Djokovic defeated Tsitsipas in a tight two-setter in which the Greek had a big opportunity to claim the second set and force a decider.\n\n\"I felt like I was playing good at the Olympics myself and I had a massive lead against him in the second set. And I honestly did feel like I had some good chances in that particular match,\" Tsitsipas said. \"It was disappointing to see myself lose up there being a double break up in that match. But at least I can say I put my best effort and I lost to the champion, the gold medalist of the Olympic Games. I did try my best. Having played good tennis at Roland Garros, at least getting any kind of medal at the Olympics would have been a dream of mine.\"\n\nPablo Carreno Busta, a close friend of Alcaraz's who also has long trained at Juan Carlos Ferrero's eponymous academy, watched the first set of the gold-medal match before his practice session.\n\n\"I think that they played unbelievable tennis,\" Carreno Busta said. \"It's true that Carlos probably at the beginning was a little bit nervous, but that's normal. For Novak also, it probably was his last chance to [win] the gold medal. I think it was a big spectacle for tennis. Carlos and Novak are probably the best in this moment and we enjoy watching them.\"\n\nThe last player to defeat Djokovic at the Olympic Games was Carreno Busta, in the Tokyo bronze-medal match.\n\n\"Probably I played one of my best tournaments of my career. I remember that when I lost in semi-finals against Karen Khachanov, I thought, 'Well, if I lost against Karen and now I have to play against Novak, how many chances will I have to win the bronze medal?'\" Carreno Busta recalled. \"But then after that I I remember that when I started the match I just thought of doing my best and we'll see what happens. If Novak plays at his 100 per cent, it's true that it's very, very difficult for me to beat him but I know also Novak lost the day before in the semi-finals in singles, also in semi-finals in mixed doubles. So for him it was probably very, very tough mentally, and I think that I took advantage of this.\"\n\nOne of the players on Tour who has known Djokovic the longest is Gael Monfils. Their first Lexus ATP Head2Head match was in 2005 and the Serbian leads their series 19-0. Even so, the Frenchman was thrilled to see Djokovic triumph in Paris.\n\n\"He completed so much before. Novak is a legend in our sport,\" Monfils said. \"He is just completely special. He is completely different, completely special and for him I think it's the biggest accomplishment possible so I'm just super happy for him.\"", "source": {"uri": "atptour.com", "dataType": "news", Here are five must see moments. We focus on the sports of golf, tennis, cycling and athletics.\n\nSports fans are in for a real treat as world number two Novak Djokovic of Serbia is set to face world number three Carlos Alcaraz of Spain. You could tout this match as the greatest player in tennis history against the best player in tennis right now. Alcaraz and Djokovic have beaten each other thrice. Alcaraz, the four-time grand slam champion, beat Djokovic 6-7, 7-5, 7-6 in the semifinals of Madrid in 2022, 1-6, 7-6, 6-1, 3-6, 6-4 in the finals of Wimbledon in 2023, and 6-2, 6-2, 7-6 in the finals of Wimbledon in 2024. Djokovic beat Alcaraz 6-3, 5-7, 6-1, 6-1 in the semifinals of the 2023 French Open, 5-7, 7-6, 7-6 in the finals of Cincinnati in 2023, and 6-3, 6-2 in the semifinals of the 2023 ATP Finals.\n\nXander Schauffele of San Diego is the hottest golfer in the world right now, and will be playing the best the LIV has to offer in Spain's Jon Rahm. Both Schauffele and Rahm are at -14 and tied for the lead heading into Sunday. Schauffele is also the reigning Olympic gold medalist.\n\nOne of the Olympics's signature events takes place on Sunday. The term signature should be used with caution however as at the Olympic Games the men's 100 mete race is worth the same amount when it comes to the overall medal standings as the women's dinghy sailing event or the men's flyweight boxing final. In any case, American Noah Lyles is the favourite after the reigning Olympic bronze medalist ran a time of 9.81 seconds at a Diamond League event in London right before the Olympic Games.\n\nEthan Katzberg of Nanaimo, British Columbia is the reigning world champion in the men's hammer throw. He is trying to become the third Canadian to win an Olympic medal in the event, following Con Walsh of Toronto, Ontario (bronze at the 1908 Olympic Games in London), and Duncan Gillis of Cape Breton, Nova Scotia (silver at the 1912 Olympic Games in Stockholm).\n\nAfter Remco Evenepoel of Belgium accomplished the remarkable double of winning the men's time trial and road race in the same Olympic {"uri": "2024-08-443681586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:06:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:06:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:02:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.thesun.ie/sport/13548022/novak-djokovic-olympics-gold-slam-alcaraz/", "title": "Novak Djokovic finally completes Golden Slam as he adds Olympics gold to haul", "body": "NOVAK DJOKOVIC completed tennis as he fulfilled a 16-year quest to have an Olympic gold medal placed round his neck.\n\nSerbia's sporting superstar, 37, arrived at the Athletes' Village in Saint Denis a few weeks ago having won nearly everything significant in his sport.\n\nHis unmatched success at Grand Slams have seen him surpass his great rivals Roger Federer and Rafa Nadal and means he is considered by many to be the Greatest Of All Time.\n\nThe one thing missing was the Olympic title for his country and in every Olympic cycle since 2008 - in the cities of Beijing, London, Rio and Tokyo - he had ultimately come up short in his mission.\n\nThat is no longer the case after he managed to get one over Carlos Alcaraz in Paris in two hours and 50 minutes, gaining a small measure of revenge for that Wimbledon Centre Court final defeat on July 14.\n\nAn unforgettable 7-6 7-6 victory on the red clay of Roland Garros, in a match for the ages, could end up being a stunning coup de gr\u00e2ce to arguably the best career we have witnessed in the men's side of the game.\n\nIn the build-up, one wag on social media had joked that Alcaraz was on a mission to 'save' tennis for a third time in an eight-week block.\n\nFirst, the 21-year-old prevented the unpopular and arrogant Alex Zverev from winning the French Open as he fought from 2-1 down in sets.\n\nNext up, those from the ABN (Anyone But Novak) brigade would have been happy that he stopped the Belgrade icon from equalling Roger Federer's tally of eight Wimbledon Championships.\n\nThat is a wee bit harsh on Djokovic - who was sporting a protective knee sleeve - and to be fair the attendees on Court Philippe-Chatrier were reasonably well-split with just as many Serbian flags as there were Spanish ones.\n\nBEST FREE BET SIGN UP OFFERS FOR UK BOOKMAKERS\n\nThis was a different crowd to those who watch the French Open annually - much noisier and rowdier and with a crying baby to add to the drama - but it made for a much better atmosphere.\n\nThis was a magnificent match and the margins of error were as fine as they had ever been in their six previous encounters.\n\nThis rivalry, defined by a 16-year age-gap, is one of the most spectacular we have ever seen.\n\nSome of the rallies were spellbinding to watch, this was edge-of-the-seat stuff and often the crowd rose to their feet to afford these racquet-welding gladiators a standing ovation for their gallant efforts.\n\nThere were 13 break-point opportunities in the first set but neither man could make that decisive in-road on their opponent's serve.\n\nA tie-break was required to resolve matters and after Djokovic had enjoyed a mini break with a wondrous forehand return, he moved a set closer to glory.\n\nWhen he converted the first of three set-points with a stretched volley at the net, Djokovic stood still and raised a clenched fist.\n\nThe match clock showed 93 minutes - it was one of the longest sets ever witnessed in Olympic history.\n\nThe second set went with serve through 12 games and you could see how much it meant to Djokovic - and how tight it was all getting - when he argued with the umpire on a serve call.\n\nIn the second tie-break, Djokovic achieved one of his proudest moments when his forehand down the line sailed past Alcaraz.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.ie", "dataType": Roddick believed that the former World No.1 wanted attention before making an appearance at Wimbledon and was different from the rest of the tennis fraternity.\n\n\"I was in the tournament once upon a time, but I was not doing this. He is not like us. He is a little bit different. This is incredible and I can't believe it. {"uri": "8259963400", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:12:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:12:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:11:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/sports/article/2024/08/05/olympic-tennis-novak-djokovic-crowned-king-of-perseverance_6709632_9.html", "title": "Olympic tennis: Novak Djokovic crowned king of perseverance", "body": "In the stands of the Philippe-Chatrier court, the inscription, in large red ochre letters, is visible to all: \"Victory belongs to the most tenacious.\" The quote is attributed to a famous aviator, Roland Garros, who was killed in action during the First World War and who the stadium that is home to the French Open is named after. In keeping with the globalization of tennis, the phrase is also displayed in English.\n\nBut when Novak Djokovic got down on his knees on the clay, raising his arms to the sky in celebration of the Olympic title he had coveted for so long, did his misty eyes even see the words, as if written for him, right in front of him, a few meters above his head?\n\nThe Serbian player, who defeated Carlos Alcaraz (7-6 [3], 7-6 [2]) on Sunday, August 4, in the tournament's finest match, is a model of perseverance. It took a good dose of tenacity to win this hard-fought battle against the 21-year-old Spanish prodigy. In a breathless first set, of the 13 break points - eight for the Spaniard, five for the Serbian - all were saved. This set, in which only the tie-break was unbalanced, lasted an hour and a half.\n\nNumbers don't tell the whole story of the intensity of the encounter and, at times, its sublime violence. More than a match, it was a duel, with sparks of talent and fierce will. For two hours and 50 minutes, the players dealt out racket strokes like uppercuts. Even the most subtle drop shots - and there were plenty of them - were distilled in an attempt to speed up the outcome. A ring of clay, adorned with a net.\n\nOn their own service games, neither of them wavered. Giving in was out of the question. It took another tie-break to break the impasse. At that point, Djokovic's nerves of steel, his years of experience accumulated over the course of his 24 Grand Slam titles, and perhaps also his rarest lost finals, made him unbeatable.\n\nHaving won the French Open in June and then Wimbledon in July - against Djokovic - Alcaraz, who had never conceded a major final, concluded the tournament with his head held high, despite the disappointment. \"I had a hungry Novak in front of me,\" said Alcaraz. \"He played at an impressive level. He did not let me take the chances I had. I gave everything I had on the court.\"\n\nIn recent months, however, the Serbian has had his share of doubts. At the beginning of 2024, he revealed he was feeling low. Then in the spring came injury season, with problems to his right knee prematurely ending his participation at the French Open in June. Had he served his time? Would he recover from his operation in time for the Games? In nine days of tournament play, Djokovic provided very direct answers, always in two sets - he didn't lose a set during the whole tournament.", "source": {"uri": "lemonde.fr", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8259901557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:33:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:33:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:32:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/roland-garros-delivered-tournament-ages-4527296", "title": "Roland Garros delivered a tournament for the ages", "body": "PARIS : Novak Djokovic on his knees sobbing tears of joy into the red Roland Garros clay after finally winning a gold medal will be the defining image of a magnificent Olympic tennis event.\n\nThe 37-year-old's win over Carlos Alcaraz was one of the best Olympic matches since the sport returned to the fold in 1988 and will be prominent in the Paris 2024 highlights reel.\n\nIt was a story for the ages, a man investing every last drop of sweat to achieve a career Golden Slam and one that surely renders arguments about tennis's place in the Games redundant.\n\n\"This kind of supersedes everything that I imagined,\" Djokovic said, describing his Olympic gold medal as his greatest sporting achievement.\n\nWhile it was mission accomplished for the Serb great it was also a job well done by the International Tennis Federation (ITF) who delivered a sensational nine days of tennis.\n\nHelped by an iconic venue, large and passionate crowds and too many story lines to shake a baguette at, it was hard to argue against the Paris tournament being the best yet.\n\nThe sight of Rafa Nadal playing quite possibly for the last time on the court on which he won 14 French Open titles was spine-tingling - especially his two victories alongside Spain's new golden boy Alcaraz. They could not deliver the doubles title but perhaps that was simply too much to ask for.\n\nThree-time Grand Slam champion and two-time Olympic champion Andy Murray waved goodbye for a final time as he headed into retirement - and seemed happy for it to happen in Paris.\n\nThree-time Grand Slam champion Angelique Kerber of Germany also said her farewell to the sport in what felt like a cross-generational Olympic tournament.\n\nChinese sport has a new superstar in the form of 21-year-old Zheng Qinwen who became the country's first Olympic singles champion by beating Donna Vekic in the women's final.\n\nAnd the other end of the spectrum, the high-quality men's doubles final featured 40-year-old American Rajeev Ram - the oldest player to contest an Olympic final since 1988 - in a clash in which the combined age was 147.\n\nAustralian pair Matthew Ebden and John Peers proved worthy winners, as did Czech pairing Katerina Siniakova and Tomas Machac in the mixed doubles.\n\nAnd just to bring the curtain down in fitting fashion, veteran Sara Errani and the ever-smiling Jasmine Paolini claimed Italy's first-ever tennis gold by winning the women's doubles. Like Djokovic, Errani completed her career Golden Slam, only in doubles, and summed up what it meant.\n\n\"This has been the dream for my whole life. {"uri": "2024-08-443700657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "15:34:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T15:34:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T15:34:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "http://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-olympics-2024-big-titles-kings", "title": "Novak Djokovic completes Career Golden Slam to extend Big Titles dominance", "body": "Djokovic completes Career Golden Slam to extend Big Titles dominance\n\nNovak Djokovic once again rewrote the record books on Sunday at the Paris Olympics.\n\nThe 37-year-old defeated Carlos Alcaraz in a scintillating gold-medal match to claim his first Olympics gold medal. By doing so, the Serbian has now won every 'Big Title' up for offer and completed the Career Golden Slam.\n\nDjokovic owns 72 'Big Titles', which are a combination of Grand Slam championships, trophies at the Nitto ATP Finals and ATP Masters 1000 tournaments, and Olympic singles gold medals. The Serbian has claimed at least one Big Title in 16 of the past 18 seasons.\n\nNo other player has won Olympic singles gold, a major and all nine Masters 1000 events. The Serbian owns the standalone men's record for championships at Grand Slams (24), Nitto ATP Finals (7) and Masters 1000s (40).\n\nThe Olympics have long been Djokovic's white whale. A bronze medalist in Beijing, the Serbian finished fourth in London and Tokyo. After losing to Alcaraz in straight sets last month in the Wimbledon final, he flipped the script in Paris.\n\nDjokovic has won one 'Big Title' for every 3.1 events played (72/225). The player closest to him in winning rate at these events is Rafael Nadal, who has won one for every 3.5 tournaments played.\n\nThe 99-time tour-level titlist will now turn his attention to becoming That wasn't the case, however, as the 37-year-old Serbian looked like a man possessed and simply unwilling to be denied. Djokovic beat Alcaraz in two pulsating tiebreaker sets of supreme quality on Court Philippe Chatrier in Paris to claim an elusive gold medal for his beloved Serbia. His only other medal at the Olympics came in 2008 when he claimed bronze as a 21-year-old. The long wait looked to be worth it.\n\nAs if the world didn't already know about his greatness, the Serbian superstar has reinforced his status as arguably the greatest tennis player that ever lived. He's won 24 Grand Slams, he contested the 2024 Wimbledon less than six weeks after knee surgery and now he's claimed gold at the Olympics. 10 Australian Open Titles, seven at Wimbledon, three at Roland Garros and four at the US Open. Somehow, this medal in Paris is the one which means most to the polyglot Serb, who speaks 11 languages.\n\n20-year-old South African Benjamin Richardson runs in a stacked semi-final alongside De Grasse and Kerley, medallists in Tokyo. Jamaica's Kishane Thompson and Kenya's Ferdinand Omanyala are two more blockbuster names in a daunting field which starts at 20:23 on Sunday 04 July. 30-year-old Simbine is a major candidate to claim a medal in Paris. There's a strong African presence in Simbine's semi-final going at 20:14. Alongside him is Liberia's Emmanuel Matadi, Nigeria's Kayinsola Ajayi and Letsile Tebogo from Botswana, and also the small matter of a clash with the defending Olympic champion Jacobs. {"uri": "8258842473", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "16:04:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T16:04:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:03:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/novak-djokovic-golden-day-for-the-greatest-1850259.html", "title": "Novak Djokovic: Golden Day For The Greatest - UrduPoint", "body": "Paris, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 4th Aug, 2024) Novak Djokovic's Olympic triumph against Carlos Alcaraz completes his collection of the game's biggest honours and enhances his status as the greatest men's player of all time.\n\nThe Serbian top seed defied a 16-year age gap at Roland Garros on Sunday to win 7-6 (7/3), 7-6 (7/2) in what was likely to be his final shot at Olympic glory.\n\nThe 37-year-old had nothing to prove against a young rival who has time on his side to surpass even his own achievements but he showed an intense desire to win.\n\nAt the moment of victory he dropped to the red clay, shaking with emotion, showing how much victory meant for him.\n\nThe Serbian is already out on his own with 24 Grand Slams -- four more than career-long rivals Roger Federer and two ahead of Rafael Nadal.\n\nHe also has a stack of other records in men's tennis including a record 40 Masters-level titles and most weeks at number one -- a staggering 428.\n\nBut up until Sunday his best performance at the Olympics was a bronze in singles at the Beijing Games in 2008.\n\nHe had not won a single tournament so far this year but in Paris he showed the astonishing will to win that sets him apart as he simply refused to be beaten.\n\nDjokovic did not win another major until 2011 but since then he has been voracious, despite the occasional fallow period.\n\nHe has made no secret of his aim to be the greatest of all and few would now argue against that.\n\nJust weeks ago he had to pull out of the French Open ahead his quarter-final before undergoing knee surgery.\n\nAn exasperated John McEnroe expressed his frustration at the way that Djokovic is sometimes treated during last month's Wimbledon.\n\nThe American three-time Wimbledon champion added: \"He's by far the guy who's taken the worst heat and that's why I would say he's the greatest that's ever played.\"\n\nDjokovic has been content to plough his own furrow and has shown an astonishing ability to shut out the noise.\n\nHe dropped gluten from his diet early in his career, crediting the change with transforming his results.\n\nThe lithe physique of the rubber man of tennis enables him to chase down seemingly lost causes and he combines a brutally efficient game with a rock-solid defence.\n\nBut some personal stances have drawn criticism -- one claim that raised eyebrows was his belief that it was possible to alter the composition of water and food through positive thinking.\n\nAt the French Open last year, he wrote \"Kosovo is the heart of Serbia\" on a courtside tv camera lens as ethnic tensions were again rising in the Balkans.\n\nHis refusal to be vaccinated against Covid proved costly -- he was deported from Melbourne on the eve of the 2022 Australian Open.\n\nOn the court, time is ticking for Djokovic but he shows few signs of losing his physical edge -- half of his 24 Grand Slams have come after he turned 30 and he can go toe to toe with men nearly half his age.\n\nWhen he does finally hang up his racquet he can do so in the knowledge he has done it all.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8258142727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "04:14:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T04:14:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T04:14:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5677934/2024/08/04/olympics-2024-watch-guide-day-9-tennis-track/", "title": "Olympics Today: Sunday's guide to what to watch in Paris", "body": "While Sunday's schedule at the Paris Games isn't quite as stacked as Saturday's -- when 31 gold medals were handed out in 24 hours -- it still packs plenty of potential.\n\nIt's also the day we say goodbye to two key sports: swimming and tennis. Both will go out with fireworks.\n\nElsewhere, American Noah Lyles headlines the men's 100-meter field and men's golf crowns a gold medalist. There are also medal events in archery, artistic gymnastics, badminton, boxing, cycling, equestrian, fencing, shooting and table tennis.\n\nLet's dive in.\n\nTime: Tennis begins at 6 a.m. ET, noon in Paris. Novak Djokovic vs. Carlos Alcaraz is the second match of the day.\n\nTV: Peacock\n\nWhat to watch: Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz meet for the seventh time -- and second on the clay of Roland Garros -- for the men's singles gold medal.\n\nThe 37-year-old Djokovic, who tore his meniscus here at the French Open two months ago, is looking to add gold to his 24 Grand Slam titles. His only Olympic medal, a bronze, came in 2008.\n\nAlcaraz, 21, would continue the splendid start to his year with a victory. He won his first French Open here in June, added a Wimbledon title in July and could make it three-for-three if he defeats the all-time great.\n\nIn their lone meeting at Roland Garros, in the 2023 French Open semifinals, Djokovic prevailed in four sets after Alcaraz struggled through leg cramps.\n\nTime: 3:50 p.m. ET, 9:50 p.m. in Paris\n\nTV: NBC and Peacock\n\nWhat to watch: After winning a bronze medal in Tokyo in the 200 meters, American Noah Lyles comes to Paris with eyes on the gold in both the 100 and 200.\n\nHis first event comes Sunday, with the wickedly fast men's 100-meter dash. Lyles posted a lifetime best 9.83 seconds at U.S. Olympic trials when he made waves for running with a Yu-Gi-Oh card tucked inside his singlet. And Lyles has been talking the talk ahead of his Olympics.\n\n\"Everybody has their own vibe. I'm a showman,\" Lyles declared in the documentary series \"Sprint\" on Netflix.\n\n\"I feel like almost an artistic director. You have all these other athletes as stars, rock stars, popular wherever they go. Track and field needs to be the same. And I'm not gonna be happy until I see that accomplished.\"\n\nIn order to gain rock star status, Lyles will have to win. Kishane Thompson of Jamaica is expected to be his top competition. But all three medalists from Tokyo -- Italy's Marcell Jacobs, the United States' Fred Kerley and Canada's Andre De Grasse -- are in Paris, too.\n\nTime: 12:30 p.m. ET, 6:30 p.m. in Paris\n\nTV: NBC and Peacock\n\nWhat to watch: The nine-day swimming program reaches its conclusion with four medal races over a one-hour span.\n\nFirst up: The always-frantic women's 50-meter freestyle, where Sweden's Sarah Sj\u00f6str\u00f6m and Gretchen Walsh of the U.S. are among the medal contenders. It's followed by the men's 1,500 free, which represents the final chance for a U.S. man to capture individual gold. Bobby Finke, who won gold in Tokyo, qualified sixth in Saturday's semifinals, where Ireland's Daniel Wiffen swam the fastest time.\n\nThe final two events are relays -- the men's 4\u00d7100 medley and women's 4\u00d7100 medley. The Americans are reigning gold medalists in the men's relay, while Australia took the gold in the women's relay three years ago.\n\nTime: 11:15 a.m. ET, 5:15 p.m. in Paris\n\nTV: USA Network, Telemundo and Peacock\n\nWhat to watch: The U.S. looks to improve to 3-0 in France with a win over Germany in the final game of the group stage.\n\nThe Americans survived their biggest guaranteed test Thursday, beating Belgium 87-74 as A'Ja Wilson and Breanna Stewart combined for 49 points and 20 rebounds. Germany, meanwhile, is one of the Olympics' surprise stories. In its first Olympics, and as the No. 19 team in the world, it has defeated Belgium (No. 6) and Japan (No. 9) in its first two games.\n\nWhat to watch: Looking for a more feature-length watch Sunday morning? Tune in to the women's road race, where 93 competitors will start at the Pont d'I\u00e9na along the River Seine for a 158-kilometer race.\n\nAustrian Anna Kiesenhofer is the reigning gold medalist. The bronze medalist from Tokyo, Italy's Elisa Longo Borghini, also returns in Paris.\n\nAustralia's Grace Brown, Great Britain's Anna Henderson and the United States' Chloe Dygert -- the gold, silver and bronze medalists in the individual time trial on July 27 -- also hope to add to their medal counts.\n\nIt's hard to choose just one highlight from Saturday. But Katie Ledecky accomplished something only one other woman has in Olympic history by winning her ninth gold medal.\n\nLedecky tied Soviet gymnast Larisa Latynina for the most gold medals by a female Olympian by winning the 800-meter freestyle for the fourth consecutive Games, outdueling Australian rival Ariarne Titmus.\n\nHonorable mention goes to Julien Alfred, who took the crown as the world's fastest woman in the 100 meters, capturing the first Olympic medal in Saint Lucia's history. And to Simone Biles, who made it three golds in Paris and seven all time.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8258624743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "12:30:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T12:30:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T12:30:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3803921639919281, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/beatboxing-tennis-umpire-steals-show-2024-paris-olympics/3511356/", "title": "Beatboxing tennis umpire steals the show ahead of Alcaraz, Djokovic final", "body": "There is no grander stage to show off your talents than at the Olympics.\n\nOne beatboxing tennis umpire did just that ahead of the gold medal men's tennis match between Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic.\n\nThe multi-talented official started breaking down beats seated in the Court Philippe-Chatrier umpire chair before making his way down the step ladder onto the clay. Numerous dancing line judges joined his electric performance.\n\nAfter over two minutes of busting beats, fans erupted into applause for the umpire who courageously showcased his talents.\n\nThere are three medaled tennis events on the schedule on Sunday.
